site_title: Brazil policeman confesses to killing Greek ambassador: police
summary: A Brazilian policeman, Sergio Moreira, confessed to murdering Greece's ambassador to Brazil, Kyriakos Amiridis, 59, in a "cowardly act" orchestrated by his wife, Françoise. The murder occurred at the couple's home in Nova Iguaçu, Rio de Janeiro, on Monday night. Both Françoise and Moreira are in custody, along with a cousin of the officer who helped carry the body. The crime has caused "profound sadness" to Brazilian President Michel Temer, who extended condolences to the ambassador's family and the Greek people.

site_title: The Unsinkable Debbie Reynolds
summary: Debbie Reynolds, a Hollywood star of the 1950s, passed away on December 28, 2016. Known for her wholesome and down-to-earth persona, Reynolds sold happiness and pragmatic romance through her acting career. She rose to fame in the 1950s with roles in "Singin' in the Rain" and "Give a Girl a Break," outpacing her male co-stars. Reynolds' career was marked by her dedication to her craft and her refusal to seek cathartic roles, instead choosing to maintain her moral purity. Her daughter, Carrie Fisher, portrayed Reynolds in a 1990 film adaptation of her memoir, capturing her mother's flair for drama and showmanship.

site_title: Keppel in deal to push back Parden rig delivery
summary: Keppel Corporation has entered into a settlement agreement with Parden Holding SRL to defer the delivery of a jack-up rig by two years, from 2017 to 2019. The agreement allows Parden's guarantor to purchase the rig at a price equivalent to the contract value, with a replacement guarantee issued by the guarantor to secure the obligations. This comes after Parden failed to take delivery of the rig and make payment for the balance 80% of the contract value.

site_title: XTRA Space
summary: Lim Choon Hong, founder of 27-year-old independent furniture store Xtra, has opened a new 13,000 sq ft showroom at Marina Square. The store, designed by local studio Produce, features a wooden laminate double-volume section and a "Apartment" section with curated brand spaces. Xtra has also introduced an in-house café, Kith, to enhance the customer experience. The move marks a significant evolution for the business, which has adapted to changing times and consumer preferences.

site_title: Lim Tian Wee
summary: Lim Tian Wee, founder and executive director of Gryphon Tea Company, has turned his family's legacy of selling Chinese tea into a premium luxury brand. Starting from his great-grandmother's 1918 provision shop, Gryphon has innovated Asian ingredients into accessible quality tea products, winning 25 Great Taste Awards in the UK. The company has recently launched its bespoke concept Monogram, allowing customers to personalize their own blends. Lim emphasizes the importance of quality water and proper steeping techniques for the perfect cup of tea, and believes Singapore is neither a coffee nor tea drinking nation, but rather a nation where consumers feel ownership of their taste.

images.alt_text: Shot on location at FOO'D by Davide Oldani.

site_title: Going for Gold
summary: Hong Kong celebrity chef Harlan Goldstein attributes his staying power to perseverance and healthy self-esteem. With a career spanning over 20 years, Goldstein has opened numerous restaurants, including Harlan's, Tuscany by H, and Gold by Harlan Goldstein. However, he has also experienced multiple partnerships ending in splits, with the most recent being with ZS Hospitality. Despite this, Goldstein remains optimistic, stating he has never hit his lowest point and plans to open his own restaurant in mid-2017. He will continue to run his consultancy firm and explore future ventures in Hong Kong and the Maldives.

images.alt_text: Harlan Goldstein.
Josper grilled lamb chops.
Harlan's crab cake.

site_title: China policymakers pledge stability for "complex" year ahead
summary: China's policymakers have pledged stability for the upcoming year despite a complex economic landscape, driven by a housing boom and government investment. The central bank will focus on maintaining a "neutral" stance to avoid asset bubbles and unbalanced growth. Lending is expected to reach a record high, while fixed asset investment by state firms is growing rapidly. Policymakers anticipate a slight tightening of monetary policy in 2017 to balance economic support and debt prevention, amidst a weakening yuan and rising interest rates.

site_title: Fathers & Sons
summary: Sebastian Fürst, 36, winemaker of Weingut Rudolf Fürst, shares how his vineyard's unique Martian-like red rocks in western Franconia contribute to the rich perfume and elegant fruit of his Spätburgunder-Pinot Noir. The rocks provide good drainage, allowing roots to reach deeper and giving the iron-rich soil a stony character. This, combined with old wisdom and new ideas, is helping the family business take the winemaking industry to a higher level.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: The Ritz-Carlton, Millenia Singapore is launching Super Night on December 31, offering an eight-course set dinner with Kaluga queen caviar and other luxurious dishes, priced from S$388 per person. The modern Spanish restaurant Esquina is celebrating its 5th anniversary with a $55 five-course tasting menu until January, featuring collaborations with head chefs from other notable restaurants.

site_title: For The Record
summary: Nick Cave's son, Arthur Cave, died in 2016 while working on the singer-songwriter's album Skeleton Tree. A documentary, One More Time With Feeling, captures Cave's grief and the album's raw emotion. The film will be screened at The Projector on Jan 1, 2017.

site_title: US: Wall Street set to end strong 2016 on dour note
summary: US stocks closed on a downbeat note on the last trading day of 2016, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite falling, despite a strong year overall. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 55.22 points, or 0.28%, to 19,764.56, and was poised to post its first weekly decline since the US election in November. Investors are uncertain about the impact of Donald Trump's policies, which has stalled the market's upward momentum.

site_title: Indonesian pilot fired after slurred cockpit announcement
summary: An Indonesian pilot, Tekad Purna, has been fired by budget airline Citilink after making a slurred announcement from the cockpit, alarming 154 passengers on a flight from Surabaya to Jakarta. The pilot was seen stumbling through airport security and dropping his belongings. The CEO of Citilink, Albert Burhan, has also offered his resignation. The airline cited the pilot's conduct as endangering passenger safety and has vowed to maintain a zero-mistake policy in the aviation industry. The incident is part of Indonesia's poor aviation safety record.

site_title: It may have been a bad year, but it's not a bad life
summary: It's the time of year for reflection and decision-making, as people consider their lives and make changes. Studies show December is a peak period for break-ups, suggesting a season for major life reflections. New Year's resolutions remain popular, despite their infrequent keeping. The author shares their biggest lessons learnt from the past year, while industry experts discuss topics such as mod-Indian cuisine, corporate purpose, and financial literacy. This reflective period encourages individuals to re-evaluate their goals and priorities, setting the stage for a new year ahead.

site_title: My Favourite Album
summary: Duran Duran's 1984 album "Arena" is praised as a classic of 80s new wave pop, featuring a "keyboard-and-drum-machine" sound.

site_title: An anti-climactic 2016 finish for the ST Index
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 2016 with a net loss of 0.07% due to a quiet week with low trading volume. The index rose to 2,880.76 but settled back, adding about 9 points or 0.3% for the week. Traders were disappointed as the index had risen on Tuesday and Wednesday, possibly due to "buy in anticipation, sell on the day" strategies. The STI ended the year with a loss of 8.39 points.

site_title: Six sporting wishes for a great 2017
summary: The article by Lee U-Wen previews the sporting events and wishes for 2017. Key highlights include the English Premier League's halfway mark, the Formula 1 season's start without champion Nico Rosberg, and Singapore's football team's potential for success. Lee expresses six wishes for the upcoming year, including Roger Federer's dramatic comeback and Singapore's football team soaring again, but no specific events are mentioned.

site_title: Europe: Shares post small loss for 2016, Britain's FTSE hits record high
summary: European shares ended 2016 with a small loss, despite strong gains in mining stocks and banks, which contributed to a 61.9% gain for Europe's basic resources index. Britain's FTSE 100 index reached a record high, rising 14.4% for the year, driven by a sharp drop in sterling after the Brexit vote. The European Stoxx 600 index finished 0.3% higher, with banking stocks surging 21.5% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Russian hackers penetrated Vermont electric utility: Washington Post
summary: Russian hackers penetrated the system of a Vermont electric utility, according to a Washington Post report citing unnamed US officials. The code, linked to the Grizzly Steppe operation, was detected but not used to disrupt operations. The penetration represents a potentially serious vulnerability in the nation's electrical grid.

images.alt_text: A code associated with the Russian hacking operation dubbed Grizzly Steppe by the Obama administration has been detected within the system of a Vermont electric utility, The Washington Post reported on Friday, citing unnamed US officials.

site_title: What do we do about Russia?
summary: US President Barack Obama announced sanctions against Russia on Thursday, expelling 35 Russian intelligence officials and closing two Russian compounds in Maryland and New York. The sanctions were in response to Russia's alleged malicious cyber activity and harassment, including hacking of the Democratic National Committee and other organizations during the US election. The move was seen as a response to Russia's efforts to influence the election, which Moscow has denied. The sanctions may be largely symbolic, but they raise concerns about how President-elect Donald Trump's administration will handle relations with Russia.

images.alt_text: The estate of George DuPont Pratt, also known as the Killenworth, purchased by the Soviet Union for its UN diplomats, in New York.

site_title: French workers win 'right to disconnect'
summary: France has introduced a new employment law requiring companies with over 50 workers to negotiate with employees about their "right to disconnect" from work-related tasks outside of working hours. Starting January 1, this law aims to tackle the issue of compulsive out-of-hours email checking and its impact on employee well-being. The law applies to organizations in France, and its implementation seeks to promote work-life balance and reduce burnout among employees.

images.alt_text: From Jan 1, a new employment law will enter into force that obliges organisations with more than 50 workers to start negotiations to define the rights of employees to ignore their smartphones.

site_title: China Trumps new year with a presidential pompadour
summary: A giant 7-meter rooster statue in northern China's Taiyuan features Donald Trump's likeness, complete with a pompadour hairstyle, bushy eyebrows, and a blood-red wattle. The statue was installed to celebrate the Chinese New Year and comes just before Trump's inauguration. The image is seen as mocking Trump's hairstyle, and its placement outside a shopping mall is likely to be seen as a form of ridicule by Trump supporters.

images.alt_text: "Let's make China great again," could be the new clarion call if this rooster gets his way at a Taiyuan shopping mall.

site_title: Putin rejects tit-for-tat retaliation after US expels 35 Russian diplomats
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has decided against retaliating against the US by expelling diplomats in response to the expulsion of 35 Russian diplomats from the US over alleged cyberattacks. Putin stated, "We won't send anyone away," after his Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, suggested a mirror expulsion. The decision comes after outgoing US President Barack Obama's administration allegedly backed the cyberattacks aimed at interfering with the 2016 US presidential election.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal looks to kickstart 2017 in Brisbane
summary: Spanish tennis great Rafael Nadal aims to kick-start his 2017 career at the Brisbane International, following an injury-plagued 2016 season. The 30-year-old won his last Grand Slam title at the French Open in 2014, but was forced to miss Wimbledon due to a wrist injury. Nadal's 2016 campaign was also marred by a wrist injury that ended his Roland Garros run after the second round. He will look to regain his form and momentum in Brisbane, a season-opening tournament that could provide a much-needed boost to his career.

images.alt_text: Spanish great Rafael Nadal will be hoping the season-opening Brisbane International gives him the chance to kick-start his career following an injury-plagued 2016.

site_title: South Korea pension chief arrested in corruption probe
summary: South Korea's former health minister, Moon Hyung-Pyo, was arrested under a court order in a corruption probe linked to impeached President Park Geun-Hye. Moon, who is now head of the National Pension Service, admitted to pressuring the state-run fund to back a Samsung merger while he served as health minister from 2013 to 2015. The arrest is part of a widening investigation into Park's alleged ties to Samsung and other businesses.

site_title: Snapshots of 2016
summary: Donald Trump won the US presidential election on November 8, 2016, defeating Hillary Clinton. In Europe, the UK voted to leave the EU on June 23, with Theresa May succeeding David Cameron as prime minister. Elsewhere, populist leaders like Rodrigo Duterte in the Philippines and nationalist parties in Europe gained ground. The year also saw economic slowdowns in Vietnam and China, and a shrinking UK economy.

site_title: Singapore labour market expected stay tepid in Q1
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to remain tepid in Q1, with few signs of a pick-up in GDP growth. Despite a weak labour market, the unemployment rate remains low at 2.1% and redundancies are lower than in 2009. A survey by ManpowerGroup predicts a slight increase in hiring prospects in the first quarter, with a net employment outlook of plus 8%. Employers are cautious due to global economic uncertainty, but jobs with critical skills and top talent will remain in demand.

site_title: Gentrification splits famous London district of Brixton
summary: Brixton, a London district once plagued by race riots and a notorious drug trade, is now facing gentrification. Rising prices are forcing long-time residents out, reversing the area's transformation from a no-go zone to a hip district. Locals and experts attribute the shift to the influx of affluent newcomers, changing the Afro-Caribbean soul of the neighborhood. The gentrification highlights the tension between preserving cultural identity and adapting to economic change, leaving residents and policymakers to weigh the costs and benefits of urban development.

site_title: Polish plane makes emergency landing in Prague after bomb threat
summary: A Polish charter airline's Boeing 707 made an emergency landing in Prague on December 30, 2016, after a passenger made a bomb threat. The passenger, a Polish man, was detained by police and claimed to have a booby trap. However, it is unclear if a bomb was actually found. The incident occurred on a flight to another destination, and the cause of the threat is still under investigation.

site_title: China tightens anti-money laundering rules for banks
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has tightened anti-money laundering rules for banks. Starting July 1, financial institutions must report any cross-border transactions of 200,000 yuan (S$41,620) or more. This move aims to curb money laundering as part of stepped-up efforts by the PBOC.

site_title: STB appoints new chairman and board members
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) appointed Chaly Mah Chee Kheong as its new chairman, replacing Chew Choon Seng, on January 1, 2017. Mah Chee Kheong is a former Deloitte CEO and chairman. The appointments were announced by the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

site_title: Singapore to conclude investment agreement with India next year
summary: Singapore and India are set to conclude an investment agreement by the end of 2017, promoting bilateral investments. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Indian Minister of Finance Arun Jaitley agreed on new initiatives for joint investments. This deal aims to enhance economic ties between the two countries, with no specific details on the agreement's content or benefits provided. The agreement is expected to be concluded in the second half of 2017.

site_title: Taiwan announces US itinerary for president, upsetting China
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen announced a US itinerary for her January visit, including stops in Houston and San Francisco, prompting China to call for the US to block the stopover. The visit, described as private and unofficial, comes after President-elect Donald Trump spoke to Tsai, casting doubt on his administration's commitment to China's "one China" policy. The US mission in Taiwan declined to comment on potential meetings with Trump's team.

site_title: China considering strong measures to contain Taiwan: sources
summary: China is considering strong measures to contain Taiwan's growing independence, according to sources with ties to senior military officers. The possible measures include conducting war games near the island and a series of economic sanctions to cripple Taiwan. The issue has become a hot topic within China's People's Liberation Army in recent weeks. The sources did not confirm whether any decisions have been made, but the situation has raised concerns about the potential for increased tensions between China and Taiwan.

site_title: Apple said to seek lower taxes to start manufacturing in India
summary: Apple seeks lower taxes to manufacture iPhones in India, writing to the industry ministry for tax concessions on import and manufacturing duties. The company aims to capitalize on India's growing phone market, despite facing challenges in meeting local content requirements. Apple's main manufacturing partner, Foxconn, has expressed plans to assemble phones in India, but most iPhones are currently made in China. The company's move is seen as a step towards India's "Make in India" policy, which aims to encourage domestic manufacturing and job creation.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as market eyes end to strong
summary: US stocks fell slightly on their final trading day of a strong year, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average failing to break through the 20,000-milestone. The S&P 500 was up about 10% for the year, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dipped 0.1% to 5,427.25. Investors remain optimistic about President-elect Donald Trump's pro-growth policies, but expect him to follow through on his promises and for corporate earnings to rise to justify the market's valuation gains since the election.

site_title: No expiration date on S&P 500 bull run
summary: The S&P 500 Index has reached a record high, with a bull run expected to continue under President-elect Donald Trump's policies. However, analysts warn that the US economy must achieve a rare feat - a 10% earnings growth rate, unseen since at least 1937 - to sustain this momentum. The cyclically adjusted P/E ratio, a popularized metric by Robert Shiller, has been above its historic average for 42 months, with only two previous instances ending in crashes. Bulls remain optimistic, but experts caution that extended valuations have historically led to market corrections.

site_title: Chill Out
summary: Siblings Travis and Suzanne Chia launched alcoholdelivery.com.sg, an online alcohol delivery platform, to provide chilled booze within an hour for parties. Established in 2012, the platform offers over 500 products, including beer, sake, hard liquor, and party packages.

site_title: Imperium Crown to seek shareholders' nod to exit Japan property entirely
summary: Imperium Crown, a Singapore-based property investment group, plans to sell all its properties in Japan, citing a net fair value loss of S$16.5 million in its Japanese portfolio. The decision comes two years after entering the Japanese market, with softer rents contributing to the loss. The group will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval for the exit.

site_title: Nomura to deepen cost cuts as CEO seeks to keep ship afloat
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, a Japanese bank, is implementing a three-year cost-cutting drive called the "Waterline Project" to combat waste and improve cost-effectiveness. CEO Koji Nagai aims to reduce non-personnel expenses and has already eliminated hundreds of overseas jobs since April. The project will review operational efficiency and potentially involve job cuts or reassignments. Despite recent restructuring efforts, Nomura is on track to post its first profit abroad in seven years, driven by a rebound in fixed-income trading.

site_title: Taiwan says will be calm when dealing with China, but 2017 will test national security
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen stated that Taiwan will maintain calmness when dealing with China, but next year's uncertainties will test the island's national security. Tsai reiterated Taiwan's commitment to maintaining peace and stability, despite China's suspicions of her pro-independence stance. China has increased military drills and warned the US to block Taiwan's transit through the US next month, but Tsai considers the transit unofficial. Taiwan remains a sovereign nation, and Tsai reaffirmed her pledge to maintain peace and stability.

site_title: Top 100 based on market capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. However, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues for the second half of the year. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport planned to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade and Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Did Not See That Coming
summary: In 2016, conventional wisdom was turned upside down with unexpected events, including Britain voting to leave the EU, the US electing a reality TV star as president, and a Singaporean winning an Olympic gold in swimming.

site_title: Jan 3 expected to be one of holiday season's busiest shopping days in US
summary: Holiday Hangover Day, occurring on January 3, is expected to be one of the busiest shopping days in the US this holiday season, following Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and Small Business Sunday. According to sale-tracking websites, online sales on this day are expected to spike as Americans return to work and spend on items like jewelry, fitness equipment, and bedding. Overall, holiday sales are expected to be 4.9% higher than last year, with online sales growing 15%. Retailers are promoting post-Christmas sales to keep momentum going, with many offering deals on items for next year's Christmas.

site_title: Happy New Gear
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

To kick-start 2017, consider upgrading your home and tech. The Devialet Gold Phantom wireless speaker offers 4,500 watts of sound and a rose gold finish, priced at S$4,490. Samsung's Gear S3 smartwatch boasts IP68 water resistance, a stainless steel case, and up to four days of battery life, available for S$548. Alternatively, the Asus Transformer 3 Pro touchscreen tablet, bundled with a detachable keyboard and speakers, is a powerful and versatile option, priced at S$1,898. These devices are set to make 2017 a productive and enjoyable year for music lovers and tech enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: Devialet Gold Phantom.
Samsung Gear S3
Asus Transformer 3 Pro.

site_title: Knock 'em Dead
summary: A theatre experience called Fight! Palast #MembersOnly is part of the M1 Fringe Festival, inspired by Fight Club, and explores the Internet age through kickboxing, hashtags, and contemporary politics and philosophy. Performed by PENG! Palast, it runs on Jan 6 and 7 at Esplanade Theatre Studio, with tickets available at S$25 from Sistic.

site_title: Apple to cut iPhone production in Jan-March quarter: report
summary: Apple plans to reduce iPhone production by about 10% in the January-March quarter of 2017, following a similar reduction of 30% in the same period last year due to accumulated inventory. The move comes as the company faces declining iPhone sales. Apple's shares fell 0.84% in midday trading, in line with the Nasdaq stock index. The company has declined to comment on the report.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc will trim production of iPhones by about 10 per cent in the January-March quarter of 2017, the Nikkei financial daily reported on Thursday, citing calculations based on data from suppliers.

site_title: US says Islamic State chief alive, still leading
summary: The US Pentagon believes Islamic State chief Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is alive and still leading the group, despite repeated efforts to take him out. Baghdadi has kept a low profile since declaring a renewed Muslim caliphate in 2014. The US has doubled the bounty on his head to $25 million and is continuing to track his movements. The group has only released one video of Baghdadi, showing him with a black beard and turban, and it's unclear if he is in the besieged city of Mosul.

site_title: Putin says Russia will not expel US diplomats
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin announced that Moscow will not expel any US diplomats, a surprise decision following Washington's expulsion of 35 Russian diplomats. Putin reserved the right to retaliate and said Russia will plan its next steps based on the policies of the incoming US administration under President Donald Trump. The Kremlin invited the children of US diplomats to a holiday party, while Russian diplomats returning home will spend the holidays with friends and family.

images.alt_text: President Vladimir Putin said on Friday that Moscow would not expel any US diplomats, a surprise decision after Washington turfed out Russian diplomats over alleged interference in the US election.

site_title: Memtech to record 21.7m yuan gain from sale of under-utilised Huzhou City land
summary: Memtech International has agreed to sell two pieces of land in Huzhou City, Zhejiang, for 41 million yuan (S$8.5 million) in cash, generating a 21.7 million yuan gain. After paying 2 million yuan in taxes, the company expects to receive 39 million yuan in net proceeds, which will be used for general working purposes and future investments.

site_title: New Menu
summary: In 2017, Singapore's food scene is expected to shift towards more local and sustainable concepts, with local chefs shining and elevated local dishes becoming increasingly popular. Expensive restaurant menus are likely to decrease, with lower-end concepts averaging $20-30 per head expected to do better. Fine-dining restaurants may adapt by changing their menus to lower price points, while the salad bar is expected to be overtaken by more interesting food options. Local restaurants and food establishments, such as Tsuta Ramen and Kith, are also expanding, with plans for new outlets and international locations.

site_title: China court sentences 23 people to jail for smuggling fuel
summary: A Chinese court sentenced 23 people to jail terms of up to 15 years for smuggling refined fuel since 2013, with over 35,000 tonnes of fuel confiscated. The smuggling occurred after authorities raised consumption taxes on oil products in 2014, creating a price gap. This crackdown is part of China's efforts to combat fuel smuggling.

site_title: Global equity raising down over 25% in 2016; bankers see a shaky 2017
summary: Global equity raising fell by over 25% in 2016, with US$648.9 billion raised compared to US$873 billion in 2015, due to geopolitical shocks and failed IPOs. The outlook for 2017 is shaky, with bankers citing concerns.

site_title: Post-mortem on pop icon George Michael 'inconclusive'
summary: George Michael's post-mortem examination has yielded inconclusive results, with police treating his death as "unexplained but not suspicious". The cause of death remains unknown, and further tests will be carried out, with results unlikely to be known for several weeks.

images.alt_text: A post-mortem examination on the body of pop icon George Michael, who died on Christmas Day after a chart-topping career and years of drug-taking, has proved "inconclusive", police said on Friday.

site_title: No space for Hong Kong independence, China says
summary: China reaffirmed that there is no space for Hong Kong independence under the "one country, two systems" agreement, with senior official Wang Guangya stating that "Hong Kong is an inseparable part of the country" and independence is not allowed. The central government has confidence in and patience with Hong Kong, tolerating differences in systems as long as the "one country" principle is respected. This comes amid concerns over a growing independence movement in the territory, with China's parliament recently interpreting the Basic Law to bar pro-independence lawmakers from taking office.

site_title: No food, no meds, no respite: A boy's death in Venezuela
summary: A 16-year-old Venezuelan boy, Kevin Lara Lugo, died after foraging for food in an empty lot due to poisoning from eating bitter yuca. His family, struggling with Venezuela's economic crisis, had no access to basic supplies, including food and medicine. The hospital where Kevin was taken care of also lacked necessary supplies, leading to his untimely death. The incident highlights the country's deepening crisis, including widespread hunger, lack of medical care, and desperation.

site_title: Party On!
summary: Zouk's EDM party on December 31 will feature Lincey and Hong, offering "all-on-the-floor, body-moving action" with non-member admission at S$45.

site_title: GIC to pay £48.5m for 50% stake in UK lifestyle complex
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is paying £48.5m (US$59.6m) for a 50% stake in the UK lifestyle complex Watermark in Southampton. The fund already has a stake in the development through a joint venture with British property firm Hammerson. The investment is part of GIC's expansion into Europe, following previous deals in student accommodation and logistics. The partnership will focus on stable income streams and is expected to generate £5.5m yearly.

site_title: Farewell, journo lingo
summary: A journalist reflects on leaving her job and bidding farewell to the newsroom's unique jargon, including "slug" and "spike." A slug refers to a simple, one-word working title for a story, while a spike is a rejected story that is "impaled" on a metal spike, symbolizing its elimination. The term "spike" originated from the physical metal spikes used in hot-metal printing, not volleyball. The journalist will miss the newsroom's terminology but looks forward to learning new words in her new job.

site_title: Tesla owner files lawsuit in California claiming sudden acceleration
summary: A Tesla Model X owner, Ji Chang Son, has filed a lawsuit in California claiming his vehicle suddenly accelerated while parked, crashing into his living room and injuring him and a passenger. The lawsuit, seeking class action status, cites seven other complaints related to sudden acceleration without warning. The owner alleges product liability, negligence, and breaches of warranty, seeking unspecified damages. Tesla, which claims its Model X is the safest SUV in history, has not commented on the lawsuit.

site_title: Claims against Swiber balloon to US$288.8m
summary: Swiber Holdings, a struggling offshore engineering group, reported total claims against it at approximately US$288.8 million as of December 29, 2016. This represents an increase from its previous valuation of US$246.1 million. The company is seeking legal advice on the claims.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries sold its 49% stake in Yancheng China Water Co for S$53 million, recognizing a net gain of S$30 million. Owi Kek Hean, former KPMG deputy managing director, joined Centurion Corp's board as a non-executive independent director. Struggling offshore engineering group Swiber Holdings received US$288.8 million in total claims, seeking legal advice. The Singapore Exchange granted DMX Technologies a waiver to not provide comparative financial statements for FY 2014-2016. Genting Singapore and Genting Hong Kong extended their service agreements for three more years.

site_title: Venture capitalists see promise after a tight year for US startups
summary: US venture capitalists see promise in startups for 2017 after a tight year, with $67.8 billion invested in 2016, a 15% drop from the previous year. Despite a 25% decline in startup deals, investors expect 2017 to be brighter, with high-profile IPOs and new funds being raised, including a $100 billion investment by SoftBank. However, some investors warn that more money may not save the most troubled startups, citing concerns that it will only contribute to their problems.

site_title: Oxley sells 2 blocks of Royal Wharf township project for £156m
summary: Oxley Holdings sold two blocks of its Royal Wharf township project in east London to Notting Hill Home Ownership Limited and Notting Hill Housing Trust for £156 million. The sale includes all flats within Block 20 and Block 24 of the Royal Wharf Development. This move marks a significant milestone for Oxley Holdings, solidifying its presence in the UK property market.

images.alt_text: PROPERTY company Oxley Holdings on Friday said it would sell two blocks of its township development project, Royal Wharf, for £156 million (S$277 million).

site_title: Breaking New Ground
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Six individuals are making 2017 notable, including first-time author Felicia Yap, whose debut novel "Yesterday" sparked a fierce bidding war among top publishers. Wee Teng Wen, a restaurateur, opened his first hotel, The Warehouse Hotel, while Rina Raj, CEO of B Capital, acquired her family's first commercial property, Carlton Place. Other notable developments include the opening of Odette, which received two Michelin stars, and the launch of new projects by restaurateur Wee Teng Wen, including a renovation of OverEasy One Fullerton. These individuals are pushing boundaries and making a name for themselves in their respective industries.

site_title: Memtech to record 21.7m yuan gain from sale of under-utilised land
summary: Memtech International agreed to sell two plots of industrial land in Zhejiang, China for 41 million yuan (S$8.5 million) as part of a strategy to divest under-utilized assets. The two sites have a total gross area of 30,573.68 square meters. The company will record a net gain of 21.7 million yuan from the sale. The proceeds will be used for general working purposes.

site_title: China says "Sky Net" campaign recovers 2.3b yuan in corruption losses
summary: China's corruption watchdog, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, reported recovering 2.3 billion yuan in losses from graft in the first 11 months of 2016. The "Sky Net" campaign, launched in 2014, has led to the capture of 908 fugitives, including 122 government officials. The campaign aims to recover illicit funds taken overseas and strengthen international cooperation. China also announced plans to prosecute a former spy chief accused of bribery and abusing his power. The recovery comes as part of President Xi Jinping's campaign against pervasive corruption.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries unit divests 49% stake in Yancheng China Water Co
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit divested its 49% stake in Yancheng China Water Co to Yancheng City Municipal Utilities Investment Company for 260 million yuan (S$53 million). The transaction results in a net gain of about S$30 million for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2016. The asset was initially valued at 116 million yuan on Sembcorp Industries' balance sheet.

site_title: S Korea central bank chief says monetary policy to remain accommodative
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Governor Lee Ju-Yeol, stated that monetary policy should remain accommodative for a considerable period due to concerns about the recovery losing steam in Asia. The bank has kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 1.25% for six meetings, despite rising oil prices. The government now forecasts economic growth of 2.6% in 2017, down from 3%, citing weaker domestic demand and job growth.

site_title: Analysts see a brighter year ahead after flat 2016
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 2016 at 2,880.76 points, almost unchanged from 2015. Despite a flat year, total company value rose 2.7% to S$879 billion. Analysts expect single-digit growth in 2017, with targets ranging from 3,000 to 3,140 points. Citi, CIMB, and Maybank Kim Eng project earnings recovery and cost management. Key sectors to watch include banks, commodity players, and property developers. Winners include DBS Bank, Wilmar International, and ST Engineering, while losers include ComfortDelGro and Keppel Corp.

images.alt_text: In the end, 2016 turned out to be a year of sound and fury, signifying nothing - at least on the surface.

site_title: Keppel reaches settlement on Parden rig contract
summary: Keppel Corporation has reached a settlement agreement with Parden Holding SRL regarding a US$206 million contract for the construction of a jack-up rig. The agreement allows Parden to defer delivery by two years, pushing it to the fourth quarter of 2017, and resells the rig to an associate of Parden's guarantor at the same price. This follows Parden's failure to take delivery and make payment for 80% of the contract value.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Corporation said after Friday trading hours, its rig-building arm, Keppel Fels has entered into a settlement agreement towards the construction of a jack-up rig that was intended for delivery to Uruguay-based Parden Holding SRL.

site_title: Singapore shares finish the year weaker
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the year with a net loss of 1.97 points or 0.07% to close at 2,880.76, down 8.39 points from the previous day. The index rose on Tuesday and Wednesday but fell short of expectations, with low trading volumes throughout the week. Despite a brief spike on Friday, the STI failed to achieve a final-day push, leaving traders disappointed.

site_title: HK, Shanghai: Stocks rally to end year on a high
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks ended the year on a high note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.96% and the Shanghai Composite Index climbing 0.24%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also saw a modest gain. These gains come ahead of the US-EU trade talks and amid ongoing tariff threats, which have been a major concern for investors. Despite the uncertainty, the rally suggests a positive outlook for the markets heading into the new year.

site_title: US dollar share of global currency reserves slips in Q3
summary: The US dollar's share of global currency reserves decreased to 63.3% in Q3 2016, down from 63.8% in the prior quarter. Meanwhile, the euro's share rose to 20.3% from 20% in the same period. This shift is attributed to the European Central Bank's quantitative easing policies and other economic factors. The decline in the US dollar's share highlights the growing influence of the euro and other currencies in the global financial system.

images.alt_text: The US dollar's share of allocated currency reserves slipped to 63.3 per cent in the third quarter of 2016 from 63.8 per cent in the prior three months, data from the International Monetary Fund showed on Friday.

site_title: Gold rises 8% in 2016, snaps three-year losing streak
summary: Gold prices rose 8% in 2016, ending a three-year losing streak, as investors sought a hedge against global economic uncertainty and rising US Treasury yields. Spot gold reached its highest since December 2014, before retreating 0.7% to $1,150.5 per ounce. The metal's annual gain of 8.5% was its largest since 2011, driven by a weak US dollar and concerns over global growth.

site_title: Former KPMG stalwart joins Centurion as independent director
summary: Former KPMG deputy managing director Owi Kek Hean has joined Centurion Corp as a non-executive independent director, starting January 1, 2017. He will also serve on the audit and nominating committees. Kek Hean retired from KPMG in October 2015 and became executive director of IMO & Partners in November 2015.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 0.4% in November, a weaker pace than October's 0.8% growth, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Meanwhile, Global Logistics Properties (GLP) received a further US$26 million investment in its fund, and the Singapore Tourism Board appointed new chairman and board members. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the year with a net loss of 1.97 points, or 0.07%, closing at 2,880.76.

site_title: Merkel says Islamist terrorism is biggest test for Germany
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Islamist terrorism is the country's biggest challenge, following a deadly attack in Berlin's Christmas market. Merkel vowed to introduce security laws after the attack, which killed 12 people. She also criticized populism, urging Germans to focus on common EU interests and reject nationalist policies. Merkel's speech came as the European Union faces numerous challenges, including Brexit and US-Russia tensions.

site_title: Yet another 'persona non grata' episode in American history
summary: US President Barack Obama expelled 35 Russian diplomats, declaring them "personae non gratae," in response to Russian hacking of American political organizations. This move follows a 1980 memo by the Department of Justice outlining the executive branch's authority to reject foreign envoys. The declaration is not unique to the US, as other countries have made similar declarations against American citizens, including Panama City in 2011. The expelled diplomats have 72 hours to leave the US, and their diplomatic status remains unchanged.

site_title: London: Stock market rebounds to new record peak
summary: The British stock market reached a new record high on December 30, 2016, closing 0.32% higher at 7,142.83 points. This rebound occurred during shortened holiday trade, a phenomenon known as the "Santa rally." The FTSE 100 index, which had spent most of the session in negative territory, finished the day at its highest point since records began. This marks the latest in a series of record-breaking peaks for London stocks this week.

site_title: China blocks India's request for UN to blacklist militant chief
summary: China has blocked India's request to blacklist Jaish-e-Mohammad's leader Maulana Masood Azhar, who is accused of masterminding attacks, including a deadly Indian air base assault. Pakistani officials found no evidence linking Azhar to the attack. This move has been criticized by India, which claims Azhar's group is linked to al Qaeda. The UN Security Council blacklist is intended to restrict funding and support for these groups.

site_title: Putin takes lead in Syria peace after battlefield wins
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has secured a key role in Syria's peace process after a series of battlefield victories, bolstering his authority and challenging US influence. A new truce and talks between Damascus and rebel groups have been announced, with Turkey on board, filling the power vacuum left by the US. Putin's military might has shored up Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, and he is now positioning himself as a mediator in the conflict. A peace deal in Astana, Kazakhstan, is expected next month, with Turkey's influence seen as a game-changer in bringing rebels to the table.

site_title: China vows to open up economy as investment declines
summary: China's government has pledged to open up its economy to foreign investment, aiming to boost a declining economy. Foreign investment is expected to reach $113 billion this year, lower than $135.6 billion last year. China will allow foreign firms to operate fully-owned subsidiaries in certain sectors, and give them the same treatment as Chinese firms in terms of capital requirements and preferential policies. The move aims to create a fair competition environment and increase foreign investment, but China ranked 84th globally in the World Bank's ease of doing business index for 2016.

site_title: Australia kicks off global New Year party defying terror threat
summary: Australia is hosting a New Year's Eve celebration in Sydney despite a global terror threat, with 1.5 million people expected to watch the midnight fireworks. The city has increased security measures, deploying 2,000 extra officers after a man made online threats against the event. The move comes amid a wave of terrorist attacks globally, including in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia, but New South Wales state premier Mike Baird urged "business as usual" in Australia.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip on last trading day of 2016
summary: European stocks declined on the final trading day of 2016, with London's FTSE 100 index shedding 0.2% to 7,108.40 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 declining 0.1% to 11,443.31. The Paris CAC 40 index also fell marginally. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with the US-EU trade talks also drawing attention. The London market closed early at 1230 GMT, while Frankfurt and Paris remained open.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends down
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index fell 0.16% to 19,114.37 on its final trading day of 2016, following the US and a stronger yen. The Topix index edged up 0.01% to 1,518.61. This downward trend was likely due to a stronger yen and US-EU trade tensions. The Nikkei's decline marked the end of 2016, which saw the index fall from its peak in 2015.

site_title: Imperium Crown to exit Japan property market
summary: Imperium Crown, a Singapore-based property investment group, plans to exit the Japanese property market due to lower rents and returns on investment. The company will hold an extraordinary general meeting to sell its five Japanese properties, valued at around S$88 million. Imperium Crown cited a net loss of S$12.38 million in FY2016 and a combined net fair-value loss of S$16.5 million on its Japanese properties. The decision marks a significant shift for the company, which had initially entered the Japanese market two years ago.

site_title: Britain criticises Kerry's comments on Israeli government
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's comments on Israel, calling them "not appropriate" to target the democratically-elected government of an ally. Kerry stated that Israel's settlement building was endangering Middle East peace and described the Netanyahu government as "the most right-wing in Israeli history." The British government believes that the construction of settlements is illegal but not the sole issue in the conflict, and that attacking the government's composition is not a constructive way to negotiate peace.

site_title: Adaro Energy likely to extend gains in 2017: analysts
summary: PT Adaro Energy, Indonesia's best-performing stock in 2016, is expected to extend its gains in 2017 due to rising coal prices and cost-cutting initiatives. Analysts predict a 8.1% stock price advance and 47% revenue increase for the year. Adaro's cost efficiency and low enterprise value over Ebitda make it the most cost-efficient coal producer, with a projected 32% net income increase and 15% revenue growth in 2017.

site_title: RBI issues warning as Indian banks' bad loans hit 14-year high
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has issued a warning as Indian banks' bad loans reached a 14-year high of 9.1% in September, up from 7.8% in March. The industry's gross bad-loan ratio is expected to rise further, putting a strain on capital buffers and profitability. State-run lenders underperformed their peers, and economists predict a slowing economy will make it harder for banks to recover loans, further increasing bad loan ratios.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: NG Yi-Sheng, a Singaporean poet, reflects on the end of 2016, a year marked by the Brexit and Trump victories, which he attributes to reactions against liberal multi-culturalist ideals. He hopes to strengthen civic community and diversity without backlash by focusing on his writing goals, including completing a novel and short stories collection. Yi-Sheng also expresses gratitude for spending time with family after his siblings returned to Singapore, and enjoying his mother's "Bacon Christmas turkey soup."

images.alt_text: Ng Yi-Sheng.

site_title: Contrasting penny tales of Best World and Serrano
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based direct selling firm, saw its stock price rise up to 10 times from 2015 to September 2016, reaching S$1.34 a share. The company reported a nine-month net profit of S$22.3 million and revenue more than doubled to S$138.9 million. In contrast, Serrano, another penny stock, was facing debt issues and a potential schemes of arrangement to repay creditors, resulting in a S$56 million loss for the half-year ended June 2016.

images.alt_text: Mr Chia, Serrano's former executive chairman, was made bankrupt in December.

site_title: China to abandon 6.5% economic growth goal by 2018
summary: China is poised to abandon its 6.5% economic growth target by 2018 as leaders seek to contain asset bubbles and financial leverage. According to Societe Generale's chief China economist, Yao Wei, the most likely change in guidance will be to a lower range of 6% to 6.5% or even 5.5% to 6.5% by the national Communist Party congress late next year. The move is driven by concerns about rapidly rising debt risk and a desire to allow for structural adjustments, with President Xi Jinping open to growth slowing below the target.

site_title: US says Taiwan president's transit based on "long-standing practice"
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen's January transit through the US is based on long-standing practice, according to the de facto US embassy in Taiwan. The transit, which will occur on her way to visiting Latin American countries, is consistent with the unofficial nature of US-Taiwan relations, with no change to the US "one China" policy. Tsai will leave Taiwan on January 7 and return on January 15.

images.alt_text: Taiwan President Tsai Ing Wen's transit through the United States next month during her January visit to allies in Latin American countries is based on common practice, the de facto US embassy in Taiwan said on Friday.

site_title: Trump praises 'very smart' Putin for holding off on reprisals against US
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump praised Russian President Vladimir Putin for not immediately retaliating against the US for expelling 35 Russian intelligence operatives and shutting down two Russian compounds. Trump tweeted that Putin was "very smart" for delaying reprisals, despite the FBI and CIA concluding that Russian intelligence agencies hacked into Democratic Party emails to benefit Trump's campaign. Trump has repeatedly praised Putin and has made cabinet picks with ties to Russia, despite acknowledging Russia's cyber-meddling in the election.

site_title: China to fund 4,000 MW power transmission line in Pakistan
summary: China's State Grid will fund and build a 4,000 MW power transmission line in Pakistan, valued at $1.5 billion, as part of a $55 billion CPEC project. The high-capacity transmission line will connect Matiari to Lahore, addressing Pakistan's electricity shortage issues. Construction begins in January, expected to take 20 months. This project is part of China's growing investments in Pakistan's energy sector, including a $1.8 billion acquisition of K-Electric and a 40% stake in the Pakistan Stock Exchange.

site_title: US dollar posts 2016 gain on Trump victory, Fed forecasts
summary: The US dollar posted a 3.7% gain for the year, its fourth consecutive year of gains against a basket of major currencies. The dollar index rose 7.1% in the fourth quarter, driven by expectations of US President-elect Donald Trump's fiscal stimulus plan and faster projected rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. Despite this, analysts note the risk of US dollar weakness if Trump's White House limits dollar appreciation. The dollar posted gains against the Mexican peso and Chinese yuan, but fell against the Japanese yen and euro, which are set to experience their third straight yearly losses.

site_title: Indians line up at banks to deposit savings or see them disappear
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decision to scrap large denomination bank notes has led to widespread disruption, with Indians lining up at banks to deposit their savings before the deadline. The move, aimed at fighting corruption, will see 500 and 1,000 rupee notes cease to be legal tender after December 30, affecting 86% of the country's cash. Analysts predict a significant impact on the economy, with potential job losses, lower economic growth, and a decline in demand for goods. The government claims the move will have long-term benefits, but critics argue it will cause immense hardship for the poor and vulnerable.

site_title: Jalan Besar with Mike Tay
summary: Mike Tay, a self-taught fabric designer, founded Onlewo, a line of whimsical patterned fabrics inspired by his Peranakan heritage and love for old neighborhoods. His shophouse studio in Jalan Besar, a bohemian enclave, serves as a hub for his design business and is home to Flaneur Gallery, which he co-owns with artist Vincent Chow. Tay chose the area for its convenience, citing its availability of hardware supplies and proximity to arts schools and museums.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares closed higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.8 points to 1,641.730, closing higher on Friday with 404 gainers outweighing 362 losers. The market saw 1.45 billion lots worth RM1.76 billion.

site_title: US scrambles to clear egg exports to bird flu-hit Korea
summary: US officials are seeking an agreement with South Korea to resume imports of American eggs, amid a bird flu outbreak in the Asian country. The ban on US egg imports, which began last year, has led to soaring egg prices and rationing in South Korea. US farmers could benefit from the shortage, while US egg shipments could also help alleviate the oversupply in the US. A potential agreement could be reached as early as next week, with US officials working to facilitate the trade.

site_title: China to prosecute former spy catcher for graft
summary: China will prosecute former spy catcher Ma Jian for corruption, accusing him of bribery and abusing power to interfere in law enforcement activities. Ma, a former vice-minister at China's Ministry of State Security, has been expelled from the party and will be handed over to the legal authorities. An investigation found Ma abused his position to benefit family members' business interests, took bribes, and interfered in unspecified law enforcement activities. Ma worked at the spy agency for over 30 years and was closely tied to a former aide to President Hu Jintao, who was jailed for life last year.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB Group to sell stake in China's Bank of Yingkou
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd agreed to sell its 18.21% stake in China's Bank of Yingkou Co Ltd to Shanghai Guozhijie Investment Development Co Ltd for 972 million ringgit (S$314.39 million). The all-cash deal, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to be completed in 2017. CIMB Group's Chief Executive Zafrul Aziz cited increasing capital requirements for minority investments as the reason for the sale, stating that the returns threshold would become too high.

site_title: Malaysian woman faces life in jail for Indonesian maid attack
summary: A Malaysian woman, Rozita Mohamad Ali, faces life in jail for allegedly attacking her Indonesian maid, Suyanti Sutrinso, with a kitchen knife and other objects, resulting in severe injuries. Suyanti, 19, sustained injuries to her eyes, head, and lung, and may have suffered "death or severe trauma." Rozita, 43, pleaded not guilty and is set to face trial on February 7. The incident highlights ongoing concerns about maid abuse in Malaysia, which has been criticized for its lack of protection for domestic workers.

site_title: Ronaldo rejects 300 million euro move to China
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo's agent, Jorge Mendes, announced that the soccer star has rejected a 300 million euro transfer to an unnamed Chinese club. The proposed deal would have included a 100 million euro annual salary for Ronaldo. Mendes stated that money is not everything for Ronaldo, and he is happy at Real Madrid. The move comes as Argentine striker Carlos Tevez joined Shanghai Shenhua and Brazil midfielder Oscar joined Shanghai SIPG, both in the Chinese Super League.

site_title: China central bank raises requirements for cash and overseas transactions
summary: China's central bank has raised the reporting requirements for cash and overseas transactions. Starting July 2017, banks will need to report transactions over 50,000 yuan (S$10,409) domestically and US$10,000 or more overseas. These reports will be sent to China's anti-money laundering supervision centre. The changes are part of adjustments to rules for large and suspicious transactions.

site_title: China's yuan set to have biggest annual loss since 1994
summary: China's yuan is set for its biggest annual loss since 1994, with a potential 7% decline against the US dollar in 2016. The currency firmed against the dollar on Friday after the central bank set a stronger midpoint rate, but is still on track for its worst performance this year. The People's Bank of China's decision to tighten its grip on capital outflows and stabilize the currency is seen as a response to global market volatility following the Brexit vote and US presidential election.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices reach record high after 8-month ascent
summary: Hong Kong home prices reached record highs in November, surpassing the previous peak in September 2015, after eight consecutive months of growth. Private home prices rose 0.79% to 0.16% above the old peak, driven by mainland Chinese buyers and high demand for primary homes. The government has raised stamp duties to cool the market, but industry insiders say it has had little effect. Property consultants predict a 5% increase in residential prices in the upcoming year, further exacerbating the city's affordability issues.

site_title: Gold firms, set to break three-year losing streak
summary: Gold is poised to break a three-year losing streak, with spot gold rising 0.1% to $1,159.36 an ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and economic uncertainty. The metal has added 9% so far in 2016, its first annual gain in four years. Despite a decline in December, gold is expected to register its best weekly gains since early June, with other precious metals also set to end the year in positive territory, including silver, platinum, and palladium.

site_title: Disney wins 'Cars' copyright suit in China
summary: Disney has won a copyright dispute in a China court over a Chinese knock-off of its animated movie "Cars." The court ordered Bluemtv and the film's publisher to stop their infringement of Disney's copyrights, and also ordered them to pay 1.35 million yuan (S$282,104) in compensation and legal fees. The court found that Bluemtv's Chinese cartoon "The Autobots" took the design of key characters from "Cars" and had an unfair competitive edge due to its similar name and sound. This is a rare victory for a foreign firm in China.

site_title: Women at wheel of 'pink taxis' challenge Jordan norms
summary: In Jordan, a group of women, including Nisrin Akoubeh, are challenging traditional norms by driving taxis, known as "Pink Taxis," exclusively for female passengers. Despite having the same driving licenses as men, women face social stigma and limited job opportunities. The Pink Taxi service, launched on Mother's Day, has been successful, with most customers being women who prefer the safety and comfort of riding with another woman. The initiative aims to break the culture of shame and prove women's capabilities in various professions, with some encouraging the move as a service to society, citing women's greater care and lower accident rates.

images.alt_text: Nisrin Akoubeh checks the oil and water before getting into her taxi and pulling into Amman's heavy traffic for another day of shuttling fellow women across the Jordanian capital.

site_title: Singapore Tourism Board appoints new chairman and board members
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) appointed Chaly Mah Chee Kheong as its new chairman, effective January 1, 2017. He replaces Chew Choon Seng, who is stepping down after a six-year tenure. This change comes as part of the board's efforts to drive tourism growth and development in the country.

site_title: Sails Pitch
summary: In 1950, 41 Malayan Girl Guides embarked on a historic trip to the Guide Jamboree in Perth, Australia, aboard the ship Gorgon. The group included royalty, including Tungku Budria, the Queen Consort of Perlis, and was advised by Lady Gimson, the Governor's wife and fellow Guide, to "make friends, learn all you can, and let others learn through you the finest characteristics of your homeland." This trip showcased the values of the Girl Guides and marked a significant moment in the organization's history.

images.alt_text: IMAGE YUSOF ISHAK COLLECTION, COURTESY OF NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF SINGAPORE

site_title: Australia: Shares post best performance in 3 years
summary: Australian shares closed at a 3-year high on Friday, ending the best quarter and yearly run since 2013. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.58% due to poor performances in financial and basic material stocks. Financial and banking shares, particularly those of "Big Four" banks, declined, with Australia and New Zealand Bank gaining 9.2% and National Australia Bank up 5.5% for their best yearly performances since 2013.

site_title: World's highest bridge opens in China
summary: The world's highest bridge, the Beipanjiang Bridge in China, has officially opened to traffic, connecting the provinces of Yunnan and Guizhou. The 1,341-meter-long bridge, which costs over $144 million, reduces travel times between Xuanwei in Yunnan and Shuicheng in Guizhou by up to three-quarters, from over four hours to around one hour. The bridge, which stands 565m above a river, has surpassed the Si Du River Bridge in Hubei to become the world's highest bridge, and is expected to be "very convenient" for travelers in the region.

images.alt_text: The world's highest bridge has opened to traffic in China, connecting two provinces in the mountainous southwest and reducing travel times by as much as three-quarters, local authorities said Friday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up, look set for 10% gain in 2016
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.8% on its last trading day of 2016, poised for a 10.7% gain for the year, outperforming most Asian peers. The government announced a plan to halve the transaction tax on day trades to boost local trading. Key electronics subindexes, including TSMC and Hon Hai Precision Industry, also rose. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar. This marks a recovery from the 10% loss in 2015.

site_title: Bank lending in Nov up, but weaker than Oct: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 0.4% in November, a weaker pace than the 0.8% growth in October, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Business loans increased 0.7% to S$361 billion, while consumer loans grew 0.1% to S$250 billion. Year-over-year, bank lending was up 1.1%.

site_title: Hong Kong up, Shanghai flat in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.68% on the last trading day of 2016, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 21,939.91. In contrast, Shanghai was flat, with the Shanghai Composite Index edging up 0.04%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.07%. These gains follow a rally in Asia, with traders brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend the market's recent uptrend.

site_title: Caves that prove Neanderthals were cannibals
summary: Archaeologists in Belgium have discovered evidence of Neanderthal cannibalism in the Goyet caves, dating back around 40,000 years. Human bones, including a newborn, child, and four adults, show signs of cutting and marrow extraction, indicating that the Neanderthals practiced cannibalism. This discovery, led by Helene Rougier, provides conclusive proof of Neanderthal cannibalism in Northern Europe, challenging previous assumptions of their sophisticated behavior. The reasons behind this cannibalism remain a mystery, with possible explanations ranging from food to symbolic practices.

site_title: China stockmarkets among world's worst in 2016
summary: China's stock markets have underperformed globally in 2016, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 12.5% for the year, making it the second-worst performing among 40-plus countries tracked by the Wall Street Journal's Market Data Center. The poor performance was attributed to a botched attempt to reduce volatility, massive capital flight, and a weakening currency. The government's lack of clarity on policy direction and the dominance of small investors have also contributed to the market's weakness.

site_title: SIAC releases rules on conduct of investment arbitration
summary: The Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) has released its first edition of the SIAC IA Rules 2017, governing the conduct of international investment arbitration. The rules, effective January 1, 2017, include provisions for appointing arbitrators, early dismissal of claims, and disclosure of third-party funding arrangements. The rules also enable the tribunal to consider these arrangements when apportioning costs. The SIAC IA Rules 2017 will be available on the centre's website starting December 31, 2016.

site_title: Indonesia's loan growth accelerates in Nov - financial regulator
summary: Indonesia's loan growth accelerated in November, increasing 8.5% year-over-year, faster than the 7.5% pace in the previous month, according to the Financial Services Authority. The Non-performing loan ratio was 3.18% of outstanding loans in December. This rebound comes after annual loan growth slowed to 6.47% in September, the weakest pace since 2009. The data was released earlier than expected, beating the usual two-month delay.

site_title: China extends overcapacity fight to more sectors in 2017
summary: China plans to increase its 2017 targets for capacity cuts in steel and coal, aiming to raise targets by over 10% in both sectors. The campaign, which began in 2016, will also extend to industries like cement, glass, and shipping. China aims to close around 500 million tonnes of coal capacity and 100-150 million tonnes of steel capacity in three to five years. The move aims to tackle inefficiency and cut capacity overhangs, with industry sources expecting the extension to "largely improve profitability" in affected sectors.

site_title: Impeached South Korean president spared court appearance
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court ruled that impeached President Park Geun Hye will not be required to appear for questioning. However, her close friend Choi Soon-Sil, also known as "Rasputin," must submit for questioning on January 10. The court's decision comes after the National Assembly asked for Park's direct questioning. Park's impeachment was triggered by a corruption scandal, and this move indicates a shift in the court's stance on her involvement.

images.alt_text: The court tasked with validating the impeachment of South Korean President Park Geun Hye said Friday that she would not be required to appear for questioning.

site_title: Hong Kong to sell first commercial site in Central since 1996
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced the sale of a commercial site in Central, the first since 1996, valued at HK$15.8 billion to HK$17 billion. The 31,000 square-foot site will set a new indicator for office rents in Central. Strong demand from Chinese companies has driven record-breaking deals, including a recent sale of HarbourGate East Tower for HK$4.5 billion. The sale may attract attention due to low prime-office vacancy rates and a lack of new supply, potentially stimulating investment demand and driving up existing office prices.

site_title: China official dealing with Taiwan accused of bribery
summary: China's state prosecutor formally accused a former deputy head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, Gong Qinggai, of bribery and abuse of power. Gong, who was put under investigation in January, allegedly took large sums of money while holding government positions in Fujian province. The case is sensitive due to Beijing's strained relationship with Taiwan. Gong's trial is expected, with the ruling Communist Party controlling the legal system and guaranteeing his conviction and imprisonment. This marks the latest in a crackdown on corruption led by President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Taiwan prisoners turn artisan chefs as 'jail food' takes off
summary: Taiwan's Taoyuan women's prison has started a food industry, where inmates turn themselves into artisan chefs to produce high-quality snacks, dubbed 'jail food'. The inmates, wearing masks and hair nets, create a range of products, including chocolate and kimchi, using ingredients provided by the prison. This initiative is part of a growing trend in Taiwan, where prisoners are being utilized to create artisan snacks, offering an alternative to traditional prison food. The venture aims to provide the inmates with a sense of purpose and skill development.

site_title: Mayor of China's Chongqing steps down, paving way for promotion
summary: Mayor of China's Chongqing, Huang Qifan, has stepped down, paving the way for a promotion to a senior position, possibly alongside Premier Li Keqiang. Huang, a respected expert on financial and economic affairs, had been tipped to replace Yang Jing as secretary-general of the State Council, helping the premier oversee the country's economy. His departure may also impact his allies, as Chongqing's party boss, Sun Zhengcai, is also a potential candidate for top national leadership.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Global Logistics Properties, Keppel T&T
summary: Global Logistics Properties (GLP) announced a US$26 million cash injection into GLP US Income Partners III, a fund holding a US$1.1 billion logistics portfolio. Meanwhile, Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation completed the acquisition of a data centre facility in Frankfurt by a joint venture between Keppel Data Centres Holding and Alpha DC Fund. These developments may impact the shares of these companies.

site_title: China's outbound M&A push to draw more scrutiny after record year
summary: China's record $105 billion in outbound M&A deals in 2016 is expected to slow down in 2017 due to increased regulatory scrutiny and capital controls. Tighter rules at home and abroad, combined with Donald Trump's protectionist leanings, may deter Chinese companies from making large purchases. The number of failed bids, particularly in the US, reached a record high, with $35.6 billion in unsuccessful bids. Chinese companies are also being vetted for large transfers abroad and are required to provide more information on their funding sources.

site_title: China tightens anti-money laundering regulations for banks
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has tightened anti-money laundering regulations for banks, requiring financial institutions to report cross-border transactions of 200,000 yuan or more starting July 1. The PBOC also requires notification of domestic cash deposits, withdrawals, or transfers of 50,000 yuan or more, and will adjust the limit if needed. The move aims to curb money laundering and is part of stepped-up efforts to tackle the issue.

site_title: Aussie shares poised for a tame end to a buoyant 2016; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares closed the year on a relatively calm note, falling 0.2% to 5,688.3, after a strong 7.4% gain this year. Financial shares underperformed, with the "Big Four" banks down more than 1% each. Materials and metals sectors, however, continued their impressive performance, with the materials index up 40% and broader metals index up 53.2% for the year. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% to 6,881.2, despite a 9% gain in 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened lower on December 30, 2016, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.8 points to 1,637.130. The market saw 52.3 million lots traded worth RM16.1 million, with 77 gainers and 45 losers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars off lows, still at risk from USD bulls
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose in holiday trading on Friday, but are still at risk from US dollar bulls. The Aussie climbed 0.36% against the US dollar, while the kiwi barely moved, staying near a seven-month low. December is set to be the third straight month of losses for the Aussie, which is down 2% this month and 0.6% for the year. Analysts expect further losses in the New Year due to the US currency's uptrend following Donald Trump's election.

site_title: Trump says will meet US spy chiefs to get 'facts' on Russian hacking
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced plans to meet with US spy chiefs to gather facts on Russian hacking allegations, despite criticizing them. Trump called on Russia to "move on" and expressed a desire to move forward. He also reiterated his election win was not influenced by Russian interference. The meeting aims to provide a clearer understanding of the situation.

site_title: CITM board chairman retires, new chairman appointed
summary: CITM board chairman Chua Yong Hai retires on Jan 1, 2017, after nearly nine years of service. Tan Guong Ching, also retiring, will step down on Jan 15. Ooi Eng Peng, current ARCC chairman, will replace Chua as board chairman, while Bruce Kendle Berry will take over as ARCC chairman. Erle William Spratt will be appointed as a new independent director, subject to approval by the Monetary Authority Singapore. Chua praises Ooi as a valuable member of the board, citing his wealth of industry experience and proven track record.

images.alt_text: Cambridge Industrial Trust Management Limited (CITM) board chairman Chua Yong Hai will retire on Jan 1, 2017 after serving close to nine years, the manager of Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) announced on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on December 30, 2016, due to a slow holiday session in the US, where stocks fell. The Nikkei 225 index eased 0.74% and the Topix index inched down 0.61%. This marked the final trading session of the year.

site_title: Singapore shares higher in early trading on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.23% to 2,895.77 on Friday, the last trading day of the year, with DBS Bank and Singtel leading gains. The S&P 500 Index fell 0.03% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.07%. The euro spiked higher as the US dollar weakened, while Japanese and Australian stocks fell. This marks the first trading day of the year for Singapore, after a 5-day rally.

site_title: Investors favour stock funds over bonds, reversing 2016 trend
summary: US-based investors have shifted their preference from bonds to stocks, with $11.8 billion invested in stock funds in the week ended Dec 28, reversing a trend seen in 2016. This marks the third straight week of bond fund withdrawals, as investors seek potential gains from lower corporate taxes and fewer regulations. The trend is expected to continue through the end of the year and into the inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: Nomura to deepen cost cuts as CEO seeks to keep 'warship' afloat
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. CEO Koji Nagai has unveiled the "Waterline Project," a three-year cost-cutting initiative aimed at reducing non-personnel expenses and improving the bank's cost-effectiveness. The project will focus on eliminating unnecessary work and streamlining operations, although Nagai acknowledged potential job cuts or reassignments. The move comes after Nomura has eliminated hundreds of overseas jobs and is seeking to return its overseas operations to profit. The company's stock has surged 34% since November, driven by speculation that the next US president will ease bank regulations and boost fiscal spending.

images.alt_text: After slashing hundreds of overseas jobs since April, CEO Koji Nagai has unveiled his so-called "Waterline Project," which will attempt to combat waste and improve the cost-effectiveness of the bank's daily operations over the next three years.

site_title: GLP US Income Partners III fund gets further syndication of stake as co-investor injects US$26m
summary: Global Logistics Properties (GLP) announced that a co-investor injected US$26m into its GLP US Income Partners III fund, further syndicating the stake. This corresponds to approximately 8.1% of the fund's aggregate capital contributions. The move reduces New Harvest Holdings' interest in the fund and its subsidiaries from 90.3% to 82.2%. The fund was established to hold a US$1.1 billion logistics portfolio acquired from Hillwood.

site_title: Hong Kong confirms 2nd human bird flu infection this winter
summary: Hong Kong authorities confirmed its second human bird flu infection this winter, with a 70-year-old man diagnosed with the H7N9 strain. The patient, with underlying illnesses, is in stable condition. This comes as concerns rise over the spread of bird flu in neighboring countries and mainland China, where at least two people have died and five have been infected so far this winter.

site_title: South Korea Dec inflation inches down to 1.3% as utility costs fall
summary: South Korea's annual inflation in December decreased to 1.3% from 1.5% in the previous month, the lowest since September. The decline was largely due to a 11.5% drop in utility costs, mainly electricity tariffs. However, inflation from agricultural products, including egg prices affected by avian influenza, rose 6.7% on-year. Despite the drop, inflation still lags the Bank of Korea's target of 2%, but is expected to approach it next year as oil prices rise and the global economy recovers.

site_title: Bankers cautious on outlook for global equity deals after 2016 slide
