summary: Global equity raising fell by more than a quarter in 2016 due to geopolitical shocks and failed IPOs, with companies raising $648.9 billion compared to $873 billion in 2015. The outlook for 2017 is uncertain, with bankers expecting IPO volumes to be similar to this year. However, several big deals are in the pipeline, including Telefonica's O2 listing and Bayer's Monsanto acquisition, which could boost ECM activity. Despite market volatility, some bankers see potential for tech companies to file for IPOs, but caution that investors will remain selective.

site_title: China's megacity housing bubble cure has small town side effects
summary: China's efforts to curb housing bubbles in megacities like Beijing and Shanghai have led to a decline in property prices in smaller towns, where oversupply and empty homes pose a significant challenge. Despite the desired effect in major cities, smaller towns continue to struggle with low prices, contributing to a widening gap between urban and rural areas. Experts warn that the issue is complex, with structural problems in the property market, and more needs to be done to address the oversupply and deflating bubbles.

site_title: South Korea film Master breaks even; maintains top position at box office
summary: South Korea's film Master has broken even within eight days of its release, achieving 3.8 million ticket admissions and $25.3 million in gross box office revenue. The crime-action film, produced by Spackman Entertainment Group, maintains its top position at the South Korean box office with 40.98% market share. Directed by Cho Ui-seok, Master features top South Korean actors Lee Byung-hun, Gang Dong-won, and Kim Woo-bin, and is set to be released in Singapore theaters on January 12, 2023.

site_title: Property investment sales surge to 3-year high
summary: Singapore property investment sales surged to a 3-year high in 2016, reaching S$22.5 billion, a 31% increase from the previous year. The office sector dominated the market, accounting for 44% of total sales, while residential sales followed with 33%. Consultants expect the trend to reverse in 2017, with office sales potentially decreasing and residential sales increasing. However, factors such as rising interest rates and a weakening US dollar are expected to impact the market, with some predicting total sales to remain in the S$18-S$20 billion range in 2017.

site_title: Euro soars in holiday-thinned trade, China basket move adds to yuan buzz
summary: The euro surged to its highest in three weeks, reaching US$1.0700, in holiday-thinned Asian trade, but is on track for a losing year due to US President-elect Donald Trump's policies expected to boost inflation and prompt faster interest rate hikes. The euro also rose against the Japanese yen, while the US dollar slipped 0.1% to 116.43 yen. Sterling rose 0.2% to US$1.2293, while China's yuan is expected to end the year down nearly 7% against the resurgent US dollar.

site_title: Philippine leader says once threw man from helicopter, would do it again
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte threatened corrupt officials with being thrown out of a helicopter mid-air, warning he has done it before. The former prosecutor, who admitted killing people during his time as mayor, made the statement during a speech to typhoon victims. The US expressed concern over reports of extrajudicial killings, while the UN's top human rights envoy called for an investigation into Duterte's claims. Duterte has denied the incident, labeling it an "urban legend".

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has threatened corrupt government officials with the prospect of being thrown out of a helicopter mid-air, warning he has done it himself before and would do it again.

site_title: Britain avoids M&A collapse as foreign buyers go Brexit bargain hunting
summary: Britain's mergers and acquisitions (M&A) market avoided a collapse after the Brexit vote, with foreign buyers snapping up British companies due to the sterling's devaluation against the US dollar. Total M&A values in 2016 were $177.5 billion, down from $394.8 billion in 2015, but in line with a five-year trend. Foreign buyers, including Rupert Murdoch's Twenty-First Century Fox, accounted for most activity, while domestic UK-to-UK dealmaking fell sharply. Despite Brexit uncertainty, some investors remain confident in Britain's economy, citing the weaker pound making UK businesses 10-20% cheaper.

images.alt_text: Britain avoided a collapse in mergers and acquisitions activity after the shock Brexit vote as foreign companies used sterling's spectacular devaluation against the US dollar to snap up British companies, Thomson Reuters data shows.

site_title: Brazil's president to pursue tax reform in 2017
summary: Brazil's President Michel Temer plans to simplify the country's tax code in 2017, aiming to expand business-friendly reforms and lift the nation from its economic recession. The move follows proposals to modify the pension system and labor laws, and comes after Congress sanctioned a spending cap for the next 20 years. Economists have long criticized Brazil's complex tax system as a barrier to growth, and the reform could include unifying federal and state taxes, simplifying the tax regime for the oil and gas industry, and reducing red tape.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE sets record closing high as gold miners shine
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index reached a record closing high, 0.2% higher at 7,120.26 points, driven by a rally in gold miners Randgold Resources and Fresnillo following stronger gold prices. The UK index is up 14% this year, outperforming the pan-European Stoxx 600 index, which fell 1.5% in 2016. Weaker banks, including Italian merger partners Banco Popolare and Banca Popolare di Milano, also dragged down the Stoxx 600, which ended 0.4% lower.

site_title: Duterte unfazed by China's island-building in contested waters
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte expressed no intention of aggressively pursuing the country's maritime claim in the South China Sea, despite China's island-building activities in the disputed waters. Duterte stated that the US should lead the way to address concerns, and he would only challenge China if it starts exploiting natural resources within the Philippines' sovereign territory, citing a "question of money." He reiterated his desire to avoid confrontation with China and maintain good relations with the country.

site_title: US dollar falls against yen on US yield drop, profit-taking
summary: The US dollar fell to a 15-day low against the yen on Thursday, dropping 0.5% to 116.65 yen, amid profit-taking and reduced appeal due to lower US Treasury yields. The decline comes after the dollar's 11.5% gain against the yen since the US election, which was driven by rising US Treasury yields and expectations of inflation. The euro also rose against the dollar, while the Swiss franc and sterling strengthened against the greenback. The US dollar index fell 0.59% to 102.69, its lowest level since December 14.

site_title: Keppel and Alpha DC Fund JV unit completes acquisition of Frankfurt data centre facility
summary: A unit of the joint venture between Keppel Data Centres Holding and Alpha DC Fund has completed the acquisition of a Frankfurt data centre facility. The two-storey facility, located in Am Martinzehnten Industrial Park, is close to Frankfurt Airport and the DE-CIX Internet Exchange, ensuring low-latency and high-quality connectivity. The acquisition was made by Graphite (DC) BV, the indirect wholly owned subsidiary of the joint venture.

site_title: Magnitude 6.2 quake hits near Sumbwa, Indonesia: USGS
summary: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake struck near Sumbawa, Indonesia, on December 29, 2016, with a depth of 72 km below the seabed, according to the USGS. The quake was initially measured as 6.4 but was later revised. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre did not issue a tsunami warning. The earthquake's location 71 km south of Raba city suggests it may have been a minor seismic event. No tsunami was predicted, and the quake was not expected to cause significant damage.

images.alt_text: An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.2 struck on Friday off the island of Sumbawa in the Indonesian archipelago, 71 km south of Raba city, according to the United States Geological Survey (USGS).

site_title: US: Stocks edge slightly lower as banks, tech retreat
summary: US stock markets ended slightly lower on Thursday, with banks and tech companies experiencing declines. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1% to 19,819.78, retreating from a milestone at 20,000 points. Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs saw their share prices drop by 1% or more, while Amazon and Tesla fell 0.9% and 2.3%, respectively. The market's performance was attributed to a sleepy holiday session, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Retailer Kate Spade exploring sale: report
summary: Kate Spade & Co, a US handbag and accessories retailer, is exploring a sale amid pressure from activist investors. The company, which had a market value of $1.86 billion, is working with a bank to identify potential buyers, including retailers. Sales have weakened in the US due to online shopping and a strong dollar, prompting competitors like Coach and Michael Kors to tighten supplies and explore deals. Kate Spade's stock has fallen 18.4% this year, and the company reported lower-than-expected quarterly sales last month.

site_title: Tennis: Serena announces engagement to Reddit co-founder
summary: Tennis superstar Serena Williams announced her engagement to Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian in a poem on her Reddit account. The 35-year-old tennis player and 33-year-old Ohanian did not reveal a wedding date. Williams won Wimbledon earlier this year, matching Steffi Graf's record for most Grand Slam singles titles. The news was met with congratulations from the WTA Tour, and Ohanian replied saying Williams made him the "happiest man on the planet." The couple's engagement marks a new chapter for Williams, who dominated the tennis world for much of her career.

site_title: Asia-Pacific IPO market to rebound from weak 2016 on China financial deals
summary: The Asia-Pacific IPO market is expected to rebound in 2017, driven by listings of financial firms in China, including Lufax's potential US$5 billion IPO. This is expected to boost deal flow and reverse the 22.5% decline in Asia-Pacific equity capital markets in 2016. Other countries, such as South Korea, Singapore, and India, are also expected to see strong IPO activity, with potential listings from companies like Netmarble Games, NetLink Trust, and Reliance Infrastructure. Greater China exchanges are forecast to remain the world's most active markets for IPOs in 2017.

site_title: Toyota hybrid bet pays off as dieselgate ignites Europe demand
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is on track for a 40% jump in annual sales of petrol-electric vehicles in Europe, driven by its hybrid models, as the continent phases out diesel vehicles to curb pollution. The Japanese carmaker's strategy, which focused on hybrids in Europe after Volkswagen's emissions scandal, is yielding results, with hybrids set to account for over half of Toyota's deliveries in the region by the end of the decade. Toyota's Europe dilemma was a product mismatch, but its focus on hybrids has made it an enviable position in the market, with diesel-reliant peers needing to shift gears to electrified powertrains.

site_title: US punishes Russia over election hacks
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on Russia's top intelligence agencies, expelling 35 agents and shutting down two Russian compounds on US soil. The move comes after the US intelligence community concluded that Russia hacked into the Democratic Party and Hillary Clinton's emails to influence the presidential election. President Barack Obama ordered the actions in response to Russia's "aggressive harassment" of US officials and cyber operations. The sanctions include designating Russian operatives as "persona non grata" and freezing their assets in the US.

images.alt_text: The United States on Thursday fired back at Moscow for meddling in the presidential election, imposing tough sanctions on Russia's top two intelligence agencies, expelling 35 agents and shutting down two Russian compounds on US soil.

site_title: ASL Marine sets out restructuring terms over S$150m debts
summary: ASL Marine, a Singaporean shipbuilder and vessel charterer, has proposed a restructuring plan to address S$150 million in debt. The company seeks an extension from bondholders on two note issues, offering to step up coupon rates and redeem part of the principal over three years. ASL Marine faces financial covenant pressure and foresees difficulty in redeeming the notes when they fall due. The proposal must be passed by at least 75% of noteholders in a meeting on January 20, 2017, to continue operating as a going concern.

site_title: Govt defers launch of Bidadari mixed-use site to Q1 2017
summary: The Singapore government has deferred the launch of a mixed-use site in Bidadari Estate until Q1 2017, citing the need to finalize site requirements for comprehensive development. Consultants have mixed opinions on the impact of the deferment, with some believing it will not affect demand due to the site's well-located and unique features, while others think it could be beneficial for developers who may see increased demand from nearby BTO flat owners. The site was expected to fetch a high bid of up to S$920 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: China warns US against allowing stopover for Taiwan's Tsai
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen will make a stopover in the US during her visit to Latin America next month, angering China which urges the US to block the stopover. China views Tsai as pushing for Taiwan's formal independence and is suspicious of her intentions. The US, following its "one China" policy, has not confirmed the stopover details yet, but Taiwan media speculates she may meet with Donald Trump's transition team. This comes after Trump's break with precedent by speaking with Tsai and casting doubt on the "one China" policy.

site_title: Slow start despite interesting plot
summary: Amazon Prime Video has released the first season of Philip K Dick's 1962 novel "The Man in the High Castle" as a 10-hour series, with Ridley Scott as an executive producer. The show, created by Frank Spotnitz, follows an alternate history where the Allied Powers lost World War II and is set in a divided 1962 America. The series premieres with a visually stunning pilot, but its slow build-up and unexciting pilot episode may deter some viewers. A young protagonist, Juliana Crain, embarks on a perilous journey to deliver a newsreel to the mysterious "Man in the High Castle," setting up a twist for the second episode.

site_title: Safe-haven eurozone bonds boosted by unease over Italian bank rescue plan
summary: German bond yields fell to multi-week lows due to concerns over Italy's plan to rescue its third-largest lender, Monte dei Paschi di Siena. The Italian government plans to set aside 20 billion euros to cover bank funding requirements, but investors remain uncertain. This has led to a shift towards safe-haven government debt, with German 10-year bond yields hitting a seven-week low at 0.18%. Italian bond yields also edged lower, while US Treasury yields rose to 2.56% due to strong consumer confidence in the US.

site_title: The Age of Incompetence
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump will take office with an unprecedented low approval rating below 50% and a Republican Senate majority that received 13 million fewer votes than their Democratic opponents. Trump's lack of qualifications and temperament are concerning, echoing past examples of George W. Bush and Ronald Reagan, who were also perceived as lacking in knowledge and intelligence. Experts warn that Trump's self-perceived "star" status and desire to be the "decider" could lead to erratic decision-making, putting the country at risk.

site_title: Trudeau's energy boss turns to electricity after oil decisions
summary: Canada's natural resources minister, Jim Carr, is shifting focus to overhauling the National Energy Board and promoting new transmission lines, potentially funded by government and pension funds. After a tumultuous autumn, Carr approved major liquefied natural gas and crude-oil projects, including a Trans Mountain pipeline, while respecting climate-change goals and accommodating indigenous peoples. With President-elect Donald Trump's administration in place, Carr plans to champion cooperation between provinces rich in green energy and those burning coal or gas for electricity, taking short-term steps towards long-term goals.

site_title: Inflation to turn positive soon
summary: Singapore's inflation is expected to turn positive soon, according to recent economic data. The country's employment rates for graduates are also showing improvement, with better job prospects. DPM Gan will visit the US for trade talks, while a new grant of up to S$100,000 will be provided to businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, Singapore is being considered as a potential global hub for advanced chip packaging and has the opportunity to support workers in future-proofing their careers.

site_title: Say 'Auld lang syne' with BT Weekend tomorrow
summary: The Weekend magazine spotlights six personalities to watch in 2017, featuring Gryphon Tea Company's founder Lim Tian Wee, and showcases various lifestyle topics, including a review of 2016's numbers, sports wishlist, and a farewell to journalism jargon. Additionally, the magazine covers articles on mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste initiatives, financial literacy, and corporate purpose.

site_title: 2016 a disappointing year for the gadget nerd
summary: 2016 was a disappointing year for gadget enthusiasts, with few revolutionary technologies emerging. Innovations in software, such as streaming services, dominated the year, rather than hardware. Designing hardware is challenging, and incremental updates to smartphones have reached a plateau. While some technologies, like home hubs and virtual reality, showed promise, they haven't yet become mainstream. In 2017, consumers can expect smaller, incremental updates rather than game-changing gadgets, with smart home devices and wearables expected to be major areas of focus.

images.alt_text: Driverless cars have made leaps and bounds in terms of research, but they aren't hitting your garage any time soon.
Even the latest Apple rumours for the iPhone are a little lacklustre.

site_title: 3 Swiber-linked vessels of Norwegian ship lessor seized in Singapore
summary: A syndicate of banks, including United Overseas Bank (UOB), has seized three vessels linked to Norwegian ship lessor Swiber Holdings in Singapore. The vessels, Swiber Else-Marie, Swiber Mary-Ann, and Swiber Ann-Christine, were arrested over an outstanding mortgage claim of over US$43.4 million. The seizures were taken by a syndicate of banks acting as security agents for the financing deal. The move is seen as an attempt by creditors to mitigate an outright default by Swiber, which has been struggling financially.

site_title: SingPost's new group CEO to start on June 1, 2017
summary: SingPost appoints Paul William Coutts as its new group CEO, effective June 1, 2017. Coutts, 60, joins from Toll Global Forwarding, bringing over two decades of experience in C-suite positions at major logistics and postal companies. His appointment was unanimously approved by the board and has received regulatory approvals. SingPost chairman Simon Israel said Coutts is well-positioned to lead the company's transformation and integrate its eCommerce logistics platforms. Coutts will also be appointed to the SingPost board as a non-independent director, replacing Wolfgang Baier who stepped down following his resignation in December 2015.

site_title: STI manages to stay in the black for 2016
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 9.2 points down on Thursday, despite a year-end gain of about seven points or 0.24% for 2016. The index was thwarted in a window-dressing push earlier in the week, with banks being the main index movers, particularly DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Turnover was low, and active stocks included Noble Group and Spackman Entertainment, with the latter's film MASTER breaching its breakeven point within eight days of its release. European markets opened on the downside, and investor confidence indices showed a decline in sentiment.

site_title: Haresh Sharma in season
summary: Haresh Sharma, a renowned Singapore playwright, is being spotlighted by The Esplanade's "The Studios 2017" for the first time. Sharma, who has written over 100 plays, collaborated with actress Yeo Yann Yann to create a monologue for her. The play, titled "Actor, 40," explores the complexities of an actress's life in the Chinese theatre and film world. Sharma immersed himself in Chinese theatre to create a nuanced and layered performance. The season, which runs from March to April, features five of Sharma's works, including "Fundamentally Happy" and "This Chord and Others," directed by various theatre makers.

site_title: Never been more diverse - and better
summary: The TV industry has experienced unprecedented growth and diversity in 2016, with over two dozen new shows debuting, including critically acclaimed series like "Stranger Things" and "The Crown". The rise of online platforms such as Amazon Prime, Netflix, and Hulu has led to an explosion of original content, allowing more voices from minority backgrounds to emerge. The increased diversity is reflected in the winners of the Primetime Emmy Awards, including Jeffrey Tambor and Raimi Malek. However, this trend may face backlash in Singapore, where conservative quarters are demanding regulation of content.

site_title: The road to 100% Brexit-proof whisky runs through Shanghai
summary: Scotland's Annandale Distillery, a 100-year-old whisky maker, is expanding its operations in Asia to counter the uncertainty of Brexit. The distillery, co-owned by David Thomson, is producing two types of whisky for the Chinese market, where it aims to break through a crowded market. With 90% of Scotch whisky exports going abroad, Annandale is seeking to minimize risks and capitalize on opportunities in countries like India and Singapore, where sales are growing despite tariffs. The distillery is pre-selling whisky casks and exploring partnerships to ensure a steady supply of its unique product.

site_title: Words of the year underscore a dark, surreal 2016
summary: The words of the year for 2016 reveal a dark and surreal year marked by "post-truth," "paranoia," "xenophobia," and a close shave with "fascism." Dictionaries worldwide chose words reflecting the year's politics, trauma, and social divisions, with "surreal" ultimately winning the day. Other notable words include "Brexit," "refugee," and "Trump," which was chosen by the Deaf Association as a sign of the year. The words underscore the challenges and uncertainties of the past year, with language reflecting the complexities and divisions of the time.

site_title: Wine collecting in Singapore today
summary: A seasoned wine collector in Singapore shares his experiences starting a wine collection in 1983. He recommends establishing early contact with wine merchants, buying a range of vintages, and direct sourcing from Bordeaux merchants to save on prices. Key vintages to consider include Bordeaux 1928-1961 and iconic wines like Cheval Blanc 1947 and Latour 1961. The collector advises against wines with US strip labels and emphasizes the importance of reliable wine merchants, such as Raeburn Wine Cellars in Edinburgh. With the rise of the internet, wine collecting has become more accessible, but direct sourcing from Bordeaux merchants remains a valuable strategy for saving on prices.

site_title: Get ready to go green
summary: In 2017, the design world is expected to focus on eco-friendliness, with more green buildings, soothing color palettes, and technology-infused furniture. Experts at Pantone predict a "green" year with yellow-green "Greenery" as a trendy color, while AkzoNobel suggests a versatile grey-blue, "Smoke Grey." Buildings in Singapore are incorporating greenery, such as the Oasia Hotel Downtown, which features a facade covered in creepers that will transform into a "furry building" over time. Furniture manufacturers are also embracing technology, with products that can withstand harsh environments and be customized using virtual reality devices. Designers are advocating for a shift towards quality spaces, simplicity, and sustainability.

site_title: Kerry looks to legacy with hard-hitting speech
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech outlining the Obama administration's vision for the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, emphasizing the two-state solution as the only path to Middle East peace. Kerry defended the administration's decision to abstain from a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlements, stating it aimed to preserve the viability of the two-state solution, which he believes has been in serious jeopardy for nearly a quarter century. Kerry argued that the Obama team has done more for Israel than any other administration.

site_title: Vard shareholders get extra time to take Fincantieri's offer (Amended)
summary: Vard Holdings shareholders have been given a two-week extension to accept Fincantieri's offer to buy out the remaining equity at S$0.24 per share. The offer, which was previously set to close on Dec 29, 2016, now closes on Jan 12, 2017. The extension follows a previous attempt by Fincantieri to privatize its Singapore-listed subsidiary, which was rejected by Vard's independent directors in 2013. The independent directors have since backed the latest offer, citing a 29.03% premium over the six-month volume weighted average price share.

site_title: Sustainability reporting ultimately good for the business
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has elevated sustainability reporting to a "comply or explain" basis, aiming to increase disclosure, accountability, and transparency among listed companies. This initiative has contributed to Singapore's top ranking in Corporate Governance Watch 2016. Good sustainability reporting promotes long-term business practices, stakeholder engagement, and multi-stakeholder accountability, ultimately benefiting companies.

site_title: US acting as global cop for financial crimes
summary: The US has taken on the role of a global policeman for financial crimes, imposing multibillion-dollar fines on major banks and companies, including Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse, for their roles in the 2008 financial meltdown. The country's strict laws and aggressive enforcement have allowed it to extend its reach beyond its borders, prosecuting foreign bribery cases and taking on multinational corporations. This approach has bolstered the US's geopolitical influence and demonstrates the connection between economics and foreign affairs, with the next conflict potentially being fought through economic means rather than bombs.

site_title: Expect another year of surprises - and opportunity
summary: 2016 has been marked by numerous losses, including the deaths of celebrities Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds, as well as icons like George Michael, Muhammad Ali, and Zaha Hadid. The year has also seen devastating conflicts, terrorism, and a significant migrant death toll in the Mediterranean. Notably, Donald Trump's presidential win and "Brexit" shocked the world, while a market rally was triggered by his election. Despite these challenges, 2016 also brought opportunities, including a growth slowdown in China and India's demonetization. The upcoming year will likely bring more disruptions, but also new chances for growth and cooperation.

site_title: A year of deaths ... and rebirths
summary: In 2016, the music industry experienced a year of significant losses, including the passing of notable artists such as George Michael, David Bowie, and Leonard Cohen. However, this year also saw a surge in local concerts and festivals in Singapore, with high-profile performances by Madonna and other major acts. The trend is expected to continue in 2017, with a packed schedule of shows and festivals. The rise of vinyl records also made a comeback, with sales overtaking digital sales in the UK, and physical formats continue to coexist with digital consumption.

site_title: UK home prices likely to lose steam in 2017
summary: UK home prices rose 4.5% in December, exceeding expectations, but growth is likely to slow in 2017 due to economic uncertainty. Nationwide forecasts 2% growth in 2017, citing low interest rates and a housing shortage as supporting factors. The slowdown in growth follows a modest increase in December, after stagnating in November, with London house prices slowing down for the first time since 2008. Economists had expected 3.8% growth, and the market's performance may be impacted by Brexit-related uncertainty.

site_title: Tan brothers to get 1.2b VGO shares in backdoor listing of Hatten's property arm
summary: VGO Corp, a Singapore-based company, plans to issue 1.2 billion new shares in a reverse takeover deal worth S$386 million, giving the property development arm of Malaysian conglomerate Hatten Group a backdoor listing in Singapore. The deal values four Malacca projects at RM1.9 billion and will give the Tan brothers, owners of Hatten Group, full ownership of Sky Win Management Consultancy. The company will also reduce its share capital and change its name to Hatten Land, with the Tan brothers holding 81.1% of the shares following the deal.

site_title: Head of Japan's largest ad agency to quit over suicide of young worker
summary: Japan's largest advertising agency, Dentsu Inc, president Tadashi Ishii to step down following the death of a young employee, Matsuri Takahashi, who died from overwork in 2015. The government has launched an investigation and raids on Dentsu offices, amid a wider push for overtime reform by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Over 20% of companies in Japan have staff working over 80 hours of overtime per month, exceeding the government threshold, and a white paper has been published on the issue.

site_title: Market recovery still uncertain
summary: Singapore's visual arts market remains uncertain, with slow art sales and lower visitor turnout in 2016. Art Stage founder Lorenzo Rudolf attributes the decline to the country's inability to compete with major markets like China and the West, and its need to position itself as a central part of Southeast Asia. Despite a global art market recovery, some galleries expect little improvement in 2017 due to a lack of serious art collectors and respect for the arts in Singapore.

site_title: Come and have a look, Beijing says as aircraft carrier skirts Japan
summary: China's first aircraft carrier, the Liaoning, passed close to Japan and Taiwan as it sailed through the South China Sea for a routine exercise. The defense ministry brushed off encounters with the Japanese military, inviting observers to watch the carrier. The Liaoning then sailed to a base in Hainan, following a passage between Miyako and Okinawa. The move was seen as a demonstration of China's naval capabilities and strategic reach in the region.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: US shale oil companies, including Continental Resources Inc and Pioneer Natural Resources Co, are preparing for a potential price surge, despite a surprise Opec agreement boosting prices. If oil reaches $70 a barrel, US production could increase by 1 million barrels a day, offsetting Opec cuts. Analysts predict better earnings for 2017, and President-elect Donald Trump's plans to ease industry regulations. Shale drillers are expected to remain disciplined and avoid overspending, with some companies, like Continental, more than doubling in value this year.

site_title: Toshiba's woes underline need for reforms
summary: Toshiba Corporation, Japan's largest electronics conglomerate, faces serious financial difficulties due to an asset impairment loss of up to several billion dollars on its US nuclear power business. The company is in talks with its main creditor banks for support, which could force it to seek a capital boost at a time when markets may not be receptive. Toshiba's woes underscore the need for corporate reforms in Japan, which has been struggling with problem-plagued electronics companies, including Sharp and Sony.

site_title: The model behind HK MTR's gold standard
summary: Hong Kong's MTR (Mass Transit Railway) has maintained a 99.9% on-time performance for years, earning its reputation as the global gold standard in performance reliability. The system's success is attributed to its "Rail + Property" model, which allows the MTR Corporation to generate revenue from land development rights, property management, and station commercial businesses. This model enables the company to invest heavily in maintenance and upgrading, with over HK$7 billion spent on infrastructure and assets in the past year.

site_title: Don't bank on boomerang of SGX-delisted firms
summary: Singapore's domestic market capitalisation may face challenges as several large firms delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in 2016, with some potentially returning when private-equity funds exit. However, market participants believe fewer large privatisations are expected in 2017, and companies that left SGX may not necessarily return. The difficulty of an IPO exit in Singapore and sector-concentrated delistings, such as the hollowing out of the consumer sector, also pose challenges for SGX.

site_title: US dollar slips to 2-week low against yen as Treasury yields fall
summary: The US dollar slipped to a 2-week low against the yen due to weaker-than-expected economic data and waning risk appetite, boosting Japan's safe-haven currency. US bond yields fell to their lowest in two weeks, mirroring the dollar's decline. The dollar dropped 0.8% to 116.30 yen, and fell 0.6% against a basket of major currencies, extending a one-week low. Sterling rose from two-month lows, while the euro gained 0.5% after the dollar's decline.

site_title: A tale of two artists and three cities
summary: A collaboration between poet Marc Nair and visual artist Nicola Anthony has resulted in an art exhibition and book launch, paying tribute to three cities: London, Yangon, and Singapore. The pair, who met in 2013, traveled to each city to gather ideas, selecting specific locations with strong intersections of history, culture, and faith. Nair wrote 24 poems, while Anthony created 33 artworks, which will be exhibited at Intersections Gallery and sold in a limited edition book, offering a unique window into the cities' histories and the merging of artistic visions.

site_title: A family drama that's given the Almodovar treatment
summary: Spanish filmmaker Pedro Almodovar's "Julieta" is an adaptation of three linked short stories by Alice Munro, featuring a strong narrative about relationships among women. The film follows Julieta, an elegant older woman, as she reflects on her life and reconnects with her long-estranged daughter after a chance meeting. Through a series of flashbacks, Julieta's past is revealed, including a tumultuous relationship with a fisherman and the birth of her daughter. The film is a restrained, reflective exploration of grief, guilt, and regret, marking a positive addition to Almodovar's impressive body of work.

site_title: Ending the year on a fresh note
summary: Chef John-Paul Fiechtner's new restaurant, Thirteen, in Singapore offers a fresh take on dining with its daily-changing menu, which showcases the chef's creativity and skill. Despite being a late entrant to the scene, the restaurant has already made a positive impression with its cheerful atmosphere and unpretentious personality. Standout dishes include baby corn with prawn butter, green apple and radish salad, and half-raw squid rings. While some dishes, such as the ox tongue and veal heart pastrami, fall short, the overall experience is enjoyable and worth a visit, earning a rating of 7.

site_title: China turns to 3.5t yuan rail expansion to boost growth
summary: China plans to spend 3.5 trillion yuan ($730 billion) to expand its high-speed rail network by 2020, covering 80% of major cities. The 30,000km network will be a significant boost to Chinese suppliers and the nation's transport network, aiming to improve connectivity and bolster growth. The government will invite private investment to fund inter-city and regional rail lines, and plans to adjust fares to ensure rail businesses are viable. This move follows China's efforts to modernize its transport network amid slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Exploring new ideas and techniques
summary: Local artists Baet Yeok Kuan and Chng Nai Wee reunited with their joint exhibition "Juxtaposition" showcasing their unique perspectives. Baet's paintings are inspired by childhood memories, while Chng's mixed media works explore the human body from a scientific viewpoint. Both artists delve into new techniques, incorporating text and digital ink transfer into their pieces. The exhibition highlights their mutual passion for painting and creation, despite differing subject matters, and presents a fresh dialogue between their artistic visions.

site_title: How China built 'iPhone City' with billions in perks for Apple's partner
summary: China has invested billions of dollars in perks, tax breaks, and subsidies to support Apple's manufacturing partner, Foxconn, in Zhengzhou, a city in central China. The facility, which produces 500,000 iPhones a day, is a key contributor to Apple's success, with the company earning 90% of the profits in the smartphone industry worldwide. The incentives, worth an estimated $1.5 billion, include subsidies for building and hiring, as well as bonuses for meeting export targets. This arrangement highlights China's efforts to attract multinational corporations and underscores the importance of the country to US technology companies, particularly Apple.

site_title: Airbus A380 woes deepen as Emirates delay accelerates cost cuts
summary: Airbus has delayed the handover of six A380 aircraft to Emirates, originally planned for 2017 and 2018, by a year due to cost-cutting measures. The delay will impact Airbus's efforts to break even on the A380 program, which has struggled to secure new orders. The delay is part of a broader effort to reduce costs and ensure the program's viability, with Airbus planning to deliver around 12 A380s per year starting in 2018. The move also affects Rolls-Royce, which will bear the full financial brunt of the extra costs.

site_title: Artivision chairman resigns; firm to place out shares, sell bonds
summary: Artivision Technologies' chairman and co-founder Soh Sai Kiang Philip has resigned, effective December 29. The firm has entered into share placement agreements with two individuals, Oxley Holdings' Ching Chiat Kwong and private investor Poh Chew Hua Christine, for S$4.5 million, resulting in 246.9 million new shares. Additionally, two other individuals have subscribed for S$4.875 million of Artivision bonds, with the firm expecting to receive S$9.285 million in net proceeds. The firm will use the funds for general corporate and working capital purposes.

site_title: Nine in 10 firms paid retrenchment benefits in 2015: MOM
summary: In 2015, 90.6% of companies in Singapore that laid off workers paid retrenchment benefits to eligible employees, down from 94.3% in 2012. The total 15,580 workers laid off that year was the highest since the 2009 global financial crisis, with a 20.5% increase from 2014. Large establishments were more likely to give out benefits, with 97.5% paying, compared to 87.9% for smaller establishments.

site_title: Foreign developers bet US$2.8b on Indonesian residential property
summary: Foreign property developers, including China Communication Constructions Group and Mitsubishi Corporation, have invested $2.8 billion in Jakarta's residential property, targeting young middle-income couples. The investments come despite a sluggish Indonesian property market, which has seen a 35% drop in property sales in 2014. Relaxation of mortgage rules and tax cuts have boosted demand, with young couples estimated to number 55 million. The market is expected to grow by at least 15% in 2017, according to research firm Indonesia Property Watch.

images.alt_text: Visitors at the sales office of a China Communications Construction Group unit in Cengkareng, West Jakarta, during the launch of the Daan Mogot City residential development on Dec 10.

site_title: Holistic elderly care: The future is now (Amended)
summary: Aging populations worldwide face unsustainable traditional care models, driving the need for innovative, tech-driven solutions. The "aging active, ageing-in-place and ageing-with-grace" paradigm offers cheaper, faster, and more reliable care through digital technology. Multimodal sensors, wearable devices, and robots can track elderly citizens, prevent falls, and combat dementia. A comprehensive technology platform must link stakeholders, incorporate new technologies, and prioritize real-time data collection for proactive care. A pilot project in Singapore's SHINESeniors initiative has shown encouraging results, highlighting the potential for a future-ready, human-centric approach to elderly care.

site_title: KS Energy's subsidiary reduces share capital
summary: KS Energy's subsidiary, Atlantic Rotterdam (ARL), has reduced its authorized and issued share capital by canceling 66.06 million shares, resulting in a change from 66.66 million shares to 600,000 shares. The capital reduction will utilize $1.32 million in reserves to reduce ARL's accumulated losses.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte calls US envoys 'spies' over alleged ouster plot
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has called US envoys "spies" after a media report alleged a US plot to destabilize his government. Duterte believes most ambassadors are in cahoots with the CIA and accused Philip Goldberg, a former US ambassador, of preparing a "blueprint to undermine" him. The US State Department has denied the allegations as "false". Duterte has previously threatened to abrogate security treaties with the US and has expressed disdain for President Barack Obama and President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: Mermaid associate secures contract extension for jack-up drilling rig
summary: Mermaid Maritime's associate, Asia Offshore Drilling, secured a three-year contract extension for the jack-up drilling rig AOD III with a Middle Eastern client until December 2019. The contract, valued at about $112 million, is at reduced rates to remain competitive. This extension continues the unit's work with the client since 2013.

site_title: US jobless claims fall in sign labour market is near full strength
summary: The US jobless claims fell to 265,000, the 95th straight week below 300,000, indicating a strong labor market. This is the longest stretch since 1970 and suggests the labor market is near full strength. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates earlier this month, citing labor market strength, and forecast three rate hikes in 2017. The number of people still receiving benefits after an initial week of aid also rose to 2.10 million, the highest since September.

site_title: US dollar slips to 2-week low vs yen as Treasury yields fall
summary: The US dollar slipped to a two-week low against the yen due to weaker-than-expected economic data and waning risk appetite, with the dollar dipping 0.8% to 116.30 yen. US Treasury yields fell to their lowest in two weeks, mirroring the decline. Sterling climbed back up from two-month lows, while the euro rose 0.5% against the dollar. Experts suggest the dollar may have reached its "crescendo of selling" and could continue to drift lower if US yields stabilize or decrease.

site_title: US refiners face severe labour shortage in 2017
summary: US refiners face a severe labor shortage in 2017, with the coastal region expected to be short of 37,400 craftsman needed to complete capital projects. The shortage is due to a high demand for labor from major energy projects, including liquefied natural gas export terminals and petrochemical units. This could delay work, drive up costs, and raise accident risks, with refineries risking unscheduled outages if they don't undertake necessary maintenance. Refiners are expected to spend $1.26 billion on planned maintenance next year, the highest level since at least 2010.

site_title: Syria army, opposition confirm nationwide truce
summary: Syria's army and opposition have agreed on a nationwide truce, effective from midnight on December 30th, under a deal brokered by Russia and Turkey. The ceasefire excludes the Islamic State group and former Al-Qaeda affiliate Fateh al-Sham Front. The National Coalition, a leading opposition group, has confirmed its support for the agreement, which aims to create conditions for a political resolution to the conflict. This is the first nationwide halt in fighting since a week-long truce in September and follows a previous truce in February.

images.alt_text: Syria's army said Thursday it would halt all military operations from midnight under a truce deal brokered by Russia and Turkey and supported by a leading Syrian opposition body.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Former OKH Global deputy CEO Bon Ween Foong sold 81.4 million shares in the company, slashing his stake from 9.5% to 2.29%, in an off-market transaction. OKH Global did not reveal the nature of the sale. Meanwhile, Rajah & Tann Singapore welcomed lawyer Norman Ho, who joins the firm's corporate service from January 3. Wee Hur Holdings agreed to sell a plot of land in Brisbane, Australia for A$65.1 million. Mermaid Maritime secured a three-year contract extension for its jack-up drilling rig in the Middle East, adding US$112 million in contract backlog.

site_title: China tightens regulation on insurance company ownership structure
summary: China's insurance regulator has tightened regulations on insurance companies' ownership structures to prevent risk. The upper limit of a single shareholder's stake will be lowered to one-third from 51% to prevent improper benefit transfers. The draft rules also forbid insurers from using wealth management funds to invest in themselves. This move aims to improve transparency and prevent potential risks in the insurance sector.

site_title: Ten years since Iraq's Saddam executed
summary: Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein was hanged on December 30, 2006, at a military intelligence headquarters in Baghdad, 10 years after his ouster. He remained defiant until the end, reciting Islamic testament and criticizing his enemies. Saddam was executed after being found guilty of crimes against humanity for the 1982 killing of 148 Shiites. The execution was met with celebrations by some Shiites but condemned by Sunni Iraqis and governments worldwide. Saddam was buried in his birthplace near Tikrit, Iraq.

images.alt_text: Ousted Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein was hanged inside one of his own regime's former torture centres a decade ago on December 30, 2006.

site_title: Artivision chairman resigns; group enters into share placements and bond subscription agreements
summary: Artivision Technologies' chairman and co-founder Soh Sai Kiang Philip resigned on December 29, 2016. The company also entered into share placement agreements worth S$4.5 million with two individuals, and bond subscription agreements worth S$4.875 million with two others. The share placement agreements granted 370.4 million share options each, with the exercise price set at 1.62 Singapore cents. A new chairman will be appointed in due course.

site_title: China dilutes US dollar role in currency basket, adds 11 more
summary: China has diluted the US dollar's role in a trade-weighted foreign-exchange basket, reducing its weighting from 26.4% to 22.4% starting January 1. The move adds 11 currencies, including the South Korean won and Turkish lira, and aims to reduce the impact of dollar strength on the basket's overall performance. The yuan is trading near a four-month high against the Cfets RMB Index, despite tumbling to an eight-year low against the US dollar. China's central bank officials aim to maintain stability against the basket amid capital outflow pressures.

site_title: US acting as global policeman for financial crimes
summary: The US has taken on the role of a global policeman for financial crimes, imposing multibillion-dollar fines on domestic and foreign financial giants. Recent cases include Deutsche Bank ($7.2 billion), Credit Suisse ($5.3 billion), and JP Morgan Chase, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, and Bank of America collectively ($40 billion). The US legal framework allows it to extend its long arm of the law beyond its borders, with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act enabling prosecution of foreign bribery cases. This has led to the US becoming a worldwide anticorruption police force, bolstering its geopolitical influence.

site_title: Wee Hur to sell Brisbane land for A$65.1m
summary: Wee Hur Holdings Ltd agreed to sell a Brisbane land plot for A$65.1 million (S$67.78 million). The plot, located in the Central Business District, will be reconfigured into two lots and sold separately. Wee Hur plans to use the sale proceeds for other Australian developments, stating it is in the best interest of the group. The sale is part of the company's strategy to optimize its portfolio.

images.alt_text: WEE Hur Holdings Ltd has agreed to sell a plot of land in Brisbane, Australia, for A$65.1 million (S$67.78 million).

site_title: Singapore SMEs' dividend track record slips over past 3 years
summary: Singapore-listed mid and small-cap companies have seen a decline in dividend payouts over the past three years, with only 25.3% maintaining or raising payouts. The average corporate governance scores have also worsened, with a 1.2-point decline from 2014. The study, which graded 359 companies, found that remuneration and interested party transactions were the most significant areas of concern, while internal controls and quality of financial reporting showed slight improvements. The trend suggests that corporate governance practices among SMEs may need to be strengthened.

images.alt_text: Dividend payouts by Singapore-listed mid and small-cap companies have deteriorated over the last three years - no thanks to the economic challenges weighing on these firms.

site_title: Hong Kong's K Wah wins residential site for HK$5.87b
summary: K Wah International Holdings Ltd, controlled by casino tycoon Lui Che Woo, won a HK$5.87 billion (S$1.098 billion) bid for a 9,700-square-meter residential site in Hong Kong's Kai Tak area. The deal surpassed market expectations and beat 15 other developers, including China Overseas Land and Sun Hung Kai Properties. The sale comes as Hong Kong's government steps up efforts to contain property prices, which have been driven by capital inflows from China. The transaction marks the latest high-stakes property deal in the city's competitive market.

site_title: King of Swing ready to ring in new year
summary: Jeremy Monteiro, known as the "King of Swing," will celebrate the start of 2017 with a dinner show at Quentin's The Eurasian Restaurant, paying tribute to Frank Sinatra. The performance will feature Monteiro's trio, along with Scottish vocalist James Flynn, playing classic Sinatra songs. The event, "Frankly, It's the New Year," will also include a buffet spread of Southeast Asian favorites. This marks Monteiro's fourth decade in showbiz, which he celebrated with an all-star concert, "Jazzy Business," last year.

site_title: OKH Global's former deputy CEO slashes stake in off-market deal
summary: Former OKH Global deputy CEO Bon Ween Foong sold approximately 81.4 million shares in an off-market deal worth S$5.5 million, reducing his stake from 9.5% to 2.29%. The sale occurred a few weeks after Foong's departure from the company. The nature of the deal and the buyer's identity remain undisclosed, while Foong's remaining shareholdings include pledged interests to several banks.

site_title: HK, Shanghai: HK Stocks end higher while Shanghai drifts down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed marginally higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.17% to 21,792.61, as Shanghai stocks drifted lower. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.20%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.31%. Thin holiday trading ahead of the New Year contributed to the Shanghai decline.

site_title: UK house prices rise in Dec
summary: UK house prices rose 4.5% in December, exceeding economists' expectations of 3.8% growth. This marks the fifth consecutive month of growth, with Nationwide predicting a 2% increase in 2017, driven by low interest rates and a shortage of homes on the market.

site_title: SingPost appoints new group CEO
summary: SingPost appoints Paul William Coutts as its new group CEO, effective June 1 next year. Coutts, 60, has over 20 years of experience in C-suite positions at major logistics and postal companies. His appointment was the result of a thorough process, with a global executive search firm assisting in the evaluation of candidates. Coutts will also join the SingPost board as a non-independent director, replacing former CEO Wolfgang Baier, who stepped down in June this year.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound a bit at open from Wednesday's sag
summary: US stocks rebounded slightly at the open on Thursday, reversing Wednesday's losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1% to 19,859.71. Analysts attributed the early gains to a "buy-the-dip" move following a sleepy session with low volume. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose 0.1%, putting the S&P 500 on track for a 10% gain for 2016, its best performance since 2013. The market has recovered from earlier challenges, including economic slowdown fears and Brexit uncertainty, and is now looking ahead to 2017 with varying predictions from analysts.

site_title: Second Chance Properties posts 50 per cent drop in Q1 FY17 profit
summary: SECOND Chance Properties reported a 50% year-on-year drop in Q1 FY17 profit to S$1.26 million, due to lower revenues from its apparel, properties, and securities businesses. Revenue fell 10% to S$7.4 million, with earnings per share declining to 0.17 cents. The company attributed the decline to the introduction of GST, weakening Ringgit, and a deteriorating retail industry in Malaysia, but expects its Singapore apparel business and gold business to remain profitable. At least 10 stores will be closed to mitigate losses.

site_title: Bosnia charges policemen over killing prisoners of war
summary: Bosnian prosecutors have charged four former police officers for the killing of eight ethnic Serb prisoners of war in 1992, during the Bosnian War. The victims were detained and shot dead in a park in Sarajevo, with two accused participating in the shooting. The other two accused were informed about the crime but failed to act. One of the accused, Dragan Vikic, a former commander of a special unit, denies any involvement, calling his hands "clean." The indictment marks a significant development in the case, which has been marked by a lack of accountability for war crimes.

site_title: Qatar World Cup construction workers to get 'cooling' hats
summary: Qatar's 2022 World Cup construction workers will receive 'cooling' hard hats to reduce heat stress and heat strokes in the desert heat. Designed by scientists at Qatar University, the solar-powered helmets blow air over a cold pack to lower skin temperature by up to 10 degrees centigrade. This technology aims to improve working conditions for approximately 5,100 migrant workers from Nepal, India, and Bangladesh who face poor safety and living conditions. The helmets will be introduced at all World Cup building sites next summer, providing cooling for up to four hours.

site_title: Israeli right dismisses Kerry speech, waits for Trump
summary: Israeli right-wing leaders have dismissed US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as having little consequence, especially with Donald Trump set to take office. Kerry's speech criticized Israeli settlement building and warned it was putting the two-state solution in jeopardy. Despite some opposition support, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has defended his government's pro-settlement stance, and religious nationalists see the West Bank as part of Israel. A Palestinian president has offered to resume peace efforts if settlement activity stops.

site_title: China says to hold first military drills with Nepal next year
summary: China plans to conduct its first joint military drills with Nepal next year, aiming to increase its influence in the landlocked country. The move comes amid a festering border dispute with neighboring India, which has traditionally been Nepal's dominant outside power. The Chinese Defence Ministry announced the plans, citing recent exchanges between the two militaries, and will provide further details in due time. This marks the first joint military exercises between China and Nepal, potentially raising concerns in India.

site_title: South Korea prosecutor seeks arrest warrant for pension chief
summary: South Korea's special prosecutor's office has applied for an arrest warrant for National Pension Service Chairman Moon Hyung-pyo, charging him with abuse of power and giving false testimony. Moon, under emergency detention, had acknowledged ordering the National Pension Service to support the US$8 billion merger of two Samsung Group affiliates while he was health minister. He had previously denied exerting pressure on the pension service to back the merger during a parliamentary hearing in November.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover losses to end higher
summary: Australia's shares ended higher, recovering losses, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 0.25% at 5,669.1. The gain was driven by a rise in gold prices and a weakening US dollar, boosting basic material stocks. Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton led gains, while New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.24%.

site_title: Bangladesh police detail suspicions of inside help in bank heist
summary: Bangladesh police suspect IT technicians from the Bangladesh central bank may have helped hackers gain access to the bank's transactions system, leading to the theft of $81 million in February. Investigators believe the technicians connected the SWIFT network to the public Internet, making it accessible to hackers. A password token was left inserted in the server for months, allowing hackers to infect the system with malware and issue fake transfer orders. No arrests have been made, and the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Malaysia to phase out 9-month Klibor rate
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, announced the phasing out of the 9-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (Klibor) effective January 2018 due to limited market demand and insufficient data. The decision affects existing and new contracts referencing the 9-month Klibor, with market participants expected to review and provide alternative mechanisms during the transitional period. The move aims to improve the relevance and reliability of the interbank benchmark rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: In Singapore, nine out of 10 firms continue to pay retrenchment benefits to eligible employees, according to a Ministry of Manpower report. The government has also deferred the launch of a commercial and residential site in Bidadari Estate until Q1 2017. Meanwhile, Vard Holdings shareholders have until January 12 to accept an offer by Fincantieri subsidiary, and ASL Marine seeks to extend the maturity date of its notes. Felda secured government financing for its US$505.4 million purchase of a minority stake in PT Eagle High Plantations.

site_title: ASL Marine seeks to extend maturity date of its notes, amend interest rates payable
summary: ASL Marine Holdings is seeking approval from note holders to extend the maturity date of its notes for three years and amend interest rates payable. The company is also introducing a call option and mandatory redemption event, allowing for a form of security to be taken and amending financial covenants. These changes are subject to the terms and conditions of the Consent Solicitation Statement.

site_title: China to boost farmland by 2020 in food security push
summary: China plans to boost its farmland reserves by 1.3 million hectares over the next three years as part of an effort to maintain sufficient acreage for crops to ensure food security. The government identified food security as one of its biggest challenges in the next decade, citing rapid urbanization and environmental damage. This move comes after a 13-year loss of arable land, with total arable land reserves falling by 2 million hectares since 2003, and continuous arable land reserves plummeting by 74% over the same period.

site_title: South Korean envoy to France grilled over Park censorship
summary: South Korea's Ambassador to France, Mo Chul Min, was questioned by investigators over allegations that the government blacklisted thousands of cultural figures deemed critical of impeached President Park Geun Hye. The alleged list, containing over 9,400 names, was used to clamp down on left-leaning artists and prevent them from securing government subsidies. The Blue House has denied the existence of the list, which includes prominent figures such as authors Han Kang and artist Hong Sung Dam. The scandal has raised concerns about censorship in South Korea, which ranked 70th in the world's press freedom index.

images.alt_text: South Korea's ambassador to France was grilled by investigators Thursday over allegations that the government blacklisted thousands of cultural figures deemed critical of impeached President Park Geun Hye.

site_title: Japan's Nomura sees opportunities from Trump's pro-business agenda
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc sees opportunities in US President-elect Donald Trump's pro-business agenda, expecting deregulation and infrastructure spending to boost the US economy. This could benefit Nomura's equity trading and advisory divisions. However, Trump's protectionist policies could limit opportunities for financial firms and have a detrimental effect on global trade, particularly for Japan's export-heavy economy. Nomura is considering options for every scenario, including relocating operations to EU cities.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings Inc sees opportunities in the pro-business stance of US president-elect Donald Trump, though his protectionist tilt brings uncertainty to the global economy, said the chief of Japan's biggest brokerage and investment bank.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 7.63 points to 1,637.93. 1.76 billion lots, valued at RM1.39 billion, were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 371 to 370.

site_title: For China's pig farmers, New Year feasts bring cold comfort
summary: Chinese pig farmers face a challenging Lunar New Year due to a slump in retail pork prices and rising feed costs. Despite historically high profits, margins have halved in six months as a result of a surge in imports. With 140 million pigs to be slaughtered in the two months leading up to the New Year holiday, farmers are bracing for a potential loss-making year. Feed costs, particularly soymeal, have increased, and analysts expect pork prices to remain under pressure beyond the New Year holiday.

site_title: Singapore stocks close weaker but STI stays in the black for 2016
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed the year 2016 in the black, despite a weaker close on Thursday, with a net gain of 0.24% for the year. The index had previously struggled to break above the 2,882 level, which marked the end of 2015, but a late surge helped it reach 2,889.15. Thin trading volume and a low 1.2 billion units worth S$565 million were reported. The year's performance marked a mixed end to 2016, with stocks closing weaker on Thursday.

site_title: Alibaba Media Unit to invest 50b yuan over 3 yrs
summary: Alibaba Digital Media and Entertainment Group plans to invest over 50 billion yuan (S$10.4 billion) over the next three years, according to its new CEO Yu Yongfu. The investment will be used to fund new projects and expand the company's media empire, which includes video website Youku Tudou, UCWeb, Alibaba Pictures Group, and digital business units. This investment comes as Alibaba continues to double down on entertainment and establish itself in Hollywood, with recent purchases including a stake in Amblin Partners backed by Steven Spielberg.

site_title: Govt defers launch of commercial & residential site in Bidadari estate to Q1 2017
summary: The Singapore government has deferred the launch of a commercial and residential site in Bidadari Estate along Upper Serangoon Road until Q1 2017. The site was initially slated for launch under the second-half 2016 Government Land Sales Programme. The Housing & Development Board (HDB) will announce the site's finalization for sale once the site requirements for comprehensive development are finalized. The site is estimated to yield 825 private homes and 15,000 sq m of commercial space with a proposed plot ratio of 3.5.

site_title: Commuters can top up Cepas cards using credit and debit cards from Jan 1
summary: Commuters in Singapore can top up their Cepas cards using credit and debit cards from any bank starting January 1, 2017. This includes foreign-issued credit and debit cards. The change aims to increase convenience for commuters.

site_title: National Bank of Oman gets offer to buy stake
summary: National Bank of Oman (NBO) has received a proposal from Treasure Fleet International, a Singapore-based firm, to buy a stake in the bank. NBO will review the proposal, which is subject to shareholder and regulator approval. The acquisition would be Oman's third major deal in the banking sector. Treasure Fleet International's business details are limited, and no legally binding commitments have been made.

site_title: Japan:Nikkei drops to near 3-week low
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average dropped to a near three-week low on Thursday, falling 1.3% to 19,145.14 points, due to weakness on Wall Street and a stronger yen. Toshiba Corp plummeted 17% after rating agencies cut its credit ratings, while Takata Corp surged 16% after a potential settlement with the US Department of Justice over defective air bags. The Nikkei is expected to end the year with a 0.6% gain.

site_title: Tan brothers to take 1.2b VGO shares for backdoor listing of Hatten's property arm
summary: The Tan brothers, Colin and Edwin, will acquire 1.2 billion new shares in VGO Corp, a Singapore-based company, in a reverse takeover deal valued at $386 million. This will give the Tan brothers full ownership of Sky Win Management Consultancy, Hatten Group's property development arm. The deal represents 92.8% of VGO's post-enlargement issued share capital and will provide a backdoor listing for Hatten's property arm in Singapore.

site_title: Felda secures Malaysian govt financing for Eagle High stake purchase
summary: Felda, a Malaysian state-owned company, secured government financing for its $505.4 million purchase of a 37% stake in Indonesian palm oil firm PT Eagle High Plantations Tbk. The deal has faced criticism for being overpriced, but Felda's deputy director-general denied this, citing the strategic importance of the acquisition and the lack of comparable plantations available at the same valuation.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on profit-taking, tracking regional markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.2% on Thursday, tracking regional markets, as investors booked profits after a one-week high. The main Taiex index closed at 9,186.47 points, its best single-session percentage gain in three weeks. The electronics subindex and financials subindex declined 0.2% each. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$32.289 per US dollar. The last trading session of the year is on Friday, with markets closing for a three-day holiday weekend and resuming on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore Q4 GDP seen likely to show economy dodging recession
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 3.7% in the fourth quarter, averting a recession, according to a Reuters poll. The growth is attributed to a jump in factory output in November. However, analysts remain cautious due to global uncertainty, including the Trump administration's protectionist measures and China's economic slowdown. The government's forecast for full-year growth is 1.0-1.5%, its weakest performance since 2009. Analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to keep its exchange-rate based policy unchanged in April, but some predict easing if the growth outlook worsens.

site_title: Most firms pay retrenchment benefits to eligible employees: MOM report
summary: Most Singaporean firms paid retrenchment benefits to eligible employees in 2015, with nine in 10 establishments continuing to provide the benefits. A total of 15,580 workers were laid off, with the majority receiving one month of salary per year of service. This was comparable to those with 25-199 employees.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip at open after London record peak
summary: European stocks declined in opening trade on December 29, 2016, after reaching a record peak the previous day. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.4% to 7,057.17, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.6% and Paris's CAC 40 fell 0.5%. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare sector losses. The focus shifted to US-EU trade tensions, which may impact the markets.

site_title: Australia shares slide on real estate stocks, NZ nudges higher
summary: Australian shares slid 0.1% to 5,678.7, dragged down by real estate stocks, including Vicinity Centres Re Ltd and Dexus Property Group, which fell 3.6% and 3.3% respectively. The decline was attributed to a broad selloff on Wall Street, driven by worries about Italian banks and rising interest rates. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% to 6887.88, driven by gains in Air New Zealand Ltd and Ryman Healthcare Ltd.

site_title: China tech giant LeEco in talks on 10b yuan support
summary: LeEco, a Chinese technology conglomerate, is in talks with an unnamed strategic investor for a 10 billion yuan (S$2.08 billion) deal. The investor is believed to be an insurance company, following a cash-strapped LeEco that has been expanding aggressively in various businesses, including electric cars and smartphones. The company has secured US$600 million in commitments to support its automotive unit and high-tech business, but has also cut 10% of its staff and restructured its business.

site_title: Gold prices rise by most in a month as US dollar eases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,148.28 an ounce, its biggest one-day gain since November 28, as the US dollar eased 0.3% against a basket of currencies. The move was attributed to the dollar's weakness, but gains were limited due to expectations of more US interest rate hikes next year. Gold has risen 8% this year despite an 8% drop in November, and its sensitivity to rising rates may limit its gains.

site_title: Gentrification splits famous London district
summary: Brixton, a London neighborhood once plagued by racism and poverty, is now facing gentrification. The area's Afro-Caribbean soul is being threatened as rising prices force long-time residents out. Network Rail's commercial refurbishment of viaduct arches is seen as an attempt to cash in on the area's growing popularity, with rents set to more than double by 2022. Local shopkeepers are refusing to close their doors, sparking an online petition and a dispute with the local council and Network Rail.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai to transit in US in move bound to anger China
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen will transit through the US during her upcoming visit to Latin America, sparking concerns in China that she aims to push for Taiwan's formal independence. China had urged the US to block the transit stopover, citing its "one China" policy. The visit, scheduled for Jan 7-15, will include stops in Honduras, Nicaragua, Guatemala, and El Salvador, with speculation that Tsai may meet with President-elect Donald Trump's transition team. The move is likely to further strain US-China relations.

site_title: Yachting: NZ's Giacomo wins overall Sydney-Hobart honours
summary: New Zealand's Giacomo, a 70-foot yacht, won the handicap honours in the record-breaking Sydney-Hobart yacht race, breaking the old record by hours. Giacomo, owned by Jim Delegat, a New Zealand winemaker, finished with a corrected time of 1 day 15hr 27min 5sec. The yacht's crew, including Delegat's two sons, outperformed rivals in the downwind conditions, which suited the 70-footer. Giacomo's victory marked a surprise win, as the yacht was not expected to lead the pack.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's Giacomo won the handicap honours Thursday in the record-breaking Sydney-Hobart yacht race after rivals were becalmed on Hobart's breathless River Derwent.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide to 3-week low as Wall Street steps back; won rebounds
summary: South Korean stocks slid to a three-week low on the last trading day of the year, closing at 2,021.62 points, down 0.1% from the previous day. Investors offloaded stocks following a sluggish Wall Street session, with offshore investors selling 26.6 billion Korean won worth of Kospi shares. The Kospi was set to post its biggest yearly percentage gain of over 3% in four years. The South Korean won inched up 0.2% against the US dollar, reversing losses from earlier in the week.

site_title: In northern Italy, a real underground wine
summary: In northern Italy, Mauro Camusso produces a champagne-style sparkling wine in a disused mineral mine, utilizing the unique conditions of the Val Germanasca mine, where the temperature remains constant at 10°C and humidity is nearly 90%. The wine undergoes secondary fermentation deep underground, adding yeasts and sugar to create bubbles. The venture has given the former industrial site a new lease of life, and Camusso hopes the unusual cellar conditions will bring an extra layer of quality to his underground wine.

site_title: China to step up audit of overseas investments by state-owned firms
summary: China's National Audit Office plans to strengthen audits of overseas investments by state-owned firms and step up audits of state assets held abroad. The move aims to safeguard overseas state-owned assets and prevent financial risks. This comes amid recent measures to tighten controls on money moving out of the country, including a 55.3% increase in non-financial outbound direct investment from January to November. The audit office will also monitor capacity cuts, debt reductions, and key public projects to prevent financial risks and ensure accountability.

site_title: Chinese video giant Leshi's in talks to raise $1.4b
summary: Chinese video giant Leshi is in talks to raise $2.08 billion from strategic investors through a private stock offering. The company, backed by LeEco founder Jia Yueting, aims to raise more than 10 billion yuan to address its financial woes. Leshi's share price has dropped 36% in the past year due to LeEco's cash crunch, and suppliers have reported delayed payments. Negotiations are ongoing, with shares expected to resume trading within 10 days.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow US lower as yen strengthens
summary: Asian stocks declined, following a lower US market, as the yen strengthened. The S&P 500 fell 0.8% to its lowest since October, while Japanese shares are headed for their biggest drop in over a month. Oil prices dropped, and gold extended its gains. Investors are selling US equities, trimming a post-election rally, and preparing for a Trump presidency, which is expected to boost public spending.

site_title: Twitter unveils 360-degree live video
summary: Twitter has unveiled 360-degree live video, allowing users to interact and get behind the scenes of live broadcasts. The feature, available on Periscope, enables users to see live videos from different angles by clicking on the stream. Twitter tested the feature with a small group of partners and plans to roll it out more broadly in the coming weeks. This marks the latest move by social media platforms to enhance live video capabilities, following Facebook's introduction of 360-degree videos earlier this year.

site_title: China completes high-speed rail links from south-west Yunnan
summary: China has completed two high-speed rail links connecting Kunming, Yunnan province, with Shanghai and Guangzhou, marking a significant milestone in its ambitious railway building programme. The new 2,252km railway, the longest east-west high-speed link, reduces travel time to 11 hours and 15 minutes. China's high-speed rail network is expected to reach 30,000km by 2020 and expand to 150,000km by the end of the decade, connecting 29 of its 31 provinces and regions.

site_title: Shareholders of Vard Holdings have till Jan 12 to accept offer by Fincantieri subsidiary
summary: Fincantieri subsidiary Fincantieri Oil & Gas SpA has extended the closing date for its voluntary conditional cash offer for Vard Holdings shares to January 12, 2017, from December 29. The offer price remains at S$0.24 per share, with shareholders having until January 12 to accept. Fincantieri owns a 55.6% stake in Vard Holdings.

images.alt_text: SHIPBUILDING group Fincantieri's wholly owned subsidiary Fincantieri Oil & Gas SpA has extended the closing date for the voluntary conditional cash offer for all of the issued ordinary shares in the capital of offshore vessel builder Vard Holdings, Vard said in a Singapore Exchange (SGX) filing on Thursday.

site_title: China slashes first round of oil products export quotas - sources
summary: China has cut oil product export quotas for its four state oil majors by 40% in the first round of licenses for 2017, from 20.54 million tonnes to 12.4 million tonnes. The move is expected to bring little relief to the saturated Asian oil market, with companies applying for more realistic quotas. Despite the cut, traders anticipate the total 2017 quota to be on par or higher than the previous year's record 46.08 million tonnes. The next round of quotas is expected to be released in the second quarter.

site_title: China turns to 3.5t yuan rail expansion to boost growth
summary: China plans to invest 3.5 trillion yuan by 2020 to expand its railway system, with high-speed rail lines spanning over 30,000 km, covering 80% of major cities. The plan includes adding 3,000 km to urban rail transit systems and inviting private investment to fund intercity and regional rail lines. The government aims to boost growth and improve connectivity, despite unprofitable operations in poorer western cities, which will be addressed through fare adjustments and private investment.

images.alt_text: China plans to spend 3.5 trillion yuan (S$729.6 billion) to expand its railway system by 2020 as it turns to investments in infrastructure to bolster growth and improve connectivity across the country.

site_title: Australia nets biggest cocaine bust on record
