summary: Australian police have seized a record 1.1 tonnes of cocaine worth hundreds of millions of dollars in a joint operation with Tahiti. The cocaine, valued at Aus$360 million, was intercepted by the French navy, seized in Sydney, and found in Fiji, all bound for the Australian market. A major cocaine ring has been dismantled, with 600 arrested and charged with serious drug importation offences. The operation, which began over two years ago, is considered a significant hit against the Australian cocaine economy.

site_title: Phillips 66 shuts several units at Rodeo, California refinery
summary: Phillips 66 shut down multiple processing units at its Rodeo, California refinery after an incident at a nearby hydrogen plant owned by Air Liquide. The release caused flaring, prompting the shutdown of two hydrocracker units at around 9:30 am. Hydrocrackers use hydrogen to process residual fuels into higher-value products like diesel and gasoline. Phillips 66 did not immediately comment on the incident. The refinery's shutdown is the latest in a series of disruptions at California's oil refineries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.29% to 21,691.97, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21% to 3,095.84. The Shenzhen Composite Index slid 0.17% to 1,969.03. The declines follow overnight losses on US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 7-month lows
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained near 7-month lows due to sustained demand for the US dollar. The Australian dollar rose 0.24% to US$0.7191, while the New Zealand dollar increased 0.14% to US$0.6925. The Aussie has fallen in 7 out of the last 10 sessions, while the kiwi has gained 1.4% for the year, its fourth consecutive year of losses. Strong US economic data and Treasury yields have contributed to the decline.

site_title: Convenience stores boom as Korea's households change
summary: South Korea's convenience store industry is booming, driven by the rise of single-person households, which are expected to account for about a third of the country's households by 2030. The number of convenience stores has jumped by over half in the past five years, with the largest chain, BGF Retail Co, likely to surpass $5.9 billion in revenue in 2016. Convenience stores are adapting to the needs of single people, offering a wide range of goods and services, including groceries, beauty products, and even car rentals.

site_title: In parting shot at Israel, Kerry warns Middle East peace in jeopardy
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry warned that Middle East peace is in jeopardy due to Israel's settlement building on occupied land. In a speech, Kerry stated that Israel will never have true peace with the Arab world if it doesn't reach an accord based on Israelis and Palestinians living in their own states. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused Kerry of bias, while Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas said he stood by his demand that Israel halt settlements before talks restart. The remarks come weeks before Kerry's departure and have sparked a bitter exchange between the US and Israel.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.59 points to 1,628.71. The market saw 111 million lots traded worth RM36.2 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 71 to 70.

site_title: Toyota hybrid bet pays off as dieselgate ignites Europe demand
summary: Toyota's hybrid models are gaining popularity in Europe, with a 40% jump in annual sales of gasoline-electric vehicles in the first full year since Volkswagen's emissions scandal. By the end of the decade, hybrids are expected to account for more than half of Toyota's deliveries in Europe. The company's strategy to focus on hybrids rather than competing directly with diesel vehicles has paid off, with Volkswagen and other diesel-reliant peers now needing to shift gears to electrified powertrains. Toyota's market share in Europe is increasing, and the company's shares have fallen 6.9% this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on December 29, 2016, in thin holiday trading, following US stocks' decline as investors took profits from recent rallies. The Nikkei 225 index eased 0.55% to 19,294.10, while the Topix index inched down 0.57% to 1,528.02.

site_title: Japan defence minister visits controversial war shrine: media
summary: Japan's Defence Minister Tomomi Inada visited the Yasukuni shrine, honouring millions of Japanese war dead, sparking controversy as China and South Korea have criticized the shrine due to Japan's colonialism and aggression. The visit coincided with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's pilgrimage to Pearl Harbor, drawing criticism from the US. This move is likely to be highly contentious, especially given the recent visit by Abe and US President Barack Obama to the site of Japan's 1941 attack on a US navy base.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says won is not weakening too fast right now
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il-Ho, downplayed the need for government intervention in the currency market, stating that the won's depreciation against the US dollar has not been too fast. The won traded at 1,209.50 against the US dollar, its weakest level since March this year, having lost around 3% against the greenback in 2016. The comments aimed to highlight the won's relative stability compared to other currencies.

images.alt_text: South Korea's finance minister said on Thursday that the won's depreciation against the US dollar has not been too fast, downplaying the urgency of any government intervention in the currency market.

site_title: Trump says Sprint, OneWeb to create 8,000 US jobs
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced that telecommunications group Sprint Corp and satellite company OneWeb will create 8,000 jobs in the US. Trump stated that Sprint will bring 5,000 jobs back from other countries and OneWeb will hire 3,000 people. The jobs are part of a US$50 billion investment by Japan's SoftBank Group Corp, which was announced in December. Trump's optimism over his election led to these job commitments.

site_title: Head of Japan's Dentsu resigns over employee's "death by overwork"
summary: Japan's Dentsu Inc president, Tadashi Ishii, has announced his resignation in January over the "death by overwork" of a 24-year-old employee, Matsuri Takahashi, who died after 105 hours of overtime. The labour ministry deemed her death "karoshi", or death by overwork, and has referred the case to prosecutors. Ishii's resignation comes as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pushes for labour law reforms, including tighter overtime regulation. This is part of a broader effort to address the country's culture of overwork and promote employee well-being.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Emas Offshore, Pacific Andes Resources Development, Second Chance Properties
summary: Emas Offshore plans to announce its first quarter results on January 10. Pacific Andes Resources Development and China Fishery have delayed publishing their annual results to June 30, 2017, due to a forensic review. Second Chance Properties expects its apparel stores in Malaysia to remain under pressure due to competition, with expected 15-20% drop in rentals.

site_title: South Korea considers new electric car rules as Tesla readies showroom
summary: South Korea is considering scrapping a rule that denies subsidies for electric vehicles with high-capacity batteries, potentially opening the market to Tesla's long-range models. The move could benefit Tesla's upcoming Model 3, which ranks among the top six in terms of reservations in Korea. Tesla plans to enter the market in early 2017, but the Model S 90D, a high-priced electric car, would not qualify for a 20% subsidy. The change could help alleviate concerns about EV range.

site_title: Manhattan luxury co-ops fall out of favor as new condos beckon
summary: Luxury Manhattan co-ops are losing appeal as newly built high-end condos with more amenities and fewer restrictive rules gain popularity. Contracts for co-op apartments priced at $4 million or more fell 25% this year, the biggest annual decline since tracking began a decade ago. Buyers are opting for newer homes with more freedom and flexibility, rejecting the exclusivity and restrictive rules of co-ops, and instead seeking luxury condos with amenities like gyms and pet spas.

images.alt_text: The luxury Manhattan co-op, a longtime sign of real estate prestige and exclusivity in New York, may be losing its appeal. Blame a glut of newly built high-end condos.

site_title: China says corruption campaign has gained "crushing momentum"
summary: China's fight against corruption has gained "crushing momentum" with significant progress made, according to the ruling Communist Party. Since President Xi Jinping's assumption of office four years ago, dozens of senior officials have been jailed, including a former domestic security chief. The party aims to continue its crackdown on corruption, with a focus on "undesirable work styles" and a plan to reduce existing corruption in 2017. The campaign has improved public confidence, but critics argue China's lack of an independent anti-corruption body hinders its ability to tackle graft effectively.

site_title: Petronas said to eye new site in US$27b Canada LNG plan
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy company Petronas is moving forward with a proposed US$27 billion liquefied natural gas project in western Canada after identifying a new site for shipping the fuel. The project, which would produce 19.2 million metric tons of LNG per year, would remain on Lelu Island in British Columbia but the docking facilities would be relocated to Ridley Island. This change aims to reduce costs and address local opposition, eliminating the need for a costly suspension bridge and a marine area that has been a point of controversy.

site_title: Kate Spade exploring sale: WSJ
summary: Luxury handbag maker Kate Spade & Co is exploring a sale after activist investor Caerus Investors and Jana Partners LLC expressed interest in acquiring the company. The potential buyers include retailers, and the process is at an early stage. Kate Spade reported lower-than-expected quarterly sales and pricing competition may dampen earnings during the holiday shopping quarter. The company's shares rose 16% following the news, valuing the company at US$1.86 billion.

site_title: Toshiba's dispute with CB&I over nuclear engineering unit
summary: Toshiba and Chicago Bridge & Iron (CB&I) are in a dispute over a US$2.15 billion claim by Toshiba, stemming from the sale of CB&I's nuclear power plant construction unit to Toshiba's Westinghouse unit in 2015. The dispute centers on the calculation of the unit's net working capital, with CB&I claiming it is owed US$428 million and Toshiba claiming it owes US$2.15 billion. An independent auditor will resolve the accounting disagreements in 2017, following a court decision that dismissed CB&I's lawsuit against Westinghouse's interpretation of the liabilities.

site_title: Actress Debbie Reynolds rushed to hospital day after daughter dies: media
summary: Debbie Reynolds, 84, was rushed to a hospital on December 28, 2016, after suffering a possible stroke at her son's home in Beverly Hills, California, a day after the death of her daughter, actress Carrie Fisher, 60, who died from a heart attack. Reynolds was transported to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in fair to serious condition. Fisher's death followed a heart attack last Friday, and Reynolds had been in frail health in the past year, missing an honorary Oscar ceremony in 2015 due to surgery.

site_title: Former world number one Ivanovic retires at age 29
summary: Former world number one tennis player Ana Ivanovic, 29, announced her retirement due to a loss of physical form and injuries. Ivanovic, a French Open champion in 2008, cited her inability to compete at the highest level as the reason for her decision. She expressed gratitude to her fans and revealed plans to become an ambassador for sport and healthy life, as well as explore opportunities in business and fashion. Ivanovic's retirement marks the end of a successful career that included a few weeks at the top of the WTA tour rankings.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment unit's Korean film Master breaks even in 8 days
summary: Spackman Entertainment's Korean film Master breaks even within 8 days of its release on December 21, with 3.8 million ticket admissions and US$25.3 million in box office revenue. The film maintains its top position at the South Korean box office, capturing 40.98% of the market share. Master will be released in Singapore theatres around January 12, 2026.

site_title: US: Largest drop in two months as Wall Street rally loses steam
summary: US stocks fell in a broad decline on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 posting its largest daily decline since October 11, 2016. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.56% to 19,833.68, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.89% to 5,438.56. The decline was triggered by a sharp drop in home resales and rising interest rates, with the PHLX housing sector index falling 1.2% to its lowest level in three weeks.

site_title: South Korea slashes 2017 GDP forecast, makes plans to shore up consumption
summary: South Korea has lowered its 2017 GDP forecast to 2.6% due to weaker domestic demand and waning job growth. The government expects slower consumption and faster inflation, with 1.6% inflation predicted for 2017. To counter slowing growth, the government plans to frontload budget spending and increase policy financing through state-supported banks by 8 trillion won. Exports are forecast to expand 2.9% next year, while 260,000 jobs are expected to be added, down from 290,000 for this year.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 18.13 points, or 0.63%, to 2,880.17. DBS Bank and Singtel led the decline, shedding S$0.11 and S$0.03 respectively. Trading volumes were 63.1 million shares worth S$54.6 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 93 to 33.

site_title: New UN chief wants to meet Trump 'as soon as possible'
summary: Incoming UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres expressed his desire to meet with Donald Trump "as soon as possible" and establish a constructive dialogue with the new US administration. Guterres, who takes over on January 1, aims to address ongoing global issues, including the Syrian conflict, amidst uncertainty over the US role in the world under a Trump presidency. The former Portuguese prime minister hopes to achieve a similar outcome with Trump as he did with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

site_title: Update: Carrie Fisher's mother Debbie Reynolds dead at 84
summary: Debbie Reynolds, mother of late actress Carrie Fisher, died on Wednesday at 84 after suffering a stroke, just a day after Carrie's death from a heart attack. Reynolds was taken to hospital after collapsing at her Beverly Hills home. Todd Fisher, her son, said she wanted to be with Carrie. The 84-year-old had been distraught since Carrie's death on a transatlantic flight four days earlier.

site_title: Oil holds near annual peaks, awaiting Opec cuts, supply data
summary: Crude oil prices rose for a fourth consecutive session, nearing annual peaks, ahead of US oil inventory figures and Opec supply reductions. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 16 US cents higher at $54.06 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose 13 US cents to $56.22 a barrel. Analysts forecast crude stocks declined 2.1 million barrels in the week to Dec 23, and Opec producers are expected to lower production by almost 1.8 million barrels per day starting Jan 1.

site_title: Greece to give migrants IDs, cash: minister
summary: Greece plans to provide electronic ID cards and cash to thousands of refugees and migrants stuck on its soil by April, according to Migration Minister Yiannis Mouzalas. The move aims to register all registered refugees and migrants in camps, hotels, and flats, and provide their legal status. This initiative will help track the migrants' whereabouts in the country.

site_title: US dollar gains against sterling on Brexit worries, US growth bets
summary: The US dollar reached its highest level in two months against the sterling on December 28, 2016, due to concerns over Brexit negotiations and expectations of higher US economic growth. Sterling fell 0.5% to a session low of US$1.2201, while the US dollar index gained 4.7% for the year. The Federal Reserve's projections of three rate hikes in 2017 also contributed to the dollar's gains. Analysts attributed the dollar's strength to the upcoming Brexit talks and the potential for fiscal stimulus under President-elect Donald Trump's administration.

site_title: Hackers add new twist to insider trading problem facing M&A law firms
summary: Three Chinese citizens, Iat Hong, Bo Zheng, and Chin Hung, have been charged with hacking into and trading on confidential information from top New York merger-advising law firms, resulting in over $4 million in gains. The hackers targeted at least seven law firms, stealing emails and installing malware to obtain deal information. The US Attorney's office says this case should serve as a wake-up call for law firms worldwide, as they are increasingly vulnerable to cyberhacking due to their valuable client information.

site_title: Pokemon Go, Trump top Google trend list
summary: Google's 2016 global trends report reveals Pokemon Go as the most-searched item online, while Donald Trump was the most-searched person, ahead of Hillary Clinton and other notable figures. The US election and Olympic Games were among the top news items searched for. The iPhone 7 was the most-searched consumer technology item, while Deadpool and Suicide Squad were the most-searched movies. The report also highlights Prince's death as the most searched celebrity death in 2016.

images.alt_text: The past year was a big one for Donald Trump, but also for Pokemon Go.

site_title: Bridging technology and culture gap
summary: A cultural gap exists between the tech industry and institutions preserving culture, with tech companies often lacking a deep understanding of time frames and the importance of preserving historical artifacts. This disconnect can lead to avoidable disasters, as seen in the tech industry's initial missteps in VR development. To bridge this gap, cultural institutions must reach out and engage with the high-tech community, using their experience and knowledge to inform and educate tech companies. This dialogue is crucial, as tech companies' decisions have significant social and political consequences.

site_title: Mastercard to launch 'selfie' verification in Singapore in 2017
summary: Mastercard plans to launch a "selfie" verification function in Singapore in 2017, using facial recognition technology to ensure online transactions are genuine. The function, called Mastercard's Identity Check, will allow consumers to upload a selfie, which will be compared to facial identification to verify transactions. The technology aims to add an extra layer of protection against online fraud, which has increased globally, with Mastercard citing a gross fraud rate of 23.9 basis points for online payments.

images.alt_text: Mastercard expects to launch in 2017 its "selfie" function to verify online transactions in Singapore and parts of Asia, a top executive said.

site_title: US mutual fund trustees feel the heat of investor lawsuits
summary: US mutual fund trustees are facing increased scrutiny from investors, who are suing them for excessive fees and failing to act in shareholders' best interests. Trustees, often paid hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, are under pressure to prove they have stood up for shareholders in an industry with $16 trillion under management. Lawsuits accuse fund boards of missteps, including failing to scrutinize fees and pass along economies of scale to investors. Despite their influence, many fund families rarely appear before investors, and firings of fund managers are rare.

site_title: Tech advancements will drive business trends in 2017
summary: Tech advancements will significantly impact businesses in 2017, with companies forced to adapt to disruption from startups and new technologies. Large companies will increasingly turn to mergers and acquisitions with startups to obtain new technologies, customers, and business models. Contingent workers, including freelancers and independent contractors, will become more prevalent as the on-demand economy grows. Companies will need to prioritize social responsibility and sustainability to remain relevant, as millennials prioritize purpose and meaning over monetary gains.

site_title: After Asia, palm oil faces the backlash in Africa
summary: Palm oil plantations in Africa are facing backlash over deforestation and land acquisition, particularly in Gabon, Cameroon, and the Congo Basin. Environmental groups, including Brainforest and Mighty, have reported Olam International's deforestation of 20,000 hectares in Gabon and accused Socapalm of targeting old-growth forests. The companies claim palm oil requires less land and provides jobs, but opponents argue it accelerates deforestation and contributes to climate change. Greenpeace has called for the renewal of concessions to be halted, citing "six years of illegal foresting" and "unfulfilled investments".

site_title: Computer science gender gap is hurting US businesses
summary: The US faces a computing-skills crisis, with 500,000 open computing jobs and fewer than 40,000 new computer science graduates, of which only 7,000 are women. This gap is hindering American businesses and economic growth. Employers struggle to fill positions, and the solution lies in encouraging girls and young women to pursue computer science education. The US needs to address this issue to support its economic growth and competitiveness in the tech industry.

site_title: A slowing economy needs smarter, not more, regulations
summary: Asean countries are seeking closer economic integration, but overly restrictive regulations are hindering cooperation. Non-tariff measures (NTMs) have increased four-fold since 2000, imposing unnecessary costs on foreign suppliers. Examples include Indonesia's 17-day refrigeration requirement for imported fresh fruit and Thailand's mandatory Thai-language labelling for imported goods, which forces companies to redesign packaging. To avoid slowing down economic growth, Asean nations should adopt smarter, not more, regulations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks inch higher in thin trading as miners advance
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on thin trading, driven by gains in commodity producers, including Anglo American and BHP Billiton. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index briefly surpassed a record closing level, and analysts predict a 1.5% increase in the index by year-end. Miners have been the top performers in the Stoxx 600 this year, up 62%. The gains were offset by declines in defensive sectors, and about 17% of Stoxx 600 members are in overbought territory.

site_title: Burger King, Tim Hortons to curb antibiotics used in chicken
summary: Burger King and Tim Hortons, owned by Restaurant Brands International Inc, plan to switch to chicken raised without antibiotics considered "critically important" to human medicine. The change aims to reduce the overuse of such drugs contributing to life-threatening human infections from antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The move follows similar commitments from McDonald's and Wendy's, and is expected to be implemented in US stores in 2017 and in Canada in 2018. This change is in response to growing health concerns and an estimated 70% of antibiotics sold for meat and dairy production.

images.alt_text: Restaurant chains Burger King and Tim Hortons plan to switch to chicken raised without antibiotics considered "critically important" to human medicine, their owner said on Wednesday, making it the latest company to ditch the drugs over health concerns.

site_title: No Happy New Year in China as currency, liquidity fears loom
summary: China's markets are facing renewed pressure ahead of the Chinese New Year, with investors bracing for a potential rush to sell the yuan as a $50,000 quota to convert it into foreign exchange resets. The yuan has declined 6.6% in 2016, its worst year since 1994, and bond yields have surged, with the 10-year government bond yield increasing 21 basis points in December. Analysts predict that bond and money markets may stabilize after the Chinese New Year holidays, but expect the yuan to continue weakening and monetary policy to tighten.

site_title: Tourist arrivals spark Macau casino revival after downturn
summary: Macau's casino industry has seen a resurgence in tourist arrivals, driven by a surge in visitors from South Korea, Japan, and the US. This shift marks a departure from the past, where high-stakes Chinese gamblers dominated the market. Analysts predict a 7% increase in gambling revenue in 2017, led by mass market players. The growth is attributed to Macau's efforts to reinvent itself with tourist-friendly resorts, following a decline in VIP players due to China's crackdown on corruption.

site_title: AA Reit's redeveloped properties in Tuas valued at S$60.7m
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial REIT (AA Reit) has completed the redevelopment of two industrial buildings in Tuas, Singapore, increasing the property's value by more than four times to S$60.7 million. The redevelopment, valued at S$41.7 million, has nearly doubled the property's gross floor area to 288,663 sq ft. The entire property is pre-leased to CWT Limited, a logistics company, and is expected to deliver S$4.15 million in annual rental income, contributing to AA Reit's fiscal 2018 Q1 results.

site_title: Keppel Land selling 49.7% stake in Wuxi project for 619m yuan
summary: Keppel Land is selling 49.7% stake in Cityone Development (Wuxi) Co Ltd for 619m yuan (S$127m). The joint venture partner is also divesting its 30% stake in CDCL. The transaction is part of Keppel Land's strategy to recycle capital and maximize returns. The completion is expected by March 31, 2017, and is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Qualcomm suffers 1.03 trillion won blow from South Korea's antitrust agency
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator fined Qualcomm Inc a record 1.03 trillion won (S$1.1 billion) for violating antitrust laws, alleging the company coerced customers into signing patent license contracts and didn't fairly pay for the use of patents held by other phone makers. Qualcomm, which earns the majority of its profit from licensing fees, will appeal the decision. The ruling adds to investor concern about the chipmaker's lucrative licensing business, which is also under investigation in the US and Europe.

site_title: God and good luck guide commuters on rebel-hit Thai train
summary: Thai rebels have targeted a train cutting through the country's insurgency-ridden "Deep South" region, blowing it up three times this year. The train, which carries around 6,800 passengers daily, has become a symbol of the Thai state's authority in the area, where Malay-Muslim separatists have been waging a rebellion since 2004, killing nearly 7,000 people. Despite efforts to keep the trains running, security forces remain on high alert, and a new round of peace talks has been held in secret, but a lasting end to the conflict appears distant.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Gold prices rose for a third day, gaining 0.5% to $1,144.56 an ounce, as it emerges from a slump triggered by Donald Trump's win in November. The precious metal is on track for its longest run of gains since early November. Despite potential risks from the Trump presidency and the UK's Brexit talks, some banks, including Commerzbank AG, have flagged potential support for gold in 2017. Inflation concerns and a decline in global ETF holdings may also boost gold prices.

site_title: NTU to develop drone traffic management
summary: Researchers at Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore have launched a four-year program to develop a traffic management system for drones. The project aims to ensure safe usage of Singapore's airspace, with a focus on smart and safe routing, detect-and-avoid systems, and traffic management. The system will include designated air lanes, virtual geofencing, and open spaces for take-off and landings. The project is spearheaded by NTU's Air Traffic Management Research Institute and is expected to address the growing demand for commercial drone services, which is expected to increase significantly over the next decade.

images.alt_text: To regulate UAV traffic, one solution is establishing coordinating stations, which would be able to track UAVs in the air, schedule traffic flow, monitor speed and ensure a safe distance between UAVs.

site_title: LQS Construction sues Mencast and subsidiary for S$3.3m
summary: Singapore construction firm LQS Construction is suing offshore services provider Mencast Holdings and its subsidiary MMPL for S$3.3 million over a contract for an office building. Mencast claims the suit has no merit and is reviewing the claim. The dispute arises from a contract for the construction of an office building at Penjuru Road, where LQS Construction is the main contractor and MMPL is the employer. Mencast is seeking to dispose of an underutilized industrial property to improve cash flow.

site_title: Prices of completed condos dip 0.7% in November: NUS
summary: Singapore's completed private apartments and condominiums experienced a 0.7% price drop in November, according to a National University of Singapore (NUS) flash estimate. Completed units in the Central Region fell 0.8%, while those outside the region dropped 0.7%. Small units (506 sq ft or below) resumed their price fall, slipping 0.1%. Experts attribute the decline to a slowdown in transactions during the year-end festive period, with cautious buying sentiments prevailing.

site_title: Bond buyers left bemoaning 13% returns after oil's wild year
summary: Bond investors experienced a disappointing year, with many failing to meet benchmarks due to missing out on beaten-down energy and mining company bonds. Despite major US junk-bond indexes rising 16.9-17% and median high-yield funds returning 13.4%, investors are left with 13% returns, indicating a lack of opportunities in the market. This year's performance was largely driven by commodities, with investors who took a chance on energy and mining company bonds at the February bottom being the top performers.

site_title: ASC reminds firms to prepare for new accounting standards
summary: The Accounting Standards Council (ASC) of Singapore has reminded companies to prepare for new Financial Reporting Standards (FRS) taking effect from 2018 and 2019, affecting various industries and requiring in-depth analysis. FRS 109 Financial Instruments, FRS 115 Revenue from Contracts with Customers, and FRS 116 Leases will impact companies across industries, including airline, retail, and energy sectors, with potential implications on financial reporting, risk management, and regulatory requirements. Companies must undertake a thorough analysis to determine the full implications of these standards.

site_title: Planned Hong Kong museum to showcase China's imperial relics
summary: Hong Kong officials have announced plans to build a museum, the Hong Kong Palace Museum, to display China's imperial relics from Beijing's Palace Museum, home to China's most treasured artifacts. The $451 million museum, scheduled for completion in 2022, will be part of the West Kowloon Cultural District and will feature two exhibition galleries, a lecture theatre, and a gift shop. The project has raised concerns among critics about Beijing's influence in Hong Kong, but officials say it is part of larger celebrations to mark the 20th anniversary of Hong Kong's transfer to China in 1997.

site_title: Tietmeyer, former Bundesbank president, dies aged 85
summary: Former Bundesbank president Hans Tietmeyer, a key architect of the single currency, has died at 85. A staunch advocate for monetary stability, Tietmeyer served as president from 1993 to 1999 and was a fierce supporter of independent monetary policymaking. He played a crucial role in designing the Stability and Growth Pact and contributed to the development of the euro, but his caution and opposition to some aspects of the currency project led to criticism from former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. Tietmeyer's legacy is marked by his unwavering commitment to European integration and monetary stability.

site_title: Record run for corporate bond sales likely to come to a halt in 2017
summary: US corporate bond sales, which reached a record $1.35 trillion in 2016, are expected to slow down in 2017 due to rising interest rates, smaller pipeline for new acquisitions, and uncertainty around tax reform and trade wars. Experts predict a 10-20% drop in new bond sales, still leaving gross volumes above $1 trillion. Despite this, investors remain active, and potential blockbusters like Bayer's takeover of Monsanto and AT&T's bid to buy Time Warner are expected to drive demand.

site_title: Tenants fight back with PIs staking out Airbnb units
summary: Tenants in San Francisco are using private investigators to track down landlords who are violating city ordinances by renting out their homes on Airbnb for short-term stays. The goal is to gather evidence to prove the landlords are evicting tenants to make way for lucrative short-term rentals. Despite Airbnb's efforts to limit the use of private homes for short-term rentals, the city's shortage of affordable housing persists. The company has taken steps to address the issue, but critics argue that more needs to be done to protect tenants and ensure that housing units are available for long-term residents.

site_title: YCH to build DistriPark in Nantong
summary: YCH Group has signed a memorandum of understanding with CPC Nantong Northern New Town Management Committee to develop a DistriPark in Nantong, Jiangsu province, China. The new hub aims to support urban logistics development, boost connectivity under the "One Belt, One Road" initiative, and enhance YCH's expansion in China's coastal and inland cities. The project will fill development gaps and intensify logistics growth in Nantong, a key port city. The development cost was not disclosed.

site_title: Debt restructuring can be hurdle to O&M recovery
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) sector is struggling with debt restructuring due to a multi-year downturn. Industry players face challenges in restructuring their balance sheets, with some stakeholders unable to agree on haircuts. Proposed legislative updates to the law, targeting to be tabled in Parliament in early 2017, aim to facilitate debt restructuring and rehabilitation of businesses through schemes of arrangements. The updates include extended rescue finance provisions and cram-down provisions, allowing companies to continue operating without having to seek creditor protection. This could provide breathing space for the sector, but analysts warn that a sectoral recovery may take years.

site_title: Sterling hits two-month low as dollar gains
summary: The dollar strengthened against the euro and sterling, reaching a two-month low for sterling, due to expectations of US inflation and growth outpacing the rest of the developed world. The dollar rose 0.6% against the euro and 0.3% against the yen, while sterling fell as much as half a cent to US$1.2222. Analysts attribute the dollar's gains to a potential for further appreciation and concerns over the UK's large current account deficit and potential impact on the pound.

site_title: Britons hoard cash as economic uncertainties prompt caution
summary: Britons are holding onto their cash amid economic uncertainties, with personal deposits growing 4.8% in November and £32.4 billion in the first 11 months of 2016, outpacing 2015's £19.8 billion growth. This cautious approach suggests Britons may be preparing for potential economic downturns.

site_title: Flight booking systems lack basic privacy safeguards, say researchers
summary: Researchers at Security Research Labs have found that major flight booking systems lack basic privacy safeguards, making it easy to hack into travel records and steal personal data. The systems use six-digit codes, known as PNRs, that can be easily guessed by hackers, allowing them to alter flight details or steal sensitive information. The researchers call for airlines to adopt modern safeguards against brute force attacks and offer passengers a changeable password. The lack of security measures has been described by travel privacy campaigner Edward Hasbrouck as a major vulnerability, and experts warn that travelers' data may never be secured.

site_title: HK's IPO destiny: Big guns but no bright lights
summary: Hong Kong's status as the world's No 1 venue for share sales may not change despite being considered for Saudi oil giant Aramco's IPO. Limited tech deals and mostly staid Chinese state-owned enterprises will contribute to a lack of excitement. The city's strict regulations, such as requiring a three-year track record for companies below a certain size, also hinder its appeal to new economy stocks. Chinese state firms will continue to list in Hong Kong, but these deals are often packed with cornerstone investors, reducing liquidity.

site_title: Without Obama, Abe's approach to US-Japan ties may be tested
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's approach to Japan-US ties may be tested, particularly with the Trans-Pacific Partnership deal in tatters and North Korea on the verge of a nuclear breakthrough. Despite this, Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is seeking to maintain a strong partnership with the US, which has been a cornerstone of Japan's security. Abe has committed to several policies favored by the Obama administration, including expanding US military bases and participating in combat missions. However, Trump's aggressive stance towards China and potential use of force may pose a risk to Japan, with analysts warning that a more confrontational US-China relationship could have unpredictable results in the region.

site_title: Retail property outlook 2017
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Retail property outlook for 2017 is expected to be influenced by various factors. US mortgage rates have begun to rise after five weeks of decline, potentially affecting demand for Singapore's prime projects. The Q3 condo launch wave may test demand for projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have hit a record high, with more increases anticipated. Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won worth of hotel and retail assets in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, according to index data. These developments signal a mixed outlook for the retail property market in 2017.

site_title: China official urges cut to required reserve ratio
summary: China's banking regulator, Yu Xuejun, has urged a reduction in the required reserve ratio (RRR) to "an appropriate time," citing its "very high" level at 17%. This could allow banks to lend more, boosting credit expansion and potentially reducing downward pressure on the yuan. However, a cut is unlikely in 2017 due to the PBOC's neutral monetary policy stance and concerns about capital outflows and yuan depreciation. The RRR is expected to decrease to 16.5% in Q4 2017 and 16% in Q1 2018.

site_title: Slowdown in price growth of UK property in 2017
summary: The UK housing market is expected to experience a slowdown in price growth in 2017 due to economic weakness and inflation, according to Halifax. Housing demand is forecast to ease, partly due to tax changes and stricter underwriting standards. London is expected to see a sharper slowdown than other areas, with luxury home prices declining by 10% this year. Halifax predicts a 1-4% rise in UK property values by the end of 2017, down from a 7% increase in October.

site_title: Turning data into decisions
summary: In the digital age, companies face a data crisis with one in four experiencing it, hindering decision-making. The challenges include volume, velocity, and clarity, requiring strategic management of data as a process. Organisations must build a data platform, adopting a five-step process: collation, cleaning, governance, analysis, and presentation. With data management evolving like consumer technology, companies must invest in becoming data-driven to stay competitive, and accessibility must be managed with privacy as a key pillar.

site_title: Author of Watership Down dies at 96
summary: British novelist Richard Adams, best known for his novel "Watership Down," has died at 96. Born in 1920, Adams began writing his classic tale of rabbits' adventures in a pastoral realm after his daughters urged him to do so. Initially rejected by literary agents, the book became a timeless allegory of freedom, ethics, and human nature, winning numerous awards, including the Carnegie Medal and the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize. It went on to become one of the best-selling novels of the 20th century, with an estimated 50 million copies in print worldwide.

site_title: Budget airline boss has tricks to take off in costly Argentina
summary: Budget airline CEO Julian Cook is launching Flybondi in Argentina, aiming to offer low-cost fares and compete with state-owned Aerolineas Argentinas and Latam Airlines. Cook believes the government will deregulate the industry, allowing him to set prices at US$10. If not, he plans to use creative strategies, such as a members-only club or free hotel rooms, to circumvent restrictions. Cook expects to operate 12 domestic routes by September and 40 within five years, with plans for international flights to Chile, Uruguay, and Brazil by 2018.

site_title: Toshiba shares tumble on problems with US nuclear projects
summary: Toshiba shares plummeted 20% to 311.6 yen after the company revealed it may need to write down billions related to its US nuclear projects. The projects, overseen by utilities Southern Co and Scana Corp, are years behind schedule and billions over budget. Toshiba's US unit Westinghouse Electric acquired contractor CB&I Stone & Webster Inc, leading to costly delays and disputes. The company's bond insurance costs jumped 225 basis points, putting them on track for a record increase. Toshiba's nuclear business executive officer attributed the miscalculation to underestimated local labor and material costs.

site_title: Chinese mall owner seeks to raise 586.4m yuan in Singapore IPO
summary: Dasin Retail Trust, a business trust holding three shopping malls in China's Guangdong province, is seeking to raise 586.4 million yuan (S$122.2 million) through an initial public offering on the Singapore Exchange. The trust's initial portfolio has a total value of about 4.6 billion yuan and includes three malls in Zhongshan city. The trust plans to acquire a fourth mall and has a pipeline of 14 properties. Ocean Metro Mall and Dasin E-Colour require income support, with major unitholders waiving distribution entitlements for the first few years.

site_title: Denver's gritty back door could become its new gateway
summary: Developers plan to create a $200 million international business campus in Denver's River North Art District (RiNo), a formerly neglected industrial area. The project, backed by World Trade Center Denver, will include offices, a hotel, conference space, and shops and restaurants. RiNo's growing corporate roster, affordability, and outdoor culture make it an attractive location for global commerce. The project aims to capitalize on Denver's diverse economy, which has diversified away from boom-and-bust industries, and its growing non-stop flights to international destinations. The development is expected to bring new life to the area, but also raises concerns about gentrification.

site_title: Lockers hold key to helping Lisbon's homeless
summary: Lisbon's homeless population has found a solution to store their belongings in 12 bright yellow lockers outside the Santa Apolonia rail station. The lockers, previously used for storing items in the hilly streets, provide a safe and secure space for the homeless to keep their belongings, reducing the need to drag them around in boxes or bags. This initiative may help improve the living conditions of the homeless in the city.

images.alt_text: The "solidarity lockers" are set up by the small charity ACA to make life easier for the city's homeless, like Mr Miguel using his locker near Lisbon's Santa Apolonia station, and help them get back on track.

site_title: Rising global economic tide may not lift Singapore's boat
summary: Singapore's economy may not benefit from a global recovery in 2017, despite forecasted 2.8% global growth. Structural changes, including the US's reduced imports and China's shift to a consumer-led economy, may disrupt global value chains and hinder Singapore's export-oriented business model. Economists predict a median forecast of 1.5% growth for Singapore, with some as low as 0.7%. Domestic issues, such as a mismatched labor market and high levels of indebtedness, also pose concerns. The government's optimism about 2017's growth may be tempered by these structural challenges.

images.alt_text: The global outlook is forecast to improve in the coming year but Singapore may not be riding that wave.

summary: Singapore has set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, while the country's economy is expected to continue growing. Graduates are advised to stay calm as early data shows better employment rates. Deputy Prime Minister Gan will visit the US for trade talks, with a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses hit by tariffs. A study suggests Singapore can become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Additionally, the government is offering support for workers who need training, citing the need for them to future-proof their careers.

site_title: Keen to invest in India? Consider Jharkhand state, says its chief minister
summary: Jharkhand, India's most mineral-rich state, is being promoted by its chief minister Raghubar Das as a strategic investment destination. With a population of 33 million and significant reserves of minerals, Jharkhand has potential for growth in industries such as IT, electronics, manufacturing, and infrastructure. The state has improved air and road connectivity, and its largest city Jamshedpur is home to Tata Steel. Das aims to host a global investment summit in Ranchi in 2023, following a business-friendly policy framework and corruption-free government.

images.alt_text: Supporting the demonetisation in India, Mr Das says it will "totally" check tax evasion, strengthen the economy and achieve transparency

site_title: US Oil Fund fails to cash in on 2016 crude rally
summary: The US Oil Fund LP, a popular oil-tracking ETF, failed to capitalize on the 45% gain in West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures in 2016 due to a pricing structure known as contango. The fund's 6.6% growth was significantly lower than the market's due to the cost of rolling over front-month contracts. Experts attribute the underperformance to the contango market, which has negatively impacted oil investors' returns. However, Citigroup researchers predict that the futures curves should flatten in 2017, improving roll yields and potentially benefiting the US Oil Fund.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A STEP-DOWN subsidiary of Swissco Holdings, Liftboat 1 International, has received a notice of appointment of receivers over its vessel Jinshan 1. KLW Holdings sold its Melbourne property for A$34.2 million, netting a gain of about A$5.63 million. Polaris Limited recovered a loan from multimedia devices maker XMI after selling its 30% stake. China Jishan Holdings' unit sold Shao Xing Yue Sheng Real Estate Property Development for 785.78 million yuan.

site_title: How JPMorgan could not save Italy's 'problem child' bank
summary: Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Italy's third-largest lender, failed to secure a privately-funded bailout, marking a significant setback for the government's efforts to address the country's banking crisis. The bank had pinned its fate on a plan engineered by JPMorgan, which aimed to clear out 28 billion euros in bad debts and raise five billion euros in equity. However, investors showed little interest, and the plan ultimately collapsed. The failure underscores the government's mismanagement of the banking crisis, which has led to a massive buildup of bad loans among Italian banks.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan's plan ended in failure in the early hours of Friday when the Tuscan lender said it could not find enough investors and asked the government to bail it out.

site_title: Changi passenger traffic up 5.7% in first 11 months
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore reported a 5.7% increase in passenger traffic to 53 million in the first 11 months of 2016, driven by growth in air travel to and from South-east Asia, North-east Asia, and South Asia. Cargo shipments also rose 6.1% to 1.79 million tonnes. The airport's new Terminal 4, set to open in the second half of 2017, is expected to boost capacity by 16 million annually.

site_title: Magnitude 6.3 quake hits Japan, no tsunami warning
summary: A magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck eastern Japan on December 28, 2016, but no tsunami warning was issued. There were no immediate reports of damages or injuries.

site_title: HPH Trust buys stake in Huizhou container terminals from sponsor
summary: HPH Trust has agreed to buy a 41.3% stake in Huizhou International Container Terminals Limited from its sponsor Hutchison Port Holdings for approximately US$86.26 million. The deal will be completed through two subsidiaries, Yantian International Container Terminals and Shenzhen Pingyan Multimodal Company Limited. The acquisition is expected to attract more intra-Asia cargoes due to the terminal's strategic position. The trust manager will receive an acquisition fee of 0.5% of the enterprise value of its effective interest in HICT.

site_title: BP to buy Australian petrol station network for US$1.3b
summary: BP has agreed to buy a network of Australian petrol stations from Woolworths for US$1.3 billion, establishing a strategic partnership to rebrand and operate 527 existing fuel and convenience stores, plus 16 under construction. This deal follows BP's existing 350 retail locations across Australia, where it supplies fuel to 1,000 independent outlets. The partnership aims to develop high-quality, differentiated fuel and convenience offers as part of BP's strategy.

site_title: New Year feasts bring cold comfort for China's pig farmers
summary: China's pig farmers face bleak prospects ahead of the Chinese New Year, with a slump in retail prices and rising feed costs eroding profits. Despite historically high profit margins, the industry is struggling due to a domestic supply shortage and a shift towards cheaper alternatives. The average profit margin for pig farmers is expected to fall to 300-400 yuan per pig, down from earlier this year. The industry's reliance on imports and increased feed costs will continue to put pressure on prices, making next year a challenging year for farmers.

site_title: China upset at name change of de facto Japan embassy in Taiwan
summary: China expressed dissatisfaction after Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan, the Interchange Association, announced it would change its name to the Japan-Taiwan Exchange Association starting January 1. China considers Taiwan a breakaway province and opposes any attempts to create "one China, one Taiwan". The move is seen as a negative development in China-Japan ties, with China urging Japan to uphold the "one China" principle and not send a wrong message to Taiwan and the international community. China's dissatisfaction is also seen as a response to Japan's historical rule in Taiwan, which is viewed positively by some.

site_title: Bleak exports haunt South-east Asian nations bracing for Trump
summary: South-east Asian nations face a bleak outlook for their exports due to global growth under pressure and the US threat to turn more protectionist under Donald Trump. Countries with growing consumer populations, such as the Philippines and Vietnam, are expected to fare better. The Philippines is anticipated to post the strongest growth, while Vietnam's low-cost production and foreign direct investment from China may help drive output. In contrast, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand are vulnerable to US protectionism and face economic challenges, with Malaysia's economic growth easing and Thailand's trade with the US highly exposed to global turmoil.

site_title: The secret feminist history of shopping
summary: The rise of shopping malls in the 19th century played a significant role in women's liberation, allowing them to assert their economic importance and occupy urban space. Initially met with criticism, shopping became a social activity and a means for women to move freely in cities, paving the way for the women's suffrage movement. The concept of shopping as a leisure activity, rather than just a means of purchasing goods, was a radical shift, giving women a foothold in modern city life. As technology advances, the notion of shopping as a social activity is becoming increasingly obsolete, with malls struggling to compete with online shopping.

site_title: China may formalise cybersecurity review on tech products
summary: China's Internet regulator plans to formalize a cybersecurity review system on tech products, potentially creating a new hurdle for foreign tech firms. The system, similar to existing reviews, would scrutinize products' encryption and data storage. This move follows a tough year for US tech companies in China, including Uber and Microsoft. The review process would be run by a committee with ties to China's military and security agencies, raising concerns about the government's intentions and the potential for a new standoff with the US. The formalization is part of broader efforts to enhance internet controls in China.

site_title: Jump in number of users at fact-checking website Snopes during US election
summary: Snopes, a fact-checking website, saw a significant jump in users during the 2016 US presidential election, peaking at nearly 2.5 million unique users. The site, which was initially dedicated to debunking urban legends, increased its staff by a dozen to address the growing need for fact-checking. Despite initial hopes that the election would calm down misinformation, the role of fake news and social media in the election's outcome reached a fever pitch. Facebook subsequently partnered with Snopes to send questionable links to fact-checking sites and mark dubious stories with a "disputed" designation.

site_title: Trump shatters peace with Obama with tweet on 'roadblocks'
summary: Donald Trump accused President Barack Obama of hindering the transition to the Republican administration with "inflammatory" statements and "roadblocks" in a tweet on December 28, 2016, just a month before Inauguration Day. The tweet came amid growing tensions between the two men, including Obama's decision to abstain from a UN Security Council resolution on Israeli settlements. Trump has since vowed to be friendlier to Israel, and his relations with Obama appear to have broken down.

site_title: Star Wars' Princess Leia dies at 60
summary: Carrie Fisher, the American actress and screenwriter best known for her role as Princess Leia in the Star Wars franchise, died at 60 due to a massive heart attack. Fisher, who suffered from numerous addictions, found success in writing and turned her struggles into bestselling works. She was a member of Hollywood royalty and left a lasting impact on the entertainment industry. Fisher's passing was announced on December 28, 2016.

site_title: Beijing prepares to dissolve ancient grip on salt market
summary: Beijing is set to dissolve its centuries-old monopoly on the salt market, allowing almost 80 salt producers and traders from across China to sell their wares in the capital starting January 1. The move is part of the government's efforts to liberalize state-owned industries and encourage consolidation and private investment. The China National Salt Industry Corp, which dominates the market, will be subject to price controls and monitoring to ensure price stability and availability of stocks. The change aims to dismantle the state-owned company's control over the edible salt market.

site_title: Stocks rise again on oil price rally
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, marking a second consecutive session of gains, driven by a crude oil recovery and a rally in Wall Street. The Straits Times Index advanced 12.54 points to 2,898.3, leaving it 0.54% up for the year. Gainers outnumbered losers 258 to 149, with oil services sector stocks like Ezion and Noble Group among the top performers. However, analysts warned that business-wise, 2017 may still not be an easy year, citing concerns over asset oversupply and potential credit issues.

site_title: Vietnam suffers first slowdown in growth since 2012
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded 6.21% in 2016, the first slowdown since 2012, with a fourth-quarter surge to 6.68%. The slowdown was attributed to adverse weather, marine environmental disasters, and a global economic downturn. Despite this, Vietnam remains one of Asia's fastest-growing economies, with solid growth in manufacturing, construction, and services. The country's trade surplus widened to $2.68 billion, and foreign direct investment reached a record $15.8 billion. Experts predict a slight improvement in growth next year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is the world's second-largest coffee producer after Brazil and ranks third behind India and Thailand in rice exports. Other key foreign exchange earners include mobile phones, textiles, footwear, fish and shrimp.

site_title: Water scarcity a key factor to regional security in India
summary: India's water scarcity is a significant regional security concern, exacerbated by population growth, urbanization, and industrialization. The country's water management practices have been inadequate, leading to conflicts over water allocations in interstate rivers. These conflicts have resulted in protests, violence, and property destruction, posing a challenge to India's future economic growth and social cohesion. The existing tribunal system for resolving water disputes has been ineffective, with non-binding results and a lack of political will to address the issue. Climate change and the potential creation of new states will further complicate water management in India.

site_title: India's generic-drug trials under scrutiny
summary: India's generic drug trials industry is under scrutiny due to serial testing of volunteers with short gaps, potentially endangering patient health and compromising clinical data. Volunteers, including those in HIV/AIDS trials, participated in back-to-back trials with gaps of only a few weeks or days, instead of the recommended 90 days. This practice has raised concerns among international medical specialists and regulators, including the WHO and India's Central Drugs Standard Control Organization. The lack of oversight and unclear guidelines have led to data manipulation and violations, with several CROs facing international regulatory scrutiny and bans.

site_title: Exxon Mobil announces new gas discovery in Papua New Guinea
summary: Exxon Mobil announced a new natural gas discovery in Papua New Guinea, confirming the presence of hydrocarbons in the same high-quality sandstone reservoirs as the Hides field. The discovery was made in the Muruk-1 exploration well, which has a 42.5% stake held by ExxonMobil. The project is part of the PNG LNG Project, a 6.9 million tonne per annum integrated LNG project operated by ExxonMobil PNG.

site_title: Putin may have done Americans a big favour on cybersecurity
summary: US cybersecurity is being alerted to the true threat of cyberwarfare by Vladimir Putin's actions, potentially prompting effective countermeasures. Despite high-profile hacking incidents, Americans view cyberattacks as mostly "annoyances" due to lack of severe consequences. However, cyberattacks pose a significant threat to society's economic and political foundations, with the potential to endanger physical safety and security. Experts recommend steps such as moving vital data networks offline, imposing security standards on the Internet of things, and streamlining agencies overseeing cyberspace to protect against this growing threat.

site_title: VW buys mobile-payment provider PayByPhone for parking services
summary: Volkswagen AG acquired North American parking-payment operator PayByPhone for its parking services, expanding the automaker's mobility services division. The purchase, valued at an undisclosed amount, will make Volkswagen Financial Services the leader in mobile payments for parking. This acquisition is part of Volkswagen's response to industry developments and follows its recent establishment of a ride-hailing and car-sharing division named Moia. The move aims to generate billions of euros in revenue and is part of CEO Matthias Mueller's strategy to diversify the company beyond manufacturing.

site_title: Commuters on Maryland trains may soon be hauling bikes
summary: The Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) plans to install bike racks on all 3 Marc lines' trains by the end of 2017, offering a first and last-mile solution to commuters and an alternative transportation option as more people in the Baltimore and Washington regions embrace cycling. The MTA aims to provide a seamless transportation option for daily commuters, similar to the bike-car service introduced on the Penn Line's weekend service in 2014, which has seen high demand.

site_title: Quoting Mao, China says Taiwan, HK independence supporters will fail 'like flies'
summary: China's government has stated that efforts by Hong Kong and Taiwan independence supporters are doomed to fail, citing a Mao Zedong poem that likens them to flies being dashed to the ground. The comments come amid growing concerns over a fledgling independence movement in Hong Kong, where recent protests have raised tensions with Beijing. The statement reflects China's increasing assertiveness in response to the city's autonomy issues and its efforts to maintain control over the territory.

site_title: Clean tech rises again, retooling nature for industrial use
summary: A decade ago, a group of biologists, venture capitalists, and computer whizzes formed "clean tech" to reprogram nature's genetic code to produce industrial chemicals. However, the idea lost billions of dollars due to the complexity of nature's genetic code. Despite this setback, clean tech continues to evolve, with new applications and innovations emerging.

site_title: May's Brexit approach slammed by leader of civil-service union
summary: Theresa May's Brexit approach is being criticized by the leader of the UK civil-service union, who says the government lacks "political courage" to acknowledge the complexity of leaving the EU. Dave Penman, FDA General Secretary, stated that ministries are stretched due to cuts and a domestic agenda, and the civil service needs more resources or to change priorities to handle Brexit. A report by the Institute for Government found the civil service is short of money, staff, and information to deal with the task.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as Mastercard sees solid holiday sales
summary: US stocks remained flat on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average edging higher and the Nasdaq Composite Index retreating slightly from its record close. A MasterCard report showed solid holiday retail sales, with 7.9% growth excluding auto and gas sales. Analysts attributed low trading volume to a traditionally quiet period between Christmas and the New Year. The S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and Qualcomm fell 0.8% after being fined by South Korea's anti-trust watchdog.

site_title: Shanghai banks told to lend more to riskier small firms
summary: Shanghai's banking regulator has instructed domestic commercial banks to increase lending to small firms and tolerate higher bad loan rates. The move aims to boost economic growth, as non-performing loans have risen to nearly 2%, the highest since the 2009 global financial crisis. The Shanghai branch of the China Banking Regulatory Commission has issued a notice to implement policies on renewing loans for small firms, a move seen as an effort to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Oil trades near 17-month high before planned Opec supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose near a 17-month high amid optimism that Opec and 11 other producing nations will cut output as promised, helping to eliminate a global supply glut. Futures rose 0.7% in New York, advancing for an eighth day in the longest winning streak in almost seven years. Crude inventories are expected to return to equilibrium and prices to stabilize as supply cuts take effect, according to Venezuelan Oil Minister Eulogio Del Pino.

site_title: Turkey, Russia agree on Syria truce plan
summary: Turkey and Russia have agreed on a cease-fire plan in Syria, excluding terrorist groups such as Islamic State and US-backed Kurdish forces. The plan, set to take effect on Thursday, aims to facilitate upcoming talks between rebels and the Syrian government in Astana, Kazakhstan. The agreement brings Russia, Turkey, and Iran together, with Turkey giving up its aspirations of regime change in Syria. US cooperation is seen as crucial to the plan's success, amid mounting tension between Turkey and the US over backing of Kurdish forces.

site_title: US denies Erdogan accusations of 'supporting IS'
summary: The US embassy in Ankara denied accusations by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan that the US supports the Islamic State (IS) in Syria, calling the claims "not true." The embassy stated that the US did not create or support IS, and that assertions of US backing for the group are false. Erdogan had claimed US-led coalition forces supported both IS and the Kurdish Peoples' Protection Units (YPG) in Syria, but the embassy disputed these claims, saying the US only works with the YPG to defeat IS, and not to support it.

site_title: Hans Tietmeyer, former Bundesbank president, dies at age 85
summary: Former Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer, a key architect of the European single currency, has died at age 85. Tietmeyer, who served as Bundesbank president from 1993 to 1999, was a strong advocate for price stability and independent monetary policy. He played a crucial role in shaping the Stability and Growth Pact, which remains the basis for Europe's common currency. Tietmeyer's legacy is marked by his unwavering commitment to European integration and his willingness to take tough decisions, including raising interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: British banks approve fewer mortgages in November
summary: British banks approved 40,659 mortgages in November, a 9% decline from the same period last year. This follows a five-month high in October. Consumer credit, however, continued to expand strongly, with credit card lending increasing by £231 million. The British Bankers' Association attributes this to consumers growing their cash reserves in anticipation of potential economic uncertainties.

site_title: Indonesian consortium to invest in affiliate of insurer Bumiputera
summary: A consortium led by Inter Milan president Erick Thohir is investing 2 trillion rupiah (S$215.79 million) in an affiliate of struggling Indonesian life insurance firm Bumiputera. The move aims to shore up the century-old insurer without taxpayer money. Bumiputera will continue serving existing policyholders, while the new affiliate will sell new insurance products. This strategic investment is part of Indonesian authorities' efforts to stabilize the insurer.

site_title: India's digital payment journey turbocharged by currency ban
summary: India's massive currency swap ban, implemented on November 8, 2016, is expected to end on December 31 and will be followed by a digitization of the country's cash-based economy. The ban on high-value notes of 500 and 1,000-rupee denominations, which accounted for 86% of the currency in circulation, aimed to reduce black money and accelerate digital payments. With India's GDP having tripled since 2004, the use of cash has also gone up exponentially, making digitization crucial for the country's economic growth.

site_title: Companies ambivalent about govt's transformation push
summary: A recent Singapore Business Federation survey found that companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), are ambivalent or strongly disagree with the government's push to transform the economy in response to slower growth and technological changes. Instead, they prioritize short-term concerns, such as survival and cost reduction. Only 62% of firms agree that they must transform to adapt, with SMEs and large companies showing limited buy-in. The survey highlights a disconnect between firms' concerns and the government's long-term view, prompting calls for more support and measures to help businesses adapt.

site_title: China Jishan to sell real estate unit for 786 million yuan
summary: China Jishan Holdings agreed to sell a real estate unit, Zhejiang Jishan Printing and Dyeing, to Shanghai Jintumu Real Estate for 785.78 million yuan, aiming to sell "under-utilised assets for cost savings". The unit, Shao Xing Yue Sheng Real Estate Property Development, holds seven land use rights but has not started property development or management. China Jishan will receive 402.14 million yuan from Shanghai Jintumu, which will then take on the debt.

images.alt_text: TEXTILE dyer China Jishan Holdings has agreed to sell a real estate unit to a Shanghai-based real estate developer for 785.78 million yuan (S$164.1 million), it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Wednesday.

site_title: French police arrest man suspected of planning New Year's eve attack
summary: French police have arrested a man suspected of planning a New Year's Eve attack in southwest France. The suspect, known to police, was taken into custody in Cugnaux, west of Toulouse, on Tuesday. Two other people, including one suspected of planning an attack on police, were also arrested in a separate case. The arrests follow a surge in security measures in France, Britain, and Germany after a Christmas market attack in Berlin earlier this month. Police have increased presence at tourist spots and densely populated areas to prevent potential attacks.

images.alt_text: [PARIS] Police in south west France have arrested a man suspected of having planned an attack on New Year's eve, a police source said on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong's ousted anti-China lawmakers make final appeal over ban
summary: Two Hong Kong lawmakers, Yau Wai Ching and Baggio Leung, announced a final appeal to overturn a Beijing-linked ban preventing them from taking their seats in parliament. The pair, who were elected in September, deliberately misread their oaths of office during the swearing-in ceremony, prompting a rare interference by Chinese authorities. They filed appeal documents with the city's Court of Final Appeal, hoping to set a precedent for future elections. The pair are still struggling to raise funds for the case, which has implications for Hong Kong's constitutional environment and the legitimacy of Legislative Council elections.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 10 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 10.62 points to 1,630.30. The trading volume reached 1.41 billion lots, valued at RM1.44 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 416 to 287, indicating a positive trend in the market.

site_title: KLW Holdings sells Melbourne property for A$34.2 million
summary: KLW Holdings sold its Melbourne property at 301 Flinders Lane for A$34.2 million, the highest of 13 bids. The property, leased to Victoria University, generated marginal rental income, and its market value was estimated at A$25.6 million. The sale resulted in a net gain of A$5.63 million, improving the group's cash flow. The sale will allow KLW to pursue other investment opportunities.

site_title: NauticAWT disposes of loss-making Papua New Guinea unit
summary: NauticAWT has sold off a loss-making Papua New Guinea subsidiary, AWT International (PNG), for a negligible RM1 (S$0.32). The unit had net liabilities of S$1.1 million and a net loss of S$66,000 as of November 30. The sale is part of the group's internal restructuring and aligns with its decision to cease operations in Papua New Guinea.

site_title: Myanmar men may face jail for not marrying pregnant women
summary: Myanmar's government is drafting a law that could jail men up to seven years for getting a woman pregnant but not marrying her. The law aims to strengthen women's rights and criminalize domestic violence for the first time. If passed, it would also make gang-rape a capital offence and impose penalties of up to five or seven years in prison for refusing to marry a pregnant woman. The law is part of efforts to combat violence against women in a socially conservative country where gender stereotypes are deeply entrenched.

site_title: Alibaba entertainment affiliate to invest over 50b yuan over next 3 years
summary: Alibaba Digital Media and Entertainment Group, the entertainment affiliate of Alibaba Group, plans to invest over 50 billion yuan (S$10.427 billion) in content and other projects over the next three years. The new CEO, Yu Yongfu, aims to consolidate the company's media assets and invest in new content, following a major reorganisation in October. The investment figure may include a previously disclosed 10 billion yuan fund for new projects. Details on the investments remain unclear.

images.alt_text: [BEIJING] Alibaba Digital Media and Entertainment Group, the entertainment affiliate of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, plans to invest more than 50 billion yuan (S$10.427 billion) over the next three years, the affiliate's chief executive said.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4 per cent up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks ended 0.4% higher on Wednesday, advancing 12.54 points to 2,898.3, boosted by a recovery in oil prices and post-Christmas holiday cheer on Wall Street. About 1.19 billion shares changed hands, with Noble Group rising S$0.007 to S$0.169. Gainers outnumbered losers 258 to 149, marking a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Polaris parts ways with XMI, recovers US$1.5m loan with interest
summary: Polaris has sold its 30% stake in multimedia devices maker XMI for S$1 and recovered a US$1.5m loan with interest. Polaris Device initially bought the stake in 2015 for S$1 and provided the loan. XMI agreed to repay Polaris Device US$1.77 million, including principal and 10.8% interest. The deal was finalized on Dec 23, with Polaris Device receiving the repayment.

images.alt_text: ELECTRONICS retailer Polaris has sold off its investment in multimedia devices maker XMI and recovered a loan it made to XMI, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Wednesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A survey by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) found companies are skeptical about the government's push for firms to transform as the economy restructures, with many expecting a challenging 2017. Meanwhile, Singapore Changi Airport saw a 3.2% increase in passenger movements in November. Private equity investments in South-east Asia surged in Q3 2016, with a majority going to ride-hailing applications. Construction firm LQS Construction is suing Mencast Holdings over a contract dispute, and Swissco's liftboat vessel received a notice of receivership.

site_title: Japan hails Pearl Harbour visit while bracing for Trump
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's visit to Pearl Harbor was met with praise for his message of reconciliation with the US, despite being wary of the future under Donald Trump's presidency. Abe's visit, which included a joint address with President Barack Obama, was seen as a symbol of renewed ties between the two countries, but some criticized his hawkish military policy. China also weighed in, calling for a sincere apology to Asian countries affected by Japanese militarism, and Trump's comments on Japan's military contributions and potential nuclear deterrent were seen as a challenge to the bilateral relationship.

site_title: HPH Trust buys majority stake in Huizhou port from sponsor for US$86m
summary: HPH Trust, a port operator, has agreed to buy a majority stake in Huizhou International Container Terminals (HICT) from its sponsor for US$86.26 million. HICT operates container terminals in China's Guangdong province, and the trust expects the new terminals to attract more intra-Asia cargoes. The deal is part of HPH Trust's expansion plans in the region.

site_title: NTU to develop traffic management solutions for UAVs
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) researchers are developing a traffic management system for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in Singapore's airspace. The four-year project, led by NTU professor Low Kin Huat, aims to create smart and safe routing systems, detect-and-avoid systems, and traffic management to coordinate air traffic. The project's goal is to ensure safe and efficient drone traffic in urban airways, with far-reaching implications for seamless travel of unmanned aircrafts without compromising safety.

site_title: Dutch police say Berlin attack suspect may have passed through Netherlands
summary: Dutch police are investigating whether Anis Amri, the Tunisian suspect believed responsible for the Berlin Christmas market attack, may have passed through the Netherlands. Amri, 24, was shot dead by Italian police on December 23 after killing 12 people in the attack. Dutch national police spokesman Wim de Bruin stated that "signs" suggest Amri may have traveled through the Netherlands on his way to France. An investigation is ongoing to determine the extent of Amri's travel through the country.

site_title: Chinese mall business trust seeks S'pore IPO
summary: A Chinese business trust, Dasin Retail Trust, is seeking to raise S$122.5 million through an initial public offering on the Singapore Exchange mainboard. The trust, which holds three shopping malls in China's Guangdong province, has lodged a preliminary prospectus without specifying pricing or unit numbers. Its sponsor, Zhongshan Dasin Real Estate, develops properties in Zhongshan city. The trust's portfolio includes Xiaolan Metro Mall, Ocean Metro Mall, and Dasin E-Colour shopping mall.

site_title: Airbus's A380 woes deepen as top buyer Emirates delays jets
summary: Airbus's A380 superjumbo jet delivery delays worsen as Emirates, the plane's largest customer, postpones 12 aircraft deliveries over the next two years. The delays are due to an agreement between Emirates and engine supplier Rolls-Royce, following technical shortcomings revealed by Emirates earlier.
