Airbus will accelerate cost cuts to mitigate financial drag. The setbacks compound Airbus's efforts to revive the A380, which lists for $433 million. The delay caps a year of negative news for the plane, with no new orders from Iran and reduced delivery targets.

site_title: Kerry plans Middle East speech as Israel moves to ease tension
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry plans to deliver a speech outlining a comprehensive vision for Middle East peace as tensions rise between Israel and the US. The speech comes amid Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's efforts to ease friction with Washington, following a UN Security Council resolution demanding Israel halt all new construction in areas won in the 1967 war. Kerry defended the US abstention from vetoing the resolution, saying it made clear both sides must act now to preserve peace, while Netanyahu lashed out at President Barack Obama, calling the US behind the scenes.

site_title: Fifa boss says football federations back expanded World Cup
summary: Fifa President Gianni Infantino announced that football federations are backing plans to expand the World Cup to 48 teams, citing financial appeal. The decision would involve a one-off preliminary round, followed by a 32-team group stage. Infantino had previously suggested a 40-team tournament and promised expansion when elected in February. A "democratic process" will be held among Fifa council members to decide on the expansion.

site_title: Beijing prepares to dissolve ancient grip on salt market
summary: China is preparing to dismantle its centuries-old monopoly on the salt market in Beijing, allowing almost 80 producers and traders from across the country to sell their wares in the capital for the first time. The move is part of the government's efforts to liberalize state-owned industries and promote private investment. The new rules, set to take effect on January 1, will allow 79 registered traders from other provinces to enter the market, and consolidate sales wholesalers and producers. The goal is to dismantle price controls and distribution channels dominated by the state-owned China National Salt Industry Corp.

site_title: Asia's Nov imports of Iranian oil more than double from year ago
summary: Iran's four major Asian buyers in November more than doubled their imports of Iranian oil to 1.94 million barrels per day, up 117% from a year ago. This was the second consecutive month of increased imports, with purchases by India and South Korea exceeding four times their year-ago levels. Iran's exports in December are set to fall 8% from November due to lower shipments to Asia, offset by increased exports to Europe.

site_title: Xiaomi-backed online bank to launch services soon
summary: A Chinese online bank backed by Xiaomi Inc, New Hope Group Co Ltd, is set to launch services soon after being officially established and rebranded as Sichuan XW Bank. The bank's establishment was approved by shareholders and regulators. This marks an important step in the bank's process, with officials stating it is the bank's official establishment. The launch date has not been specified.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stable at open as London reopens
summary: European stocks remained stable on Wednesday as London reopened after a two-day closure, with the FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% to 7,059.72 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices were almost unchanged, following Tuesday's closing levels. The stable markets come ahead of US-EU trade talks, which have been a focus for investors.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at their highest in nearly 17 months
summary: Australian shares closed at their highest in nearly 17 months, ending 1% higher at 5,685 on the S&P/ASX 200 index. The benchmark has gained for three consecutive quarters, its longest streak since 2014. A post-Donald Trump rally and higher US consumer confidence supported gains, with major miners like Rio Tinto and Fortescue rising 2.4-3.5%. Gold stocks also surged, while consumer stocks like Woolworths and Wesfarmers advanced 1.9-1.1%.

site_title: LQS Construction sues Mencast
summary: LQS Construction is suing Mencast Holdings and its subsidiary Mencast Marine for S$3.3 million over a contract for an office building. However, Mencast announced that its mainboard listing means it is not a party to the building contract, rendering the suit without merit. Mencast's lawyers are reviewing the claim and will advise the company on how to resist and refute LQS Construction's claims.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up after Christmas break on commodity strength
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.8% on the first trading day after Christmas, driven by a rebound in commodity prices and gains in energy and raw material shares. The Hang Seng index reached 21,754.74 points. Information technology stocks led the gains, with Tencent Holdings Ltd rising 2% after announcing a deal to use platform services from a digital mapping company. Most sectors advanced, with raw material shares surging 1% after rebar and coke futures jumped 5-7% on the mainland.

site_title: China says Taiwan, HK independence supporters will fail 'like flies dashed against the wall'
summary: China's government stated that efforts by Hong Kong and Taiwan independence supporters to link up are doomed to fail, likening them to flies dashed against a wall. The comments come amid heightened tensions over Taiwan, following a US President-elect Donald Trump's telephone call with Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen, which upset Beijing. China has not renounced the use of force to bring Taiwan under its control, and the comments reflect the country's increasing concern over the independence movements in both Hong Kong and Taiwan. Beijing warns that such efforts will ultimately fail.

site_title: "Disruptive" influence from NDF on ringgit has subsided: Malaysia central bank
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, says the "disruptive influence" of the non-deliverable forward (NDF) market on the ringgit has subsided. The NDF market, which allows traders to bet on the currency's value, was forced to cease trading by the central bank. As a result, liquidity on the onshore foreign exchange market increased, reaching a daily average of US$9 billion in December. This marks a success for the central bank's efforts to stabilize the ringgit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks flat in thin holiday trade
summary: Tokyo shares remained flat in holiday trading on December 28, 2016, due to thin trading volumes. Toshiba's potential massive one-time loss led to a 20% nosedive in the company's stock. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.01% to 19,401.72, while the Topix index rose 0.04% to 1,536.80.

site_title: Vietnam's growth slows in 2016 but remains resilient
summary: Vietnam's economic growth slowed to 6.2% in 2016, a dip from the previous year's 6.68%, due to a global trade slowdown and environmental disasters. Despite this, the country's GDP growth was still considered a success due to its stability. Foreign investment increased by 9% year-on-year, with Vietnam attracting a record $15.8 billion in 2016. Analysts hail Vietnam as a bright spot in the region, citing its competitive labor costs and favorable outlook.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's economic growth eased off in 2016 but remained resilient in the face of a global trade slowdown and environmental disasters, authorities said Wednesday.

site_title: Qualcomm fined 1.03t won by South Korean antitrust agency
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator fined Qualcomm Inc. a record 1.03 trillion won (S$1.23 billion) for violating antitrust laws. The Fair Trade Commission found Qualcomm licensed its key patents only to mobile-phone makers, coerced customers into signing contracts, and didn't fairly pay for patent use. Qualcomm will appeal the decision and may struggle to defend its lucrative licensing business, which generates most of its profit from selling technology fundamental to all modern phone systems.

images.alt_text: South Korea's antitrust regulator slapped a record 1.03 trillion won (S$1.23 billion) fine on Qualcomm Inc. for violating antitrust laws, the latest in a string of government actions that threaten the U.S. chipmaker's most profitable business.

site_title: Region's private equity deals in Q3 2016 outstrip total investment in H1 2016
summary: In Q3 2016, private equity investments in South-east Asia surpassed the total investment in H1 2016, with a majority going to ride-hailing apps in Indonesia, totaling $1.91 billion. The two ride-hailing apps raised $1.3 billion in Q3, outstripping the region's total investment in the first half of the year.

site_title: China state-owned firms profit up in first 11 months
summary: China's state-owned firms reported a 2.8% increase in profits in the first 11 months of 2016, driven by a raw material price rally and construction boom. Total profits reached 2.1 trillion yuan, while revenue rose 2.4% to 40.8 trillion yuan. However, some sectors, such as coal, steel, and building materials, saw significant profit growth, while others, like textiles and petroleum, suffered declines. The government's debt servicing capabilities may be hampered by the potential for slower economic growth and rising debt levels, which are expected to reach 250% of GDP.

site_title: China's yuan slightly eases, market sentiment remains weak
summary: China's yuan edged down against the US dollar, weakening to 6.9495 per dollar, amid weak market sentiment at the end of the year. The spot yuan is on track to finish the year with a 7% loss, and traders expect further depreciation in 2017, with some predicting a 1-2% weakening in the first quarter. The offshore yuan borrowing rate surged to 15.18% in Hong Kong, while one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts traded at 7.274, indicating a 4.46% weakening.

site_title: Hong Kong's feline friends offer insight into city's past
summary: A Dutch photographer's book and exhibition showcase cats in traditional Hong Kong shops, capturing their calm demeanor amidst bustling city streets. The photographs, featuring cats in various settings, highlight the city's changing landscape while preserving its timeless character. Hong Kong's celebrity shop cat, Cream Brother, a British Shorthair with 200,000 Facebook followers, has become a symbol of the city's feline friends, who bring a sense of calm to the busy urban environment. The exhibition and book offer a nostalgic glimpse into Hong Kong's retail past.

site_title: India train crash injures at least 43
summary: A train derailed in northern India on Wednesday, injuring at least 43 people near the city of Kanpur in Uttar Pradesh state. This is the third such accident in recent weeks, raising concerns about the safety of India's ageing rail network. The train was carrying over 20 million passengers daily, with thousands dying in accidents every year. The government has promised to upgrade safety apparatus, but analysts estimate that the railways need $293.21 billion in investment by 2020.

site_title: End of lockup for subsidised Thai cars fuels hope of sales boost
summary: Thailand's auto industry is hopeful for a sales boost in 2017 as a five-year restriction on selling subsidized cars has ended. The restriction, introduced in 2012, depressed demand after a record 1.44 million cars were sold in 2012. With about 1.1 million vehicles bought under a government subsidy scheme, the removal of the restriction could lead to increased sales. The industry is looking forward to a recovery after years of falling domestic sales, following massive flooding in 2011.

site_title: Companies downbeat about 2017 prospects: SBF survey
summary: A survey by the Singapore Business Federation found a disconnect between the government's push for firms to transform and how they are responding. 62% of respondents agree they must transform to adapt to slowing economic growth, but only 15% of small and medium-sized enterprises and 36% of large ones strongly agree. Nearly half expect the economic climate to worsen further next year, and only 13% believe the government's efforts are sufficient to help them adapt.

site_title: Swissco unit receives notice of appointment of receivers for vessel
summary: Swissco Holdings Limited's subsidiary, Liftboat 1 International, received a notice of appointment of receivers for its vessel Jinshan 1. Joint and several receivers Andrew Grimmett and Lim Loo Khoon were appointed by DBS Bank, the lender and mortgagee. The interim judicial managers are considering their options and will provide further updates.

site_title: Prices of completed non-landed units slip 0.7% in Nov: NUS
summary: Prices of completed non-landed private apartments and condominiums in Singapore slipped 0.7% in November, according to the National University of Singapore's flash estimates. Completed units in the Central Region, including Districts 1-4, fell 0.8% during the month. The revised SRPI for October showed a 0.2% dip in prices.

images.alt_text: Prices of completed private apartments and condominiums slipped 0.7 per cent in November from a month ago.

site_title: China: Stocks down in thin trading, hurt by regulatory measures
summary: China's stocks fell 0.4% in thin trading on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous day, due to stricter regulatory measures on insurers' stock investments. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.4% and 0.4% respectively. Insurers were put under closer supervision after the China Insurance Regulatory Commission suspended two insurers from online insurance business and ordered them not to apply for new product approvals for three months. The measures dampened investor confidence, with infrastructure and property shares declining around 1%.

site_title: China's Jiangling Motors unit awarded electric car licence
summary: A unit of China's Jiangling Motors Corp Ltd has been awarded a licence to manufacture 50,000 electric vehicles, making it the seventh company to receive such permission under a new energy vehicle licencing programme. The licence was granted by the country's state planner, according to an online posting. This move aims to promote the development of China's electric vehicle industry and support the country's growing demand for new energy vehicles.

site_title: Vietnam's 2016 FDI inflow hits record high of US$15.8b: govt
summary: Vietnam received a record-high US$15.8 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2016, a 9% increase from the previous year. New pledges and additional funds for existing projects reached US$24.4 billion, with South Korean investors contributing the most, including LG Display's US$1.5 billion OLED screens plant and LG Innotek's US$550 million camera plant. This marks a significant increase from 2015, demonstrating Vietnam's growing attractiveness to foreign investors.

site_title: Yahoo's data breaches seen unlikely to derail Verizon deal
summary: Yahoo's second major data breach, involving over 1 billion user accounts, is unlikely to derail its $4.83 billion acquisition by Verizon. Experts say that data breaches have become common and public sentiment has shifted, with people becoming desensitized to the issue. Despite the breach, investors and the public tend to move on, and the costs of data breaches have been substantial but not devastating. The breach is just one of many in the US, with over 1,000 reported in 2016, and is not seen as a major concern for the acquisition.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slips to 2-week low as the market goes ex-dividend, won flat
summary: South Korean shares fell to a two-week low, dropping 0.7% to 2,025.56 points, as investors sold stocks after the ex-dividend date. The decline was attributed to cautious trading following substantial gains in the index, with investors waiting for global events in January. Foreign investors were net sellers, offloading 24.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while domestic investors declined 472 to 328. Key losers included Hyundai Motor Co (-2%) and Korea Electric Power Corp (-4%). The South Korean won remained stable at 1,207.3 to the US dollar.

site_title: Hitachi considering selling power tools unit Hitachi Koki
summary: Hitachi Ltd is considering selling its power tools unit, Hitachi Koki Co, reportedly in talks with US private equity firm KKR & Co for over 150 billion yen (S$1.85 billion). The Japanese conglomerate is exploring various options to strengthen its business, including the sale, but no decision has been made. Negotiations are in the final stages, with a potential agreement possible next month.

site_title: Gold prices extend gains on strong technical signals
summary: Gold prices rose for the fourth consecutive session, driven by a technically-driven rebound in thin volume, amid a slightly weaker US dollar. Spot gold edged 0.2% higher to US$1,141.45 an ounce, reaching a near two-week high of US$1,148.98 on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index up 2.29 points, or 0.08%, to 2,888.05. The market followed a bullish day on Wall Street, where US stocks traded near a record high. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 40, with 40 million shares worth S$27.5 million changing hands. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.06%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 24.75 points to settle at a record close.

site_title: UK house prices may barely rise as Brexit weighs on economy
summary: UK house prices may rise only 1-4% in 2017 due to economic growth weakening and inflation squeezing consumers, according to Halifax. Tax changes and stricter underwriting standards are restricting buy-to-let investment, and London's housing market is expected to see a sharper slowdown. The shortage of properties, low interest rates, and uncertainty over the UK's EU exit are supporting prices, but a slowdown in the labor market and reduced household spending power are likely to curb demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.2 points to 1,620.89. Trading volume reached 86.5 million lots worth RM34.1 million, with 117 gainers outnumbering 72 losers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars off multi-month lows, still vulnerable
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were pinned near multi-month lows due to upbeat US economic data supporting the US currency. The Australian dollar held at US$0.7192 and the New Zealand dollar at US$0.6900. The Aussie is set to end the year down 1.3%, while the kiwi is seen ending on an annual gain of one percent. US Treasury yields rose, and Australian government bond futures dropped to one-year lows, amid expectations of further Federal Reserve tightening.

site_title: South Korea special prosecutor detains pension fund chairman
summary: A South Korean special prosecutor has detained the chairman of the National Pension Service, Moon Hyung-Pyo, on suspicion of abuse of power in connection with a corruption scandal involving the merger of two Samsung Group affiliates. The arrest comes as the investigation into President Park Geun-Hye's ties to the scandal continues, with parliament having already voted to impeach her. The case has raised concerns about the influence of the founding family of Samsung and the ties between the president and a friend, Choi Soon-Sil. The special prosecutor can hold the chairman under emergency arrest for up to 48 hours.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord, Jumbo, Ying Li, SATS
summary: Yanlord Land Group acquired a 541,000 sqm site in China for $1.5 billion, Jumbo Seafood is expanding in China and Asia, and China Everbright increased its stake in Ying Li International Real Estate. SATS signed a conditional share sale agreement to acquire a 10% stake in Evergreen Sky Catering Corporation for $32.3 million, boosting its stake to 25%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge higher tracking overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.9% to 9,191.91 points, tracking overseas markets. The electronics and financials sectors led the gains, with display makers Innolux and Hannstar Display rising 1.3% and nearly 9% respectively. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$32.288 per US dollar. Traders expect the index to potentially slide back to 8,900 if it fails to stay above 9,130 by the end of the week.

site_title: Singapore defaults seen as bellwether for 2017 Asia distress
summary: Singapore's commodities-related defaults could signal a broader distress in the Asia-Pacific region, with more companies expected to struggle due to rising interest rates and President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies. Companies in the shipping and oil service sectors, including those in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, face significant debt and revenue challenges. The region's non-bank borrowers, particularly in China and Indonesia, also face a significant increase in dollar bond maturing in 2017, with US$76.4 billion at risk. Experts predict a sustained level of distress in the bond market throughout Asia next year.

images.alt_text: Singapore's commodities-related defaults could turn out to be the canary in the mine.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on December 28, 2016, in thin holiday trading, with the Nikkei 225 index easing 0.12% to 19,380.13 and the Topix index down 0.09% to 1,534.78.

site_title: Space programme must help protect national security, says Beijing
summary: China's space programme must prioritize national security, but the country opposes a space arms race. The government stated that its space programme is for peaceful purposes, focusing on economic, scientific, and technological development. China has made significant advancements, including manned spaceflight, lunar probes, and anti-satellite missiles. The country aims to establish itself as a space power, with plans to launch a Mars probe by 2020 and a lunar probe on the dark side by 2018. China also plans to land a person on the moon by 2036, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Singapore Changi Airport's passenger movements in Nov up 3.2% from a year ago
summary: Singapore Changi Airport reported 4.78 million passenger movements in November, a 3.2% increase from the previous year. Growth in air travel to and from South-east Asia, North-east Asia, and South Asia drove the increase, with China, Vietnam, and India seeing significant gains. China led with a 13.7% increase, while Vietnam and India saw 9.9% and 9.8% gains, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks edge down in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.1% in early trade on December 28, 2016, as investors returned from a four-day holiday weekend. The Hang Seng Index fell 21.37 points to 21,553.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.03% to 3,113.77. The Shenzhen Composite Index also decreased 0.06% to 1,978.47.

site_title: Delta drops Boeing Dreamliner order inherited from Northwest
summary: Delta Air Lines has cancelled an order for 18 Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner jets valued at $4 billion, inherited from its 2008 merger with Northwest Airlines. The airline is sticking with its existing order of 120 narrowbody Boeing 737-900ERs. Delta cited its fleet strategy to prudently address widebody aircraft needs, as the 787 had similar capabilities to its existing 777 aircraft. The decision was predicted, with some analysts noting that Delta tends to fly larger planes and the 777 is more consistent with its strategy.

site_title: Airbus's A380 woes deepen as jets delayed for top buyer Emirates
summary: Airbus delays deliveries of 12 A380s to Emirates, its biggest customer, due to an agreement with Rolls-Royce over engine performance and maintenance concerns. The delays will impact Airbus's efforts to turn around the fortunes of the A380, the world's largest commercial jetliner. The company will accelerate cost cuts to offset the financial drag. This marks a bad year for Airbus's flagship model, with no new orders and a cut in delivery targets in July.

site_title: Trump Tower lobby briefly evacuated over suspicious package
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's Trump Tower lobby in New York City was briefly evacuated on December 27, 2016, after a suspicious package was discovered. The NYPD's bomb squad responded, but an all-clear was issued shortly after. Trump was not at the 58-story skyscraper at the time, as he was spending the holidays at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. The lobby, often visited by tourists, was evacuated as a precautionary measure.

site_title: Richard Adams, author of 'Watership Down,' dies at 96
summary: British author Richard Adams, creator of the classic novel "Watership Down," has died at 96. The author of the 1972 novel, which was adapted into an animated film and television series, passed away peacefully on Christmas Eve. The book, which tells the story of a group of rabbits searching for a new home, was inspired by a story Adams told his daughters during a car journey and is dedicated to them. Adams also wrote "Shardik" and "The Plague Dogs," which are also taught in British schools.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges up in low volume, boosted by tech shares
summary: US stocks rose slightly on Tuesday, supported by upbeat consumer and housing data, with tech shares lifting the Nasdaq Composite to a record close. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, while volume remained low at around 4 billion shares traded. The rally is attributed to optimism over Donald Trump's plans for deregulation and infrastructure spending, but some analysts caution that the data is not significantly different from six months ago.

site_title: Finns top list of 32 countries in Internet use on phones, tablets
summary: Finland tops the list of 32 countries in internet usage on phones and tablets, with Finns consuming nearly twice as much mobile data as South Koreans. The country's cheap subscription plans and nationwide mobile networks are key factors, with over half of all phone and tablet connections coming with unlimited data plans. The excessive internet usage has led to concerns among authorities, particularly among parents, who are encouraged to spend more time with their children and less time on their smartphones.

site_title: Toshiba flags hit of 'billions of dollars' on US nuclear acquisition
summary: Toshiba may need to book billions of dollars in charges related to a US nuclear power plant construction company acquisition, sending its stock tumbling 12%. The Japanese conglomerate, already reeling from a US$1.3 billion accounting scandal, faces potential cost overruns and liabilities at the US nuclear construction business. Toshiba's latest writedown would further undermine confidence in the company's management and nuclear credentials, with asset sales or a potential listing of its cash-cow flash memory chips division being considered to boost capital.

site_title: Carrie Fisher, 'Star Wars' Princess Leia, dies at 60
summary: Carrie Fisher, the iconic actress known for her role as Princess Leia in the 'Star Wars' franchise, died on Tuesday at the age of 60 after suffering a heart attack while flying into Los Angeles. Fisher, a mental health advocate, had previously disclosed her struggles with bipolar disorder and cocaine addiction. Her family, including her mother Debbie Reynolds and daughter Billie Lourd, expressed their gratitude for the support and prayers received. Fisher's legacy includes her memoirs, films, and her portrayal of strong and resilient characters, leaving behind a lasting impact on the entertainment industry.

site_title: United settles US lawsuit over hazards for baggage handlers
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc. has settled a US lawsuit over hazards in its baggage handling operations at Newark Liberty International Airport. Federal inspectors found hazardous conditions, prompting the US Department of Labor's lawsuit in 2015. As part of the settlement, United will install new conveyor belts and improve worker safety. The agreement may serve as a template for other carriers. The Labor Department announced the resolution on December 27, 2016.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady in quiet trade, Parmalat soars
summary: European shares steadied on Tuesday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index up 0.1% as trading resumed after the Christmas break. Parmalat soared 10% after its French owner, Lactalis, announced a buyout bid. Most sectors traded positively, with banks lagging after the European Central Bank's capital shortfall announcement. Deutsche Bank fell 1.5% despite the ECB's decision to lower minimum capital requirements.

site_title: Japan Nov factory output rises, firms upbeat on outlook
summary: Japan's factory output rose 1.5% in November, beating market forecasts, and manufacturers expect a further 2% increase in December and 2.2% in January, indicating optimism about overseas demand. This data supports the Bank of Japan's view that a global demand pick-up will underpin a steady economic recovery. The economy has recorded three consecutive quarters of annual expansion, albeit at a modest pace. The recent rebound in exports has offered hope for policymakers struggling to revive the economy.

images.alt_text: Japan's factory output rose in November and manufacturers expect to ramp up production in coming months, data showed on Wednesday, underscoring the central bank's view that a pick-up in global demand will underpin a steady economic recovery.

site_title: Abe answers Obama's Hiroshima visit with Pearl Harbor trip
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visited Pearl Harbor on Tuesday, becoming the first Japanese leader in decades to tour the site of the surprise attack that drew the US into World War II. Abe did not apologize for the 1941 attack, but offered condolences to the victims and expressed a desire to prevent future wars. The visit was seen as a gesture of reconciliation matching President Barack Obama's trip to Hiroshima earlier in the year, and aims to enhance the US-Japan alliance. Abe's visit is part of his efforts to strengthen ties with the US, which has been a key partner in the region amid rising tensions with China.

site_title: US dollar gains against yen in thin trading after US data
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen on Tuesday in thin holiday trading following stronger-than-expected US economic data and expectations of a hawkish Federal Reserve. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller composite index of home prices rose 0.6% in October, and US consumer confidence hit its highest level in over 15 years. The dollar index extended gains to a session high against the yen, but remained below a 10-month high. Analysts expect the dollar to continue its uptrend driven by expectations of inflationary policies under the new US administration and faster pace of Fed rate hikes.

site_title: Arrest in US$4m insider trading case from law firm hacks
summary: US prosecutors have charged three hackers with insider trading, allegedly making $4 million in illicit profits from law firms' confidential information. The hackers, two from Macau and one from China, breached law firms' computer networks and bought shares in companies that were later acquired. The hackers made $380,000 on Intermune, $1.4 million on Altera, and $841,000 on Borderfree. The US Attorney's office announced the charges, warning law firms that they are targets of cyber hacking due to their valuable information. The two remaining defendants are at large.

images.alt_text: The three defendants, two from Macau and one from China, successfully breached the computer networks of international law firms with New York offices by unlawfully obtaining a firm employee's credentials and installing malware on his company's server, the US Attorney's office in New York said.

site_title: Equation plans major restructuring to focus on anti-theft business
summary: Equation, a Singapore-based company, is undergoing a major restructuring to refocus on its proprietary anti-theft technology. The company plans to issue S$12 million of convertible bonds, reduce its capital by S$135.6 million, and consolidate its shares. The restructuring aims to create a single-business company with the resources to pursue growth and a capital structure to attract additional capital. After selling its environmental and computer solutions businesses, Equation's sole business will reside in subsidiary Disa Digital Safety, which offers product-locking technology for consumer electronics.

site_title: Mexico to raise gas price by 20%
summary: Mexico's finance ministry announced a 20.1% increase in gasoline prices and a 16.5% increase in diesel prices, effective January 1, as part of the country's energy reform. The price increases will be adjusted every 24 hours, eventually allowing market pricing to determine prices nationwide by the end of 2017. The move aims to deregulate the energy sector and open it to private investment and foreign competition, following President Enrique Pena Nieto's landmark energy reform signed in 2014.

site_title: Asia follows Wall Street higher, upbeat US data lifts US dollar
summary: Asia stocks rose 0.2% as they followed Wall Street higher, boosted by upbeat US economic data. The US dollar strengthened against peers, while crude oil prices held gains due to expected supply cuts. The US data release lifted the US dollar and contributed to the rally.

site_title: China Beige Book shows broad improvement across all industries
summary: China's economy showed broad improvement in the fourth quarter, with gains across all industries, according to the China Beige Book. Revenues, profits, jobs, and capital expenditures improved from the third quarter, while new orders remained stable. However, deteriorating corporate cash flow remains a risk in the year ahead. Economists raised growth estimates, citing policies that plan prudent and neutral monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy next year. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Yanlord acquires second Nanjing site for 7.8b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group acquired a 541,000 sq m development site on Sino-Singapore Nanjing Eco Hi-Tech Island for 7.84 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion). The site will feature residential apartments, hotel, offices, and tourism space. This is Yanlord's second land acquisition on the island, following a 386,000 sq m site purchased three years ago. The new site is expected to benefit from the island's growing amenities and is well-connected to the city center.

site_title: Trump: UN 'a club for people to get together, talk and have a good time'
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump criticized the UN, calling it "a club for people to get together, talk and have a good time", after it adopted a resolution condemning Israeli settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Trump had instructed his predecessor Barack Obama to abstain from voting, and vowed to challenge the institution's approach to the Middle East once he takes office. Trump's harsh criticism signals a shift in US policy, potentially undermining the UN's role in addressing global conflicts and humanitarian crises.

site_title: Miners drive Australia shares to 16-month high; NZ treads water
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.1% to a 16-month peak on Wednesday, driven by gains in miners, oil majors, and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5689.8, on track for its longest quarterly gain since March 2014. The benchmark is also poised for its best yearly performance since 2013. Thin trading volumes and expectations of international market leads contributed to the gains.

site_title: Abu Dhabi bourse to introduce shortselling in Q1 2017: CEO
summary: Abu Dhabi's stock market plans to introduce covered shortselling in Q1 2017, aiming to boost liquidity and attract foreign investors. The Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange (ADX) has held meetings with brokerages and obtained approval from the Securities and Commodities Authority to introduce the service. Covered shortselling allows investors to borrow shares and sell them in expectation of repurchasing them later at a lower price. The ADX aims to diversify investment instruments and match global markets, with rules in place to reduce risks surrounding shortselling.

site_title: Steel prices to continue climbing for another half year: fund manager
summary: A fund manager predicts that steel prices will continue to rise for another six months, driven by demand in other countries and a lack of significant weakening. Steel prices have doubled this year, improving profitability at Posco and other steelmakers. Despite a 1.5% drop in demand in China, the world's largest steel market, prices are expected to remain strong.

site_title: Singapore's year of misbehaving moneymen puts MAS on high alert
summary: Singapore's financial sector faced a year of high-profile allegations of misconduct, including market manipulation and money laundering, prompting regulators to take enforcement actions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) shut local units of two Swiss banks, fined major lenders, and seized S$240 million of assets. The government responded by strengthening enforcement functions under a new department, vowing to protect the reputation of its financial sector, which relies on finance for 13% of its economy. The city-state's image as a clean financial hub is under test, but it remains the least corrupt nation in Asia, according to Transparency International.

site_title: Outrage over the economy does not explain surging global populism
summary: Global populism surged in 2016, driven by discontent with governance rather than economic abandonment. Retirees and farmers in the US and Europe cited issues with undocumented immigrants, bureaucracy, and a lack of representation, rather than solely economic grievances. The rise of nationalist parties threatens the euro and globalisation, with some warning of a potential "deglobalisation" that could slow growth and erode international trade. Policymakers are struggling to address the root causes of populism, which may require a shift in rhetoric and a more inclusive approach to globalisation.

site_title: Oil rallies in thin trade, adds to year's gains
summary: Oil prices rose 1.5% on Tuesday, continuing its year-end rally, driven by expectations of tighter supply once the first output cut deal between Opec and non-Opec producers takes effect on January 1. US crude surged 25% since mid-November, with prices near the year's high of $54.51. Analysts say doubts about Opec's commitment will be put to rest, and a meeting on January 13 may give an early indication of compliance with the deal.

site_title: Searchers recover main black box of crashed Russian plane
summary: Russian authorities have recovered the main black box of a military plane that crashed into the Black Sea on Sunday, killing 92 people. The Tu-154 jet, carrying over 60 members of the Red Army Choir, was en route to a military airbase in Syria. An act of terror is not being considered as a possible cause, but investigators are looking into pilot error, technical failure, and other factors. The black box, 1,600 meters from the shore at a depth of 17 meters, will be sent to Moscow for deciphering, potentially providing information on the crash.

site_title: Giant glowing orb about to become the new home of the EU
summary: The European Union is set to move into a new headquarters, the Europa, a giant glowing orb building in Brussels. The €325 million structure, designed by Philippe Samyn, aims to promote transparency and "joyful" surroundings for European leaders. The building, visible from the street during the day and night, will become the EU's new home after its move from the current headquarters. The Europa is expected to be completed soon, marking a new chapter for the EU's institutional presence in Brussels.

site_title: Three foreign banks eyeing Turkish market, says bank regulator
summary: Three foreign banks, including one from the US, are considering entering the Turkish market, possibly as early as 2017. The head of Turkey's banking watchdog stated that three foreign banks had expressed interest in doing business in Turkey. Another foreign bank from Dubai and a fourth from Bank of Bahrain and Kuwait are also interested in acquiring a banking license. The Turkish market has been challenging for foreign banks due to stiff competition and local lenders offering services like biometric ATMs and accounts in different currencies.

site_title: Vietnam stocks outperforming Asean peers
summary: Vietnam stocks have outperformed their Asean peers for the first time in two years, driven by planned stake sales of major government companies expected to boost the bourse. Analysts predict 19% net growth in earnings for next year, driven by an expanding economy and stable inflation. The country's stock prices are now pricier than their Southeast Asian counterparts.

site_title: European banks struggling to stay above water
summary: European banks face significant challenges, with Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse struggling to stay profitable due to billions in settlements. The two banks agreed to pay $12.5 billion in US investigations into toxic debt sales, highlighting the handicaps to generating increased profits in Europe. European bank shares are headed for a third straight losing year, and shrinking profitability has become a "concern for financial stability" due to reduced ability to recover from shocks. Italy's banking system is also under strain, with the government providing 20 billion euros in support.

site_title: Foreland takes legal action against its former executive chairman
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has taken legal action against its former executive chairman, Tsoi Kin Chit, over possible breaches of securities laws. The company claims breaches occurred due to a public reprimand by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and a complaint lodged with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD). Foreland has requested an immediate suspension of its shares due to the uncertainty surrounding the legal actions. The company's subsidiary, Fulian Knitting Co Ltd, may also face similar measures. The actions follow an SGX reprimand and a complaint against Tsoi.

site_title: Solving the currency chaos in Venezuela
summary: Venezuela is experiencing its 57th hyperinflation crisis, with the bolivar currency losing 42% of its value since November. Officials have proposed printing higher-denomination bills to mitigate the effects, but experts warn this will not be enough. Venezuela's experience with hyperinflation, similar to Yugoslavia's in the 1990s, has shown that redenomination alone cannot solve the issue. The only solutions are to either replace the bolivar with the dollar or implement an orthodox currency board, which would provide stability and regain international faith in the country.

site_title: Panasonic to invest in Tesla PV cell plant
summary: Panasonic is investing over 30 billion yen (S$370 million) in a Tesla production facility in Buffalo, New York, to make photovoltaic cells and modules. The partnership will enable Tesla to increase module production to one gigawatt by 2019, as part of a solar partnership announced in October. Panasonic will provide factory buildings and infrastructure, and Tesla will make a long-term purchase commitment. The joint statement marks a significant expansion of their collaboration, focusing on corporate clients and automotive components.

site_title: Opec's 2017 balancing act could face headwinds from US shale
summary: Opec aims to boost oil prices to $58 a barrel in 2017 by cutting production, but US shale firms may counteract the move, potentially undermining the plan. Analysts predict a 29% increase in oil prices, but US drillers could respond by adding rigs, reversing the cuts. Even a $58 oil price may not eliminate budget deficits for all Opec members, with some requiring prices to average at least $62. Challenges include compliance with the output agreement, Russia's potential non-compliance, and the resilience of US shale firms.

site_title: For a niche American jazz label, vinyl is the future
summary: A small American jazz label, Newvelle Records, is shifting its focus to vinyl records, citing the medium's growing popularity. The label, founded by Elan Mehler two years ago, is investing in vinyl-cutting technology to produce high-quality records. Mehler and his business partner, Jean-Christophe Morisseau, are working together to cut master recordings, marking a renewed emphasis on vinyl production. This move is seen as a response to the growing demand for vinyl records, which has seen a resurgence in popularity in recent years.

site_title: Fund managers bullish on emerging markets in 2017
summary: Global fund managers are optimistic about emerging markets in 2017, despite credit rating agencies' less positive outlook. Emerging market stocks have declined nearly 7% since the US election, and currencies such as the Mexican peso and Turkish lira have tumbled 10% or more. However, some fund managers believe the sector will rebound, citing structural problems and long-term perspectives. BlackRock expects solid gains from emerging market bonds, while others are investing in healthcare, retail, and energy sectors in countries like Nigeria, Indonesia, and Russia. Credit rating agencies, however, have lowered positive credit outlooks and written negative outlooks for emerging markets.

site_title: Turnbull's coalition stands firm despite credit rating threats
summary: Australia's ruling coalition remains sensitive to a potential downgrade of its AAA credit rating, despite a recent report from Standard and Poor's stating there's a one-in-three chance of a downgrade within the next two years. The government projects a budget surplus by 2020-21, but economists predict a downgrade due to concerns over the nation's fiscal outlook. A downgrade may lead to higher borrowing costs, but history shows that market yields often fall after a downgrade, as seen in cases of Britain and Japan.

site_title: Web advertising: greater reach but at what cost?
summary: Advertisers face a moral dilemma as they balance the reach of online automated advertising with the risk of funding fake news portals. The issue arose during the 2016 presidential election, where fake news sites were found to be financially motivated by online ads. Companies are now grappling with how to mitigate the risk of advertising on toxic sites, with the marketing industry struggling to find a solution to this problem.

site_title: Industrial profits in China grow faster in Nov, but chance to sustain gains clouded
summary: China's industrial profits rose 14.5% in November, the highest since August, driven by a rebound in commodity prices. However, policymakers noted the gains were overly reliant on price increases in oil products, iron, and steel. Industrial profits rose 9.4% for the first 11 months, with manufacturing profits increasing 13.7%. But analysts say recent signals from top leaders to crack down on asset bubbles may put pressure on raw material prices, casting doubts on the sustainability of the price rebound.

site_title: PEs on the prowl for O&M bargains
summary: Private equity investors are searching for bargains in the struggling offshore and marine sector. Despite a lack of functional benchmarks for asset prices, PEs are interested in companies with scale and geographic diversification in the shallow-water sub-sector, which is expected to recover faster than deep-water activities. Analysts predict that operating day rates for shallow-water rigs and vessels will rebound quickly in 2018, while deep-water drilling floaters may not see improvement for five years. Industry players are also eyeing opportunities in the offshore support vessel and subsea space, where acquiring companies require lower capital outlays.

site_title: Cash ban turns India's promising start in 2016 into damp squib and adds to next year's woes
summary: India's economy showed a promising start in 2016, but the country's cash ban and demonetization decision have derailed momentum for key reforms, including the rollout of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) from April 1. The move has stalled spending, caused a political stalemate, and led to a slowdown in industrial production and investment. Despite expected growth of 6.5% for the quarter, economists predict a challenging 2017, with GDP growth likely to slow down in the long term. The government's inability to pass supporting legislation for the GST has also raised concerns about its ability to implement reforms.

site_title: Sony deletes tweets on Britney Spears's death, says hackers to blame
summary: Sony Music Entertainment's Twitter account was compromised, posting fake tweets announcing Britney Spears's death. The tweets were quickly deleted and a clarification issued, stating that Spears is "fine and well." The incident is the latest in a series of erroneous celebrity death reports, with hackers such as OurMine, a Saudi teenager, suspected of involvement. OurMine has previously hacked celebrity accounts and offered security services.

site_title: Spanish property in boom phase with mini bubbles forming
summary: A Spanish construction firm, La Casa por el Tejado, is building new apartments on rooftops in cities like Madrid and Barcelona due to a lack of available land, signaling a resurgence in Spain's property market eight years after a brutal crash.

site_title: Autonomous vehicles, IoT among most disruptive techs in 2017
summary: Autonomous vehicles, the Internet of Things (IoT), and enterprise mobile apps were voted the top three disruptive technologies in 2017 by Asian budding entrepreneurs, according to a survey by Oslo-based telco Telenor. Autonomous vehicles were chosen as the most disruptive tech for the second year, with 37% of respondents supporting this trend. The survey also found that 38% of respondents were likely to create an IoT startup in 2017, and a third of entrepreneurs polled want to achieve a social impact alongside profit and business growth.

site_title: GIC to acquire 10% stake in HERE with Tencent, NavInfo
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, Tencent Holdings, and NavInfo have jointly acquired a 10% stake in HERE, the Open Location Platform company. The transaction is expected to be completed in the first half of 2017, subject to regulatory approvals. HERE will form a strategic partnership with the three companies to develop location services for the Chinese market, including a 50:50 joint venture to create high-definition mapping and location services for autonomous cars. The partnership aims to expand HERE's global presence and develop IoT solutions for the Chinese market.

site_title: North Korea planning to complete nuclear development in 2017
summary: North Korea plans to complete its nuclear development by the end of 2017, according to a high-ranking defector. The country's leader, Kim Jong-Un, has issued a directive to "complete" nuclear development, citing leadership transitions in South Korea and the US as a prime time for nuclear development. This comes after North Korea conducted two nuclear tests in 2016 and numerous missile launches. Analysts question the country's progress in developing an inter-continental ballistic missile, but agree it has made significant strides since Kim Jong-Un took over.

site_title: JUMBO's appetite for expansion could prove good for growth
summary: JUMBO Seafood, a restaurant group, is expected to drive revenue growth through expansion in China and Asia. Despite a challenging F&B industry in Singapore, analysts predict the company will open more stores, with a focus on the business district. DBS Group Research analysts expect revenue to be driven by store openings, particularly in China, with potential locations in Singapore. This expansion could prove promising for investors, with the company poised to capitalize on growing demand in the region.

site_title: ECB says Paschi bank needs 8.8b euros of capital
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has determined that Italian bank Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA needs approximately 8.8 billion euros in capital to bolster its balance sheet due to deteriorating liquidity. Despite being solvent according to Tier 2 capital requirements, the bank is seeking further information on the ECB's calculations. The Italian government plans to invest up to 20 billion euros in the bank to address liquidity issues, which are considered a serious problem, but the ECB believes the bank is still solvent and will continue to work on finding a sustainable business model.

site_title: China Everbright raises Ying Li stake
summary: China Everbright Ltd, the asset management arm of China Everbright Group, has increased its stake in Singapore-listed Chongqing developer Ying Li International Real Estate to 22.92% by purchasing 205 million shares for S$28.29 million. This move raises its total stake from 14.9% previously. Ying Li's founder Fang Ming remains the largest shareholder with a 36% stake. Analysts say the purchase shows China Everbright's commitment to the firm, and its share price has already factored in many of the risks associated with the China property market.

site_title: Toshiba warns of multibillion-dollar loss on US nuclear acquisition
summary: Toshiba warns of a potential multibillion-dollar loss related to its US nuclear acquisition by Westinghouse Electric. The company may book a loss of up to 500 billion yen due to a dispute over the value of the acquisition. This would significantly impact Toshiba's earnings, potentially eclipsing the projected net income of 168 billion yen for the current fiscal year. Toshiba's shares plummeted 12% to 392 yen, and the company's bond risk increased, with credit-default swaps on track for their biggest gain since February.

images.alt_text: Toshiba was fined a record 7.4 billion yen in December last year after Japanese regulators found that the manufacturer misled investors by filing false financial statements.

site_title: Steeper declines in rents, prices
summary: Steeper declines in rents and prices are expected, with US mortgage rates climbing after five weeks of declines. In Singapore, the Q3 condo launch wave will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases anticipated. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. These trends signal a shift in the real estate market.

site_title: GLP secures Sagamihara site in Greater Tokyo
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) secures a 655,000 sqm site in Sagamihara, Greater Tokyo, for a total investment cost of 133 billion yen (S$1.6 billion). The project will start in 2020, following a sale-and-leaseback arrangement, and is part of GLP's US$39 billion fund management platform. Sagamihara has emerged as a major logistics hub due to a lack of quality logistics space and available land parcels in metropolitan Tokyo, with a strong leasing pipeline and expected to complement GLP's existing portfolio in the region.

site_title: Thailand detains nine for hacking govt websites in protest
summary: Thailand authorities have detained at least nine people suspected of hacking government websites in response to a new cyber censorship law. The law, approved by Thailand's rubber-stamp parliament, allows the junta to easily remove content from the web. The detentions follow days of disruptions to government websites.

site_title: Mounting criticism for Felda's plan to strike 'expensive' Indonesian palm deal
summary: Felda, Malaysia's state-owned palm oil firm, is facing mounting criticism for its plan to purchase a 37% stake in Indonesian palm oil firm PT Eagle High Plantations Tbk for US$505.4 million, a 95% premium to the company's closing price. Critics argue the deal is overpriced and may affect Felda settlers, who rely on the company for aid. Opposition parties and Felda settlers have called for the government to intervene and stop the deal, with some accusing Prime Minister Najib Razak of pushing the deal for personal gain.

site_title: Wanted: Analysts with 'no ego'
summary: Stanford University's endowment fund, valued at $22.4 billion, is seeking analysts to join a team of 16 investment professionals. The non-profit organization, Stanford Management Co, is looking for candidates with a "non-hierarchical, no ego" culture, where analysts will work closely with senior team members. The fund, which has trailed its peers in performance, aims to drive additional performance through a focused approach. The search follows the departure of senior managers and other staff, including CEO Robert Wallace, who has overhauled the fund's operations since joining in March 2015.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' subsidiary sold a London hotel for £13.78 million (S$24.5 million), generating a net gain of £2.6 million. Global Yellow Pages received approval to construct 225 houses in Queenstown, New Zealand, while SATS signed a conditional share sale agreement with Malaysia Airlines to acquire a 10% stake in Evergreen Sky Catering Corporation for RM100 million (S$32.3 million). RHT Health Trust ditched its investment adviser RGAM Corporation and partnered with Stellant Capital Advisory Services. Swee Hong sold a freehold property for S$3.1 million, and Rex International secured an extension of a 400 million Norwegian kroner (S$66.5 million) credit facility.

site_title: Largest coral die-off at Great Barrier Reef
summary: The Great Barrier Reef has experienced its largest coral die-off ever recorded, with an average of 67% of coral dying across a long stretch of its northern end. The die-off, caused by water temperatures up to two degrees warmer than normal, has led experts to conclude that climate change is making such events more likely and increasing the risk of long-term damage to the reef. Rising ocean temperatures and acidity pose additional threats to coral, highlighting the need for urgent action to curb greenhouse-gas emissions and protect biodiversity.

site_title: China reassures homeowners worried about land rights
summary: Chinese officials have clarified that some homeowners in Wenzhou, eastern China, won't have to pay a fee to extend the rights to the land under their residences, which is a closely watched issue affecting millions of Chinese homeowners. The decision, made by China's vice-minister of land and resources, stops short of providing a clear legal framework on land-ownership rights nationwide, but could pave the way for similar moves in other cities. The measures apply to 20-year leases, with 600 households affected, and are seen as a positive step by the government.

site_title: Japan Inc shows promise with savvy holiday deal spree
summary: Japan's companies are showing promising signs of recovery with savvy holiday deals. Asahi Glass Co acquired CMC Biologics for $739 million, expanding into contract drug manufacturing, while TDK Corp acquired InvenSense Inc for $1.3 billion, adding motion sensors and gyroscopes. Panasonic Corp also made a majority stake acquisition in Zetes Industries SA for $226 million. These deals demonstrate a strategy of diversifying into new areas and leveraging existing operations to balance risks and avoid government bailouts, a calculated risk needed for Japan's companies to thrive.

site_title: International cricket facing threat of too many matches
summary: The international cricket calendar is facing a threat due to an over-scheduling of matches, compromising the quality of the sport. The Australian national team will play two matches in 24 hours on different continents, with leading players potentially being forced to choose between formats. The congested schedule is driven by the desire to maximize television rights revenue, with the "Big Three" countries (Australia, England, and India) receiving more funding than the rest. This could lead to a decline in the quality of Test cricket and "cannibalization" of the sport.

site_title: Land acquisition for KL-Singapore High Speed Rail to take place by Q3 2017
summary: Land acquisition for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project is set to take place by Q3 2017, according to MyHSR Corporation Sdn Bhd. The agency will comb through 50m-wide tracts, primarily plantation land, to acquire the necessary land for the 350km rail track spanning across Malaysian and Singaporean territories. The project aims to connect Kuala Lumpur's Bandar Malaysia with Singapore's Jurong East via two rail tracks.

site_title: China's cabinet names Harvard graduate as central bank vice-governor
summary: China appointed Harvard graduate Yin Yong as a vice-governor of the People's Bank of China, replacing Guo Qingping. Yin, a PhD holder from Tsinghua University and Harvard University, previously worked at the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. The appointment follows a series of promotions by central bank chief Zhou Xiaochuan to boost management. Yin's predecessor, Guo Qingping, was 60 and reached the retirement age, while another official, Yang Ziqiang, was removed due to violating rules by using public funds for a private trip.

site_title: Use underground space to boost retail in Singapore
summary: Singapore aims to boost retail by utilizing underground space, as land scarcity hinders traditional methods of expansion. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has implemented an incentive scheme to co-fund underground links, but none have been taken up by developers on Orchard Road. A study found that underground walkways can enhance connectivity, foot traffic, and rents, but high construction costs and land premiums make it commercially infeasible. The study recommends incentives and space design schemes to encourage development, and suggests a tenant mix of fashion, convenience, and food options to maximize the potential of underground spaces.

site_title: Why some holiday gifts are on many airlines' no-fly list
summary: Some holiday gifts, such as portable power banks and wireless earbuds, are banned by many airlines due to safety concerns, including overheating and fire risks. These items are often added to the airline's no-fly list, despite being designed to make air travel more convenient. Airlines are required to follow strict regulations regarding prohibited items in carry-on luggage. Passengers are advised to check with their airline before purchasing any gifts that may be restricted from being brought on board.

site_title: Japan's Fuel Cell Valley on cutting edge of energy storage
summary: Japan's Fuel Cell Valley project in Yamanashi prefecture is a hub for energy storage development, featuring flywheels, solar panels, and hydrogen fuel cells. The project aims to attract companies like Panasonic and Toray Industries Inc. to collaborate on energy storage and supply chains. The site includes a 1-megawatt solar power station, flywheel storage devices, and hydrogen production, showcasing Japan's efforts to dominate the energy technologies industry and become a leader in energy storage by 2024, with cumulative energy storage expected to reach 7,440 megawatts.

site_title: Yuan turnover soars in sign of December outflow pressures
summary: The onshore yuan's trading volume surged to a record high in December, reaching $34 billion in Shanghai. This represents a 51% increase from the first 11 months of the year. The rapid growth in yuan transactions is seen as a sign of capital outflow pressures in China.

site_title: Dollar gains, sterling slides after Christmas
summary: The US dollar gained against the yen and euro, reaching 117.40 yen and US$1.0441 per euro, amid concerns over Brexit negotiations. Sterling slid almost half a percent to US$1.2243, trading near an eight-week low. Analysts attribute the dollar's strength to rising cross currency basis and fundamental factors for next year, while a slowdown in US Treasury yields and President-elect Donald Trump's relationship with China may support the Japanese yen.

site_title: Democratic reforms will win the day, assures former Indonesian ambassador to Singapore
summary: Former Indonesian ambassador to Singapore Luhut Pandjaitan expressed nervousness about discussing Indonesia's blasphemy laws, despite being a long-time friend of President Joko Widodo. Pandjaitan, current coordinating minister for maritime affairs, previously served as a special-forces commander and Cabinet minister, but avoided the topic. His comments come as Indonesia is pushing for democratic reforms.

site_title: Super Mario Run no longer highest grossing iOS app
summary: Nintendo's Super Mario Run, released on Dec 15, no longer holds the top spot as the highest-grossing iOS app in any country, according to App Annie data. The game's price, requiring a $10 payment for progress beyond the first three levels, has been criticized for being too high. Analysts estimate that lowering the price to $2 could increase revenue by $20 million. The game's poor performance has contributed to Nintendo's shares falling 18% since Dec 12, raising doubts about the company's mobile strategy.

site_title: STI ends on a merrier note despite thin trade
summary: The Singapore Stocks Index (STI) closed 14.71 points higher at 2,885.76 on Tuesday, led by gains in banking stocks. Thin trading volumes of 601.1 million units worth S$363.5 million occurred, with oil prices rising due to Opec and non-Opec output cuts set to start soon. The "Trump Trade" may resume in late January, with US equities and European stocks expected to rally, while emerging markets may tread water until clarity on the Trump administration's protectionist agenda is established.

site_title: Tepco, investors eye 1st bond sale since Fukushima
summary: Tepco, Japan's largest power utility, is considering its first bond sale since the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster. The move comes after the government reassessed decommissioning and compensation costs, making investors more comfortable with the utility's outlook. Some market participants expect a sale as early as February, with Tepco gauging demand for the issue. The sale would mark a significant step forward for the company, which has faced skepticism from investors in the past.

site_title: Wall St upbeat over 'tax holiday'
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump plans to create a "tax holiday" to allow American companies to repatriate profits held overseas at a lower rate. The proposed 10% tax rate is a significant reduction from the current 35% rate. Corporate boards and executives are expected to use the repatriated funds for acquisitions, stock buybacks, or debt reduction, potentially leading to job losses. Some companies, such as Apple and Microsoft, may delay deal-making due to uncertainty about tax reform. Activist investors are also expected to deploy repatriated funds, potentially leading to increased payouts to shareholders.

site_title: China vows to protect information security 'using all means'
summary: China has pledged to protect its information security, using all necessary means, including its military, according to its first strategic report on cybersecurity. The report calls for a "secure and controllable" Internet and outlines a review process for domestic and foreign companies selling key information products and services in China. China has also adopted a cybersecurity law requiring cooperation with police investigations and the provision of source code and encryption keys. The move comes amid heightened tensions with the US, with China expressing concerns over foreign operators and cybersecurity threats.

site_title: IoT devices become new targets for cybercriminals (Amended)
summary: Cybercriminals are increasingly targeting IoT devices in Singapore, with a recent attack on StarHub's home broadband network demonstrating the sophistication of these attacks. Devices such as DVR players, WiFi cameras, and routers were infected with malicious code and used to launch a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack. Experts warn that the lack of security in IoT devices makes them vulnerable to attacks, with the risk of security breaches increasing as more devices are installed. The government has set up the Cyber Security Agency to coordinate responses to cyber attacks and has outlined a new cybersecurity strategy to strengthen the resilience of Singapore's digital network.

site_title: Putin says new gas pipeline will boost annexed Crimea's economy
summary: Russia activated a new gas pipeline to Crimea, a peninsula it annexed from Ukraine in 2014, with President Vladimir Putin hailing it as a step to boost economic growth. The pipeline, which carries Russian gas, will help meet Crimea's energy needs, which were previously met by Ukraine. This is the latest in a series of infrastructure projects Moscow is building to support the peninsula, including a road and rail bridge and an electricity link. The move is seen as a key part of Putin's efforts to solidify Russia's control over Crimea.

site_title: Security set to be key election issue across EU in 2017
summary: European leaders are under pressure to strengthen security measures in 2017, following a year of high-profile terrorist attacks across the continent. The German attack, which killed 12 people, has raised concerns about the effectiveness of current border controls and intelligence sharing. Eurosceptic parties, including the National Front and UK Independence Party, are championing the idea of ending the Schengen Agreement, which allows passport-free travel across most EU states. The EU is also considering a new European Defence Action Plan, which aims to reverse decade-long defence spending cuts and create a more coordinated approach to security.

site_title: Saudi royals spending big in age of austerity
summary: Saudi royals continue to spend lavishly despite the country's fiscal austerity program, which has led to pay and subsidy cuts for government staff. The royal family's fortune comes from oil reserves, and they own French chateaus and Saudi palaces, stashing money in Swiss bank accounts. The family's spending is estimated to be in the billions, with some royals buying property in Paris and others maintaining the same allowances as before. The king's health and succession issues raise concerns about the family's ability to maintain their lavish lifestyle and grip on the country.

site_title: Actively managed funds nursing withdrawals despite US market's bull run
summary: US-based actively managed stock funds suffered a record $288 billion in withdrawals year-to-date through November, surpassing outflows of $139 billion in 2015 and $218 billion in 2008. In contrast, passive index mutual funds and equity exchange-traded funds (ETFs) attracted $112 billion each. Only 33% of active stock managers beat their benchmarks this year, leading investors to shift to lower-cost funds that track indexes. To bring investors back, performance must improve, according to analysts, who warn that the industry may need to shrink if active managers fail to outperform in the future.

site_title: Telegram the 'app of choice' for terrorists
summary: Terrorist groups, particularly the Islamic State, have increasingly turned to the messaging service Telegram due to its discreet and highly encrypted nature, allowing them to exchange ideas and spread propaganda with minimal interference. Despite efforts by Telegram to block extremist content, the platform has become the "app of choice" for many ISIS and other terrorist elements, surpassing Twitter in importance. Critics argue that Telegram's creator, Pavel Durov, could do more to prevent terrorists from using the platform, citing the company's encryption features and lack of proactive measures to combat extremism.

site_title: China on the rise
summary: China's influence is on the rise as it challenges the US in the South China Sea, seizes unmanned underwater vehicles, and pressures Singapore and Taiwan. China has also browbeaten Mongolia, a traditionally Buddhist nation, and frozen relations with Norway after the Norwegian Nobel Committee awarded a Nobel Peace Prize to an imprisoned dissident. A global survey conducted by the Beijing newspaper Global Times found that 56.6% of respondents believed China would be the most influential country in Asian affairs in the next 10 years. China's economic and military muscle is increasing its global presence, with 67.9% of respondents saying China is a global power.

site_title: Japan's Nov household spending slides for 9th straight month
summary: Japan's household spending fell 1.5% in November for a ninth consecutive month, reflecting a preference to save rather than spend. Core consumer prices also fell 0.4% for the ninth consecutive month, indicating the Bank of Japan is still far from achieving its 2% inflation goal. The economy is expected to rely on investment to meet its 1.5% growth target for fiscal 2017. The Bank of Japan is likely to maintain its ultra-easy monetary policy to prevent deflation and a stronger yen.

site_title: Bank Negara reminds financial institutions of their reporting obligations
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia reminded financial institutions of their reporting obligations under the Financial Services Act 2013, following a crackdown on the offshore ringgit NDF market. A recent enforcement action was taken against a financial institution for failing to report a significant audit finding related to fixing the USD/MYR exchange rate. The central bank views such reporting breaches seriously and will take enforcement actions, including monetary penalties and public reprimands, against any institutions that breach provisions under the FSA. The ringgit remains under pressure, trading at 4.4785 against the US dollar, with analysts predicting a possible breach of the 4.5 mark and a slide towards 4.70/4.80 next year.

site_title: Abe's Pearl Harbor pilgrimage underlines US-Japan tie
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visited Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, to reinforce US-Japan reconciliation 75 years after Japan's surprise attack drew the US into World War II, killing 1,177 crew members. The visit comes amid uncertainty over US-Japan relations, with incoming US President Donald Trump expressing opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership and questioning US security guarantees. Abe aims to promote reconciliation and healing between the two nations, with a ceremony at the USS Arizona memorial scheduled for Tuesday.

site_title: China's giant cow farms leave neighbours up milk creek
summary: China's large-scale dairy farms have become a significant contributor to the country's milk production, with thousands of cows generating massive amounts of manure and effluent. The farms, which have boomed in recent years, are located in areas like Gannan, China, where the black manure and rancid-smelling effluent have become a nuisance to neighboring residents. The growth of China's dairy industry has helped meet the country's increasing demand for milk, despite centuries of cultural reluctance to consume it.

images.alt_text: A photo taken on May 3, 2016 shows a pipe carrying waste from a dairy farm (in the background - behind the brick wall) in Gannan county, Heilongjiang province, China.

site_title: Oil extends longest run of gains since august before Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices extended a seven-session winning streak, advancing 0.5% in New York, before Opec and other producers agreed to cut output by 1.8 million barrels per day starting next year. Prices have traded near or above $50 a barrel since Opec's production cut agreement last month. Analysts expect prices to recover next year as production cuts help rebalance the oversupplied market. Oil prices rose to $53.27 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and $55.23 a barrel for Brent.

site_title: Tata Sons files legal notice against ex-chairman Mistry
summary: Tata Sons, the holding firm for the US$100 billion Tata conglomerate, has filed a legal notice against former chairman Cyrus Mistry, accusing him of breaching confidentiality rules by sharing sensitive data, business strategies, and financial information. The notice, seen by Reuters, states that Tata Sons intends to pursue all available remedies under the law. This comes after Mistry began legal proceedings against Tata Sons last week. A public relations agency representing Mistry has declined to comment.

site_title: US: Dow nears 20,000, Nasdaq hits record as tech stocks gain
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones nears 20,000 and the Nasdaq hitting a record, driven by gains in technology and energy shares. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 29.42 points, or 0.15%, to 19,963.23, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 15.38 points, or 0.28%, to 5,478.07. Energy stocks rose due to oil price gains, while tech stocks led the broader S&P 500 index to its seventh straight week of gains.

site_title: Low-cost airlines slow to take off in Latin America
summary: Low-cost airlines in Latin America are slow to take off due to high airfares, limited secondary airports, and burdensome regulations. In contrast, Europe, the US, and Asia have more established low-cost carriers, with fares often six times cheaper. However, several start-ups, including Flybondi and Viva Air Peru, are poised to change the landscape, with major investors backing their expansion plans. Experts predict the region's growing middle class and tourism sector will eventually attract low-cost airlines, but for now, air travel remains a luxury for the rich.

site_title: Amazon says 2016 holiday season "best-ever"
summary: Amazon reported its best-ever holiday season, shipping over one billion items worldwide through its Prime membership program. The company saw a 72% increase in mobile device shopping and reported that the Amazon Echo and Echo Dot were best sellers. Despite production issues, other top sellers included Keurig K-Cups, Samsung's Gear VR headset, and Nintendo's Pokémon Sun and Moon games. Amazon's shares rose 1.4% in morning trading.

site_title: German lawmakers urge tougher security measures after market attack
summary: German lawmakers are urging tougher security measures after a Christmas market attack that killed 12 people, with Chancellor Angela Merkel promising to introduce new laws if needed. The suspected perpetrator, Anis Amri, was an asylum seeker who had escaped deportation. Merkel's conservative allies are calling for greater powers for police and intelligence agencies, and improved data exchange. Some 550 people are registered as potentially violent, and polls show that Germans' opposition to state monitoring is waning. Merkel remains a popular leader, with 56% of Germans believing she can solve major political problems.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's film Master has achieved a remarkable feat in the South Korean box office, grossing over US$20 million in just four days and capturing 55% of the country's total box office revenue. The film's success has boosted Spackman's expectations, with analysts raising their forecast net profit after tax to US$1.76 million. The company's distribution rights have been presold to 31 countries, and its other production house, Zip Cinema Co, has a good track record, leading to a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.32.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
