summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) proposed changes to the Companies Act, seeking public consultation. GIC acquired a 10% stake in HERE with NavInfo and Tencent. JTC launched industrial sites at Woodlands and Tuas, while GLP secured a site in Greater Tokyo. Lum Chang sold a London hotel and Equation Summit issued redeemable convertible bonds. Singapore shares rose 14.71 points, led by banking stocks, and Foreland took legal action against its former executive chairman.

site_title: Hong Kong's first bird flu patient this winter dies
summary: A 75-year-old Hong Kong man has died from bird flu, marking the first human infection in the city this winter. The man, diagnosed with the H7N9 strain, recently traveled to China. This is the first reported human case in Hong Kong this season, following seven reported cases in China with two fatalities. Hong Kong has been battling sporadic cases of avian influenza in humans since 2003, when six people were infected and killed.

site_title: French art experts blast Seoul over 'fake' painting
summary: French art experts have criticized South Korean state prosecutors for declaring a painting by renowned artist Chun Kyung Ja as genuine despite scientific findings that contradicted the artist's claims. The 1971 painting, "Beautiful Woman," was previously declared a forgery by a French imagery analysis firm, Lumiere Technology, but prosecutors sided with the National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, citing forensic evidence and local art experts. Chun's family and French experts dispute the prosecution's conclusion, accusing it of ignoring empirical evidence and seeking to help museum authorities save face.

site_title: Rex unit gets extension of 400m Norwegian kroner credit facility
summary: Rex International Holding has secured an extension of its 400 million Norwegian kroner (S$66.5 million) credit facility from Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken for two more years, until December 2018. This extension is considered a "bridging" credit facility and is 100% backed by tax refund receivables from the Norwegian government. Rex has no long-term loans or borrowings.

site_title: Trump taps Bossert for counterterrorism post
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump appointed Thomas Bossert, former deputy homeland security adviser to President George W Bush, as his White House adviser on security and counterterrorism issues. As assistant to the president for homeland security and counterterrorism, Bossert will be Trump's top counterterrorism chief. Bossert currently runs a risk management consulting firm and has a cyber risk fellowship with the Atlantic Council think tank. The appointment aims to address counterterrorism concerns in the Trump administration.

site_title: RHT Health Trust taps Fortis's unit Stellant as new investment adviser
summary: RHT Health Trust has terminated its investment adviser agreement with RGAM Corporation and appointed Stellant Capital Advisory Services, a Fortis Healthcare subsidiary, as its new investment adviser. The deal was signed "on substantially the same terms" and will last until October 19, 2017. Stellant will provide investment recommendations and advisory services to the trust manager.

site_title: US consumer confidence hits 15-year high in December
summary: US consumer confidence reached a 15-year high in December, rising to 113.7, according to The Conference Board. This marked the highest level since August 2001, driven by expectations for job growth, business conditions, and the stock market. The increase surpassed estimates and was a result of optimism following the US presidential election.

site_title: Turkey opens first trial related to failed coup with case against police
summary: Turkey's first trial related to the failed coup began on Tuesday, with 29 police officers charged with disobeying orders to defend President Tayyip Erdogan's palace on the night of the July 15 coup. The officers are seeking 3 life sentences and prison terms ranging from 7-1/2 to 15 years. The trial comes as more than 100,000 people have been sacked or suspended in a crackdown targeting the military, police, and civil service, and 40,000 people have been arrested. The alleged ringleaders are due to go on trial next year.

site_title: US housing prices sustain growth in October
summary: US housing prices experienced modest growth in October, with a 0.6% increase in the S&P Case-Shiller price index and a 5.6% year-over-year gain in the National Home Price Index. Despite rising mortgage interest rates, industry figures suggest a near-term reversal in trends due to robust hiring and high consumer confidence. However, affordability has declined 20-30% since the market trough of 2012, with home prices outpacing wage and income gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 2.53 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.53 points to 1,619.680. The market saw 1.09 billion lots valued at RM1.02 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 375 to 333.

site_title: Swee Hong sells Choa Chu Kang property for S$3.1m
summary: Swee Hong has agreed to sell a freehold property at Choa Chu Kang Avenue 1 for S$3.1 million to Hong Ee Corporation, a privately held firm run by one of its employees. The property, comprising two strata-titled units, was valued at S$3.1 million by Jones Lang LaSalle. Swee Hong will book a gain of S$2.6 million and use 80% of the net proceeds to repay creditors. The sale is expected to net the company around S$2.9 million.

site_title: Indian passenger plane skids off runway, injuring 15
summary: A Jet Airways plane carrying 161 passengers and crew skidded off the runway at Goa airport in India, injuring 15 people. The cause of the incident is unclear, but the runway has since been cleared. Minor injuries, including bruises and fractures, were sustained by the 15 passengers. Everyone else was evacuated safely, and medical assistance is being coordinated. The plane was bound for Mumbai when it veered off the runway during take-off.

site_title: Investors bet on Vietnam as valuations top region
summary: Vietnam's stock market is becoming increasingly expensive, with the benchmark VN Index trading at 15.9 times earnings, surpassing its South-east Asian peers for the first time in two years. Economists predict the country will be among the world's fastest-growing economies in 2016, driven by a strong manufacturing industry and increased foreign-direct investment. The government aims for GDP growth of 6.7% next year, with projected earnings growth of 23% for companies on the benchmark gauge. Investors are optimistic about the market's future, with some recommending the government lift the foreign ownership limit in the banking sector to boost liquidity.

site_title: Toshiba considering capital strategy after flagging potential big losses
summary: Toshiba is considering a capital strategy after flagging potential big losses, including a huge charge to its US nuclear business. The company's US nuclear unit, Westinghouse, may have to book billions of dollars in losses related to a US nuclear power acquisition. Toshiba's CEO Satoshi Tsunakawa stated that the company is considering measures to raise capital, but no details were provided. The charge could potentially wipe out Toshiba's shareholders' equity and even lead to negative net worth.

site_title: SATS to buy 10% stake in Evergreen Sky Catering Corp from Malaysia Airlines
summary: SATS has entered into a conditional share sale agreement with Malaysia Airlines to acquire a 10% stake in Evergreen Sky Catering Corporation (ESCC) for RM100 million (approximately S$32.3 million). This acquisition will boost SATS' stake in ESCC to 25%. The proposed acquisition aligns with SATS' strategy to grow its food business and enhance connectivity to serve customers across Asia.

site_title: Yanlord acquires Nanjing site for 7.84b yuan to build integrated development
summary: Yanlord Land Group acquired a 541,000 sqm development site in Nanjing, China, for 7.84 billion yuan. The integrated site will feature residential apartments, offices, and commercial units, with easy access to metro lines and key thoroughfares. This acquisition marks a new chapter in Yanlord's history, expanding its presence in the Nanjing market and enhancing its prime development landbank.

site_title: Chinese court jails former Chinalco president for 16 years for graft
summary: A Chinese court has sentenced former Chinalco president Sun Zhaoxue to 16 years in jail for graft. Sun resigned in 2014 after a government investigation into suspected corruption. He had also stepped down as chairman of Chinalco's listed unit, Chalco. The conviction marks a high-profile crackdown on corruption in China's state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Foie gras maker Labeyrie eyes IPO by 2018
summary: Labeyrie Fine Foods, a French foie gras specialist, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) by 2018. The company's private equity firm, PAI Partners, which controls 43% of shares, plans to sell its stake, prompting Labeyrie to develop a new strategic plan. CEO Pierre-Yves Ballif stated that the IPO will take place at this time.

site_title: Single bidder for Korean shipbuilder STX French unit
summary: A single bidder, identified as Italian shipbuilding giant Fincantieri SpA, has submitted a binding proposal to buy STX France, the profitable French unit of South Korean shipbuilder STX Offshore and Shipbuilding Co. The proposal is being studied by Samil PricewaterhouseCoopers, and the court will announce whether it has been accepted on January 3. If the offered price is deemed too low, a fresh round of bidding will open. The French state, which holds the remaining share, is concerned about the future of the shipyard, which is a major local employer with a healthy order book.

site_title: Tepco, investors discussing first bond sale since Fukushima-sources
summary: Tokyo Electric Power (Tepco) is considering its first bond sale since the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, with potential maturities of three to ten years. The company is expected to offer a premium of 1 percentage point above Japanese government bonds, due to the risk involved. Discussions with investors are ongoing, with a possible sale as early as February, although a specific target date or size has not been confirmed.

site_title: Europe: Stocks inch higher, Parmalat soars
summary: European shares rose 0.2% in early trading, with Parmalat surging 9.7% after its French owner, Lactalis, announced a buyout offer. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index also saw gains in Germany's DAX and France's CAC, with all sectors trading in positive territory. However, banks were weighed down by an ECB statement requiring Italy's Monte dei Paschi to plug a capital shortfall of 8.8 billion euros, higher than previously estimated.

site_title: Update: Main black box of crashed Russian plane found
summary: A Russian military plane crashed in the Black Sea on Sunday, killing 92 people. The main black box from the Tu-154 jet was found 1,600 meters from the shore at a depth of 17 meters. The black box will be flown to Moscow for deciphering. Authorities have recovered 12 bodies and 156 body fragments, which will be sent to Moscow for identification. The cause of the crash is being investigated, with pilot error, technical fault, bad fuel, and foreign object in the engine being considered possible explanations.

site_title: North Korea plans nuclear push in 2017: top defector
summary: North Korea plans to accelerate its nuclear development in 2017, taking advantage of leadership transitions in South Korea and the US. According to a high-ranking defector, Thae Yong Ho, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un issued a directive to complete nuclear development by the end of 2017. Analysts are divided on the progress made, but the defector claims Kim will never trade away the nuclear arsenal. The goal is to establish the North as a confirmed nuclear power to open a new dialogue with the US, which has vowed not to accept the North as a nuclear state.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank takes action against firm over ringgit trade
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has taken action against an unnamed financial institution for failing to promptly notify the central bank of a significant audit finding related to its dealers' misconduct involving the fixing of the dollar-ringgit exchange rate. The central bank views such breaches seriously, particularly those involving offshore ringgit NDF markets or market manipulation. The action could include monetary penalties, a public reprimand, and other measures to mitigate or remedy the breaches.

site_title: Taiwan warns of increasing threat as Chinese warships conduct drill
summary: Taiwan warned on Tuesday that the threat of its enemies is growing, amid Chinese warships led by the sole aircraft carrier, Liaoning, conducting a routine drill in the South China Sea. The aircraft carrier skirted Taiwan's eastern air defence identification zone, and is expected to arrive at a Chinese military base on the island of Hainan. The drill comes amid renewed tension over Taiwan, following US President-elect Donald Trump's telephone call with the island's president.

site_title: JGBs little changed, underpinned by decent 2-year sale
summary: Japanese government bonds (JGBs) remained relatively stable on Tuesday, with the benchmark 10-year yield edging up 0.5 basis points to 0.060%. A 2-year JGB auction saw strong demand, with bids exceeding 4.51 times the amount offered, despite a slight widening of the average and lowest accepted price. The 2-year yield rose to minus 0.175%. Trading in JGB futures and options was halted due to a technical glitch, and the market is expected to remain thin due to year-end holidays.

images.alt_text: Japanese consumer prices rose 0.2 per cent in November from a year earlier when stripping away the effect of energy and fresh food costs, an indicator released by the Bank of Japan showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore to release advance Q4 GDP data on Jan 3
summary: Singapore will release advance estimates of gross domestic product (GDP) for the fourth quarter and 2016 on January 3 at 8am GMT. The economy contracted 2% in the third quarter, but industrial production in November rose at the fastest annual pace in 2.5 years, reducing the risk of a GDP contraction. This follows a 1.1% growth in the July-September quarter.

site_title: Monte Paschi says ECB Sees the need for 8.8b euros of capital
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) estimates that Italian lender Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA needs approximately 8.8 billion euros of capital to bolster its balance sheet. This is based on the results of a 2016 stress test, despite the bank meeting Tier 2 capital requirements. The Italian government will invest up to 20 billion euros in the bank, while the ECB has requested a 4.5 billion-euro contribution from the state and 4.3 billion euros from bondholders. The bank had failed to raise 5 billion euros from private investors.

site_title: China says space programme must help protect national security
summary: China's space programme must protect national security while adhering to peaceful use of space principles. The country aims to establish itself as a space power, with capabilities including anti-satellite missiles and manned spaceflight. China has tested its space programme, including the longest manned space mission to date, and plans to launch a Mars probe by 2020 and land on the dark side of the moon in 2018. The government opposes a space arms race and emphasizes the programme's importance in economic, scientific, and technological development.

site_title: Gold edges higher in thin trade after holiday weekend
summary: Gold prices rose slightly on Tuesday, 0.3% higher at $1,136.80 an ounce, due to thin trading after the holiday weekend. Investors are waiting for US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, expecting a stronger dollar and stock market, which may reduce demand for gold. The US dollar rose against the yen and euro, and hedge funds cut their net long position in Comex gold for a sixth straight week. Other precious metals, such as silver, platinum, and palladium, also saw gains.

site_title: China targets 'toilet revolution', rustbelt regions in plan to boost tourism
summary: China aims to boost tourism by investing 2 trillion yuan (S$416.9 billion) from 2016 to 2020, aiming for 14% annual growth in direct investment. The plan includes developing rustbelt regions and upgrading public toilets, with a goal of building or renovating 100,000 public toilets. The government predicts domestic travelers will take 6.4 billion trips annually by 2020 and overseas travelers will increase to 150 million. The tourism sector is expected to account for 12% of annual economic growth by 2020, up from 10.8% last year.

site_title: China vows to protect information security 'using all means'
summary: China has pledged to protect its information security using all necessary means, including its military, in its first strategic report on cybersecurity. The report calls for a "secure and controllable" internet and outlines a review process for domestic and foreign companies selling key information products and services in China. The move comes amid growing concerns over international cybersecurity and espionage, with China criticizing US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on Taiwan. China also seeks global cooperation to prevent cyberwar and will issue further implementing measures on its cybersecurity law.

site_title: China to speed up drafting overseas investment regulations
summary: China plans to expedite the drafting of regulations on overseas investments, citing irregularities in sectors such as property. A senior commerce ministry official stated that huge investments abroad are often made by firms with excessive debt. The official, Zhou Liujun, noted that overseas investment in the property sector has shown "unreasonable tendencies." The move aims to address risks and ensure transparency in foreign investments.

site_title: Yen breaks winning streak
summary: The yen halted its four-day advance, slipping 0.3% to 117.40 per dollar, as major financial markets reopened after a holiday weekend. Most other currencies were lower against the dollar, except for the Indonesian rupiah, which rose 0.2%. The dollar was near a 10-year high, and U.S. equities are trading near a record, driven by the Brexit vote and Donald Trump's presidency. Trading is expected to be thin this week due to market closures.

site_title: Singapore shares end session up 14.71 points, led by banking stocks rally
summary: Singapore shares ended Tuesday's session higher, rising 14.71 points to 2,885.76, led by a rally in banking stocks. Trading was thin with 601.1 million units valued at S$363.5 million. The rally was driven by gains from DBS, OCBC, and UOB, with gainers beating losers 188 to 174. The market showed resilience despite a lull in trading during the holiday period.

site_title: Brazil commercial real estate prices and lease values fall in Nov
summary: Brazil's commercial real estate prices and lease values have fallen in November, extending year-to-date losses to 3.18%. The FipeZap indicator showed a 0.45% drop in commercial property prices and a 0.35% decline in leases, with the largest drop recorded in Rio de Janeiro. The cities of São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Porto Alegre, and Belo Horizonte were surveyed. This contraction signals the sector's vulnerability to the country's recession.

site_title: China: Stocks edge down as investors shrug off profit data
summary: China's main stock indexes fell 0.2% on Tuesday, edging down from solid profit growth data for the industrial sector in November, which rose 14.5% year-over-year. Trading volume declined to nearly three-month lows, despite economic improvement signs. Shares of construction firms surged on hopes for infrastructure investment, while the property sector remained the best performer. Energy majors were dragged down by a 2% decline in futures contracts for coke.

site_title: JTC launches three industrial sites at Woodlands and Tuas
summary: JTC has launched three industrial sites at Woodlands and Tuas, as part of the government's efforts to offer more industrial development options. The sites include two Confirmed List sites (Woodlands Industrial Park E8/E7, Tuas South Link 3) and a Reserve List site (Tuas South Link 1), which are the final sites for the 2016 industrial government land sales programme. This move aims to provide more choices for industrial development and support the country's economic growth.

site_title: Spain's property market goes through the roof
summary: Spain's property market is experiencing a significant recovery, with home prices nearing pre-crisis levels in major cities. Construction firm La Casa por el Tejado is building new apartments on rooftops, a sign of the market's resurgence. Home prices, rents, and mortgages are surging, while hotel and resort prices are rising sharply. The market's revival has helped Spain become one of Europe's few economic success stories, with estimated growth of 3% next year. However, concerns remain that the market could slow if interest rates rise, particularly if the European Central Bank cuts its asset purchase program.

site_title: MOF, Acra propose changes to Companies Act; seek public consultation
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) have proposed changes to the Companies Act, Limited Liability Partnerships Act, and Accountants Act to reduce regulatory burden and improve ease of doing business. Key changes include exempting private companies from holding annual general meetings, removing common seal requirements, and requiring beneficial owners to maintain registers of beneficial owners. The amendments are open for public consultation until January 13, 2027, to enhance transparency of businesses and improve regulatory efficiency.

site_title: Fund managers bullish on emerging markets, ratings agencies less keen
summary: Fund managers are optimistic about emerging markets in 2017, despite the sector's 7% decline since the US election. They believe the US's protectionist policies and restricted immigration will harm most emerging markets, but see potential for rebound in sectors such as healthcare and retail. However, credit rating agencies like S&P Global and Moody's have downgraded their outlooks, citing concerns over geopolitical risk and energy companies' ability to adjust to lower oil prices.

site_title: Land acquisition for KL-Singapore high speed rail likely late next year
summary: Land acquisition for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail project is likely to take place by the third quarter of 2027, following the public display of the alignment plan by mid-2027. MyHSR Corporation Sdn Bhd oversees the bilateral project, spanning 350km with 335km within Malaysian territory. The project aims to bridge Kuala Lumpur with Singapore's Jurong East via a pair of rail tracks.

site_title: Shanghai: Shares slightly lower in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares opened slightly lower on Tuesday morning, with the Shanghai Composite Index slipping 0.17% to 3,117.39, and the Shenzhen Composite Index edging down 0.03% to 1,977.68. Investors remained cautious near the year-end, citing concerns over the US-China trade tensions. Hong Kong markets were closed for a holiday.

site_title: Indonesia court to proceed with blasphemy trial of Jakarta's governor
summary: An Indonesian court has decided to proceed with a blasphemy trial against Jakarta's Christian governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, who is accused of insulting the Koran. A panel of judges rejected a defense call to strike down the case due to human rights and procedural violations. Purnama denied the charges in the first hearing, and the case is seen as a test of religious freedom in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim-majority nation.

site_title: S Korea household debt burden threatens vulnerable households as yields rise
summary: South Korea's central bank warned that vulnerable households face default risks due to rising interest rates and a delay in economic recovery. The Bank of Korea reported that 6.4% of borrowers will struggle with debt repayment when interest rates increase, with those in low-income baskets and low-credit groups most at risk. Household debt has risen 11.2% to 1,295.8 trillion won, with the debt-to-disposable income ratio reaching 151.1%. The warning comes as US interest rates are expected to rise in 2017, causing bond yield spikes in emerging economies.

site_title: China's central bank proposes tighter rules for car loans
summary: China's central bank has proposed tighter rules for car loans, aiming to standardize criteria and address concerns over borrower defaults. The guidelines, issued on Dec 27, require lenders to establish a credit rating system and use independent external credit rating facilities to assess borrowers' creditworthiness. The move follows a surge in car loan financing, with nearly 30% of purchases made on credit last year, up from 20% in 2013. The guidelines will be open for public feedback until Jan 27.

site_title: Trump calls UN 'a club for people' to 'have a good time'
summary: President-elect Donald Trump criticized the United Nations as "a club for people to get together, talk and have a good time" after the UN adopted a resolution calling on Israel to halt Jewish settlement activity. Trump, who will assume the presidency on January 20th, hinted he would challenge the institution's approach to the Middle East. This criticism comes after President Barack Obama abstained from voting on the resolution, citing concerns about undermining a two-state solution. Trump's comments signal he will likely challenge the UN's approach to global issues, despite the organization's continued role in delivering humanitarian assistance and brokering cease-fires.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks mostly flat in thin trade
summary: Taiwan's stocks were largely flat on Tuesday in light trading ahead of the year-end, with the main Taiex index unchanged at 9,114.04 points. The electronics subindex rose 0.1%, while the financials subindex lost 0.4%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$32.269 per US dollar, trading at its lowest since early July.

site_title: South Korea Dec exports seen up for 2nd month, Nov output rebounding: poll
summary: South Korea's exports are expected to rise 6.4% in December, the second consecutive month of growth, driven by rising commodity prices and global demand. This follows a 2.5% increase in November, the first gain since August. Policymakers are optimistic about the trend, with the trade minister predicting the first quarterly rise in exports in two years. However, protectionist policies and financial instability in China pose risks, and imports are forecast to rise 6.8% in December.

images.alt_text: South Korea's exports are expected to have risen for a second straight month in December, a Reuters poll showed on Tuesday, on rising commodity prices and as global demand picks up.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends nearly flat in thin trade
summary: Japanese stocks were nearly flat on Tuesday in thin trade, with the Nikkei ending 0.03% higher at 19,403.06. Toshiba Corp plummeted 12% after considering a goodwill impairment loss. The broader Topix fell 0.1% to 1,536.22, and the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 dropped 0.1% to 13,775.68. Thin trade volume of 1.749 billion shares compared to a 30-day average of 2.375 billion shares.

site_title: Australia's Uluru reopens after rains turned rock into cascading waterfalls
summary: Uluru, also known as Ayers Rock, reopened in Australia's Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park after record-breaking summer rains transformed the monolith into cascading waterfalls. The park was closed on Christmas Day and Monday due to heavy rain and flash flooding, but reopened on Tuesday. The unusual weather turned the desert area into a scenic sight, offering a rare respite from the usual scorching heatwaves.

site_title: China's Nov industrial profits rise 14.5% y-o-y
summary: China's industrial profits rose 14.5% year-over-year in November, firming from October's 9.8%. This marks the second consecutive month of growth, with profits increasing 9.4% in the first 11 months compared to the same period last year. The data covers large enterprises with annual revenues over 20 million yuan.

site_title: 'Rogue One' pads Disney's record year with second weekend win
summary: "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" won the second consecutive weekend at the US and Canadian box office with $96.1 million in sales, beating new releases including "Sing," "Passengers," and "Why Him?" The film's success contributes to Disney's record-breaking year, which has topped $7 billion in global ticket sales. "Rogue One" is the latest installment in the Star Wars series, a prequel to the original 1977 film, and is part of a planned six-film series.

site_title: Yuan trading volume soars in sign of December outflow pressures
summary: The onshore yuan's trading volume surged to $34 billion in December, the highest since 2014, as capital fled China at a faster pace. This signals deteriorating sentiment since November, when foreign-exchange reserves shrank by the most since January. The yuan is headed for its steepest annual slump in over two decades, with authorities facing a triple whammy of renewed US$50,000 conversion quota, potential interest-rate increases, and US tariffs. Policy makers have set stronger-than-expected fixings and tightened capital controls to prevent a vicious cycle of depreciation and fund exodus.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday morning, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.07% to 19,382.98 and the Topix index losing 0.11% to 1,536.52. The decline follows the global market's gradual return after the holiday break.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed in muted session, US dollar recovers some losses
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Tuesday in thin trade, with Japan's Nikkei rising 0.3% and China's CSI 300 index little changed. The US dollar recovered some losses, driven by a 0.3% gain to 117.39 yen. European stocks were little changed, while the US 10-year Treasury yield extended gains by almost 1% on Tuesday. Consumer spending in the US showed modest growth in November, but the slowdown is likely temporary due to low unemployment, rising house prices, and a strong stock market.

site_title: Foreland takes legal action against former executive chairman over possible breaches
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings is taking legal action against former executive chairman Tsoi Kin Chit over possible breaches related to securities laws and public reprimand by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The breaches occurred after the SGX publicly reprimanded Foreland and Mr Tsoi for failing to promptly announce a significant claim and implementing internal controls. Foreland has also lodged a complaint with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) against Mr Tsoi. The company has requested an immediate suspension of its shares due to the uncertainty surrounding the legal actions.

images.alt_text: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings said on Tuesday that it is in the process of engaging legal advisers to take further action against its former executive chairman, Tsoi Kin Chit (pictured), over possible breaches.

site_title: Smartphone-obsessed Finns rank tops in screen time
summary: Finland ranks top in screen time among 32 European and Asian countries, with Finns using nearly twice as much mobile data as South Koreans in the first half of 2016. The country's low-cost subscription plans and affordable internet connections contribute to this trend. Authorities have launched campaigns to address concerns about excessive smartphone usage, particularly among parents, who are often glued to their screens instead of interacting with their children. Experts attribute Finland's love of smartphones to its culture of adopting new technology, introverted nature, and the need for reliable infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Finland, once a world leader in mobile telephony with Nokia, is in a class of its own when it comes to internet usage on smartphones and tablets, thanks to cheap subscription plans.

site_title: Equation Summit issues redeemable convertible bonds, undertakes capital reduction exercise
summary: Equation Summit has announced plans to issue redeemable convertible bonds worth S$12 million, undertake a capital reduction exercise of S$135.6 million, and consolidate existing shares. The company also signed a non-binding letter of intent to sell four entities to Bronze Holdings. Following these announcements, Equation Summit has filed a request to lift a trading halt on its shares.

site_title: Super Mario run no longer highest grossing app
summary: Nintendo's Super Mario Run has lost its position as the highest-grossing app, with the title no longer ranking first in any country as of December 24, according to App Annie. The game's price point, requiring a $10 fee to progress beyond the first three levels, has been a point of criticism from fans. Analysts estimate that lowering the price to $2 could increase revenue by $20 million, sparking hopes that Nintendo's mobile strategy can be salvaged. Nintendo shares rose 4.8% on Monday following the news.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip in early trading
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.33% in early trading, with the Straits Times Index falling to 2,861.57. Losers outnumbered gainers 54 to 42, with SingTel and DBS Group Holdings contributing to the decline. 66.4 million shares worth S$25.2 million changed hands.

site_title: Blindsided by SUV boom, Hyundai Motor trims costs, perks
summary: Hyundai Motor is trimming costs amid a fourth consecutive annual profit decline. The company is scaling back on business class flights, family home trips, and printing costs, aiming to buy time to prepare new models and a design revamp. Executives have taken a 10% pay cut, and the number of executives has risen 44% in five years. Hyundai is also encouraging video conferencing as a cheaper alternative to travel. The company's costs as a proportion of revenue have risen for five straight years, with a current ratio of 81%.

site_title: GIC acquires 10% stake in HERE with NavInfo, Tencent
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, along with Chinese companies NavInfo and Tencent, will jointly acquire a 10% stake in HERE, an Open Location Platform company. The deal is expected to be completed in the first half of 2017, subject to regulatory approvals. HERE's indirect shareholders, Audi, BMW, and Daimler, will reduce their stake equally. The partnership aims to expand HERE's global presence and develop its Highly Automated Driving Map, with plans for a 50:50 joint venture with NavInfo in China.

site_title: US dollar inches up vs yen, euro holds to modest gains
summary: The US dollar inched up 0.1% against the yen to 117.230 yen, while the euro remained steady at US$1.0453. The US currency had surged 10% against the yen since Trump's election win, but some expect a deeper downward correction due to concerns over his protectionist policies and potential inflation. The US dollar index was little changed at 102.970, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars also declined against the US dollar.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 1.94 points to 1,619.09. Volume was 81.5 million lots worth RM24.2 million, with 88 gainers outnumbering 68 losers.

site_title: Parts of crashed Russian plane found in Black Sea
summary: Russian rescuers have found the first parts of a crashed Tu-154 military plane in the Black Sea, off the coast of Sochi, where it went down on Sunday with all 92 people on board. The plane was headed to Russia's military base in Syria. Officials have dismissed terrorism as a possible cause of the crash, instead investigating pilot error, technical faults, bad fuel, and foreign objects in the engine. A massive search operation involving 45 vessels, planes, and drones is ongoing, with over 3,000 people involved in recovering the remaining bodies and debris.

site_title: Seoul: Won steps down on firm US dollar; stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won dropped 0.4% to 1,205.9 against the US dollar, as investor sentiment cooled ahead of the new year. The won's movement is expected to be influenced by the dollar's performance. South Korean shares rose 0.2% with the Kospi index at 2,041.32 points, driven by a 5% gain in Cheil Worldwide Inc's shares. Offshore investors purchased 31.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Oil gains post-Christmas ahead of Opec, non-Opec cuts
summary: US oil prices rose 16 cents to $53.18 a barrel on Tuesday, amid expectations of Opec and non-Opec output cuts starting January 1 to support oil prices. Oil markets were boosted by Libya's potential increase in production and the US Department of Energy's plans to release emergency oil reserves. Hedge funds also increased bullish bets on US crude oil for the third consecutive week. Oil prices are expected to remain supported by the output cuts, with Libya's production potentially adding 270,000 barrels per day within three months.

site_title: Sailing-leader Wild Oats XI drops out of Sydney-Hobart race
summary: Australian super maxi Wild Oats XI dropped out of the Sydney to Hobart yacht race due to a broken hydraulic ram. The race leader had commanded a steady lead at the end of the first day, but was forced to retire approximately 20 hours into the treacherous race. Perpetual Loyal took the lead, with the leaders expected to finish in Hobart on Wednesday. Wild Oats XI's retirement is its second consecutive, following a similar issue last year, and marks a disappointing end to the race for skipper Mark Richards.

site_title: Lum Chang unit sells London hotel
summary: Lum Chang Holdings sold its London hotel, 52-57 Princes Square, for £13.78 million (S$24.47 million) after agreeing to sell 11.4 million shares in Pembridge Palace Holdco. The sale is expected to generate a net gain of £2.6 million. The proceeds will be used to fund future investments. This marks an opportunity for Lum Chang to "realise its investments" and is seen as a strategic move to allocate resources efficiently.

images.alt_text: Lum Chang Holdings said on Tuesday that its subsidiary has sold a hotel located at 52 to 57 Princes Square, London, for £13.78 million (about S$24.47 million).

site_title: Toshiba shares fall 10% on nuclear business loss reports
summary: Toshiba shares plummeted 10% on Tuesday following reports of a significant loss in its US nuclear power operations, estimated to be around 100-500 billion yen. The company's shares traded at 397.10 yen, down from an earlier loss of 16.3%. The loss is attributed to Toshiba's struggling nuclear business, which has faced financial difficulties in recent years.

site_title: CCTV confirms Berlin attacker transited France: probe source
summary: Surveillance footage confirms Anis Amri, the suspected Berlin truck attacker, transited through Lyon, France by train on December 22, wearing a cap and backpack. Investigators are trying to determine how Amri left Germany and reached France and Italy. Amri was gunned down by Italian police in Milan after a four-day Europe-wide manhunt. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the Berlin rampage, which killed 12 people. German authorities are probing possible help from others before or after the attack, with hundreds of investigators working on the case during the holiday season.

site_title: Korean Air to get tougher on unruly passengers and ease stun gun rules
summary: Korean Air Lines has announced plans to increase security measures against unruly passengers. The airline will allow crew members to use stun guns to manage in-flight disturbances, following criticism from US singer Richard Marx over its handling of a violent incident. The carrier will also enhance security training for crew members. This move comes after Marx accused Korean Air crew of being "ill-trained" and "ill-equipped" to handle the situation. The changes aim to improve safety and security on flights.

images.alt_text: Korean Air Lines said it will allow crew members to "readily use stun guns" to manage in-flight disturbances, after coming in for criticism from US singer Richard Marx for its handling of an incident involving a violent passenger.

site_title: Japan consumer prices, household spending slump in November
summary: Japan's core consumer prices declined 0.4% in November for the ninth consecutive month, missing the central bank's 2% inflation target. Household spending also fell 1.5% for the ninth straight month, driven by slow wage growth. Japan's economy expanded for the third quarter in a row, but exports and factory output have recently shown signs of life due to a pick-up in global demand. The Bank of Japan reiterated its ultra-loose policy, indicating it will not raise interest rates until inflation reaches its target.

site_title: GLP secures Sagamihara site in Greater Tokyo
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) secures a 655,000 sqm site in Sagamihara, Greater Tokyo, Japan, for a total investment of 133 billion yen (S$1.6 billion). The project is expected to start in 2020, with a leasing pipeline strong enough to complement GLP's existing portfolio in the region. The site's layout flexibility will cater to various customer segments, including cold storage, manufacturing, and research and development, making Sagamihara a major logistics hub in metropolitan Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has secured a site in Sagamihara, Greater Tokyo, which it plans to develop over 655,000 square metre of gross floor area at a total investment cost of 133 billion yen (S$1.6 billion).

site_title: George Michael dies at 53
summary: British pop star George Michael, known for his hits like "Last Christmas" and "Careless Whisper," has died at 53, according to his publicist. Thames Valley Police confirmed his death, treating it as unexplained but not suspicious. Tributes poured in from the music world and beyond, with Elton John, Duran Duran, and Bryan Adams among those paying tribute to Michael's talent and kindness.

site_title: Stocks to watch: S-Reits, Global Logistic Properties, Global Yellow Pages, Equation Summit
summary: Shares of S-Reits may be a defensive yield play amid sector volatility, following growing uncertainty and slowing growth in major economies. Global Logistic Properties secured a site in Tokyo to develop 655,000 square meters of gross floor area at a total investment cost of 133 billion yen (S$1.6 billion).

site_title: Digital disruption a friend, not a foe, to furniture industry
summary: The Singapore Furniture Industries Council (SFIC) is embracing digital disruption, viewing it as a complement to its future strategies. The council is exploring mobile and e-commerce, virtual and augmented reality, and 3D printing to enhance its members' businesses. New president Mark Yong aims to create a virtual platform for members to market their products, reduce costs, and increase brand trust. He also plans to expand the council's membership to emerging markets, including South-east Asia, and rejuvenate the industry with younger members.

site_title: French jobless total falls for third straight month in November
summary: France's unemployment rate fell to its lowest point in almost four years in November, with 3,447,000 people registered as unemployed, down 0.9% from October and 3.4% from November 2015. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, with Labour Minister Myriam El Khomri describing the drop as "significant." The November jobless numbers come after eight years of rising unemployment, which contributed to President Francois Hollande's unpopularity and led him to decide not to seek re-election in next year's presidential election.

site_title: South Korea Dec consumer sentiment drops to lowest in 7-1/2 years
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment has dropped to its lowest level in 7-1/2 years, according to a central bank survey. The composite consumer sentiment index fell to 94.2 in December from 95.8 in November, indicating pessimists outnumber optimists about economic conditions. Fears of policy paralysis and a constitutional court review of President Park Geun-Hye's impeachment are contributing factors. The lowest reading since April 2009, it marks a further decline from November.

site_title: Chinese carrier enters South China Sea amid renewed tension
summary: China's sole aircraft carrier, the Liaoning, led by a group of warships entered the South China Sea amid renewed tension, particularly with Taiwan, following US President-elect Donald Trump's telephone call with the island's president. The carrier passed south of Taiwan and entered the top half of the South China Sea, sparking concerns over China's military modernization. China claims the South China Sea and has been conducting military exercises, including long-range drills above the sea. The US has expressed concerns, stating its position remains unchanged, while China says the carrier's movements are within international law.

site_title: Britney Spears isn't dead: Sony says Twitter account compromised
summary: Sony Music Entertainment apologized to Britney Spears and her fans after its Twitter account was hacked, falsely reporting the pop star's death. The tweets, which included "RIP @britneyspears #RIPBritney 1981-2016," were later deleted. The incident occurred two years after a major cyber-attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, which was blamed on North Korean hackers. Sony Music stated the issue has been rectified, and they apologized for any confusion caused to Spears and her fans.

site_title: George Michael: 10 key songs by a hit-making machine
summary: George Michael left an indelible mark on the 1980s and 1990s with his iconic hits, including "Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go," "Last Christmas," "Careless Whisper," and "Faith." The British pop icon released numerous era-defining songs, such as "I Want Your Sex," "One More Try," and "Freedom! '90." Michael's music continued to inspire artists, with covers by Coldplay, Kylie Minogue, and Taylor Swift. He passed away on Christmas Day at 53, leaving behind a legacy of timeless hits.

site_title: Abu Dhabi bourse to introduce short-selling in first quarter 2017: CEO
summary: Abu Dhabi's stock market, Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange (ADX), plans to introduce covered short-selling in the first quarter of 2017 to boost liquidity and attract foreign investors. Covered short-selling involves borrowing shares and selling them in expectation of repurchasing them later at a lower price. The move comes after the UAE market regulator approved rules on short-selling, following similar introductions in Saudi Arabia and Qatar. ADX aims to diversify investment instruments and increase liquidity to match global markets, with rules in place to reduce risks surrounding short-selling.

site_title: Europe's 'FDA' in limbo as hidden costs of Brexit continue to mount
summary: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) is facing uncertainty due to the UK's decision to leave the European Union (EU) through Brexit. The agency, which oversees the approval of drugs across Europe, is likely to relocate to another EU city, potentially leading to staff shortages and public safety concerns. The relocation could result in up to half of the agency's 890 staff members leaving, impacting the approval of new drugs and monitoring existing ones. Pharmaceutical companies and lawmakers are warning of potential disruptions to the UK's biotech and pharmaceutical sector, as well as increased costs for drug authorisations.

site_title: Peru president proposes dredging reservoir for gold
summary: Peru President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski proposed dredging Poechos, the country's largest reservoir, to extract gold, claiming it holds more gold than Peru's biggest gold mine, Yanacocha. The reservoir, a key water source for drinking and farming, could hold one gram of gold per cubic meter in 580 million cubic meters of sediment. Kuczynski proposed a 5-6 year extraction process, followed by a 20-year wait for the sediment to accumulate again. The proposal has sparked concerns and demands from farmers, who want to raise the reservoir's ridge to reduce sediment buildup.

site_title: China smog war moves to courts, with range of crimes to widen
summary: China's Supreme People's Court is expanding the definition of environmental crimes to prosecute polluters, particularly in northern Hebei province, which has been plagued by severe smog. The new rules allow prosecutors to focus on specific offenses such as tampering with sensor equipment or providing false emissions data, rather than the amount of pollution. This move aims to address public anger over pollution and enforcement laxity amid concerns about economic growth and jobs in Hebei.

site_title: Director buying rises again, buyback activity down
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show a rise in director buying for the second consecutive week, with 12 companies purchasing shares worth S$1.76 million. However, buyback activity decreased for the second week, with only nine companies repurchasing shares worth S$1.73 million. Notable director buys include mm2 Asia's CEO Ang Wee Chye purchasing 1.24 million shares, and ISEC Healthcare's CEO Wong Jun Shyan buying 25,000 shares. Substantial shareholders also made significant purchases, with Shanghai Industrial Holdings increasing its stake in SIIC Environment Holdings to 37.03%.

site_title: Brazil taps academic to lead microeconomic reforms: sources
summary: Brazil's government has appointed Joao Manoel Pinho de Mello, a professor at Insper, to lead microeconomic reforms aimed at boosting productivity. Finance Minister Henrique Meirelles invited Pinho de Mello to join his team, as part of a broader effort to stimulate the economy. The move is seen as a significant step towards implementing reforms, although details of the plan remain unclear. Pinho de Mello's appointment is part of a broader effort to revitalize the Brazilian economy, which has been struggling in recent years.

site_title: Fighting back: How Indonesia's elite police turned the tide on militants
summary: Indonesia's elite police unit has successfully foiled at least 15 attacks this year, making over 150 arrests and disrupting plots targeting the nation's capital and neighboring Singapore. The unit's unique, strategic approach to interrogations has aided in intelligence gathering, helping to stem a wave of bloody attacks by Islamist militants. The anti-terrorism efforts come as the world battles a spike in assaults and plots by militant groups. This marks a significant victory in the fight against terrorism in Indonesia, a Muslim-majority nation plagued by such threats.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages subsidiary gets approval to construct 225 houses in NZ
summary: Global Yellow Pages' subsidiary, The Remarkable Residences, has received approval to construct 225 houses in Queenstown, New Zealand. The approval, granted by Queenstown Lakes District Council on December 23, is subject to certain conditions. The project will not have a significant impact on the company's financials for the 2017 fiscal year. The construction will take place on a 38,400 square meter freehold land plot at Eastern Access Road.

site_title: A last-gasp push on the ST Index this week?
summary: Singapore stocks may experience a last-gasp push on the ST Index in the final days of 2016, with the odds of the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing above 20,000 for the first time in history higher than usual. This phenomenon, known as "year-end window-dressing," could see major blue chips like banks, Singtel, and Keppel Corp surge in performance. However, the market has been weak for the past 12 months, and 2017 forecasts are uncertain due to the Trump administration's economic stance towards China and Asia.

site_title: Latest cooling measures unlikely to work: HK property watchers
summary: Hong Kong's housing market remains plagued by troubles, with high prices and limited supply expected to take center stage during the March 2017 chief executive election. The city's land supply is less than 25% developed, leading to unaffordable housing and social unrest. Recent cooling measures, including a 15% stamp duty on residential purchases, may be too little, too late. Experts warn that loopholes in the policy allow wealthy buyers to skirt the higher stamp duty rate, and that the market's demand will continue to outstrip supply in the long term.

site_title: Japan beefs up defence spending with 5.1t yen budget for fiscal 2017
summary: Japan has approved a record 97.5 trillion yen budget for fiscal 2017, with a 2.6% increase in its defense budget to 5.1 trillion yen. This is the fifth consecutive year of defense budget increases, driven by perceived threats from China and North Korea. Japan is also expanding its arms sales to other countries, such as Thailand, to counter growing Chinese influence. The government has established a new agency to handle arms exports and has proposed increasing defense spending as a national strategy.

site_title: Chicago agricultural commodities close lower; NY cocoa rallies sharply
summary: Chicago agricultural commodities closed lower on Friday, extending losses ahead of the Christmas holiday. Corn and wheat futures fell 1.5 cents and 3.5 cents, respectively, while soybean prices dropped 6.5 cents. South American weather forecasts have boosted soybean harvest expectations, potentially increasing competition for US exports. Cocoa futures rallied sharply, with the March contract up 3.43% to $2,264 per tonne, as traders covered short positions ahead of the holiday.

site_title: Surge in tourists 'puts strain on Thailand's infrastructure'
summary: Thailand's tourism industry has put strain on its infrastructure, with bottlenecks building up in popular destinations like Chiang Mai, Bangkok, and Phuket. Despite a record 29.9 million visitors in 2015, the country's infrastructure still hasn't expanded to meet the demand. The World Bank economist Kiatipong Ariyapruchya warned that new destinations must be introduced and monitored closely to support sustainable tourism. The tourism ministry expects 32.4 million visitors this year, and airport congestion is a major issue, with plans to spend $5.5 billion over 15 years to expand six main airports.

site_title: Human smuggling: crime or service?
summary: Human smuggling, a crime in international law, poses a dilemma for governments as desperate migrants seek help from smugglers, garnering global sympathy. The smuggling of migrants generates an estimated $7 billion annually, primarily through two routes: Africa to Europe and South America to North America. While governments aim to prevent smuggling, the supply of potential migrants exceeds demand, and most migrants lack desired skills for legal immigration. Addressing root causes, such as economic imbalances and limited governance, is key to combating human smuggling, but this is a complex and challenging issue.

images.alt_text: While globally around 50 million people are estimated to be unauthorised migrants, many were not smuggled, but simply overstayed short-term visas.

site_title: China's growth "reassuring" for "weak and vulnerable" global economy: Xinhua
summary: China is expected to meet its 6.5-7% growth target for 2016, a reassuring sign for the "weak and vulnerable" global economy. Despite a "troublesome start" to the year, China's economy is expected to maintain stable growth in 2017, driven by external demand, deleveraging, and a slowly recovering property sector. However, the country still faces pressure from weak external demand and ongoing capacity-reduction efforts, which may impact growth in 2017.

images.alt_text: China will meet its growth target of 6.5 per cent to 7 per cent growth this year, a reassuring sign for a "weak and vulnerable" global economy, state news agency Xinhua said in a commentary on Monday.

site_title: Backpage.com hit with new criminal charges
summary: California Attorney General Kama-la Harris has filed new criminal charges against Backpage.com CEO Carl Ferrer and controlling shareholders Michael Lacey and James Larkin, accusing them of pimping and money laundering. The charges include 26 counts of money laundering and 13 counts of pimping and conspiracy. The allegations revive a case previously dismissed by a judge, and the charges are seen as significant in a case that has faced scrutiny over allegations of sex trafficking.

site_title: Startups hope to shake up the US$17b moving industry in US
summary: US startups are entering the $17 billion moving industry with new technology and on-demand services, aiming to disrupt traditional companies. Adam Pittenger, who has moved six times in six years, started a company called Moved to help make moving less of a chore. Other companies are also innovating with on-demand services and technology, as consumers increasingly prefer to conduct business online.

site_title: 3 US energy firms to start 2017 with bankruptcy
summary: Three US energy firms, Forbes Energy Services, Bonanza Creek Energy, and Memorial Production Partners, plan to file for bankruptcy in 2017, citing unsustainable debt from the 2014-2016 oil price plunge. Bonanza and Memorial will give shareholders some recovery, while Forbes will allocate nothing to shareholders. About 24 US companies filed for bankruptcy in 2016, impacting $47 billion in debt. Industry experts blame the companies' failure to prepare for low oil prices, with prices now around $50 a barrel.

site_title: Amazon starts flexing muscle in new space: air cargo
summary: Amazon has expanded its air cargo service, Prime Air, with 40 leased planes, flying nearly full but with lightweight loads, to meet growing delivery demand from its 35-50 million US Prime members. The service is helping Amazon dodge rising shipping fees by sending its own big, light packages, and operating flights late at night to speed up delivery. By flying to remote locations and avoiding airport hubs, Amazon is cutting shipping times and costs, with experts predicting the need for more planes to meet growing demand.

site_title: Experience of virtual home, thanks to local furniture player Commune
summary: Singapore-based furniture company Koda introduced virtual reality (VR) and 3D-planning services at its retail store, allowing customers to experience and design their dream homes before making a purchase. The technology, available at all Koda stores starting January 2024, uses VR headsets and controllers to transport customers into a virtual environment where they can interact with and customize furniture and spaces. This innovative approach aims to simplify the home renovation process and enhance the customer experience.

images.alt_text: The writer, a Business Times journalist, tries out virtual reality for an immersive experience of a small, furnished apartment at Commune Experience Centre.

site_title: US online dating sites looking to refresh themselves
summary: US online dating sites are seeking to refresh themselves amid declining revenues and increasing competition. Spark Networks, which owns JDate and ChristianMingle, has faced management turnover and a 22% revenue decline since 2014. The company has sold 16% of its stock and closed its Israel office, but plans to modernize technology and focus on its two best-known sites. Despite a 70% market share of the Jewish population, paid subscribers have declined, and the industry faces challenges such as the shift to mobile devices and changing consumer preferences.

site_title: The growing quest for hygge culture
summary: Hygge, a Danish concept of coziness, has gained popularity worldwide, with numerous books and articles on the subject. According to Meik Wiking, founder of the Happiness Institute, hygge is a national obsession in Denmark, characterized by homespun pleasures like candlelight, fires, and social connections. The concept is linked to Denmark's high happiness ratings, with experts attributing it to the country's emphasis on home life, low expectations, and community. Books like "The Little Book of Hygge" and "How to Hygge" are part of the growing lifestyle category, with authors offering recipes, furniture, and meditative approaches to achieving hygge.

site_title: China and Sao Tome restore diplomatic ties
summary: China and Sao Tome and Principe have restored diplomatic ties, following Sao Tome and Principe's decision to cut ties with Taiwan. The agreement was signed by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi and Sao Tome and Principe's counterpart Urbino Botelho on December 26, 2016. This move comes amid heightened tensions between Beijing and Taiwan, which Chinese leaders view as a "renegade province". The restored relations mark a significant shift in Sao Tome and Principe's diplomatic landscape.

site_title: Synergraphics' 30-year glass act
summary: Florence Ng, founder of Synergraphics, a 30-year-old glass art company in Singapore, has scaled the heights of producing works of art. She began with a small studio and $500, employing two people, and has since grown to a company of 30, operating out of a landed terraced factory space. Ng's success is attributed to her passion, open-mindedness, and ability to break boundaries. She has worked with various clients, including hotels and office buildings, and has introduced functional art by combining glass with lighting features, mirrors, and glass partitions. Ng's daughter, Sara, has joined the company and is now executive director, helping to take over business functions and allowing Ng to focus on her art.

site_title: Small businesses a great fit for the new nimble marketplace
summary: E-commerce continues to rise, with 85% of online shoppers starting and finishing their purchase on different devices. Small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly successful due to their agility and personal approach to customer engagement. As e-commerce grows, SMEs must optimize marketing, sales, and delivery strategies to meet consumer needs. Investing in e-commerce capabilities can lead to competitive advantages and global growth. Globally, m-commerce accounts for 35% of retail e-commerce transactions and is projected to rise to 47% by 2018.

site_title: Analysts give cautious forecast after a rough 2016 (Amended)
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to remain cautious in 2017 due to global uncertainty, including the US Federal Reserve's interest rate moves and rising trade tensions. Despite a modest recovery in the third quarter of 2016, the economy grew at 1.4% year-on-year, with retail sales and exports experiencing declines. Analysts forecast flat growth or a slight drop in 2017, with some predicting a better outlook in 2018 due to a new chief executive and potential reforms to boost the retail industry.

site_title: Fox News stays resilient in a year of challenges
summary: Fox News remains a resilient network despite a challenging year, including an internal crisis and competition from CNN. The network's prime-time audience declined 14% in the weeks following the US election, but it still leads CNN and MSNBC in the 25-54-year-old demographic. Fox News' Tucker Carlson Tonight has become a top-rated show, averaging 2.9 million viewers per night. The network faces challenges, including the expiration of contracts for big stars Bill O'Reilly and Megyn Kelly, but its ability to attract and retain viewers suggests it will continue to thrive.

site_title: Savings app Upside pits gas stations against one another
summary: A new 13-person company, Upside, is launching a savings app that pits gas stations against each other, offering users discounts on petrol prices. By negotiating with individual stations and posting prices on a map, Upside aims to reinvent the gas market. The app makes money by keeping a small portion of the savings, and 650 gas stations in the DC area, Maryland, and Virginia have already signed up. This approach exploits a quirk in how gas stations compete for customers, reducing the likelihood of price wars.

site_title: Why Barclays opted for war when JPMorgan chose surrender
summary: Barclays is facing a multi-billion-dollar settlement with the US over allegations of deceptive mortgage-backed securities sales a decade ago. The bank, led by CEO Jes Staley, rejected government accusations, citing "disconnected facts." Barclays initially offered a $2 billion settlement, but the US is seeking $5 billion. Staley's decision to hold firm may be influenced by the success of JPMorgan Chase's similar settlement in 2013, which was seen as a negotiating tactic. The outcome could impact Barclays' efforts to refocus on core markets and overcome £20 billion of misconduct charges.

site_title: Pro wrestling meets formidable challenges in China
summary: World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) has launched a new service live-streaming Chinese-language matches and commentary to tap into the country's 1.4 billion population. Despite challenges posed by the government's tight controls over media and the unfamiliarity of US-style wrestling, WWE aims to introduce Chinese audiences to the sport through digital platforms and local talent. The company has hired four social media directors in Shanghai and is hosting viewing parties to promote its brand. WWE's first mainland wrestler, Wang Bin, has gained popularity on social media, and seven other mainlanders will relocate to Orlando for training.

site_title: Chinese warships, aircraft carrier enter South China Sea
summary: Chinese warships, led by the sole aircraft carrier Liaoning, entered the South China Sea on Monday after passing south of Taiwan, sparking renewed tension over the disputed territory. The move comes amid heightened US-China relations following President-elect Donald Trump's phone call with Taiwan's president. China claims the South China Sea, which handles $5 trillion in ship-borne trade, and has been conducting military exercises in the area, including long-range drills and the deployment of submarines. Beijing asserts its right to freedom of navigation and overflight, as set by international law.

site_title: 2017 economic outlook: welcome to the jungle
summary: The 2017 economic outlook is expected to be volatile, with a mix of risks and opportunities. The US election of Donald Trump is anticipated to lead to fiscal expansion, boosting the US economy and potentially the global economy. However, this may not translate to global benefits, as other countries may not follow suit. Tightening financial conditions in the US could dampen growth, particularly in emerging markets, and the euro may come under pressure against the US dollar. Emerging markets' currencies and financial vulnerability are likely to increase amid interest rate hikes and a steeper US Treasury curve.

site_title: Business can gain more from sustainable development
summary: Businesses can gain from sustainable development by partnering across industries, working with non-governmental organizations, and collaborating with the public sector. Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the moral obligation of businesses to ensure responsible growth. Research shows that investment in agriculture is more effective in enhancing income for the region's poorest people, but declining resources pose a challenge. Companies are committing to the Good Growth Plan, a series of commitments to improve resource efficiency and support rural communities. Sustainable value chains can help farmers, particularly smallholders, and ensure profitable and responsible farming practices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sabana Reit plans to lower the conversion price of its 4.5% convertible sukuk due 2017 if a planned S$80.2 million rights issue is completed, with the conversion price adjusted to S$0.8628 per unit from S$1.0131 per unit. The rights issue, aimed at funding the acquisition of three properties in Singapore, will issue over 310.7 million new units. International Healthway Corp has postponed its extraordinary general meeting by a month to Jan 23, 2017, after concluding that its previous announcement gave shareholders insufficient notice.

site_title: European populism and Trumpist populism: real vs phony?
summary: US President Donald Trump's emerging policy agenda is vastly different from the benefits provided by European far-right movements, which have implemented policies such as mortgage relief and increased child benefits. Trump's proposals aim to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, privatize Medicare, and cut Social Security benefits, resulting in huge losses for the middle class and the white working class that supported him. Critics warn of a "betrayal of supporters" and a "scam sold to working-class voters," with potential efforts to distract the public and shift blame to minorities.

site_title: Indonesia marks tsunami 12 years ago with prayers
summary: Indonesia marked the 12th anniversary of the devastating 2004 tsunami that killed approximately 220,000 people, with thousands gathering at mass graves and mosques to pray for their loved ones. The disaster, triggered by a 9.1-magnitude earthquake, also caused widespread destruction in coastal areas, including Somalia. The commemoration aimed to remind the public of the need to prepare for future disasters, coming weeks after a recent earthquake in Aceh province.

site_title: China cancer patients turn to unapproved drugs on grey market
summary: In China, many cancer patients are turning to unapproved, grey market drugs due to the country's high drug prices and limited access to newer treatments. Two-thirds of 30 cancer patients interviewed reported buying generic or counterfeit drugs from online pharmacies or agents, often at a fraction of the cost of approved drugs. The lack of official data on this practice, combined with a five-to-10 year delay in regulatory approvals, contributes to the issue. Patients are willing to take risks, including legal consequences, to access affordable treatment options.

site_title: MacBook Pro buyers freaking out about battery life may want to try this tip
summary: Consumer Reports has given its new MacBook Pro laptops a mixed review, citing inconsistent battery life issues, with some models lasting up to 10 hours and others barely 3.45 hours. The publication found that using a non-Apple browser, such as Google Chrome, improved battery life, but this does not explain the inconsistent results. The review highlights battery life problems with the 13-inch and 15-inch models with the Touch Bar control strip. Apple has responded by removing the "time remaining" feature from the battery indicator, stating that estimates can be inaccurate.

site_title: Taiwan gets closer to legalising same-sex marriage
summary: Taiwan's Parliament passed the first draft of a marriage equality bill, moving the island closer to becoming the first place in Asia to legalize same-sex marriage. The bill, proposed by Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Yu Mei-nu, requires further vetting before it can take effect. Despite opposition from protesters, lawmakers hailed the decision as an example of Taiwan's "mature democracy." The process is expected to take around six months, with President Tsai Ing-wen's support for same-sex marriage contributing to the momentum.

site_title: In a world of computing cloud domination
summary: Big cloud companies like Amazon, Microsoft, and Google are expanding their reach, aiming to control the US$1 trillion global market for business computers and software. Amazon's AWS division is increasingly entangled with mobile phones, sensors, and other devices, known as the Internet of Things. The companies are putting cloud components in mobile computing, home games, and e-mail marketing campaigns, seeking to be everywhere. This trend has profound consequences, including cheaper designs and lower prices for computing, potentially affecting devices themselves. The competition is intensifying, with the big cloud companies investing heavily in global networks and local devices.

site_title: Beijing to step up measures to cool market for homes
summary: Beijing plans to step up property controls to keep home prices stable, citing rising social tensions and speculators. Average new home prices in Beijing rose 26.4% in November, prompting measures to curb speculation. The city will require higher downpayments on property purchases and impose strict limits on credit flowing into speculative buying in the property market in 2017. This follows similar measures taken by over a dozen Chinese cities to curb speculation and stabilize the market.

site_title: US-China ties: No need to challenge the status quo on Taiwan
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has indicated a tougher stance on China, vowing to put pressure on Beijing over trade and potentially reassessing the diplomatic status quo in Taiwan. Trump's appointment of China trade sceptic Peter Navarro as White House National Trade Council head demonstrates a commitment to confront Beijing on the geo-economic front. However, challenging the current understanding between Washington and Beijing over Taiwan could lead to instability and disrupt cooperation on policy issues, benefiting both sides. The one China policy has provided a foundation for peaceful coexistence and strengthened diplomatic and economic ties for nearly four decades.

site_title: Value investors see opportunity in HK
summary: Value investors in Singapore are shifting their focus to Hong Kong's stock exchange, driven by the latter's relatively weaker small-cap stocks, which have fallen 12% in the year to Dec 22. This trend contrasts with the 1% decline of the Hang Seng Index.

site_title: Sales of new US homes rise to second-fastest pace since 2008
summary: US new home sales rose 5.2% in November to a 592,000 annualized pace, the second-fastest pace since 2008. This surge was driven by buyers signing contracts amid rising mortgage rates, which reached 4.3% in December. The Midwest saw the largest gain, while the West experienced its fastest pace in nearly nine years. Despite the increase, the supply of homes fell to 5.1 months, and median sales prices decreased 3.7% from November 2015.

site_title: China's outward investment seen hitting 1.12t yuan in 2016
summary: China's non-financial outbound direct investment (ODI) is expected to reach 1.12 trillion yuan ($233.29 billion) in 2016, surpassing foreign direct investment (FDI) into the country, which totals 785 billion yuan. Commerce Minister Gao Hucheng attributed the growth to local firms investing abroad amid a slowing economy and weakening yuan. The government plans to promote "healthy and orderly development" of ODI in 2017, while reducing restrictions on foreign investment access. This year, ODI is projected to surpass FDI by 335 billion yuan, amid capital outflow concerns.

site_title: Deutsche Bank reassures staff of strength after US settlement
summary: Deutsche Bank has reached a US$7.2 billion settlement with US regulators over toxic sub-prime debt, reassuring staff of its financial strength. The lender found no evidence of a breach of sanctions against Russia and expects to pay coupons on all debt instruments. The settlement, which was half the initial demand of US$14 billion, is expected to ease concerns over the bank's credit risk, with its shares rising and perceptions of its credit risk easing.

site_title: Selling Trump's hotel to end conflicts of interest may mean loss
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's Washington hotel, which he owns through a limited liability company, could face significant financial losses if sold due to high costs of redevelopment. The Trump Organization spent $212 million to renovate the hotel, and potential buyers would need to pay around $806,100 per room to recoup their investment. The hotel's lease from the federal government and Trump's ownership through his children make it challenging to divest, raising concerns about conflicts of interest and potential criticism.

site_title: Bursa Malaysia set to end in negative territory for third year
summary: Bursa Malaysia's benchmark FBMKLCI is likely to finish the year in negative territory for the third consecutive year, with only 11 IPOs raising under RM600 million this year. The lack of big-ticket IPOs is attributed to "liquidity drying up" and poor investor sentiment stemming from the 1MDB scandal. Despite this, some companies are still interested in going public, including larger ones such as port operator MMC and QSR Brands. The market outlook remains unflattering, with a severe downturn in global trade posing a significant risk to export-dependent Malaysia.

site_title: Christmas typhoon leaves four dead, eight missing in Philippines
summary: A powerful typhoon, Nock-Ten, left at least four people dead and eight missing in the Philippines as it crossed the archipelago on Christmas Day, causing strong winds, heavy rains, and destructive flooding. The storm ravaged the Bicol region and surrounding areas, forcing over 383,000 people to flee their homes and canceling over 80 domestic and international flights. The typhoon's impact marred traditional Christmas celebrations in the country, with many homes and farms flooded and electricity cut off to millions.

images.alt_text: Nock-Ten made landfall on the eastern island province of Catanduanes with gusts of 235 kmh on Christmas Day, ravaging the Bicol region and surrounding areas.

site_title: Cocoa a bittersweet cash crop for Madagascar
summary: In Madagascar, cocoa is a valuable yet bittersweet cash crop, with the prized Criollo variety earning the country a reputation for high-quality cocoa. Despite an annual production of 7,000 tonnes, Madagascar's role in chocolate production is limited, with most exports processed abroad and sold at low prices. Local small-scale farmers struggle to negotiate fair prices, with some calling for prices to be tripled to reflect the crop's true value. The country's isolation and dry season help preserve the quality of the beans, but the bulk of the harvest is exported, leaving little for local consumption.

site_title: Colombia confirms crashed plane was out of fuel
summary: A LaMia airlines charter flight that crashed in Colombia's mountains on November 28, killing 71 people, including most of a Brazilian football team, was confirmed to be out of fuel, according to preliminary investigations. The British Aerospace 146 jet ran out of fuel despite pilots being aware of the limitations. The plane was also overweight, but this did not appear to be a decisive factor. The pilots did not sound the alarm until several minutes before the crash, and the plane crashed at a speed of 115 knots due to a total electrical failure.

site_title: Blindsided by SUV boom, Hyundai Motor trims costs and perks
summary: Hyundai Motor is trimming costs and perks to address a decline in annual profits, citing weak emerging markets and a mismatch between its product line-up and market trends. The company is scaling back on business-class flights, annual family home trips, and printing costs, and encouraging video conferencing. Hyundai is also focusing on new SUV models, a design revamp, and research and development in emerging technologies.
