site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 7-month lows, little changed on year
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near 7-month lows, unchanged on year, due to investor selling ahead of Christmas holidays. The Aussie fell 0.14% to US$0.7226, while the Kiwi edged up 0.01% to US$0.6908. The currencies have fallen in six out of their last ten sessions, with the Aussie set to finish 2016 down 0.8%, its fourth straight year of losses.

site_title: UK economy grows faster than expected in Q3, no sign of Brexit hit
summary: Britain's economy expanded 0.6% in Q3, exceeding expectations, despite the Brexit vote. The growth was driven by robust consumer demand, but was hindered by a 1.2 percentage point drag from net trade. The country's current account deficit widened to 5.2% of GDP, approaching a record 6.0% in late 2013. Sterling's sharp fall after the Brexit vote did not boost exports, and inflation is expected to squeeze household spending.

images.alt_text: Britain's economy grew more strongly than expected in the third quarter, showing no sign of any slowdown from June's Brexit vote, but the country's current account deficit rose back towards record levels.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.55% in early trading on December 23, 2016, following a negative lead from Wall Street ahead of the Christmas break. The Hang Seng Index dropped 119.38 points to 21,516.82, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.05%.

site_title: Gold heading for 7th weekly loss on 2017 rate hike views
summary: Gold edged up slightly, but is on track for a seventh straight weekly decline due to expectations of US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes in 2017. US gold futures remained steady, and spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,131.19 an ounce. Economic growth data beat expectations, but jobless claims hit a six-month high, and consumer spending increased modestly. The US dollar hovered below a 14-year high, and gold prices remain neutral in a range of $1,121-$1,137 per ounce.

site_title: Army takes control of Aleppo in major boost for Assad
summary: The Syrian army has taken full control of Aleppo, its largest city, after a month-long offensive against opposition forces. The city, a symbol of the devastating civil war, was retaken after a landmark evacuation deal that ended the battle. Thousands of inhabitants celebrated in the streets, while rebel forces agreed to withdraw from the city. The loss is a major blow to the opposition, with the government now in control of five main cities. The victory is seen as a boon for President Bashar al-Assad's allies in Russia and Iran.

site_title: Italian govt approves decree to rescue Monte dei Paschi
summary: The Italian government approved a 20-billion-euro fund to rescue Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world's oldest bank, which failed to secure investor backing for a capital increase. Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni authorized the creation of the fund, which will support Italy's embattled banking sector, with Monte dei Paschi expected to be first in line for help. This move aims to reassure depositors and mark a turning point for the bank.

site_title: Russia works to shake off bootleg vodka hangover
summary: Russian authorities are cracking down on bootleg vodka production, seizing over 100,000 bottles from an illicit distillery in the village of Kuchki. The black market vodka accounts for thousands of deaths each year due to toxic methanol. Authorities have dismantled over 170 workshops and seized 37 million liters of illicit vodka since 2015. Despite efforts to curb the black market, experts warn that the issue persists due to poverty, with up to 25 million Russians unable to afford official vodka.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets are closed on Friday, Dec 23, 2016, for a public holiday. No other key market updates are provided in the article.

site_title: US dollar dozes, saves its strength for New Year
summary: The US dollar experienced a slight recovery on Friday, reaching 117.55 yen and US$1.0434, before the Christmas holidays. The dollar's rally is attributed to widening yield spreads in its favor, driven by bets on the Trump Administration's tax cuts and debt-funded spending. Analysts expect the US dollar to rise, but caution that a further sharp increase in yields could weigh on stocks and the economy.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was dozing at 117.55 yen after reaching 118.66 yen a week ago, its strongest since early February.

site_title: One size fits all? In offshore oil sector, using standard gear could cut costs 30%
summary: Offshore oil majors could reduce exploration and development costs by 30% by adopting industry-wide equipment standards, according to the International Marine Contractors Association. This approach, similar to the US shale oil industry, could help oil companies cut costs and increase profitability. Industry-wide standards for drilling equipment have been proposed by a group of 10 oil majors, including BP and Royal Dutch Shell, and are expected to be implemented in the near future. This move could bring stalled projects back to the market and help the oil sector recover from declining budgets.

site_title: Seoul: Won weaker as US dollar in driver's seat; stocks shaky
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.4% against the US dollar for the seventh consecutive session, trading at 1,203.8 won per dollar. The decline was attributed to the US dollar's bullish outlook due to expectations of increased US fiscal spending. South Korean shares were subdued, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) remaining almost flat at 2,036.52 points. Analysts expect the currency to pare its losses if foreign exchange authorities intervene to stabilize the market.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on slower pre-Christmas trade
summary: Singapore shares opened 13.69 points lower, or 0.48%, at 2,868.35, amidst slowing pre-Christmas trade. The US stock market also declined, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 23.08 points, or 0.1%, to 19,918.88. Oil prices rose on positive US economic data, including a 3.5% expansion in the third quarter and an increase in US-made capital goods orders. The Trump rally appears to have cooled, with investors pulling back ahead of the Christmas weekend.

site_title: More Asian defaults loom in 2017 amid record Korea shipyard debt
summary: Concerns mount over South Korean shipyards' ability to repay record debt maturing in 2017. Yields on Daewoo Shipbuilding and Samsung Heavy Industries' bonds have surged, with Daewoo's three-year bond reaching a record 13.9%. The top four Korean shipbuilders face 2.3 trillion won in notes due next year, with some potentially struggling to meet obligations without government or group firm support. The debt slump adds to Asia's debt market jitters, following Chinese defaults and Singapore delinquencies.

images.alt_text: As if investors in Asia's troubled corporate bond markets don't have enough to worry about, concern is mounting about whether South Korean shipyards will be able to repay record amounts of debt coming due next year.

site_title: Australia shares falter on slips in commodity prices; NZ strong
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 5637.9, ending a four-session bull run, due to weak commodity prices and profit-taking in the basic materials sector. Copper and Chinese iron futures prices dropped, hurting metals giant BHP Billiton and other related stocks. Energy shares, however, outperformed due to strong US economic data and rising oil prices. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% as industrials led gains, driven by Auckland International Airport's 12.9% increase in international passengers for November.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.11 points to 1622.09. The market saw 61 losers compared to 37 gainers, with total volume reaching 15.5 million lots worth RM3.8 million.

site_title: AusGroup flags potential event of default
summary: AusGroup, a Singapore-listed company, has flagged a potential event of default due to outstanding ministerial consent for a mortgage in Australia. The company had sought to restructure $110 million medium-term notes by pushing back the redemption deadline to 2018. However, the Australian minister-in-charge will be away from December 16, 2016, to early January 2017, and AusGroup failed to obtain the consent by December 19, 2016. This may constitute an event of default under the notes, which could have significant implications for the company.

site_title: UK consumer confidence slips to lowest level since Brexit vote: YouGov/Cebr
summary: British consumer confidence has fallen to its lowest level since the Brexit vote, with a survey showing a one-point drop to 108.1 in December. Concerns over rising inflation pressures have contributed to the decline, with a significant drop in optimism about household finances over the coming 12 months. The survey also notes that inflation is expected to rise sharply, potentially straining the spending power of households.

site_title: At 70, sitcoms stand firm against wave of TV changes
summary: The sitcom remains a popular television format, with the most-watched show in the US last season being "The Big Bang Theory." Despite the rise of sophisticated dramas, sitcoms continue to thrive due to their relatable stories and comedic elements that mirror everyday life. Key to their success is creating family-like characters that viewers can relate to, and providing a relaxing viewing experience. Sitcoms also play a role in society, addressing social issues in a lighthearted manner, making them more approachable and engaging for audiences.

images.alt_text: Television dramas have become ever more sophisticated in recent years, from the zombie apocalypse of The Walking Dead to medieval power struggles in Game of Thrones.

site_title: Asia: Stocks pressured by Wall Street, US dollar holds below 14-year peak
summary: Asian stocks declined on Friday as Wall Street took a breather from its recent rise, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index easing 0.1% and set for a weekly drop of 1.4%. The US dollar hovered below its 14-year high, while Japan's Nikkei lost 0.1% but was on track for a small weekly gain. The decline followed a five-month low in the index on Thursday.

site_title: Oil prices fall on profit taking, strong US dollar
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday due to profit-taking and a strong US dollar, with US West Texas Intermediate crude slipping 31 US cents to US$52.64 a barrel and Brent futures for February delivery dropping 30 US cents to US$54.75 a barrel. A strong US dollar makes greenback-denominated commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies, and prices are expected to be supported by a deal to cut oil output by almost 1.8 million bpd from January 1. Forecasters predict US crude will trade around US$60 a barrel in the first quarter and Brent around US$62-US$63 a barrel.

site_title: Passenger removed from flight after confrontation with Ivanka Trump
summary: A JetBlue passenger was removed from a flight after making angry remarks at the sight of Ivanka Trump on a flight from New York's John F Kennedy International Airport to San Francisco. The passenger, described as making agitated comments, was removed by the airline after staff approached him to calm him down. Ivanka Trump was en route to Hawaii for a vacation with her family. The Trump transition team did not comment on the incident, and the removed passenger's identity remains unknown.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nam Cheong, Keppel, Aztech
summary: Malaysian shipbuilder Nam Cheong's subsidiary, Nam Cheong International, received a letter of demand from Petra Offshore for the refund of a US$8.4 million deposit under a contract. Keppel Land and PT Metropolitan Land Tbk will jointly develop landed homes in Greater Jakarta. Independent financial adviser Stirling Coleman Capital advised Aztech shareholders to vote in favour of the delisting resolution.

site_title: Britain reports bird flu in wild duck
summary: Britain has reported a highly contagious strain of bird flu in a wild duck found dead in Wales, with the H5N8 strain also detected at a turkey farm in Lincolnshire. The government advises poultry keepers to follow biosecurity measures, with the risk to public health considered "very low." This is the latest in a series of outbreaks, with 13 European countries including France and Germany affected since October, with Hungary reporting the highest number of outbreaks.

site_title: Pitt accuses Jolie of risking children's privacy
summary: Brad Pitt has filed a motion in a Los Angeles court, accusing Angelina Jolie of compromising the privacy of their six children. Pitt's lawyers claim Jolie is disregarding their welfare by making public the names of family therapists and trying to discredit him. Jolie had filed for divorce, citing irreconcilable differences, and is seeking sole custody. Pitt is seeking joint custody and has already been granted supervised visits with the children. A hearing on Pitt's motion is scheduled for January 17.

site_title: Paschi drops private fundraising, paving way for state aid
summary: Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA, the world's oldest lender, abandoned plans to raise 5 billion euros from the market, making a state rescue likely. The bank failed to lure sufficient demand from investors, citing a lack of anchor investors. A state rescue is expected, which could hit bondholders and further slow Italy's efforts to revive its banking industry burdened with 360 billion euros in troubled loans. The bank's CEO had sought investors to back a reorganisation plan, but it will now seek a state rescue, which could be followed by rescues for other lenders.

site_title: Nokia files more patent suits against Apple
summary: Nokia has filed 40 patent lawsuits against Apple in 11 countries, accusing the iPhone maker of violating 32 technology patents. The lawsuits are being filed in Asia, Europe, and the US, and analysts warn that a legal battle could delay royalty payments crucial to Nokia's profits. Nokia's shares dropped nearly 5% following the announcement.

site_title: US: Retailer shares dive as US stocks retreat
summary: US stocks retreated, with retailers suffering sharp declines. Bed, Bath & Beyond's earnings report showed a 29% drop in net income, while Target, Best Buy, and Wal-Mart Stores also fell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.1%, and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%. Meanwhile, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries rose 1.5% after agreeing to pay $519 million to settle bribery charges. Alibaba dropped 2.8% after the US Trade Representative criticized one of its platforms for selling pirated goods.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange granted Ezra Holdings a two-month extension of its annual general meeting, following a delay in the release of its financial year-end results. Global Invacom issued a profit warning for FY16 due to one-off shutdown expenses. Spackman Entertainment's film Master topped the South Korean box office on its release day. Chip Eng Seng was granted an option to buy a leasehold industrial property, and OKH Global narrowed its net losses in the first quarter. Sheng Siong received a written notice that its supermarket lease will not be renewed after April 2017.

site_title: Trump pressures Lockheed, says told Boeing to price out fighter aircraft
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump pressured Lockheed Martin to reduce the cost of its F-35 fighter aircraft, stating that Boeing should offer a comparable F-18 Super Hornet at a lower price. Trump met with Lockheed and Boeing CEOs, saying the F-35 is too expensive and lacks stealth capabilities. Lockheed shares fell 2% and Boeing rose 0.7% after Trump's tweet. Experts say the move could disrupt the F-35 program, which has been plagued by cost overruns, but some argue it's a normal tactic for a businessman-turned-president.

site_title: Honda in talks with Google's Waymo over self-driving alliance
summary: Honda is in talks with Google's self-driving unit Waymo to integrate its autonomous-drive system into some of Honda's vehicles. The discussions, focused on research, aim to provide Waymo with modified vehicles to test its technology. This partnership could help Honda speed up its own self-driving system development. Honda shares rose 0.5% after the announcement, while Waymo is eager to work with more car companies to prepare for commercialization. The deal underscores Waymo's growing credibility and momentum in the self-driving car project.

site_title: Christmas Day terror plot foiled in Australia: police
summary: Australian police foiled a Christmas Day terror plot targeting central Melbourne with explosives, arresting seven individuals after raids across the city. The plot, inspired by ISIS, aimed to attack high-profile locations, including a train station and St Paul's Cathedral. The suspects, all in their 20s, are believed to be self-radicalised and were inspired by ISIS propaganda. Four of the suspects are Australian-born, while the fifth is an Egyptian-born Australian citizen. The plot was foiled after a criminal investigation, with five suspects remaining in custody.

site_title: Apple's search for better iPhone screens hinges on sole supplier
summary: Apple's next-generation iPhone is expected to feature OLED displays, but the company's ability to meet demand is uncertain due to a shortage of machines capable of producing these screens. Canon Tokki Corp, a single supplier in Japan, has a near monopoly on the machines needed for OLED production, but has a growing backlog and a two-year wait time for new machines. This has raised concerns about whether Apple will be able to line up additional suppliers and meet demand for the new iPhone.

site_title: American Airlines's flight attendants say new uniforms make them sick
summary: American Airlines flight attendants have filed a grievance over new uniforms that have caused headaches, skin irritation, and other health problems since their introduction in September. The Association of Professional Flight Attendants has requested the airline reimburse flight attendants for related health-care costs and set aside $2 million to fund a study. About 300 attendants have reported experiencing a reaction, and the airline has tested the clothing three times. American Airlines will cover the cost of dermatological testing and respond to the union's letter within 20 days.

images.alt_text: American Airlines flight attendants filed a grievance with the carrier over new uniforms they say have caused headaches, skin irritation and other health problems since being introduced in September.

site_title: Europe: Monte Paschi shares sink further, bucking steady European trend
summary: European shares fell 0.2% in thin pre-holiday trade, with mining and financial stocks weakening. Monte Paschi, Italy's third-largest bank, sank 7.5% to a record low, as investors anticipate a state rescue. Despite this, European bank shares have rallied strongly over the past two weeks, and the Stoxx 600 remains close to its highest level since January. The Italian government is set to discuss an emergency decree to bail out the bank, which could be part of a 20 billion euro safety net.

site_title: Germany says Tunisian suspect's fingerprints found in Christmas market crash truck
summary: Germany's Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere says fingerprints of Tunisian suspect Anis Amri, 24, have been found inside the truck that crashed through a Berlin Christmas market, killing 12 people. Investigators assume Amri was at the wheel and a hunt is underway across Europe for him. The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the attack, which has intensified pressure on Chancellor Angela Merkel to take a tougher line on immigration and security. Amri, a failed asylum seeker, had been radicalized while in prison in Italy and had been identified as a potential threat by security agencies.

site_title: Uber takes self-driving cars to Arizona after California demands permit
summary: Uber has removed its self-driving test cars from California after the state revoked the registration of 16 cars due to lack of permits. The company relocated the cars to Arizona, where self-driving vehicles do not require special permits. Uber's program had been testing in San Francisco for a week before the dispute with California regulators. The company plans to expand its self-driving pilot in Arizona in the coming weeks. California's Department of Motor Vehicles had threatened legal action if Uber did not remove its cars from the road, while Arizona Governor Doug Ducey welcomed the company's arrival.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc on Thursday removed its self-driving test cars from California and put them on trucks bound for Arizona, shuttering the autonomous vehicle project in its home state after a week-long battle with regulators.

site_title: Duterte signs 2017 record 3.35 trillion peso budget into law
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed a record 3.35 trillion peso budget into law, a 11.6% increase from 2016, prioritizing infrastructure spending to boost economic growth and address poverty. The budget allocates more funds to roads, bridges, and airports, and aims to meet a 6.5-7.5% economic growth target. Duterte also promised free education at state universities, universal health care, and a rice allowance for beneficiaries of conditional cash transfers. The country's benchmark interest rate remains at a record low, and economists forecast that the central bank will be among the first to follow the Federal Reserve in tightening policy next year.

site_title: Australia's Tatts rejects KKR-backed bid as inferior to Tabcorp's
summary: Australia's Tatts Group rejected a takeover bid worth up to A$7.3 billion from a consortium backed by KKR and Macquarie Group, citing concerns over assumptions and unrealistic valuations. Tatts preferred an earlier offer from Tabcorp Holdings Ltd. The consortium's proposal relied on A$353.6 million in operating results, which Tatts deemed too high, and undervalued the spinoff wagering company. Tatts shares fell 4% on the news, while Tabcorp's offer, valued at A$6.2 billion, was seen as more attractive by several shareholders.

site_title: Leadership of IMF and World Bank a joint responsibility of all members
summary: A special court in France acquitted IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde of negligence over a 400 million euro payout in 2008, despite her guilty verdict. The IMF's executive board expressed confidence in her ability to continue her duties. The lack of transparency and democracy in selecting IMF and World Bank leaders has been criticized, with a 2008 report suggesting deal-making among national governments. Governance reforms are needed to make the selection process fairer, more structured, and transparent, involving all member countries.

site_title: US sues Barclays for mortgage securities fraud
summary: The US Department of Justice sued Barclays Plc and two former executives, John T Carroll and Paul Menefee, on charges of mortgage securities fraud in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis. Barclays was accused of deceiving investors about the quality of loans underlying mortgage securities, with loans made to borrowers with no ability to repay and based on inflated home appraisals. The lawsuit alleges violations of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 and claims the bank deceived investors through intentional misrepresentations and omissions.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Justice on Thursday sued Barclays Plc and two former executives on charges of fraud in the sale of US mortgage securities in the run-up to the financial crisis.

site_title: Trump says US nuclear arsenal must be 'greatly' expanded
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has called for a significant expansion of the US nuclear arsenal, contradicting decades of reduction efforts. Trump stated that the US must "greatly strengthen and expand" its nuclear capability, echoing Russian President Vladimir Putin's similar remarks. The comments have sparked concerns about a potential new arms race and have been met with criticism from arms control groups. Trump's intention, according to his spokesman, was to emphasize the need to prevent nuclear proliferation, particularly among terrorist organizations and unstable regimes.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump said Thursday the US should increase its nuclear arsenal, an apparent reversal of a decades-long reduction of the nation's atomic weaponry that came hours after Russian President Vladimir Putin reiterated calls for his country's arsenal to be reinforced.

site_title: Chipmaker Micron's forecast powered by improving PC market
summary: Micron Technology Inc reported its first rise in quarterly revenue in nearly two years, driven by a stabilizing PC market and higher prices for its memory chips. The company forecast revenue and profit above estimates, with shares rising 10% in after-market trading. Average selling prices of DRAM chips rose 5% and sale volumes jumped 18% in the first quarter. Micron expects favorable supply-demand dynamics to persist in 2017, driving memory prices higher.

site_title: Deep, diverse and distinct
summary: In 2016, Singapore's arts and entertainment scene showcased diverse and impactful works. Key plays include Manifesto, a powerful portrayal of government censorship and artistic struggles, and Falling, a tear-jerking family drama. The Singapore International Festival of Arts featured challenging works like Five Easy Pieces, which tackled the real-life case of Belgian paedophile Marc Dutroux, and Grandmother Tongue, a poignant tale of language and cultural barriers. Other notable plays include The Last Bull: A Life In Flamenco, Sandaime Richard, Cafe, and Ophelia and Electra, which reimagined classic stories with innovative approaches.

site_title: China insurance regulator tightening licence issuance: sources
summary: China's insurance regulator, the China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC), is tightening licence issuance to reduce risks from aggressive business and investment practices. The regulator has suspended several insurers for speculative trading and barred others from selling policies with high investment returns. CIRC has also delayed issuing new licences, with only eight new insurance licences issued this year, compared to 13 last year. The regulator is focusing on new solvency rules requiring stronger risk controls and higher capital buffers, with firms expected to be fully compliant by next year.

site_title: Giving is not a zero-sum game
summary: A recent study found that voluntarily lending a helping hand to coworkers can have numerous benefits, including protecting against emotional exhaustion and nurturing self-worth. In contrast, receiving help from colleagues can have mixed effects, potentially making the recipient feel cared for but also perceived as incompetent. The study of 102 customer service representatives in Singapore showed that employees who engaged in self-initiated, autonomous behaviors, such as giving help, could buffer the negative effects of "surface acting" and maintain emotional well-being. The findings suggest that fostering a culture of trust, support, and respect is crucial for improving customer satisfaction and business performance.

site_title: Odebrecht settlement spurs bribery inquiries across Latin America
summary: Brazil's construction giant Odebrecht agreed to pay at least $3.5 billion to Brazilian, US, and Swiss prosecutors for a decade of bribe payments in 12 countries. Nearly 80 executives and employees have turned state's witness, providing evidence of corruption in several nations. Latin American politicians and investigators are demanding more information, with Peru's president and a Venezuelan opposition leader calling for Odebrecht to explain payments in their countries. Investigations are ongoing in Ecuador, Colombia, and other nations, with experts warning that Odebrecht's admissions could lead to new investigations.

images.alt_text: Politicians and investigators across Latin America demanded more information from Brazil-based construction giant Odebrecht on Thursday after it admitted to a decade of immense bribe payments in the region.

site_title: Time to court Asia's gleaming silver dollar
summary: Singapore is poised to capitalize on Asia's aging population, with consumer companies expected to boom from 2020. The region is aging faster than any other, with 511 million elderly people by 2030. A study by the Asia Pacific Risk Center notes that 200 million people will reach the age of 65 in the next decade. Companies are looking to tap into this demographic, with a focus on seniors like Uncle Sim, a fictional character who embodies the technoliterate and financially powerful elderly. This trend presents opportunities for consumer companies to establish a presence in Singapore.

site_title: Boeing tells Trump Air Force One can be built for less than US$4b
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg told President-elect Donald Trump that the company can build a new version of Air Force One for less than $4 billion, contradicting Trump's previous criticism of the aircraft's cost. Muilenburg made the statement after meeting with Trump at Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. The revised estimate aims to meet Trump's goal of reducing the cost of the aircraft, which has been a point of contention between the two.

site_title: Syrian conflict may be a new 30 Years' War in the making
summary: The Syrian conflict may be mirroring the 30 Years' War of the 17th century, with tensions between Russia and Turkey, and the involvement of great powers, similar to the Holy Roman Empire, France, and Sweden in the past conflict. The Sunni-Shia Islamic conflict in Syria, which began during the 2011 Arab Spring, has led to a protracted and bloody war, with the fall of Aleppo to government forces. The conflict has become a proxy war for rival powers, with Russia supporting the Syrian government, Turkey opposing it, and the US and its allies providing support to various rebel groups.

site_title: A space movie that raises interesting ethical issues
summary: A 2016 sci-fi film "Passengers" follows Jim Preston, an astronaut who wakes up 90 years early from his 120-year journey to a distant colony. He befriends an android bartender and falls for a sleeping passenger, Aurora Lane, despite knowing he shouldn't. As systems fail on the spaceship, the film raises ethical questions about playing God and manipulating someone's happiness. Despite a provocative premise, the execution feels bland and uninspired, leading to a rating of C.

site_title: Businesses 'friskier' after Trump's win: BofA CEO
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan says US businesses are "friskier" after Donald Trump's election, with mid-sized companies actively seeking funds to expand due to improved prospects for the regulatory environment and consumer demand. The bank forecasts 2% growth in 2017, up from 1.6% estimated for 2016. Executives are cautious, waiting to see how Trump's tax reforms are implemented, and may postpone decisions until details are clearer. Bank of America's stock has surged 33% since the election.

site_title: Parting gifts and beautiful sounds
summary: In 2016, the music world lost several notable artists, including David Bowie, Prince, Leonard Cohen, and Glenn Frey, with many leaving behind modern classics. Meanwhile, vinyl sales surpassed digital downloads in the UK for the first time. As Christmas shopping approaches, consider gifting albums like David Bowie's "Blackstar", Leonard Cohen's "You Want It Darker", Blood Orange's "Freetown Sound", and Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds' "Skeleton Tree", which showcase the artists' final works.

site_title: Mistry takes Tata to court; supporter Nusli Wadia booted from board
summary: Cyrus Mistry, the ousted chairman of Tata, has taken the company to court, claiming he was unfairly removed due to alleged corporate malfeasance. Mistry claims he was dismissed without prior notice and at the behest of Ratan Tata, who has taken interim charge of the conglomerate. The National Company Law Tribunal has instructed Mistry's counsel to provide evidence within a week. Meanwhile, Tata Sons has stated its petition is not maintainable in law and will file its response.

site_title: Philippine casinos to overtake Singapore's: Okada
summary: Japanese tycoon Kazuo Okada predicts the Philippine gaming market will surpass Singapore's within years due to improved ties with China, boosting tourism and revenue. Okada's US$2.4 billion casino in Manila, set to open in 2017, aims to become the largest in the country. The Philippine gaming market is expected to reach US$3 billion this year and US$3.6 billion in 2018, driven by increased overseas gamers and improved relations with China.

site_title: Current perspectives
summary: BT Lifestyle rounds up the year in arts, entertainment, food, and design in Singapore, featuring notable exhibitions. Notable shows include Charles Lim's "Sea State" at NTU CCA, teamLab's "Future World" at ArtScience Museum, and Iskandar Jalil's "Clay Travels" at National Gallery Singapore. Other highlights include Chun Kai Feng's satirical works, Samuel Chen and Justin Loke's parody of Chen Wen Hsi's gibbon paintings, and Su Xiaobai's abstract lacquer-on-linen paintings at Pearl Lam Galleries. Group shows like the Singapore Biennale 2016 and exhibitions at the National Museum of Singapore also made notable appearances.

site_title: Limited room for China to tighten policy as debt fear grows
summary: China's leadership signals a slight slowdown in economic growth to 6.5% in 2017, as it balances supporting the economy with containing debt and speculative investment. The interest rate easing cycle may be over, and the People's Bank of China is unlikely to raise benchmark interest rates until consumer inflation reaches 3%. The government may instead focus on fiscal policies and tightening capital controls to address debt concerns, while preparing for a potential slowdown in 2017.

site_title: A year of stars, ramen and salted egg yolk
summary: A year of significant growth and changes in Singapore's food scene in 2016. Despite initial concerns about an economic recession, the industry saw a surge in popularity, with Michelin-starred restaurants opening, food apps gaining traction, and the rise of bingsu cafes and new dining destinations. The love for salted egg yolk remained strong, and the introduction of new cuisines such as Mexican options also gained popularity. The year marked a continuation of Singapore's food-obsessed culture, with many notable milestones and the establishment of new restaurants and dining concepts.

images.alt_text: Above: Thirty-seven stars were handed out to 29 establishments at the launch of the Michelin Guide in Singapore.
Liao Fan Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice and Noodle is a one-star recipient and its chef-owner Chan Hon Meng hopes to turn it into a global chain.
Apps like Share Food will deliver home-cooked meals right to the doorstep.
Couch potatoes can have their cake and eat it too with UberEats.
Japan Food Town at Wisma Atria boasts 16 different concepts ranging from ramen to teppanyaki.
The salted egg craze is still going strong.

site_title: Touch of Seoul in Japanese menu
summary: Chef Akira Back's mod-Japanese restaurant could benefit from incorporating more Korean elements to add zest to his dishes. However, the article does not provide further details on this suggestion.

site_title: Need to review R&D tax incentive scheme to boost innovation
summary: Singapore's R&D tax incentive scheme, part of the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC), will expire in 2018, reducing benefits and making it less attractive for R&D activities. The country's current policy, which offers broad-based tax incentives, may not be sufficient to support innovation, particularly for smaller businesses and startups. Experts recommend reviewing the scheme to make it more refundable, allowing companies to carry forward benefits even if they have no profits, and to provide more targeted support for smaller businesses.

images.alt_text: Countries around the world have identified innovation as the key engine of growth, and Singapore needs to ensure it does not fall behind in its support of businesses in their innovation drive.

site_title: GLP takes in US$32m for US$1.1b US portfolio
summary: Global Logistics Properties (GLP) has secured US$32 million in funding for a US$1.1 billion logistics portfolio from Hillwood, with a total equity commitment of US$620 million from six institutional investors. The fund's total investment capacity is expected to be US$1.5 billion. Following the initial syndication, GLP's interest in the fund and its subsidiaries has decreased to 90.3% from 100%. The investment will be used to acquire US$700 million from Hillwood in December 2016 and a further US$400 million of assets upon full lease-up.

site_title: Asia Pacific carriers remain profitable but headwinds loom
summary: Asia-Pacific carriers have remained profitable despite global headwinds, with key carriers such as Delta Air Lines offering an upbeat outlook on travel demand. However, the region faces challenges, including potential tariff increases and rising costs. Meanwhile, major carriers are investing in new technologies, with Tesla launching its robotaxi services in California and Arizona, and FedEx partnering with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for commercial deliveries. Japan's carmakers have also taken steps to mitigate the impact of US tariffs, cutting export prices to the US market. Profitability remains a priority for carriers in the region.

site_title: Trump picks Death by China author for trade advisory role
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump named Peter Navarro, an economist who has urged a hard line on trade with China, to head the newly formed White House National Trade Council. Navarro, who authored "Death by China," has highlighted concerns over China's economic threat to the US and intellectual property theft. Trump also named Kellyanne Conway, his former campaign manager, as White House counsellor, praising her as a "trusted adviser and strategist." The appointments reflect Trump's focus on trade and economic issues.

site_title: Trump hotels reach deal with unions
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's hotels have reached agreements with their workers' unions, ending a series of cases claiming violations of federal labor law. The Trump International Hotel Las Vegas and Washington DC have signed four-year collective bargaining agreements, guaranteeing annual raises and benefits. The unions will withdraw cases filed against the hotels, and Trump Hotels will allow workers at the Washington hotel to organize. The agreements come ahead of Trump's presidency, which will influence the National Labor Relations Board.

site_title: Pretty places and objects that inspire us
summary: Local architects and designers have created innovative spaces and products, including a social hostel, co-working space, and community kitchen, that prioritize functionality and social interaction. COO, The Great Room, and Goodlife! Makan showcase unique designs, such as a digital interest matching tool and a fenceless compound, to foster connections among users. Other notable designs include Birds of a Feather, a Sichuan-inspired eatery with an Instagram-worthy interior, and the Open House, a porous facade that blurs the lines between indoors and outdoors. These designs aim to inspire better projects in the future.

images.alt_text: COO markets itself as a ''sociatel''
The interior of Birds of a Feather brings to mind a sunlit aviary awash with positive feelings.
The Great Room is a co-working space that feels more like the lobby of a luxury hotel than an office.
Goodlife! Makan is a community kitchen that offers a place for seniors who live alone to prepare, cook and share their meals with each other.
The interior of Birds of a Feather brings to mind a sunlit aviary awash with positive feelings.
Bynd Artisan Travel Sleeve
Supermama Singapore Architecture Collection
WMF Tea Stick

site_title: Concerts galore for every music lover
summary: A full concert calendar is set for Singapore in 2017, featuring acts such as Metallica, Bryan Adams, and Guns N' Roses. This year saw memorable gigs by Madonna, Jamie Cullum, Bon Iver, Weezer, and Damien Rice, among others. The Neon Lights festival also took place, despite rain and muddy conditions, with a strong line-up. Other notable acts include PJ Harvey, Two Door Cinema Club, Passenger, and Sting. The concert season is expected to continue into the new year with a diverse range of performances.

site_title: Outlook for S'pore's offshore, marine sector still challenging
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine sector remains challenging, with Maybank Kim Eng analysts warning of more failures of weak players and potential fresh provisions. The sector is plagued by severe asset oversupply and a cut in Opec production has yet to translate into business improvements. Analysts predict a tough 2017, with potential asset sales from failed companies providing price discoveries below expectations. However, financially strong asset owners may benefit from increased oilfield activities, with analysts recommending a "buy" call on Ezion Holdings.

site_title: US$ dips for second day on profit-taking
summary: The US dollar dipped 0.1% on Thursday, marking its second consecutive day of decline, as traders booked profits ahead of US data releases. The dollar had surged since Donald Trump's election victory, reaching a 14-year high earlier in the week. Analysts expect the dollar to continue its rally as US interest rates are expected to increase in 2017, with some predicting yields could reach 2.75% in Q1. The euro rose 0.2% against the dollar, rebounding from its lowest level since January 2003.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit sells 4 Japan nursing homes for 3.72b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit has sold four nursing homes in Japan for 3.72 billion yen (S$48.9 million). The nursing homes were originally purchased for 2.77 billion yen and had a net book value of 3.54 billion yen. The Reit expects to recognize a divestment gain of about S$5.2 million. The sale will provide financial flexibility to seize "other attractive investment opportunities offering better value." The divestment follows recent global market shocks and is aimed at preserving the Reit's portfolio quality.

site_title: Asia's environment may suffer in dash for infrastructure: ADB
summary: A report by the Asian Development Bank warns that environmental safeguards may be neglected in Asia's infrastructure development due to increased financial and other resources. The report highlights the need for robust safeguards to protect the environment and affected communities amid climate change and environmental degradation. It also notes that few government agencies employ regular environmental specialists to enforce safeguards, and that ADB specialists are over-stretched. The report calls for raising the standards of country safeguard systems to ensure public and private sector infrastructure projects avoid or mitigate environmental and social risks.

site_title: Ontario firm backs move to lend millennials cash for homes
summary: Ontario's realtor group CEO, Tim Hudak, supports a proposed program to lend first-time buyers cash for homes, helping them overcome the financial hurdle of down payments and closing costs. Hudak likens many millennials to being stuck in their parents' basement due to lack of funds. British Columbia Premier Christy Clark's plan to match down payments of up to 5% of the purchase price has been met with mixed reactions from economists, who warn it may drive up prices and fuel debt.

site_title: Shopping for festive wine with Penfolds
summary: Penfolds has released a new festive wine gift set, the Penfolds Aevum Crystal Decanter, which comes with a standard 750ml bottle of Grange 2012 and costs S$2,100. The decanter is designed to showcase the wine and enhance the service ritual. Additionally, Penfolds' Magill Cellar 3 programme allows customers to buy a whole barrel of wine, with a price tag of S$207,000. The programme also includes a Global Concierge Service and a VIP experience. Other festive wine options are available, including a 2016 Christmas Gift Box and individual bottles of Bin 389 and 2013 St Henri Shiraz.

images.alt_text: The wine in the barrel, though central to the Magill Cellar 3 programme, is just the tip of the iceberg. You get a Global Concierge Service which helps you decide when you want your barrel bottled, and in what bottle size.
The Penfolds Aevum Crystal Decanter is only available in a special S$2,100 set that comes with a standard 750ml bottle of Grange 2012.

The wine in the barrel, though central to the Magill Cellar 3 programme, is just the tip of the iceberg. You get a Global Concierge Service which helps you decide when you want your barrel bottled, and in what bottle size.

site_title: Saudi Arabia cuts 2016 budget deficit, to boost 2017 spending
summary: Saudi Arabia successfully cut its 2016 state budget deficit to 297 billion riyals, below projections and last year's record deficit. The move aims to boost economic growth in 2017 by increasing government spending. The country's deficit reduction is a positive sign for its economy, which has been struggling.

site_title: Uber halts self-driving car pilot programme in California
summary: Uber has halted its self-driving car pilot program in California after the state's Department of Motor Vehicles revoked the registrations for the vehicles. The move follows a clash between Uber and the DMV over the need for a special permit. Uber disputed the DMV's interpretation that its cars require a permit, citing Tesla's optional "autopilot" feature. Despite the setback, Uber remains committed to California and plans to redeploy the cars, with the company arguing that statewide rules regarding self-driving cars are unevenly applied.

site_title: US formally ends controversial registry program for visitors
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has formally ended the National Security Entry-Exit Registration Systems (NSEERS) program, a registry similar to a Muslim registry considered by President-elect Donald Trump. The program, suspended in 2011, was deemed redundant and inefficient, and its removal will divert limited personnel and resources to more effective measures. The decision drew praise from critics who said it was discriminatory, and several tech companies have vowed not to help the Trump administration build a Muslim registry. The program's removal comes as Trump transition aides have stated they will not resurrect the program.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp is set to acquire ComfortDelGro Cabcharge, an Australian bus company, for A$186 million. The acquisition is expected to add S$12-13 million to ComfortDelGro's profit in 2017-18, with the company maintaining a cash balance to fund the deal. RHB Research reiterates its "buy" call, citing ComfortDelGro's strong cash flow, steady profit growth, and potential for dividend growth. The target price is raised to S$3.24, reflecting increased earnings growth forecasts.

site_title: STI goes into the red for 2016
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed marginally in the red for 2016, losing 19.66 points to 2,882.04, due to a 0.8% decline in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and a 25-point drop in Dow futures. This marks the third time the STI has failed to stay above 2,882.73, the level it ended 2015. Despite a late bounce, the index's loss for the year was 0.69 of a point.

site_title: Bumiputera in uphill battle to find white knight
summary: Indonesian life insurer Bumiputera faces a significant uphill battle in finding a strategic investor to shore up its financial woes. Despite restructuring efforts since 2013, the firm remains burdened by liabilities of 20 trillion rupiah, far exceeding its assets worth 13-14 trillion rupiah. Authorities are keen on a private sector solution but have seen little progress, with plans for a backdoor listing marred by confusion. A potential government bailout may be considered if other solutions fail, amid concerns that failure to resolve Bumiputera's problems could impact Indonesia's underdeveloped life insurance sector.

images.alt_text: Life insurer Bumiputera still has liabilities of around 20 trillion rupiah - far outstripping its assets worth 13-14 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Abe hopes to close yawning budget gap by going for growth
summary: Japan's Cabinet approved a record 97.5 trillion yen draft budget for fiscal 2017, with little progress towards fiscal consolidation. The government aims to balance the budget through economic expansion, despite a massive burden of outstanding debt equal to 220% of GDP. Finance Minister Taro Aso stressed the need for reflationary policies and "flexible" fiscal spending to support economic growth. The budget includes significant increases in defense spending and social security costs, but the government is expected to pursue growth-friendly policies to bolster the economy.

site_title: Pacific Radiance transferring Mexican ops and assets to JV
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-based offshore marine services provider, is transferring its Mexican operations and assets to a joint venture (JV) with private equity firm Axis Capital Management. The JV, Navigatis Radiance, will own approximately 40% of key companies and vessels in the Gulf of Mexico. Pacific Radiance executive chairman Pang Yoke Min believes the move will sharpen the firm's competitive edge and capitalize on Mexico's liberalized energy market, which is expected to grow with increased exploration and production activity.

site_title: DFS wins master duty-free concession from Singapore Cruise Centre
summary: DFS Group has won a five-year master duty-free and general merchandise concession from the Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC) to operate seven duty-free outlets in two terminals. The concession, which commences on April 1, 2017, includes a two-year extension option. The SCC has reconfigured its retail space, boosting the area to 6,000 sq ft, and DFS plans to renovate its outlets, offering products from over 150 brands, including new food and whiskey tasting stations and e-commerce options. The concession is part of DFS's growth with the SCC, which manages over 6.3 million ferry passengers annually.

site_title: Mobile patent spat escalates as Nokia sues Apple, claiming patent violations
summary: Nokia has sued Apple, claiming patent violations, escalating a mobile patent spat. Nokia alleges Apple refused to license its video coding patents at established industry rates, despite agreeing to do so in 2011. The company has filed complaints in multiple German and US courts, seeking compensation and licensing agreements. This public battle marks a bitter escalation of tensions between the two companies.

site_title: Alibaba back on US blacklist for fake goods
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has been restored to the US blacklist for fake goods, four years after being removed, due to an unacceptably high level of reported counterfeiting and piracy on its Taobao platform. The US Office of the Trade Representative cited Alibaba's inability to combat fakes, despite efforts to tighten policies and remove listings. The decision damages Alibaba's credibility in the US and may impact its expansion plans, with shares falling 0.7% to $89.25.

site_title: Shareholders cold to more placements at Natural Cool EGM
summary: Shareholders at Singapore airconditioning firm Natural Cool voted 97.64% to revoke the board's share issuance mandate, a decision described by executive chairman Joseph Ang as a "disappointment" and "defeat". The move follows the recent appointment of a substantial investor via a private placement and comes after Ang's narrow victory at a previous EGM. The decision was seen as a response to concerns about the company's governance and the potential misuse of a share issuance mandate, with shareholder Mak Yuen Teen criticizing the absence of independent directors at the meeting.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang called the outcome of the vote to revoke the board's share issuance mandate a "disappointment" and "defeat".

site_title: Actelion re-enters transaction talks with Johnson & Johnson
summary: Actelion, a Swiss biotech company, has entered exclusive talks with Johnson & Johnson (J&J) for a "strategic transaction", reversing earlier talks with rival suitor Sanofi. Actelion's market value rose 11% following the announcement, while J&J shares fell 0.3%. The talks may sideline Sanofi, which had been circling Actelion to broaden its drug line-up.

site_title: IFA recommends accepting exit offer for Aztech
summary: Independent financial adviser Stirling Coleman Capital advises Aztech's independent directors to recommend shareholders vote in favor of a delisting resolution, despite the offer price-to-RNAV ratio being below precedent voluntary offers and delistings. Aztech has incurred net losses for FY2015 and the first half of 2016, and its financial performance has been declining. The IFA considers the exit offer fair and reasonable, based on sound commercial grounds, but warns that the group's NAV may not be fully realisable at its book value or revalued value within a short time frame.

site_title: SK Hynix to invest 3.16t won in memory chip output
summary: SK Hynix Inc, South Korea's second-largest memory chip maker, plans to invest 3.16 trillion won (S$3.8 billion) in its home country and China to boost production. The majority of the investment will go towards building a new NAND flash chip plant in South Korea. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for memory chips driven by the adoption of SSD storage and 3D NAND solutions. Analysts predict strong demand for memory chips will continue in 2017, with NAND industry revenue expected to grow 5.9% to US$35.7 billion.

site_title: Merkel says she's confident Germany to beat terrorist challenge
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed confidence in Germany's ability to overcome the terrorist challenge, following the Berlin Christmas-market attack that killed 12 people. Merkel stated that Germany's values of democracy and the rule of law will prevail, and praised investigators for their efforts to catch the main suspect, a 24-year-old Tunisian. She believes that the arrest of the suspect will give Germany the confidence to master the broader challenge of Islamist terrorism.

site_title: Keppel to build S'pore's fourth desalination plant in Marina East
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings has been named the preferred bidder to design, build, own, and operate Singapore's fourth desalination plant in Marina East. The new plant, expected to be operational in 2020, will produce 137,000 cubic meters of drinking water per day. The project is PUB's sixth DBOO (Design, Build, Own, and Operate) project with the private sector, with a 25-year concession agreement. The desalination plant will strengthen Singapore's drought resilience and enhance water supply reliability for city and eastern Singapore areas.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings Pte Ltd has been named the preferred bidder by national water agency PUB to design, build, own and operate (DBOO) Singapore's fourth desalination plant to be located in Marina East.

site_title: Hyundai gets rid of US chief, seeks to boost sluggish growth
summary: Hyundai Motor has announced the departure of its US chief, amid sluggish growth for the luxury brand Genesis, introduced four months ago. Despite a multimillion-dollar NFL promotional campaign, Genesis has failed to meet expectations, leading to a re-evaluation of the company's strategy to boost growth.

site_title: Vancouver home prices may see double-digit decline in 2017: realtor
summary: Vancouver home prices are expected to decline by double digits in 2017, according to Royal LePage CEO Phil Soper. The market has been cooled by policy initiatives, including a 15% tax on foreign buyers and tighter mortgage rules. Prices have risen nearly 40% in the past year, making the typical single-family house unaffordable for many residents. A correction is necessary to align home prices with underlying wages and salaries, with a 10% decrease expected to bring prices back to March levels, still 20 times the median household income.

site_title: Prime office rents: No reprieve in sight for 2017
summary: Analysts predict a 10% drop in prime office rents in Singapore's Central Business District next year, as companies take advantage of softening rents to upgrade their working spaces. This trend, known as the "flight-to-new projects," is expected to continue, causing pain to landlords of older buildings. Despite the rent drop, capital values may still hold up, providing a reprieve for landlords.

site_title: A Singapore stock market wish list for 2017
summary: Singapore's stock market faced a dismal 2016, with the Straits Times Index losing 14.3% and low daily volume. For 2017, market players hope for US economic policy to avoid protectionist measures and a return to normal interest rates. A slowdown in China's growth is also seen as beneficial. Additionally, a reversal of the local market's "defensive" reputation and faster regulatory action on market manipulation are desired. These hopes aim to boost the market's performance, which lagged behind regional peers in 2016.

site_title: 'New' office leases make up only 10% of the total this year: Cushman
summary: New office leases in Singapore accounted for only 10% of total leases this year, down from 20% in 2015. Relocation leases made up 63% and renewal leases 27%, according to Cushman & Wakefield's analysis. This marks a shift away from tech firms, which previously accounted for 33% of all leases, down from 33% in 2015. Finance firms, however, saw their share increase to 24%. The trend suggests a challenging business environment.

site_title: Keppel Land in tie-up to build homes in Indonesia
summary: Keppel Land has invested approximately S$26 million in a 50% stake in a joint residential development in Greater Jakarta, Indonesia, with PT Metropolitan Land Tbk (Metland). The 450 landed homes will be built on a 12-hectare site in Tangerang, a satellite city adjacent to West Jakarta. The project aims to meet the needs of Indonesia's growing middle class seeking quality homes, with Keppel Land focusing on scaling up its presence in the region.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker slapped with 30-month jail term
summary: A former BSI banker, Yeo Jiawei, has been sentenced to 30 months in jail for attempting to obstruct justice in connection with Singapore's largest money-laundering probe linked to the 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) scandal. Yeo, an associate of financier Jho Low, was convicted on all four counts of attempting to obstruct justice by urging witnesses to lie to the police and destroying evidence. The sentence is less than the prosecution's push for a three-year deterrent term. Yeo faces separate trials on money laundering and cheating charges.

site_title: US third-quarter economic growth raised to 3.5%
summary: The US economy grew faster than initially thought in the third quarter, expanding at a 3.5% annual rate, its strongest performance in two years. This beat the previously reported 3.2% pace and followed a 1.4% pace in the second quarter. Consumer spending, which accounts for over two-thirds of US economic activity, increased at a 3% rate, while business investment and exports also contributed to the growth. The revised estimates underscore the economy's solid fundamentals, which led to the Federal Reserve raising interest rates last week.

images.alt_text: The US economy grew faster than initially thought in the third quarter, notching its best performance in two years, amid solid consumer spending and a jump in soybean exports.

site_title: Obama-Abe meeting at Pearl Harbor fraught with symbolism
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to meet US President Barack Obama at Pearl Harbor on December 26-27, a symbolic visit to showcase US-Japan relations amid growing concerns about a "rising China." The meeting comes as China pushes for its own free trade area, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, and tensions in the South China Sea escalate. Abe seeks to strengthen Japan's alliance system and potentially overturn its post-war pacifist constitution, which limits military spending. The visit is also seen as a way to boost Abe's domestic popularity ahead of a potential snap election.

site_title: Lagos development boom sparks fears slum dwellers will be left homeless
summary: In Lagos, Nigeria, the government's urban development drive has sparked fears of homelessness for 30,000 slum dwellers, including Roseline Alphonse, who fled her burning home in Otodo Gbame. The demolition, blamed on inter-ethnic clashes, has left residents without shelter, forcing them to live in makeshift canoes on the Lagos Lagoon. Authorities deny responsibility, citing public health and safety issues, but activists argue that the evictions will plunge the poorest residents deeper into poverty, contradicting the New Urban Agenda's goal of providing decent housing for all.

images.alt_text: Bustling Oluwole Urban Market in the central business district, in Lagos. Lagos is one of several major African cities where urban development amid booming population growth and a lack of affordable housing is pitting the poorest against the state.

site_title: Clarkson and co still very much in top gear
summary: Jeremy Clarkson has found success with his new Amazon Prime Video show, The Grand Tour, after leaving the BBC's Top Gear. The 12-part series has become one of the most-viewed original series on the platform, praised for its chemistry between Clarkson and co-hosts James May and Richard Hammond. The show's formula, which features the trio testing high-end cars and engaging in witty banter, has been well-received by critics and audiences alike. With its slick editing and cinematic touch, The Grand Tour has become a hit for Clarkson, who has proven he can still deliver entertaining motoring journalism.

images.alt_text: From left: The Porsche 918, Ferrari LaFerrai, and McLaren P1 go head-to-head with each other in a drag race on The Grand Tour.
From left: May, Clarkson and Hammond reunite in The Grand Tour, which streams on Amazon Prime Video.

site_title: Q3 growth sees best performance in 2 years at 3.5%
summary: The US economy grew at a 3.5% annual rate in the third quarter, its best performance in two years, due to solid consumer spending and a jump in soya bean exports. This upward revision from the initial 3.2% pace was driven by stronger business investment in structures and intellectual property products. Consumer spending increased at a 3% rate, while exports grew at a 10% rate, the fastest pace since 2013. The revised GDP growth rate surpassed economists' expectations, contributing to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike last week.

site_title: Ending the year on a high note
summary: The 2016 film year ended on a high note, thanks to the late-season success of Damien Chazelle's musical "La La Land." This standout film, along with others like "Hell or High Water," "Nocturnal Animals," "Indignation," "Florence Foster Jenkins," and "Sing Street," proved that cinema can still surprise and entertain. Despite some disappointing films, the industry's ability to innovate and innovate will ensure that year-end lists will continue. The top 10 films of 2016 include "La La Land," "Hell or High Water," "Nocturnal Animals," "Indignation," "Florence Foster Jenkins," "Doctor Strange," "Sing Street," "The Handmaiden," "Dheepan," and "10 Cloverfield Lane."

site_title: Pacific Radiance transfers Mexican assets and operations into joint venture
summary: Pacific Radiance is transferring its Mexican assets and operations into a joint venture, Navigatis Radiance Pte Ltd, owned 51% by the company. The joint venture will own 40% effective interest in a ship management company and 99% of a vessel leasing company, among other assets. The move aims to sharpen Pacific Radiance's competitive edge in the Gulf of Mexico, with the joint venture investing up to $40 million. This collaboration with Navigatis and its private equity firm Axis Capital Management underscores Pacific Radiance's confidence in its operational experience and fleet.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while stocks in Europe and the US fell due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Novel approaches
summary: The article highlights the best books of 2016 in Singapore, covering various genres and authors. Notable mentions include Balli Kaur Jaswal's "Sugarbread", a novel about a young girl's experience with racism in Singapore; Samuel Lee's poetry debut "A Field Guide To Supermarkets In Singapore", which explores the mundane and the philosophical; and Shubigi Rao's "Pulp: A Short Biography of the Banished Book", a visually stunning and erudite book about books and libraries. Other notable titles include O Thiam Chin's "Now That It's Over", Daryl Qilin Yam's "Kappa Quartet", and Annabelle Thong's "Sarong Party Girls".

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat in light pre-holiday trading
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday ahead of the holiday season, with the Dow Jones down 18.68 points (0.09%) at 19,923.28, the S&P 500 down 4.32 points (0.1907%) at 2,260.86, and the Nasdaq Composite down 5.04 points (0.09%) at 5,466.40. The slight decline follows recent record highs, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks and the upcoming holiday season.

site_title: ISDN may indicatively dual-list in Hong Kong around Jan 12 next year
summary: ISDN Holdings expects to dual-list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (SEHK) around January 12, 2017, pending approval from the SEHK and fulfillment of conditions. The listing is subject to change and there is no assurance of approval. The company has convened a hearing with the SEHK listing committee on December 15 to consider its application. The final listing date may also change.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit divests 4 nursing homes in Japan for 3.72b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit divested four nursing homes in Japan for 3.72 billion yen (S$48.9 million). The divestment is expected to result in a gain of approximately S$5.2 million. The proceeds will provide greater financial flexibility for the trust to pursue other investment opportunities.

site_title: US core capital goods orders jump in November
summary: US core capital goods orders rose 0.9% in November, exceeding expectations, driven by strong demand for machinery and primary metals. This suggests the oil-related drag on manufacturing is fading. Economists expect business spending to rebound in 2017, driven by president-elect Donald Trump's perceived business-friendly policies. However, manufacturing gains may be limited by renewed US dollar strength. Shipments of core capital goods rose 0.2% last month, while durable goods orders dropped 4.6% due to a decline in civilian aircraft orders.

site_title: UN says observers on ground to monitor east Aleppo evacuation
summary: The UN has deployed 31 observers to monitor the evacuation of east Aleppo, Syria, as the last stage of the process unfolds. The observers, including international staff members, are at the crossing-point in Ramussa, where convoys have been leaving the city. As of Thursday morning, 35,000 people have left Aleppo, with the UN humanitarian taskforce warning of a "very large, dangerous, difficult, and complex" evacuation. The monitoring mission is part of a UN Security Council resolution, and the Syrian government has agreed to allow the UN to oversee the evacuation and report on the protection of civilians.

site_title: 66,000 workplace deaths in China last year: report
summary: China reported 66,000 workplace deaths in 2015, despite strengthened legislation, with 282,000 workplace accidents also occurring that year. Deaths have decreased by 50% since 2002, but poor safety supervision and inadequate enforcement remain major issues. Coal mines and steel factories were singled out for poor safety supervision, and insufficient law enforcement and outdated regulations contributed to workplace accidents.

site_title: US jobless claims rise to six-month high last week
summary: US jobless claims rose to a six-month high of 275,000 for the week ended Dec 17, surpassing a level associated with labor market strength. The 94th consecutive week of claims below 300,000 remains a positive indicator of a healthy labor market. The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate last week, forecasting three rate hikes in 2017, amid labor market strength. The four-week moving average of claims increased 6,000 to 263,750, suggesting some moderation in job gains.

site_title: Nam Cheong unit receives letter of demand for deposit, serves notice of arbitration
summary: Malaysian shipbuilder Nam Cheong's subsidiary, Nam Cheong International, has received a letter of demand from Petra Offshore for the refund of a $8.4 million deposit under a contract terminated in December. NCIL claims the termination was "wrongful and unwarranted" and has served a notice of arbitration to POL. The contract was entered in June 2014 and NCIL is seeking damages and the forfeit of the deposit. This follows NCIL's announcement on December 1 that it was terminating the sale of an accommodation work barge.

site_title: Trump names adviser Conway as his presidential counsellor
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump named Kellyanne Conway, a key adviser, as his counsellor to the president. Conway, who was Trump's former campaign manager, played a crucial role in his victory and has "amazing insights" on communicating his message, according to Trump. Conway will serve in this role, supporting Trump's agenda.

site_title: Bailout looms in Monte dei Paschi's funding scramble
summary: Italy's troubled lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena is at risk of a state bailout as its plan to raise 5 billion euros through a share offer and debt-for-equity swap falls short. The bank, the world's oldest, has failed to attract a Qatari investor and has only raised 2 billion euros. A 20-billion-euro bailout package approved by the Italian parliament aims to stem the woes of the ailing banking sector, with the government considering a precautionary recapitalisation if the operation fails.

site_title: Changes in Singapore's permanent secretary appointments
summary: Singapore's Public Service Division announced changes in permanent secretary appointments, effective January 1, 2017. Ng How Yue will be appointed as second permanent secretary at Ministry of Health, while Aubeck Kam will relinquish his concurrent appointment at Ministry of Communications and Information. Gabriel Lim will relinquish his appointment as CEO of Info-communications Media Development Authority and become permanent secretary at MCI. These changes aim to support the priorities and programs of the respective ministries.

site_title: Singapore shares close down, bank sell-off drags STI marginally into red for year
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped into the red for 2016, closing at 2,882.04 after a 0.8% loss in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and a 25-point drop in Dow futures. The index struggled to stay above 2,882.73, a level it reached on Nov 30. A late bounce cut its loss to 0.69 of a point for the year, with the lowest turnover in a month and a sell-off in mainly bank shares dragging the index down to an intraday low of 2,874.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker Yeo Jiawei given 30-month jail term
summary: Former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei was sentenced to 30 months in jail for attempting to pervert the course of justice in connection with Singapore's largest money-laundering probe linked to the 1MDB scandal. Yeo, 34, was found guilty of four attempts at witness tampering and was convicted of urging witnesses to lie to the police and destroy evidence. He had been on bail after being arrested in March 2016. The conviction is a significant development in the 1MDB probe, which is one of the largest money-laundering cases in history.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, closing 6.39 points down at 1,623.20 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. The market saw 1.05 billion lots traded worth RM1.2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 514 to 215.

site_title: Bank Negara reserves unchanged at US$96.4b as of Dec 15
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has maintained its international reserves at US$96.4 billion as of December 15, unchanged from November 30. The reserves are sufficient to cover 8.3 months of retained imports and are 1.2 times the short-term external debt, a level seen since mid-March. The reserves had fallen by nearly US$2 billion in the previous month.

images.alt_text: [KUALA LUMPUR] Malaysia's central bank said on Thursday that gross international reserves stood at US$96.4 billion as of Dec 15, unchanged from Nov 30.

site_title: Keppel Land to jointly develop landed homes with Metland in Greater Jakarta
summary: Keppel Land has partnered with Metland to jointly develop landed homes in Greater Jakarta. Keppel Land acquired a 50% stake in the joint venture, PT Metropolitan Permata Development, for 250 billion rupiah (S$26.8 million). The development will yield 450 landed homes on a 12-ha site in Tangerang, adjacent to West Jakarta.

site_title: Australia shares climb for a fourth day; NZ up for a fifth
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth day, closing 0.5% higher or 30.43 points at 5,643.9, driven by financial stocks. Investors await US economic data, including the third revision of US third-quarter GDP, for further cues.

site_title: Four people arrested in connection with Berlin attack suspect
summary: German police arrested four people in connection with the Berlin Christmas market attack that killed 12 people, in which a truck was driven into crowds on Monday. The attack was claimed by the Islamic State, and the suspect, Anis Amri, a 24-year-old Tunisian, is still on the run. Authorities believe Amri was looking for accomplices and was interested in automatic weapons. The arrests come as German Chancellor Angela Merkel faces calls to tighten asylum procedures, with some politicians suggesting the country needs to be more rigorous in deporting rejected asylum seekers and illegal immigrants.

site_title: What the world's most successful people read
summary: The article "What the world's most successful people read" by Michelle Quah reveals that the most successful people read a mix of self-help books, industry reports, and personal accounts to stay ahead. Examples include Bill Gates, who reportedly reads 50 books a year, and other successful individuals who follow influential leaders and industry experts. The study suggests that reading diverse sources helps them stay informed and adapt to changing market conditions, ultimately contributing to their success.

site_title: Philippine president says he will stop all online gambling
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte announced a halt on all online gambling in the country, effective immediately. The ban was part of a 2017 budget focused on populist measures, but no timeframe or details were provided. This move follows Duterte's previous actions against the online gambling industry, including scrapping a 13-year monopoly in licensed online cafes in August. The ban is expected to impact the country's booming online gambling sector.

site_title: Accept exit offer for Aztech, says independent financial adviser Stirling Coleman Capital
summary: Independent financial adviser Stirling Coleman Capital advises Aztech's independent directors to recommend shareholders vote in favour of delisting resolution. The exit offer, valued at 42 Singapore cents per share, is deemed fair and reasonable by the adviser, citing declining financial performance and industry conditions. Aztech's financial performance has been declining, with net losses for FY2015 and the first half of 2016, and the group's assets are considered specialised and difficult to value. The independent directors concur with the adviser's advice, recommending shareholders vote in favour of the delisting resolution.

images.alt_text: INDEPENDENT financial adviser (IFA) Stirling Coleman Capital on Thursday told the independent directors of Aztech, the object of a delisting offer, to recommend that shareholders vote in favour of the delisting resolution.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte signs 2017's record 3.35t peso budget into law
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed a record 3.35 trillion peso budget into law, increasing spending by 11.6% from last year's budget. The budget prioritizes infrastructure spending and aims to achieve a 6.5-7.5% economic growth target. Education will receive 544.1 billion pesos, with plans for free state university education and universal healthcare. Duterte also promised to provide free irrigation for farmers, fulfilling an election campaign promise. The budget is the first under his administration and aims to address poverty and lift long-term economic growth.

site_title: South Korean court allows prosecution documents in Park impeachment case
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court allowed the admission of prosecutors' investigation documents in President Park Geun-hye's impeachment proceedings, dismissing an objection by her defence team. The court also reviewed procedural plans for the impeachment vote passed by parliament on Dec 9. This decision paves the way for the impeachment process to move forward, although the court's final ruling on the impeachment remains uncertain.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets nudge lower at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined 0.2% at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices falling to 7,029.01 and 11,444.41 points respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns over Italy's troubled bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena, which needs to raise 5.0 billion euros to avoid collapse. The bank has only four months' worth of liquidity left and has raised 2.07 billion euros through a debt swap. The low probability of achieving the required capital increase has raised the odds of a government rescue.

site_title: China's Xi calls for wide-ranging measures to regulate hot property market
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has called for a wide range of measures to regulate the country's rapidly rising property market, where home prices are increasing by over 20% annually.
