The government aims to develop a long-term mechanism to address speculation and make housing more affordable for the middle class. Measures will include financial, fiscal, tax, land, and regulatory controls to limit credit for property speculation and prevent price volatility. The government also plans to develop a well-functioning rental market to satisfy basic housing demand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei was sentenced to 30 months in jail for attempting to pervert the course of justice in connection with Singapore's largest money-laundering probe linked to the 1MDB scandal. Keppel Corporation was named the preferred bidder to design, build, own, and operate Singapore's fourth desalination plant. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) slipped into the red for 2016 due to a 0.8% loss in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and a 25-point drop in the Dow futures.

images.alt_text: The sentencing of former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei for attempting to pervert the course of justice in connection with Singapore's largest money-laundering probe linked to the massive 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) scandal will take place on Thursday afternoon.

site_title: Nikkei slips from 1-year high as trading thins ahead of holidays
summary: Japanese stocks slipped from one-year highs on Thursday, with the Nikkei share average dropping 0.1% to 19,427.67. Investors took profits from recent gainers, particularly financials, ahead of the holiday season. The broader Topix also fell 0.1% to 1,543.82. Thin trade and concerns over US-EU tariffs contributed to the decline.

site_title: Beijing districts to cap population in bid to tackle smog, congestion
summary: Beijing's five districts plan to cap or lower their population in an effort to tackle pollution and congestion. Dongcheng aims to cut its residents to 762,000 by 2020, while Xicheng targets 1.1 million in five years. Other districts, Daxing and Shunyi, aim for populations below 1.7 million and 1.3 million, respectively. Plans include relocating residents, companies, and government departments to suburban areas, and demolishing illegal buildings, to address the city's "Big City Syndrome" and reduce strain on public services.

site_title: Troubled Indonesian insurer Bumiputera in uphill battle to find white knight
summary: Indonesian insurer Bumiputera, struggling with liabilities of around 20 trillion rupiah, is facing a difficult time finding a strategic investor or engineering a backdoor listing. Despite restructuring efforts since 2013, the firm has 6.7 million policyholders and pressure is mounting on the government to consider a bailout. Financial authorities are working to resolve the issue without government funds, but have sounded out state-owned enterprises and foreign companies for potential involvement. A government bailout may be a last resort, following a bitter experience with the 2008 bailout of Bank Century.

site_title: Malaysia extends bauxite mining ban by three months
summary: Malaysia extended its bauxite mining ban by three months, starting Dec 31, in response to public outcry over water contamination and environmental destruction. The ban, which was first imposed in January, is the fourth extension, amid the industry's rapid growth to meet China's demand for aluminium. The move aims to address concerns over the environmental impact of the largely unregulated mining industry.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down after US losses
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, following a rare drop on Wall Street, amid concerns over Italy's banking sector. The Dow slipped for the fourth time this month, with thin trading volumes contributing to the losses. Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore fell, while Seoul remained flat. Financial firms were hit due to worries over Italy's banking industry, with the world's oldest bank, Monte dei Paschi di Siena, plummeting over 12%.

site_title: Gold steady as US dollar edges away from 14-year peak
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,131.54 per ounce, unaffected by the US dollar's drop from 14-year highs. The Federal Reserve's decision to hike interest rates three times next year is expected to lower demand for gold. Analysts attribute the metal's stability to the holiday season and thin trading margins. Gold futures and other precious metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium, also remained unchanged.

site_title: Japan's 2016 births likely fell below 1m for first time: media
summary: Japan's birth rate is expected to fall below 1 million for the first time since data began in 1899, with a projected 980,000 to 990,000 births in 2016. A shrinking population of young women and low fertility rate are major factors. Japan's fertility rate has been recovering, but still lags behind the government's goal of 1.80. This marks the 10th consecutive year of natural population decline due to deaths outpacing births.

images.alt_text: The number of annual births in Japan is set to fall below 1 million this year for the first time since data became available in 1899, reflecting a fast-ageing society and the high cost of childcare, Japanese media reported on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower, enter correction phase
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.80% on Thursday, entering a correction phase, due to a sell-off in property firms and losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 173.60 points to 21,636.20, more than 10% down from its recent high. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined. The decline marks the beginning of a correction phase for Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: China foreign minister says US ties face new uncertainties
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that US-China ties face new uncertainties but will remain stable due to mutual respect for core interests. A call between President Xi Jinping and US President-elect Donald Trump was seen as a positive sign for a smooth transition. Wang emphasized that China and the US can achieve long-term cooperation if they respect each other's interests and concerns. The disputed South China Sea is expected to be an area of tension, with China defending its sovereignty as a "sacred mission".

site_title: Broker's take: 2017 likely to stay tough for Singapore's offshore and marine sector
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine sector is expected to face a tough 2017 due to severe asset oversupply, despite recent OPEC production cuts boosting sentiment. Analysts predict that utilization improvements may not be enough to prevent some players from running out of cash. Experts at Maybank Kim Eng warn of potential failures of weak players and another round of fresh provisions, highlighting the sector's challenging outlook.

site_title: Clifford Capital leads in project financing for Sembcorp's Bangladesh power project
summary: Singapore-based Clifford Capital led in project financing for Sembcorp Industries' Sirajganj power project in Bangladesh, marking the first green-field project financing between the two parties. Clifford Capital extended the longest loan tenor for project financing in Bangladesh with this deal. The project aims to provide clean energy to the region, and this partnership is expected to drive economic growth and development in Bangladesh.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Clifford Capital took the lead in extending project financing to Sembcorp Industries' Sirajganj power project in Bangladesh.

site_title: Seoul: Won down for 6th day on domestic, global headwinds; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won fell for a sixth consecutive day, down 0.2% to 1,196.8 against the US dollar. Analysts predict further losses due to global and domestic headwinds, including US interest rate hikes and uncertainty about Donald Trump's policies. The won may drop as low as 1,210 if global oil prices don't rise. South Korean shares were steady, with chipmaker SK Hynix rising 3.7% on plans to invest in memory chip production capacity.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat at 2,900.91 points, down 0.03% after US stocks declined overnight. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.16% on Wednesday. Oil prices dropped due to US crude inventory increase, with West Texas Intermediate futures falling 1.5% to $52.49. Investors took a step back from the Trump rally as they awaited his policies.

site_title: Seoul: Won drops to 9-month low, shares slightly down
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a 9-month low, closing at 1,199.1 to the dollar, down 0.4% from Thursday's close. The decline follows pressure from expected higher US interest rates and uncertainty over President Donald Trump's policies. This marks the sixth consecutive session of decline for the won, breaking through the psychological level of 1,200 intraday.

site_title: Blue skies return to Beijing as wind clears dangerous pollution
summary: Blue skies returned to Beijing on Thursday after overnight winds cleared the city of dangerously high levels of pollution that had blanketed the Chinese capital for five days. The air quality index (AQI) in Beijing dropped from over 400 to about 50, ending a pollution red alert that had been issued since December 17. The sudden improvement in air quality is attributed to the strong winds that blew away pollutants, bringing relief to residents and authorities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down slightly by 0.94 points to 1629.03. The market saw a 58-44 loss-to-gain ratio, with 25.6 million lots traded worth RM13 million.

site_title: Yahoo email scan shows US spy push to recast constitutional privacy
summary: US spy agencies have been pushing to loosen constitutional protections against arbitrary governmental searches, aiming to expand their ability to sift through vast amounts of online data without a court order. A secret Yahoo email scan, ordered by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, is part of this effort, which seeks to redefine what constitutes a "reasonable" search under the Fourth Amendment. Critics argue that this approach could lead to the collection of innocent messages, while proponents claim that the shift in focus towards overall "reasonableness" is necessary due to the increasing availability of digital data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, GLP, Global Invacom
summary: Keppel Corporation's Keppel Infrastructure Holdings has been named the preferred bidder for Singapore's fourth desalination plan. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has received a US$32 million investment for a logistics portfolio. Global Invacom Group has issued a profit warning for the financial year ending December 31, 2016.

site_title: Apple's search for better iPhone screens leads to Japan's rice fields
summary: Apple is seeking a reliable supplier for its next-generation iPhone screens, with Canon Tokki Corp in Japan's Niigata prefecture being the primary source for organic light-emitting diode (OLED) displays. The company, founded by Canon Inc in 1967, has a near monopoly on OLED screen manufacturing equipment, but faces a growing backlog and production bottleneck, potentially delaying the iPhone's OLED feature. With demand expected to remain strong for the next three years, Canon Tokki's output capacity is limited, raising concerns about Apple's ability to meet demand and supply chain disruptions in Japan.

site_title: Oil seen at US$100 by end 2018 in options trade
summary: A trader in the oil market has bought a large number of US$100 December 2018 call options, indicating optimism about a potential surge in oil prices to US$100 per barrel by the end of 2018. The options likely cost over US$1 million, but could be worth multiple times that if futures prices spike. This bet is seen as a hedge against unforeseen geopolitical events, and comes after Opec and other producers agreed to a production cut deal earlier this month, which could lead to a supply-demand imbalance in 2019.

images.alt_text: The US$100 December 2018 call option - a contract that gives the right to buy Dec 2018 futures at US$100 per barrel - was the most traded contract on Tuesday across the whole ICE Brent market, the latest sign of resurgent optimism in oil.

site_title: Alibaba again named 'notorious market' in blow to overseas push
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has been restored to the US Office of the Trade Representative's "Notorious Markets" list due to a high level of reported counterfeiting and piracy on its Taobao platform. This move damages Alibaba's credibility in the US and raises concerns about its ability to expand overseas. Despite efforts to combat fakes, Alibaba's shares fell 0.7% to $89.25 after the decision. The US agency warned Alibaba needed to improve its policies to avoid the designation, which could be influenced by politics, particularly amid tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Oil prices rise on weaker US dollar, optimism on output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, supported by a weaker US dollar and optimism over output cuts. US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 13 cents to $52.62 a barrel, while Brent futures for February delivery climbed 17 cents to $54.63 a barrel. The agreement to curb oil output by 1.8 million barrels per day, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, is expected to be complied with, with Russia's Energy Minister saying "compliance is likely". However, Libya's decision to boost output and unexpected US crude inventory build capped gains.

site_title: Singapore Cruise Centre awards DFS master duty-free operations at terminals
summary: Singapore Cruise Centre has awarded DFS Group a master duty-free operations contract at its HarbourFront and Tanah Merah ferry terminals for five years, starting April 1, 2017. The contract consolidates six separate duty-free concessions and aims to maximize space productivity and offer a wider range of merchandise. The selected operator will benefit from economies of scale and focus on categories with higher yield. The move is expected to enhance the shopping experience for over 6.3 million ferry passengers and 560,000 cruise passengers annually.

images.alt_text: Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC) has awarded its first master duty-free and general merchandise concession to luxury travel retailer DFS Group.

site_title: Uber puts brakes on self-driving cars in California
summary: Uber has stopped its self-driving car pilot program in California after the state revoked the registration of its vehicles. The move follows a dispute between Uber and the California Department of Motor Vehicles over the need for a special permit. Uber's vice president argued that its cars, which have a human driver capable of taking control at any time, do not require a permit and are comparable to Tesla's "autopilot" feature. The decision marks a setback for the company's efforts to expand its autonomous car testing in the state.

site_title: Ezra gets SGX green light to postpone AGM
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted Ezra Holdings a two-month extension to its annual general meeting (AGM) due to delays in releasing the group's FY2016 results. The group posted a net loss of $339.6 million for its fourth quarter, mainly due to huge impairments and provisions. The AGM will now be held by February 28, 2017, subject to certain conditions, including confirmation that there are no undisclosed material information affecting investors' decisions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, December 22, 2016, due to a pullback on Wall Street and concerns over European banks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.27% to 19,391.87 and the Topix index declined 0.23% to 1,541.40.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on December 22, 2016, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 9.58 points to 21,800.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.17% to 3,132.16. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.02% to 1,995.65. Traders are winding down ahead of the Christmas break.

site_title: US dollar loses steam ahead of holidays, US indicators
summary: The US dollar lost steam ahead of holidays, slipping to a 14-year-low of 103.02 against a basket of currencies. The decline was limited by the Federal Reserve's signal of more frequent rate hikes in 2017, driven by expectations of faster economic growth under the Trump Administration. Key US economic data is due Thursday, including revised GDP and durable goods orders, which may impact the US dollar further.

site_title: US charges Pakistani exec in US$140m fake diploma scheme
summary: A US federal court charged Umair Hamid, 30, an executive at software firm Axact, with wire fraud and identity theft in a $140 million "fake-diploma mill" scheme. Hamid allegedly sold bogus university degrees online to tens of thousands of consumers, despite Pakistani authorities shutting down Axact in 2015. The scheme was part of a global crackdown on fake diploma scams, with Pakistan seeking US help to investigate Axact last year. Hamid's arrest marks the latest step in the case.

site_title: Keppel to build Marina East desalination plant
summary: Keppel Corporation announced it has been named the preferred bidder for Singapore's fourth desalination plant in Marina East. The 25-year concession period project will produce 137,000 cubic meters of fresh drinking water per day, using reverse osmosis and advanced membrane technology. Keppel will undertake construction and commissioning, and operate the plant. The project is expected to be operational by 2020, supporting PUB's vision for a robust and sustainable water supply.

site_title: Australia rises for a fourth day; NZ goes for a fifth
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, while New Zealand shares climbed for a fifth day. Investors await US quarterly economic data, including GDP, personal income, and spending, which may impact markets. Australian shares edged up, despite a Wall Street breather, with investors hoping the data will push the Dow above 20,000.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall tracking overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.6% to 9,152.88 points, tracking losses in overseas markets ahead of the central bank's rate review. The electronics subindex dropped 0.3% and the financials subindex lost 1.3%. This is the fifth consecutive session of lower closes, following a 0.4% decline in the previous session. The central bank is expected to keep the key policy rate unchanged but provide its 2017 outlook.

site_title: Trump picks 'Death by China' author for trade advisory role
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has named Peter Navarro, an economist who has written about China's threat to the US economy, to head the newly formed White House National Trade Council. Navarro, a professor at the University of California, Irvine, has authored books including "Death by China" and has suggested a hard line on trade with China. Trump praised Navarro's "visionary" approach to trade policy, which aims to shrink the trade deficit and stop job losses. However, some economists have criticized Navarro's ideas as flawed, and China's foreign minister has expressed concerns about the impact of Trump's trade policies.

site_title: South Korea central bank says 2017 growth may cool, suggests more fiscal stimulus needed
summary: South Korea's central bank warned that the economy may slow down in 2017, with growth potentially falling below 2.8% this year. Governor Lee Ju-yeol suggested the government should increase fiscal stimulus to boost growth, citing low planned spending and corporate restructuring issues. The Bank of Korea held interest rates steady at 1.25% for a sixth month, citing domestic and global uncertainty, including US interest rate hikes. The bank will review policy on January 13, with Lee indicating more room to offer stimulus if needed to support the economy.

images.alt_text: In a statement prepared for a parliament session, the Bank of Korea said there is a chance growth next year may slow below an expected 2.8 per cent for this year.

site_title: Petrobras to sell Total US$2.2b worth of assets, including oilfields
summary: Petrobras, Brazil's state-run oil company, agreed to sell $2.2 billion worth of assets, including oilfields and power stations, to France's Total SA. The deal includes a 22.5% stake in the Iara oilfield and a 35% stake in the Lapa field, with Petrobras retaining 42.5% and 10% respectively. The agreement aims to reduce Petrobras' $125 billion debt and is part of the company's $13 billion divestment program over two years. Total also acquired 50% of two thermal power stations in Bahia state, marking a strategic partnership between the two companies.

site_title: UN creates team to prepare cases on Syria war crimes
summary: The United Nations General Assembly has voted to establish a special team to collect and analyze evidence on war crimes and human rights abuses in Syria. The team, which will work with the UN Syria Commission of Inquiry, aims to prepare cases for potential prosecution at international courts. The resolution was adopted with 105 in favor, 15 against, and 52 abstentions, with critics including Syrian, Russian, and Iranian ambassadors. The move aims to hold accountable those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during the Syrian conflict.

site_title: Icahn tapped as Trump's special adviser on regulatory issues
summary: Billionaire Carl Icahn has been appointed as Donald Trump's special adviser on regulatory issues, aiming to rescind "excessive regulation" on US businesses. Icahn, with significant investments in insurance and oil refining, will not receive a salary for his service. His role could draw scrutiny, given his influence on shaping rules related to Wall Street and environmental protection. Icahn has expressed support for breaking free from the 2010 Dodd-Frank banking law and has been a vocal critic of the US biofuels program.

site_title: US fines Goldman Sachs US$120m in rate-rigging scandal
summary: US regulators fined Goldman Sachs US$120 million for attempting to manipulate the widely-used global interest rate benchmark, the US Dollar International Swaps and Derivatives Association Fix, between 2007 and 2012. Goldman Sachs traders deliberately timed and priced trades to influence the benchmark, and made false submissions to skew the rate at the expense of counterparties. The company's cooperation prior to the investigation was deemed unsatisfactory. This is the third enforcement action against Goldman related to the benchmark interest rate manipulation.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas to study two oilfields in Iran
summary: Malaysia's state oil firm Petronas has agreed to study two oilfields in Iran, South Azadegan and Cheshmeh Khosh, with the National Iranian Oil Company. The study is expected to conclude in the second quarter of 2017. This follows agreements with Russia's Gazprom Neft and Thailand's PTT Exploration and Production to study oilfields. The deal comes as Iran plans to launch a new-style contract for developing its oil and gas fields, aiming to attract foreign investment. Malaysia has also given the go-ahead to pursue a free trade agreement with Iran.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's state oil firm Petroliam Nasional Berhad inked a deal to study two oilfields in Iran with the National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC).

site_title: Chocolate maker Hershey promotes COO to chief executive
summary: Hershey Co has named Michele Buck, its current COO, as the new CEO and president, effective March 1. Buck, who joined the company in 2005, oversaw the expansion into snacking categories and acquisitions. The promotion is seen as a continuation of the company's recovery in North America demand. Buck's appointment follows John Bilbrey's retirement as CEO and president, and comes as the company faces challenges, including declining stock prices and a reform agreement with its charitable trust. The move is expected to build on the company's recovery efforts.

site_title: GLP fund receives US$32m injection
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) received a US$32 million injection from a co-investor into a fund holding a US$1.1 billion logistics portfolio acquired from Dallas-based developer Hillwood. The contribution represents 9.7% of the fund's aggregate capital contributions. GLP and six institutional investors committed US$620 million to the fund, reducing New Harvest Holdings' stake to 90.3% from 100%. The fund's total investment capacity is US$1.5 billion, with US$700 million from Hillwood and US$400 million from Hillwood upon full-lease up.

site_title: China confirms 2nd human bird flu infection this week
summary: China has confirmed a second human case of bird flu, the H7N9 strain, a 44-year-old man in the Siming district of Xiamen city. The patient is stable and being treated in hospital. This comes after Hong Kong confirmed a similar case earlier this week. Authorities have ordered a halt to poultry sales in the affected area and banned imports of poultry from countries with outbreaks, as concerns over regional spread grow. This is the second human case reported in China this week, following a previous case in Hong Kong.

site_title: New Zealand's economy races ahead on people boom
summary: New Zealand's economy surged ahead in the third quarter with a 1.1% gross domestic product (GDP) growth, exceeding economists' forecast. The country's population growth, driven by a record influx of migrants, contributed to the growth, with a 2.1% annual expansion rate. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, despite subdued inflation and wages growth, as the economy shows signs of sustained growth.

site_title: UK consumers gloomy about 2017's looming inflation and Brexit talks: GfK
summary: British consumers are downbeat about the economy in 2017 due to looming inflation and Brexit uncertainty, with a GfK survey showing a -7 index in December, the weakest since June's Brexit vote. Despite robust consumer spending and growth in certain sectors, households' outlook for 2017 has deteriorated, with expectations of higher inflation eroding spending power and wages unlikely to keep pace. The UK's formal Brexit talks are set to begin early next year, further weighing on consumer sentiment.

site_title: Burning van rams Australian Christian Lobby office
summary: A burning van collided with the Australian Christian Lobby (ACL) office in Canberra, Australia, causing significant damage. The incident occurred on Wednesday night, with the driver injured but the staff safe. ACL managing director Lyle Shelton reported receiving death threats this year, and the attack was condemned as an "attack on free speech in Australia." Police refused to confirm whether the incident was terror-related, and investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Honda, Alphabet's Waymo in talks over self-driving technology
summary: Honda Motor Co has entered talks with Alphabet's self-driving division Waymo to integrate its autonomous technology into Honda's vehicles. This marks the second potential customer for Waymo, following a deal with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles in May. Honda has already committed resources to autonomous driving and aims to achieve full highway autonomy by 2020. As part of the collaboration, Honda may provide Waymo with modified vehicles and engineers will work closely with Waymo engineers to advance fully self-driving technology and make roads safer.

site_title: Chipmaker Micron's forecast powered by improving PC market
summary: Micron Technology Inc forecasted above-estimate revenue and profit for the current quarter, driven by an improving PC market and rising prices of its memory chips. The company's shares rose 10% in after-market trading, with average selling prices of DRAM chips up 5% and sales volumes jumping 18%. Micron expects favorable supply-demand dynamics to persist in 2017, with adjusted profit of 58-68 cents per share and revenue of $4.35-$4.70 billion.

site_title: Japan's government approves record military spending
summary: Japan's government has approved a record increase in military spending, a 1.4% rise to 5.13 trillion yen (S$63.1 billion), to counter growing Chinese military power and North Korean ballistic missile threats. The move, which would be the fifth straight annual increase, is expected to be approved by lawmakers, controlled by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. The decision aims to bolster Japan's defense capabilities in light of escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: Boeing CEO says Air Force One to cost under US$4b
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg stated that his company can build a new version of Air Force One for under $4 billion, meeting with President-elect Donald Trump at his Florida resort. This comes after Trump criticized the Pentagon's budget for the new 747 jumbos, citing costs and security concerns. Muilenburg expressed his commitment to working with Trump to reduce costs, while Lockheed Martin Corp faces criticism from Trump over the F-35 fighter jet project. The Pentagon has defended the F-35 project's progress and on-budget status.

site_title: Global Invacom issues profit warning
summary: Global Invacom Group, a satellite broadcast solutions maker, issued a profit warning for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2016, citing a full-year net loss of about US$3 million due to one-off shutdown expenses related to the closure of Radiance Electronics Shenzhen Co Ltd. The group expects improved gross margins and operational cost efficiencies in FY2017.

site_title: Monte dei Paschi on the brink as finance drive falters
summary: Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Italy's third-largest bank, teeters on the brink of collapse after failing to raise billions of euros to shore up its balance sheet. The bank needs to complete a five-billion-euro funding drive by the end of December, but a debt-for-equity swap offer raised only slightly over two billion euros, sparking fears of a government bailout. The bank's liquidity is dwindling, with only four months' worth left, and analysts warn that failure to save the bank could aggressively shake up the Italian and European banking sector.

site_title: YouTube star says kicked of Delta flight for speaking Arabic
summary: A Yemeni-American YouTube star, Adam Saleh, was removed from a Delta flight from London to New York for speaking Arabic, sparking accusations of racism. Saleh claimed fellow passengers complained, leading to his ejection. He later boarded a different flight with another airline and vowed to see his lawyer. The incident has sparked a boycott of Delta, with Saleh's video garnering over 200,000 retweets. Delta has launched an investigation into allegations of discrimination, stating that treating others with respect is essential to its culture.

site_title: Britain's ministry of defence loses hundreds of laptops
summary: Britain's Ministry of Defence has lost over 700 laptops and computers, along with 328 CDs, DVDs, and USBs, between May 2015 and October 2016, according to records released under the Freedom of Information Act. This loss occurred over 18 months, with 759 laptops and computers being lost and 32 stolen during this period. The ministry did not specify the cause of the loss or the cost of replacing the lost equipment.

site_title: Canada regulator declares high-speed internet an essential service
summary: Canada's telecommunications regulator has declared high-speed internet an essential service, requiring telecoms to provide speeds of at least 50 Mbps download and 10 Mbps upload to all Canadians by 2021, with the remaining 10% within 10-15 years. A C$750 million fund will be created to support rural and remote areas. The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) chairman Jean-Pierre Blais emphasized the importance of high-quality digital connectivity for Canadians' quality of life and economic prosperity.

site_title: Europe: Shares ease as Monte Paschi, Spanish lenders slump
summary: European shares fell 0.2% as Monte dei Paschi, an Italian bank, slumped to record lows due to concerns over its rescue plan. The lender aims to raise 5 billion euros, but has failed to find an anchor investor, prompting speculation of government intervention. Spanish lenders also declined sharply after the European Court of Justice overturned a ruling on mortgage contracts. Meanwhile, merger and acquisition activity supported the market, with Actelion rising 6.4% after Sanofi's takeover talks progressed.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as FedEx falls on disappointing earnings
summary: US stocks retreated on Wednesday, falling 0.2% to 19,941.96, as FedEx declined 3.3% due to disappointing earnings, and European stocks were pressured by uncertainty about Italian banks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also lost 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. Analysts attributed FedEx's decline to increased driver hiring costs, while Nike rose 1.0% on strong earnings growth in China.

site_title: Families of Orlando victims sue Facebook, Google, Twitter
summary: Families of Orlando nightclub shooting victims have filed a lawsuit against Facebook, Twitter, and Google, accusing them of providing "material support" to the Islamic State group by spreading extremist propaganda. The attack, carried out by Omar Mateen, killed 49 people and injured 53 in June 2016. The lawsuit claims that the social media platforms allowed the spread of propaganda that inspired the attack.

site_title: Lurid bribe scam hits massive New York retirement fund
summary: US prosecutors charged Navnoor Kang, a former New York state retirement fund official, with a $2.4 billion bribe scam. Kang allegedly received cocaine, luxury items, and bribes from brokers Deborah Kelley and Gregg Schonhorn in exchange for steering business to their firms. The scheme involved Kang testifying falsely under oath and aligning his story ahead of hearings. Kang was arrested, while Kelley was expected to surrender. The New York State Common Retirement Fund, the third largest pension fund in the US, lost billions in business to corrupt practices.

site_title: Child labour in Congo mines fuelled by flawed diamond regulations
summary: Child labour and sexual abuse are rampant in artisanal mines in the Democratic Republic of Congo's Kasai region, fuelled by flawed diamond regulations. Thousands of children work to pay for food and school fees, with girls facing rape, forced marriage, and prostitution. European jewellery firms have failed to scrutinise their supply chains, and the Kimberley Process Certification Scheme (KPCS) is criticized for obscuring rights abuses, classifying only 0.1% of diamonds as untradeable for ethical reasons. Campaign group Swedwatch calls for the Congolese government to protect children and jewellery companies to improve supply chain regulation and demand KPCS reform.

site_title: Swiss watchdog fines seven banks US$100m for rate-rigging
summary: Seven US and European banks were fined approximately $100 million by Switzerland's Competition Commission for participating in cartels to manipulate widely used financial benchmarks, including the Libor and Euribor rates. The cartels operated between 2005 and 2009, with JPMorgan Chase & Co and Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc being fined $47.8 million and $33.9 million respectively. The fines are part of a global probe into banks' manipulation of financial benchmarks, with over $9 billion in fines triggered for a dozen banks in the last four years.

site_title: Nokia sues Apple for patent infringement
summary: Nokia is suing Apple in German and US courts for patent infringement, claiming the tech giant used Nokia technology in "many" products without paying for it. The lawsuit concerns 32 patents related to displays, user interface, software, antennae, chipsets, and video coding. Nokia had previously licensed some of these patents to Apple in 2011, but declined subsequent offers to license others. The complaint was filed in three German cities and a Texas district court, with Nokia preparing further legal action elsewhere.

images.alt_text: Nokia announced on Wednesday it is suing Apple in German and US courts for patent infringement, claiming the US tech giant was using Nokia technology in "many" products without paying for it.

site_title: Car COE premiums bounce back up again
summary: Singapore's passenger-car Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums rebounded, with Category A and B increasing to S$49,751 and S$51,109 respectively, after falling below the S$50,000 mark two weeks ago. Category C and D premiums fell, while Category E rose. Industry experts attributed the surge to a "roller-coaster" effect, with premiums expected to fluctuate in the short term. The Cat A premium is likely to remain stable around the S$50,000 level, while Cat B premiums may continue to attract buyers waiting for further drops.

site_title: NY metro in largest expansion in 50 years
summary: The New York City subway is set to undergo its largest expansion in 50 years, with the opening of three new stations in eastern Manhattan on January 1. The Second Avenue subway, costing $4.4 billion, will link the Upper East Side to Brooklyn's Coney Island, alleviating overcrowding on existing lines. Despite initial skepticism, Governor Andrew Cuomo hailed the project as a significant improvement, citing the addition of contemporary art installations. However, critics argue the expansion will only provide minor relief and that the project falls short of its original vision.

site_title: Germany fingers Tunisian asylum seeker in Berlin market attack
summary: A 24-year-old Tunisian asylum seeker, Anis Amri, is suspected of involvement in a deadly truck attack on a Berlin Christmas market, claiming the lives of 12 people, including the truck's driver. Authorities found asylum office papers in the truck's cab linking Amri to the radical Islamist scene. He had been under investigation for planning an attack and had been rejected for asylum. A European wanted notice has been issued, and a reward is offered for information leading to his arrest.

images.alt_text: Officials said the suspect, 24-year-old Tunisian national Anis Amri, had already been under investigation for planning an attack, in a development certain to fuel public outrage.

site_title: Twitter's chief technology officer joins exodus of top executives
summary: Twitter's chief technology officer, Adam Messinger, has left the company after five years, marking the latest high-profile executive departure. His exit follows that of Adam Bain, Twitter's chief operating officer, and raises questions about the stability of the company's executive bench. Messinger's departure comes as Twitter continues to struggle with user growth and revenue, and the company is in cost-cutting mode. The company is now searching for a new chief financial officer and product leader, and Messinger's responsibilities will be taken over by Edward Ho, a vice-president of engineering.

site_title: Brazilian firms to pay record US$3.5b penalty in corruption case
summary: Brazilian construction company Odebrecht SA and petrochemical company Braskem SA agreed to pay at least $3.5 billion in penalties to resolve international charges of payoffs to Brazil's state oil company Petrobras. The companies pleaded guilty to violating a US foreign bribery law as part of a broad settlement with US, Brazilian, and Swiss authorities. The huge penalty is the largest ever in a foreign bribery case. The settlement resolves charges of corruption involving payoffs to Petrobras and other entities. The case was uncovered in an investigation into political kickbacks at Petrobras.

site_title: ST Index slips as early gains fizzle out
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 9.61 points to close at 2,901.70 on Wednesday, despite early gains, due to a quiet trading session and capital withdrawal from emerging markets. Brokers cited upcoming holidays and a faster-than-forecast US interest rate hike cycle as reasons for the dull session. DBS Group was the main index mover, rebounding from a sharp drop, while New Silkroutes shares rose on volume of two million after a recent placement.

site_title: Berlin attack threatens Merkel's liberal stance
summary: A truck attack on a Christmas market in Berlin killed 12 people and injured 48, in a highly symbolic incident that threatens Chancellor Angela Merkel's liberal stance. The attack, which involved a hijacked lorry and a Pakistani national suspect, has sparked widespread fear and mistrust in Germany. Merkel's attempt to maintain control and call for justice has been met with criticism, and the incident is seen as a major juncture in Germany's rising tide of mistrust and uncertainty. The attack has also raised concerns about the country's social contract and the erosion of trust in institutions.

site_title: Dollar retreats from 14-year high, Swedish kronor soars
summary: The dollar retreated from a 14-year high on Wednesday, while the Swedish kronor surged to its highest level in over two months after the Riksbank voted to ease policy by a narrow margin. The euro rebounded from a 14-year low, and the Japanese yen rose 0.3% against the dollar. The dollar's gains since the US presidential election are expected to be reversed, with some economists predicting a slowdown in stimulus and monetary policy.

site_title: SMRT, Uber, Grab on commuters' minds
summary: In 2016, Singapore's public transport sector saw significant changes, including the privatization of SMRT and the expansion of ride-hailing services like Uber and Grab. Meanwhile, COE (Certificate of Entitlement) premiums for cars remained firm despite expectations of a decline. The government's decision to take over SMRT's rail assets led to improved service, while the easing of loan curbs allowed more people to buy cars, contributing to a surge in car registrations. As a result, COE premiums were not reduced as anticipated, with the small car category showing strong demand.

site_title: US tycoon plans to use shipping containers to house the homeless
summary: California billionaire developer John Sobrato proposes building 200 micro-apartments, using repurposed shipping containers, to house homeless and low-income renters in Santa Clara. The project, called Innovation Place, aims to provide a cost-effective solution to the city's affordable housing shortage. Sobrato has requested a 57-year lease at $1 per year and plans to build and own the apartments, leasing them back to Santa Clara County. The project could open as early as 2018, with half the units for homeless residents and half for low-income renters.

site_title: Debt backing UBS's trading floor complex in Stamford up for sale
summary: UBS's former trading floor complex in Stamford, Connecticut, is up for sale after a US$149.4 million loan backing the property became "matured non-performing." The 103,000 sq ft trading floor, once considered state-of-the-art, is being sold through financial consultant Mission Capital Advisors LLC. Despite being marketed by brokers, the building remains vacant, with the Stamford office market showing a 29.1% vacancy rate at the end of the third quarter. The buyer will control the former UBS property, which UBS will maintain until its lease expires at the end of next year.

site_title: China's US$9 trillion bond market showing signs of distress
summary: China's US$9 trillion bond market is showing signs of distress, with prices tumbling over the past week and yields reaching new highs. The market's decline is attributed to global financial shifts, including the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and the expected impact of a Trump presidency. The Chinese government is attempting to curb excess money in its financial system, which may lead to further bond price drops. At least 40 companies have postponed or cancelled bond offerings, and investors are becoming increasingly wary of the market's stability.

site_title: Jason Hldgs in dilutive placement to raise S$1m
summary: Jason Holdings, a Singapore flooring firm, has signed a binding term sheet with its chairman to issue 2 billion new shares at S$0.0005 per share, raising S$1 million. The shares represent 73.28% of the enlarged share capital. The deal is at a 99.2% discount to the previous market price and exceeds the 10% limit under the Catalist rules, requiring shareholder approval. The company is seeking funds to restructure debts and liabilities, citing a current financial status of being practically insolvent.

site_title: TDK agrees to buy InvenSense for about US$1.3b
summary: TDK Corp has agreed to buy InvenSense Inc for approximately US$1.3 billion, with TDK CEO Shigenao Ishiguro stating the deal aims to make TDK a strong player in the sensor business. InvenSense, a supplier of sensors to Apple Inc and other smartphone makers, is valued at US$13 per share, a 20% increase from its closing price. The acquisition will further expand TDK's portfolio in the Internet of Things, following its expansion into batteries and automotive components.

site_title: How to get the US government out of mortgage lending
summary: The US government's control over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, entities that own or guarantee about half of all US home mortgages, is a pressing economic challenge for the incoming Trump administration. President-elect Donald Trump's Treasury Secretary pick, Steven Mnuchin, wants to put housing finance back into private hands. However, this requires a significant step forward, such as a risk-transfer program to attract private capital, and a well-designed reform to avoid discredit the idea of privatization. A well-planned transition could lead to a smaller government footprint and new competition, but an abrupt or poorly designed reform could have the opposite effect.

site_title: May raises possibility of transition deal to ease Britain's EU departure
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May plans to negotiate a deal on Britain's departure from the EU and its future relationship by 2019, with a possible transition period required to ease the economic adjustment. The government wants a smooth exit that works for all sectors of the UK economy, with Finance Minister Philip Hammond calling a transition deal "helpful" to manage the adjustment and prevent disruption. The EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has expressed concerns about the need for clear details of Britain's plans before an interim deal can be discussed.

site_title: American Airlines wins antitrust case against Sabre
summary: American Airlines won a US$15.3 million antitrust lawsuit against Sabre Corp, accusing the airline booking service of charging inflated booking fees and harming competition. A Manhattan federal jury awarded nearly US$5.1 million, which will be tripled under federal antitrust law. The verdict rejected claims that Sabre conspired with competitors to suppress competition. Sabre shares fell 1.4% following the verdict, and the company plans to appeal.

site_title: Sao Tome and Principe ends ties with Taiwan
summary: Sao Tome and Principe ended diplomatic ties with Taiwan, citing financial struggles, prompting Taiwan to accuse China of using the situation to push its "one China" policy. Taiwan Foreign Minister David Lee stated that China's actions are not beneficial to cross-Strait relations, while China welcomed the decision and expressed appreciation for Sao Tome's return to the "one China" principle. The move leaves Taiwan with 21 allies and raises concerns about its diplomatic isolation.

site_title: China sells 3-year, 7-year bonds at lower than expected yields
summary: China sold 3-year bonds at 3.0065% yield and 7-year bonds at 3.1797% yield, both below market expectations. The yields were lower than Tuesday's benchmark secondary market yields of 3.1229% and 3.2939% respectively. The auctions were successful, with 16 billion yuan of 3-year and 7-year bonds sold.

site_title: Governance code review, dual-class debate point to more changes in 2017
summary: Singapore's 2016 market regulations focused on improving access to products and capital while strengthening disclosure and accountability. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) relaxed some rules to offer investors more investment opportunities, but also introduced changes to enhance market quality. In 2017, the SGX is expected to launch a public consultation on a proposal to allow dual-class shares and review the Code of Corporate Governance. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will also review bond markets and consider changes to improve board diversity and disclose rebates received by private banks.

site_title: Cyber security in S-E Asia needs collective response from stakeholders
summary: Singapore is spearheading efforts to strengthen cyber security in Southeast Asia, with a $10 million investment in the Asean Cyber Capacity Programme. The region is vulnerable to malware threats, with four of the top five most vulnerable countries being from the Asia-Pacific. Experts cite the lack of mandatory reporting laws and inadequate cyber security workforce as major vulnerabilities. To address these issues, stakeholders must come together to share information, collaborate on education and training, and develop robust infrastructure to secure the digital economy.

site_title: European banks ceding share of int'l bond underwriting to US rivals
summary: European banks are ceding market share in international bond underwriting to their US rivals, with American banks being quicker to bolster their capital bases and benefiting from more regulatory certainty. This trend is accelerating, with European banks facing increased competition. US banks' advantages, including their ability to quickly adapt to changing market conditions and regulatory environments, are contributing to their growing market share. As a result, European banks are reassessing their strategies to remain competitive in the global financial markets.

images.alt_text: With its market share rising from 5.2 to 6.6 per cent, HSBC is one of the few European banks to have increased its international bond underwriting business since 2010.

site_title: Fidrec doubles non-insurance related adjudicated claims limit to S$100,000
summary: Fidrec, Singapore's Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre, has doubled the limit for non-insurance related adjudicated claims to S$100,000, effective January 3, 2017. This increase aims to provide more consumers access to an affordable dispute resolution process. Non-insurance related claims include disputes between consumers and banks, finance companies, and insurance intermediaries. The move was welcomed by Fidrec chairman Goh Joon Seng and Consumers Association of Singapore president Lim Biow Chuan, who see it as a step towards amicable and mutually acceptable resolutions in disputes.

site_title: Japan's economic prospects rise; yen eyed to fall further on BOJ moves
summary: Japan's government upgraded its economic outlook for the first time in 18 months, citing improved prospects for moderate expansion. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) also upgraded its view, but will likely keep domestic interest rates low to encourage the yen to fall and inflation to rise. The yen hovered near a 1 1/2-month low, and Japanese exporters are expected to benefit from a weaker currency. The BOJ aims to achieve its 2% inflation target, which could be reached if the yen falls to 120-125, allowing the central bank to let the US Federal Reserve drive interest rate hikes.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime's notes restructuring plan rejected again
summary: Rickmers Maritime's noteholders rejected the company's restructuring plan for S$100 million of medium-term notes maturing in May 2017, with 212 votes (67.3%) against the proposal out of 315 total votes. The trustee manager of Rickmers Maritime stated that one of the noteholder groups' financial adviser denied claims the group sought to liquidate the shipping trust. The rejection is the second time the restructuring plan has been rejected.

site_title: Two Australian banks sanctioned by regulator over forex practices
summary: Australian banks Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank Ltd have agreed to pay A$2.5 million each to the nation's financial literacy fund after a regulator found they had engaged in inappropriate foreign exchange practices between 2008 and 2013. The banks will also strengthen oversight of their currency trading divisions. The Australian Securities & Investments Commission investigated incidents involving confidential information sharing and proprietary positions, resulting in the enforceable undertaking. The agreements come weeks after other banks, Macquarie and ANZ, paid combined fines for cartel conduct.

site_title: Climate change at Natural Cool EGM
summary: Natural Cool's executive chairman Joseph Ang Choon Cheng sold a significant portion of his shares in the company, reducing his stake from 11.46% to 0.35%. Meanwhile, two substantial shareholders, Lim Teck Chuan and Ong Mun Wah, increased their holdings, with Lim becoming the single largest shareholder. The company's stock price soared before easing, and an EGM on Dec 22 proposes revoking the board's share issuance mandate. The outcome of the EGM is uncertain, but the power struggle at Natural Cool appears far from over.

site_title: Coca-Cola to buy out AB InBev from Africa JV for US$3.15b
summary: Coca-Cola has agreed to pay US$3.15 billion to acquire Anheuser-Busch InBev's 54.5% stake in a joint venture in Africa, marking a significant move for the US beverage company in the region. The deal comes after AB InBev completed its takeover of SABMiller, allowing Coca-Cola to gain a firm foothold in a region where it can grow its core soft drinks products. The acquisition is part of AB InBev's asset pruning efforts following its purchase of SABMiller, with the brewer expected to continue selling non-core assets quickly.

site_title: Asian thermal coal prices hit by China's steps to curb pollution
summary: Asian thermal coal prices are expected to come under pressure due to China's efforts to curb pollution. China has shut power stations, factories, and ports, reducing heating demand and coal consumption. Domestic coal prices are now around $77 per tonne, down from $100 in early November. Seaborne coal arbitrage into China has closed, removing a key demand driver. Mild winter weather in the Northern Hemisphere and reduced coal consumption are expected to continue, putting downward pressure on coal prices.

site_title: US hotels ride trend of patients travelling for care
summary: US hotels are capitalizing on the growing trend of medical tourism by locating near major medical centers. Developers are building hotels in areas with limited options, catering to patients and their families. The Edge Hotel in New York and the InterContinental Houston Medical Center are examples of hotels specifically designed to accommodate medical tourists. These hotels offer amenities such as on-site labs and extended-stay options, making them more appealing to patients undergoing lengthy treatments. By providing affordable accommodations, hospitals can reduce costs and improve patient comfort, making medical tourism a lucrative market for developers.

site_title: 2017 set to be another roller-coaster year for bonds: Schroders
summary: Schroders predicts 2017 will be a roller-coaster year for bonds due to ongoing uncertainties and challenges. Head of Global Macro Strategy Bob Jolly attributes this to central banks underestimating consumer spending and government spending becoming a necessary bridge. Despite potential fiscal policy, structural issues persist, including slow reform in Europe and Japan's low growth-low inflation setting. Schroders recommends adopting an opportunistic investment strategy, focusing on break-even inflation, the US dollar, and corporate bonds, while being cautious about removing policy accommodation prematurely.

site_title: Eggs in short supply as S Korea battles worst bird flu outbreak
summary: South Korea is facing its worst bird flu outbreak, with nearly 20 million birds, mostly egg-laying hens, culled to control the spread. The shortage has led to a significant increase in egg prices, with a 25% rise in the average retail price for 30 eggs since the outbreak began. The shortage is expected to last at least a year, potentially two years, for the industry to rebuild flocks. This has resulted in economic losses, with some stores restricting egg purchases and restaurants rationing portions of egg-based dishes.

site_title: South Korea seeks arrest of daughter of president's friend
summary: South Korea has issued an arrest warrant for Chung Yoo-ra, the 20-year-old daughter of President Park Geun-hye's friend Choi Soon-sil, who is on trial for corruption and abuse of power. Chung fled to Germany with her mother and child in September. Authorities are working to invalidate her passport and gather information on her whereabouts and financial assets. The warrant includes charges of obstruction of justice. The move comes as President Park faces impeachment over corruption allegations, with a Constitutional Court decision expected soon.

site_title: UK home-price growth to slow, transactions to decline in 2017
summary: The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) forecasts a slowdown in UK house-price growth and a decline in transactions in 2017, driven by affordability issues. Values are expected to rise 3% and the number of transactions to decline moderately, following a 6.9% year-on-year increase in October. The supply shortage and lack of properties for sale will continue to support prices, making affordability a significant challenge for many buyers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger load factor declined 1.9 percentage points in the peak season, reaching 76.9% in December, the lowest in eight months. This decline, combined with a slowdown in cargo traffic growth, may negatively impact peak Q3 earnings expectations. The airline's passenger loads on the Southwest Pacific route fell 8 percentage points, attributed to increased industry capacity, mainly from Chinese carriers. Rising fuel prices could lead to higher fuel costs, partly offset by lower hedging losses. The brokerage maintains a "hold" rating and target price of S$10.10.

site_title: Petronas to cut oil output by 20,000 barrels per day
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, has agreed to cut its oil production by 20,000 barrels per day (bpd) starting from January 2017, as part of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and non-Opec producers' effort to curb production and stem the oil glut. The move is expected to have a limited impact on global supplies, and analysts believe that higher prices will offset the reduction. The cut is symbolic, given Malaysia's relatively small oil production, but underscores the joint effort to control supply and stabilize prices.

site_title: SME sentiment sinks past neutral point to all-time low of 49.8
summary: Singapore's SME sentiment has reached an all-time low of 49.8, according to the latest SBF-DP SME Index, which measures business sentiment of small and medium-sized enterprises. Five out of six industries have a negative outlook for the coming six months, with scores below 50.0. The decline in sentiment is in line with recent economic indicators, including Singapore's Q3 GDP growth rate of 1.1%, and is attributed to factors such as the volatile global environment, Brexit, and slower wage growth. Industry watchers expect the declining sentiment to continue in 2017.

site_title: Indonesia aiming to be weightlifting giant
summary: Indonesia aims to modernize its weightlifting program to increase its medal haul at the 2018 Asian Games and Tokyo 2020. The country has already seen success with its weightlifters, including two silver medals at the Rio Games. The national team is working with foreign expertise, nutrition, and rehabilitation to improve the sport. However, traditional weightlifting clubs in rural areas still rely on outdated methods, resulting in high injury rates. The federation is trying to lure young talent to Jakarta, where tailored programs are available, and hopes to win 20 gold medals at the next Asian Games.

site_title: Indonesian police kill three terror suspects, foil suicide bomb plot
summary: Indonesian police killed three suspects in a gunfight on the outskirts of Jakarta, foiling a suicide bomb plot targeting the presidential palace and another undisclosed location. The suspects, believed to be supporters of the Islamic State group, planned to stab officers and detonate a homemade bomb. Police also found five bombs at the suspects' house and arrested three more people in separate raids. President Joko Widodo commended security forces for preventing attacks and called on the public to be vigilant against radicalism, following a surge in recent weeks of disrupted bomb plots.

site_title: Foreign firms locked out of Fukushima clean-up
summary: Foreign firms are largely excluded from the cleanup process at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant, despite their expertise in decommissioning regular nuclear facilities. An opaque bidding process has led to criticism from independent investigators, who point to collusion between the government, regulators, and the plant's operator contributing to the disaster. Only 9 of 70 contracts have gone to foreign companies, with the majority awarded to local companies that designed and built the facility. The Japanese government has created an English website for bids, but critics argue that the system is still unclear and ripe for corruption.

site_title: India overtakes Britain as world's 6th largest economy
summary: India has overtaken the UK as the world's 6th largest economy, surpassing Britain for the first time in over 100 years. India's rapid economic growth, driven by reforms under Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has led to a 7.6% GDP increase in 2017. The UK, on the other hand, is projected to grow by only 1.8% in 2016 and 1.1% in 2017 due to post-Brexit challenges. This milestone marks a significant shift in the global economic landscape, with India's economy benefiting from a global commodities price slump and lower-than-expected inflation.

site_title: Emissions scam: Volkswagen to pay another US$1b
summary: Volkswagen agreed to pay approximately US$1 billion to settle the US government's emissions cheating scandal, covering about 80,000 diesel cars from Volkswagen, Audi, and Porsche. The settlement involves buying back or fixing the affected vehicles and provides compensation. This marks one of the United States' largest consumer class-action settlements. The agreement follows last-minute negotiations that led to multiple rescheduled hearings.

site_title: Australia set for strong M&A year
summary: Australia is poised for a strong year in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in 2017, with billions of dollars in acquisition funds expected to flow into the country. However, government-imposed limits on foreign investment could temper the market, bringing down valuations. The federal government has introduced limits on foreign investment for the sale of New South Wales power grid Endeavour Energy, potentially limiting participation from international investors. Despite this, corporate advisers expect a stable or improving M&A market, with 96% of respondents in a survey indicating they expect the total to remain stable or improve.

site_title: Old Mutual-JPM Natural Resources Fund reaps rewards of metals rebound
summary: A natural resources fund run by JPMorgan Asset Management has delivered a 79% return this year, beating most of its competitors. The fund, which holds mining firms, took a contrarian stance during the metals slump in 2015, and now reaps the rewards of a rebound. Key holdings, such as Glencore and Freeport-McMoRan, have tripled and doubled, respectively, as the industry cuts debt and costs to capitalize on rising prices and demand. Industry analysts, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, are optimistic about the sector's recovery, driven by China's economic stabilization and US infrastructure spending.

site_title: Deutsche Bank ramps up equity-derivatives unit
summary: Deutsche Bank is expanding its Asia-Pacific equity-derivatives unit, led by former Societe Generale executive David Bruchet, to capitalize on expected demand for quantitative strategies from local investors. This move is part of a strategy by head of equities James Boyle to turn around Deutsche Bank's fortunes in equity-derivatives trading. At least six hires have been made in the region under Boyle's leadership, signaling the bank's efforts to regain market share in the region.

site_title: Russia cosies up to Japan in a pivot to Asia
summary: Russia seeks to improve relations with Japan, capitalizing on the delicate balance of power in Asia, as it tries to counterbalance US influence and China's growing presence. Russia has a long-standing territorial dispute with Japan, which it hopes to resolve through the handover of two islands. The country aims to secure Japanese investment in the Russian Far East and relief from sanctions imposed by Japan following Russia's annexation of Crimea. Improved relations with Japan could be used as leverage against China, as the two nations engage in a regional power struggle.

images.alt_text: Iturup is one of the islands "liberated" by the Soviet Union when Joseph Stalin ordered the Red Army to join the Pacific Theatre after the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

site_title: EU to boost border checks on cash, gold to tackle 'terrorism financing'
summary: The European Commission proposed tightening controls on cash and precious metals transfers from outside the EU to combat terrorism financing. The move comes after a Christmas market attack in Berlin, where 12 people were killed, and follows proposals to tighten controls on virtual currencies and prepaid cards. Customs officials in EU states will be able to step up checks on cash and prepaid payment cards, and authorities will be able to seize cash or precious metals carried by suspect individuals entering the EU. The proposals must be approved by EU states and the European Parliament to become law.

site_title: With champagne, big can be beautiful, too
summary: The rise of grower champagne has transformed the perception of champagne, emphasizing its regional character and quality. However, this shift has led to a decline in popularity of big champagne houses, which are often unfairly dismissed as dull and uninteresting. Many big houses, such as Charles Heidsieck and Louis Roederer, produce high-quality champagnes that offer distinct expressions of place. The growers' influence has pushed big houses to focus on viticulture, resulting in improved quality across the board. Embracing both grower and big-house champagnes is essential to appreciate the diversity of styles in the market.

site_title: Has dry bulk bottomed out?
summary: The dry bulk market may have reached a bottom, with prices stabilizing after a significant decline. The industry has been affected by a surplus of iron ore and other dry bulk commodities. Meanwhile, the logistics sector is seeing advancements, including the potential for robotaxis and autonomous delivery systems, with companies like Tesla and FedEx exploring these technologies. Additionally, Japan's carmakers are adapting to US tariffs by reducing export prices.

site_title: KL minister says 1MDB has paid bond coupon due this quarter
summary: Kuala Lumpur's 1MALaysia Development Bhd has paid the interest on its $6.5 billion 1MDB debt, following a US court order to service the coupons earlier in 2016. The move could be part of an attempt to settle a dispute with International Petroleum Investment Co PJSC, with the finance ministry overseeing 1MDB taking over its assets and projects. The payments come as the government winds down the embattled fund, with Second Finance Minister Johari Abdul Ghani indicating a possible amicable resolution through arbitration talks.

site_title: Third ex-BSI banker to be sentenced on Thursday
summary: Former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei will be sentenced on Thursday for attempting to pervert the course of justice in connection with Singapore's largest money-laundering probe linked to the 1MDB scandal. Yeo was convicted on four counts of obstructing justice, and faces a maximum jail term of 2.5 years and a fine. This is the third conviction of former BSI bankers in Singapore's 1MDB-linked investigations, following Yak Yew Chee and Yvonne Seah Yew Foong.

site_title: Existing home sales in unexpected rise to near 10-year high
summary: US existing home sales rose 0.7% to a 10-year high in November, reaching 5.61 million units. The increase was driven by buyers locking in low interest rates before anticipated further increases. Despite the rise, a housing shortage continues to affect affordability, with home prices and rents outpacing incomes in many areas. Mortgage rates have surged 60 basis points since the presidential election, reaching a 2-year high, and are expected to rise further. This may make it difficult for some borrowers to qualify for loans.

site_title: Reliance on tax breaks hits Puerto Rico economy
summary: Puerto Rico's economy has been hindered by its reliance on tax breaks, which has led to a municipal debt crisis and an unemployment rate 2.5 times the US average. Despite efforts to promote entrepreneurship, the island still lacks a sustainable economy, with only 2.3% of the workforce being self-employed. The island's economic struggles began with the Operation Bootstrap industrialization push, which prioritized attracting US manufacturers over local business creation. Proposed fixes aim to restructure debt and replenish investment, but some fear that more tax break schemes will only perpetuate the artificial stability that preceded the latest economic crash.

site_title: Lobster-loving Americans willing to pay for crush on crustaceans
summary: Americans are willing to pay for lobster, with prices increasing 37% this year and remaining popular. Despite a glut in supply, lobster demand has outpaced it, with exports to China surging and American restaurants adding lobster to dishes. The market is now "outstripping the supply," according to the Coldwater Lobster Association. American lobster consumption jumped 38% in the decade through last year, driven by its status as a luxury food item in Asia, particularly in China.

site_title: Russian ring steals US$5m daily selling ads on fake sites
summary: A Russian cyberforgery ring, dubbed Methbot, has created over 500,000 fake Internet users and 250,000 fake websites to trick US advertisers into paying $5 million daily for video ads that are never watched. The scheme, which began in September, uses bots to mimic human Web surfers, making it look like ads are being viewed on popular websites, including Fox News and The New York Times. The operation is sophisticated and profitable, exploiting known flaws in the digital advertising system.

site_title: Blockchain: Opportunities and challenges
summary: Singapore has declared its commitment to fintech and blockchain, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore unveiling initiatives worth S$225 million to support the development of fintech. The financial-technology event, attended by 11,000 participants from 50 countries, highlights the potential of blockchain technology to transform financial services with more transparent and secure exchanges. With 80% of banks predicted to initiate blockchain projects by next year, the technology is poised to become integral to the financial sector, with global investment in blockchain startups exceeding S$1.4 billion and expected to grow four-fold by 2019.

site_title: No fast track for EU-Singapore trade deal: EU court adviser
summary: A top EU Court of Justice adviser has ruled that a trade deal between Singapore and the European Union cannot be fast-tracked into force due to concerns over labour and environmental standards. The decision may slow down ratification of other trade deals, including those with Canada, Vietnam, and the US. EU advocate-general Eleanor Sharpston found that certain aspects of the Singapore deal require national parliament scrutiny, a lengthy process that can take several years. This ruling may impact the EU's ability to push through other trade agreements.

images.alt_text: For UK Prime Minister Theresa May, the implications are big as she should brace herself for Britain's own painful process with 27 other national parliaments and in some cases their regional lawmakers.

site_title: Time to push ahead with Asean Economic Community
summary: Asean launched the Asean Economic Community (AEC) in 2016, aiming to create a single, seamless production base and consumer market, but progress has been slow. The treaty's implementation has been hindered by domestic and international issues, including protectionism and depressed global trade volumes. Asean leaders have released a new blueprint outlining additional steps to be taken through 2025, but an improved institutional framework is needed to implement the AEC's provisions. The region's competitiveness in key supply chains, such as electronics, and labor market integration are also major concerns, with the flow of skilled labor being limited.

site_title: Nike's Q2 revenue and profit beat analysts' estimates
summary: Nike Inc reported Q2 revenue and profit beating analysts' estimates, driven by higher demand in Western Europe and Greater China. Sales rose 6.4% to $8.18 billion, with North America sales increasing 3% to $3.65 billion. However, gross margins contracted 140 basis points to 44.2% due to increased product costs and higher off-price sales. Nike's net income rose to $842 million, or 50 cents per share, beating analysts' average estimate of 43 cents per share.

site_title: Michigan challenges Silicon Valley's lead in self-driving tech
summary: Michigan is challenging Silicon Valley's lead in self-driving technology, with General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles investing in autonomous vehicle projects in the state. Governor Rick Snyder signed a package of laws allowing more extensive testing of self-driving cars on public roads and clearing the way for use of autonomous vehicles in trials by ride-hailing services. The state aims to regain its position as a hub for innovation, with the potential economic boost of millions of dollars in research and engineering investments and high-paying jobs.

site_title: Sembcorp unit secures financing for power project in Bangladesh
summary: Sembcorp Industries' subsidiary, Sembcorp North-West Power Company, has secured project financing for its 1,320 MW Sirajganj power project in Bangladesh. The 22.5-year project aims to alleviate the country's electricity shortages and provide cost-effective energy solutions. The International Finance Corporation (IFC) sees significant development impact, with the project expected to lower the cost of generation and help Bangladesh meet its growing power demand.

site_title: Blockchain: the next Internet wave?
summary: Blockchain technology is poised to revolutionize the financial industry in 2017, with Singapore leading the way in a pilot project backed by the central bank. Eight banks will use blockchain to deposit cash as collateral for digital currency, redeemable for cash. Experts say the technology has the potential to be as transformative as the internet, with benefits including cost savings and simplified documentation. Regulators are also recognizing that blockchain is not related to cryptocurrencies and can be designed to run privately, with only necessary information shared among trusted entities.

site_title: Whisky makers in pro-EU Scotland raising a toast to Brexit boon
summary: Whisky makers in Scotland are benefiting from the Brexit vote as the devaluation of the pound makes exports cheaper. 90% of Scotch whisky is sold outside Britain, and many distilleries have reported increased sales since the pound's 15% drop against the US dollar. However, the industry warns of potential long-term uncertainty and rising import costs. Despite this, more than 10,000 people are now employed directly in the industry, and exports reached £533 million in the first half of this year.

site_title: SGX's watch list tweak replaces one inadequate rule with another
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has revised its watch list rules, replacing one inadequate metric with another. The new rule allows companies to fail either the minimum trading price or profitability tests, but still remain on the watch list if their market capitalization is at least S$40 million. Critics argue that market capitalization overrules profitability and trading price, and propose a two-of-three regime to assess company quality. The revised rule change has raised concerns about the effectiveness of the watch list system and the need for a more holistic assessment of company quality.

images.alt_text: The quality of a company is rarely, if ever, measured on a single metric. It is therefore unfortunate that the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) minimum trading price amendment has merely replaced one single-facet test with another.

site_title: Thailand holds rate as Fed hike pressures Asian currencies
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, maintained its key interest rate at 1.5% for the 13th consecutive meeting, citing stability and the prospect of higher US borrowing costs weighing on Asian currencies. The decision was unanimous among monetary policy committee members, with economists predicting the move. The baht rose 0.1% to 35.99 USD following the announcement. The decision aims to support the economy, which is growing at the slowest pace among peers in South-east Asia, amid risks from a year-long mourning period and potential protectionist tilt in the US.

site_title: Trump: A disruptor or an 'innovator'?
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's presidency has raised concerns about the direction of the country's politics and policies. Trump's appointees, such as Scott Pruitt and Betsy DeVos, have been criticized for their potential to dismantle environmental regulations and reduce support for public education. This shift in policy could lead to significant changes in Washington, including a reduction in government responsibilities and a shift in power from the federal government to the states and private sector. Trump's ability to negotiate and make deals may be key to mitigating the impact of these changes, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: Swiss regulators fine banks for rate-rigging
summary: Swiss regulators have fined eight large global banks a joint total of nearly $100 million for rate-rigging and cartel activities between 2005 and 2010. The banks, including Barclays, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, and UBS, were found to have manipulated the Europe Interbank Offered Rate (Euribor) and other interest rates. Four banks have reached amicable settlements, with Barclays taking the largest hit of nearly $30 million. Proceedings against other banks, including JP Morgan and BNP Paribas, continue.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to buy out 49% stake in Australian venture for A$186m
