summary: Fidelity's investment in FutureAdvisor, a start-up financial company, has inadvertently given BlackRock an early advantage in the e-advice business. BlackRock acquired FutureAdvisor in 2015 for an estimated $150 million, while Fidelity's digital wealth manager, Fidelity Go, has yet to launch a full marketing campaign. Analysts expect investment behemoths Fidelity and BlackRock to grow quickly in the robo advising space, with BlackRock's FutureAdvisor now managing over $1 billion in assets.

site_title: Air Berlin appoints new CEO following restructuring
summary: Air Berlin appoints Thomas Winkelmann as new CEO, replacing Stefan Pichler on February 1, following a restructuring plan that includes halving its fleet and leasing aircraft to Lufthansa. The move aims to ensure a sustainable future for the airline, which remains loss-making despite efforts to reduce costs. Winkelmann, 57, previously headed Lufthansa's budget carrier Germanwings and Munich hub, while Pichler, 59, was brought in to turn around the carrier after successfully restructuring Fiji Airways. The changes are part of a broader shake-up by Air Berlin, which has also spun off tourist routes and leased aircraft to Lufthansa.

site_title: Switzerland unblocks 180m francs frozen in Egypt probe
summary: The Swiss Office of the Attorney General has unfrozen 180 million Swiss francs (S$253.7 million) previously blocked in an investigation into money laundering and supporting a criminal organization in Egypt. The inquiry, launched in 2011, was related to the Arab Spring protests that led to Hosni Mubarak's downfall. Although 430 million francs remains frozen, six unnamed persons are now under investigation, and a meeting between Swiss and Egyptian attorneys general led to the asset release.

site_title: Tillerson will need to change course at state
summary: US Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson, former CEO of ExxonMobil, faces scrutiny over his close ties with autocrats and human rights record. Tillerson has represented ExxonMobil in countries with poor human rights records and has a history of negotiating with leaders like Vladimir Putin and Hugo Chavez. Critics argue that his background as a big oil company executive may prioritize corporate interests over public interest. NGOs question whether he can shift from representing ExxonMobil to representing US interests on the world stage.

site_title: Ukraine to nationalise its biggest lender, PrivatBank
summary: Ukraine will nationalize PrivatBank, its largest lender, on December 19, 2016. The move is in coordination with international lenders and aims to ensure the bank's stable operation. The state will take over the bank, which is partly owned by Ukraine's richest man. The transition period will begin on December 19, with the government guaranteeing the bank's smooth operation. The decision was made after private shareholders proposed it to the government in the interests of the bank's clients.

images.alt_text: Ukraine will on Monday nationalise PrivatBank, the country's biggest lender, a move undertaken in coordination with Ukraine's international lenders and with their support, the government said in a statement late on Sunday.

site_title: Foreign banks in Britain pay fraction of tax rate
summary: Foreign banks in Britain paid an average tax rate of 6% on their profits, less than a third of the UK corporate tax rate of 20%. This is attributed to historic losses used to offset current tax bills, a legal but potentially questionable practice. The analysis is based on regulatory filings and does not imply any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Banks in Britain are pushing back against a government decision last year to increase their corporate tax rate to 28 per cent this year - a move that was offset by a cut in the levy on their assets.

site_title: Lattes and pizzas, cars and drugs
summary: Key themes discussed in 2016 include cracking the S$5-latte problem, looking beyond Singapore's shores for investment opportunities, and investor education at home. The year highlighted the importance of valuing real estate investment trusts, understanding accounting fundamentals, and recognizing cheap cash-rich companies. Safe investments were discussed, including government bonds and CPF savings accounts. The column also emphasized the need to educate investors, especially beginners, on complex topics like investing.

site_title: More firms in US tapping the skills of the recently retired
summary: More US companies are establishing part-time programs for "boomerang retirees" – individuals who leave a job and then return shortly after, often to work with fewer hours. These programs benefit both the employer and retiree, providing experienced hands to train younger employees and reduce labor costs. Companies like Atlantic Health Systems and Michelin North America sponsor these programs, which are becoming increasingly popular, especially among larger companies.

site_title: When stockmarket declines affect compensation
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index has declined by approximately 15% since January 2015, affecting corporate earnings and leading to job cuts, reduced executive salaries, and lower bonuses. Long-term incentive plans, which align management and shareholder interests, are impacted, with companies awarding lower bonuses. Typically, these plans reward forward-looking performance, such as total shareholder returns (TSR) exceeding a certain hurdle rate. The decline in the index has also led to concerns about the impact on companies' ability to meet TSR targets.

site_title: Hollywood legend Zsa Zsa Gabor dead at 99: husband
summary: Zsa Zsa Gabor, the Hungarian-born Hollywood actress and socialite, died at 99 after suffering a heart attack at home, her husband Frederic von Anhalt confirmed. Gabor, known for her numerous high-profile romances and beauty pageant wins, was married to von Anhalt in 1986, her longest marriage. Her career spanned film roles in movies such as "Moulin Rouge" and "Lili," but she was also famous for her celebrity status and numerous affairs with Hollywood heartthrobs. Gabor had been in poor health in recent years, including a car accident and stroke, but died surrounded by friends and family.

images.alt_text: Zsa Zsa Gabor, the Hungarian-born Hollywood siren perhaps better known for her prodigious love life than her movie credits, died on Sunday after suffering a heart attack, her husband said.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds key rate to weigh Fed, domestic politics
summary: The Bank of Korea held its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1.25% for a sixth month, amid concerns over South Korea's economic growth due to parliamentary vote to impeach President Park Geun-hye and US Federal Reserve rate hikes. The decision was unanimous, with economists forecasting at least one more rate cut in 2017. The central bank faces a balancing act, weighing risks to growth against inflation concerns. Private economists have lowered growth projections for next year to reflect political uncertainty.

site_title: Gold: back to square one
summary: Gold prices have dropped, and investors are bracing for the potential impact of US-EU tariffs. Despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, the overall market is experiencing a downturn, with European and US stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. The US stock market edged down from record levels amid tariff threats. In Asia, traders are shrugging off new Trump threats, continuing the recent stocks rally.

site_title: GitHub is building a coder's paradise. It's not coming cheap
summary: GitHub, a popular platform for coders, is struggling financially despite its growth. The company lost $27 million in revenue in 2016, despite generating $95 million, and has since doubled its headcount to 600. GitHub's CEO, Chris Wanstrath, attributes the losses to excessive spending and a failed attempt to expand its sales team. The company has hired a new CFO to manage spending and has seen revenue increase, but still faces competition from rival startup GitLab and other code repository platforms. GitHub's valuation has risen to $2 billion with fresh capital, but the company's financials remain a concern.

site_title: Yahoo security problems a story of too little, too late
summary: Yahoo's 2013 data breach, which exposed over 1 billion user accounts, was attributed to the company's continued use of the discredited MD5 encryption technology. Despite warnings from security experts and the Carnegie Mellon University's Software Engineering Institute as far back as 2008, Yahoo had not moved away from MD5 in a timely fashion. The breach was likely the result of Yahoo's prioritizing business challenges over security, with former employees stating that the company's security team was often turned down when requesting new tools and features due to cost or low priority concerns.

site_title: Duterte's painkiller use draws concern
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has sparked concern about his health after admitting to using a powerful painkiller, fentanyl, due to a spinal injury. He claimed his doctor stopped him from using it after he took more than the prescribed dosage. Lawmakers have urged him to undergo a medical examination and disclose the results, citing speculation about his health and the potential impact of the medication on his lucidity and decision-making abilities. The admission has revived rumors about his health, including claims of cancer, which Duterte repeatedly denied during his election campaign.

site_title: 'Unpresidented' Trump tweet on China sets off deluge of mockery
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump faced ridicule on Twitter after tweeting that China's seizure of a US naval probe was an "unpresidented" act, with the misspelling quickly becoming a top trending topic. Trump deleted the tweet and later replaced it with a corrected version using the word "unprecedented." Despite criticism, Trump's supporters defended him, saying critics were focusing on a typo while ignoring the bigger issue. China has confirmed it will return the probe, amid rising tensions between the two countries in the South China Sea.

site_title: NYC's new suburbia: More urban
summary: New York suburbs are evolving into more urbanized areas, attracting empty nesters and professionals. Multifamily housing and condominium communities near mass transit hubs are expanding downtowns, offering amenities like restaurants, bars, and parks. Developers are catering to this trend with luxury rentals and condos, some with amenities like golf simulators and concierge services. The shift is driven by people seeking a balance between suburban living and urban lifestyle, with prices ranging from $409,000 to $6 million. This redefinition of suburban living is changing the landscape, with some areas experiencing densification and increased demand for multifamily housing.

site_title: Summit concludes with Russia-Japan ties getting a bit warmer
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Russian President Vladimir Putin concluded a two-day summit with agreements on economic cooperation, including a large-scale natural gas field development project on the Gydan Peninsula. However, no progress was made on the long-standing territorial dispute between the two countries, which has been a major obstacle to improving relations. The two leaders signed 80 documents, mostly memoranda of understanding, and agreed to launch talks on joint economic activities on the disputed islands, a step towards a potential peace treaty. Japan will provide advanced technology and expertise to Russia, while Russia will offer cooperation on decommissioning nuclear plants and cyber security.

site_title: Australian government to give budget update, top credit rating at risk
summary: Australia's conservative government is set to give a budget update on Monday, which could lead to a downgrade in the country's triple A credit rating and increased borrowing costs due to its over $1 trillion debt. Treasurer Scott Morrison is expected to reaffirm a pledge to return to surplus by 2020/21 through spending cuts and tax-raising measures, but contentious measures are blocked in the Senate. The government faces slowing economic growth and a large deficit, impacting revenue and pushing up costs.

site_title: Tata Motors emerges as key battle in biggest Indian proxy fight
summary: Tata Motors is at the center of India's largest proxy fight as the company's board faces opposition to removing Chairman Cyrus Mistry. US proxy advisory firms Glass Lewis & Co and Institutional Shareholder Services Inc have recommended investors vote against Mistry's ouster, citing unclear reasons for the move. Foreign investors holding American depositary receipts (ADRs) control 18.5% of Tata Motors' stock and could influence the vote. Tata Group's holding company, Tata Sons, is attempting to convince investors to support Mistry's removal, but the outcome is uncertain, with more than 50% of investors needed to pass the resolution.

site_title: China SOEs told to stop social welfare services
summary: China has ordered state-owned enterprises (SOEs) to stop providing social welfare services, part of a plan to reduce financial burden on heavily indebted state-owned firms. The move, aimed at reducing costs by 850 billion yuan annually, is expected to cause significant social and financial changes in regions like Pingdingshan, where a single conglomerate, Pingmei Shenma Group, provides extensive services, including hospitals, schools, pensions, and utilities. The deadline for SOEs to ditch their "social functions" is 2020, but Henan province aims to complete the process by the end of 2017, affecting thousands of workers and residents.

site_title: Vanke scraps plan to buy transit-firm stake amid ownership spat
summary: China's Vanke Co scrapped plans to buy a stake in Shenzhen Metro Group Co due to shareholder dissent. The move comes amid a tug-of-war for control with Baoneng Group, Vanke's largest shareholder. The plan, valued at up to $12.5 billion, was intended to fund the purchase. Major shareholders failed to reach an agreement, and Vanke promised not to plan major asset restructuring plans for the next month. This decision follows a public spat between Vanke and Baoneng, with Vanke labeling Baoneng's approach as a "hostile takeover".

site_title: US arsenal to counter hack faces limitations
summary: US intelligence agencies have assembled a range of options to counter Russia's hacking during the 2016 presidential election, including manipulating cyberweapons and exposing financial ties. However, some options have been rejected as ineffective or too risky, and President Barack Obama is now facing a complex calculus on how to use the US cyberarsenal. The goal is to send a clear message to Russia without escalating the confrontation, and Obama has insisted on maintaining "escalation dominance" to ensure a peaceful resolution.

site_title: Cloudier skies ahead for airlines in South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asian airlines face a challenging 2017 due to stiff competition and rising fuel costs. Despite projected profits of $7.3 billion in 2016 and $6.3 billion in 2017, margins are expected to fall, and the sector may turn back into the red. The region's carriers are competing with budget carriers and Gulf airlines, leading to downward pressure on yields. Jet fuel prices are expected to rise from $52 to $65 per barrel, further increasing costs. However, improving cargo revenues and new airport developments, such as Changi Airport's Terminal 4, may provide a bright spot for the region.

site_title: New startup wave challenges Japan's aversion to risk
summary: A wave of startups is emerging in Japan, challenging the country's risk-averse culture. Cash-rich corporations are delegating tech tasks to smaller businesses, with funding reaching a record high of 92.8 billion yen in the first half of the year. Despite this, many startups struggle to raise funds, with foreign investors making up only 10% of investments. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe supports startups as a way to revitalize Japan's economy, but the country still lags behind the US and China in startup funding.

site_title: New LC takes Lexus closer to emotion target
summary: Lexus is aiming to create a more emotional brand by incorporating lifestyle elements into its cars, focusing on both design and performance. The new Lexus LC500, launched in Seville, Spain, embodies this approach with its radical styling, low bonnet line, and large wheels. The car's 10-speed automatic transmission and naturally aspirated V8 engine are designed to provide a better driving experience, akin to enjoying a good dinner or feeling free by the sea. Lexus plans to use the LC's platform architecture for future models, aiming to appeal to a wider public and share technology with other Lexus models.

site_title: 2016: The year of the long shots
summary: US stocks finished near records in 2016 as traders bet on the economy's ability to absorb higher interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average came close to 20,000, a level historically associated with the Dotcom boom, but was ultimately supported by fiscal stimulus and anticipation of further economic growth. Despite concerns over fiscal stimulus and potential market corrections, stocks ended the year strong, with the energy sector rebounding amid reduced oil supplies. The year was marked by unexpected market movements, with many strategists noting that 2016 was the "year of the long shots."

site_title: Asia looking to tap Europe's offshore wind expertise
summary: Asia is seeking to tap into Europe's expertise in offshore wind energy, with countries such as Taiwan and China aiming to boost industrial output through offshore wind development. Dong Energy, a Danish energy company, has established itself as a leader in offshore wind development, with a presence in Asia and a goal of installing 20-30 GW of offshore wind capacity off China's coastline. The company's expertise and experience have attracted interest from policymakers in Taiwan and China, who are seeking to promote offshore wind development and create jobs in the industry.

site_title: Solar energy now cheaper than wind
summary: Solar energy has become the cheapest form of new electricity, surpassing wind power, according to data from Bloomberg New Energy Finance. Unsubsidized solar costs are now lower than coal and natural gas on a larger scale, with new solar projects in emerging markets costing less to build than wind projects. This shift is driven by rapid deployment of solar in China and investment in other countries. The world is adding more capacity for clean energy each year than for fossil fuels, with peak fossil fuel use for electricity potentially reached within the next decade.

images.alt_text: While solar costs were bound to fall below wind eventually, given its steeper price declines, few predicted it would happen this soon.

site_title: Buying by directors up, sales flat; buyback activity declines
summary: Singapore directors made 18 purchases worth S$2.13 million from Dec 12 to 16, up from the previous week. Buyback activity declined with 44 repurchases worth S$1.58 million. Significant purchases were made by AEM Holdings, Sinostar PEC Holdings, Lian Beng Group, and Japan Foods after share price increases.

site_title: Good economic news is now good for stocks?
summary: The US presidential election may bring a shift in market trends, with rising interest rates potentially becoming good news for stocks. Following Donald Trump's election, the major indices have risen to all-time highs despite expectations of higher interest rates. This change in market sentiment may be welcomed, as it could mark a return to normalcy in monetary policy and a reduction in artificially low interest rates that have fueled asset allocation and risk-taking.

site_title: UK firms absorb Brexit shock, get on with business for 2017
summary: UK firms are adapting to the Brexit shock, with many investing in expansion projects despite initial concerns. Orders are strong, and a new growth plan is in place, with companies like Mec Com Ltd and technology giants Facebook and Google announcing plans to create jobs in Britain. Economists are raising their predictions for British economic growth next year, with the Bank of England forecasting a 1.4% growth rate in 2017. Companies are taking precautions to mitigate potential tariffs on exports to the EU, but overall, the economy has barely slowed.

site_title: Asia Wind Energy Association launched in Singapore
summary: The Asia Wind Energy Association (AsiaWEA) was launched in Singapore to promote the growth of wind energy in the Asia-Pacific region. Founded by industry executives, the association aims to coordinate international policy, research, and networking opportunities for wind energy developers, suppliers, and investors. The organization plans to host quarterly membership gatherings, industry-specific seminars, and the inaugural annual Asia Wind Energy Conference in October 2017. The establishment of AsiaWEA aligns with Singapore's position as a leading clean energy hub in Asia, leveraging the country's strong R&D competencies and intellectual property protection.

site_title: Zalando uses a made-in-China approach to take on Amazon
summary: Zalando, Europe's largest digital fashion player, is adopting a made-in-China approach to take on Amazon in the digital fashion market. The company, co-founded by Robert Gentz, has been inspired by China's e-commerce model, which combines brands, retailers, and fashion houses in a single platform. Zalando aims to replicate this model in Europe, partnering with fashion houses and retailers to offer a digital shopping mall experience. The company has spent heavily on logistics hubs and has partnered with brands like Adidas to offer same-day deliveries. Zalando's strategy may give it a competitive edge in Europe's fast-growing online fashion market, but it faces challenges from established players like Amazon and European competitors.

site_title: Metro's swelling needs alarm local govts in US
summary: Metro's financial needs have prompted alarm from local governments in the US, with a projected $1 billion increase in funding required over the next three years to improve the transit system's safety and reliability. The District of Columbia, Maryland, and Northern Virginia are facing a 36% increase in annual operating subsidies and a $600 million jump in capital investments. Without additional funding, officials warn that they may have to cut spending on competing priorities, such as education and infrastructure. Metro officials and experts urge the region to find a dedicated funding source, citing a long-standing financial weakness in the system.

site_title: Henry Heimlich, of famed manoeuvre, dies at 96
summary: Henry Heimlich, the thoracic surgeon who developed the Heimlich maneuver, a lifesaving technique for choking victims, has died at 96. Heimlich, who used the maneuver himself to save an 87-year-old woman's life in 2014, had been credited with saving an estimated 100,000 lives with the technique. Heimlich also developed and patented numerous medical innovations and devices, including mechanical aids for chest surgery and procedures for treating chronic lung disease.

site_title: Rigging charge exposes fish tale behind antibiotic prices
summary: A US pharmaceutical company has been accused of price-gouging for antibiotics. Tanja Vanderlinde, an internist, says patients struggle to afford generic antibiotics like doxycycline due to high deductibles in health plans. The "gold standard" antibiotic is often prescribed for Lyme disease. The issue highlights the high cost of generic medications, with patients forced to pay out-of-pocket for essential treatments.

site_title: Opec deal tests oil majors' risk-reward appetite
summary: OPEC's production cut deal has given oil majors like Total the opportunity to invest again after two years of layoffs and slumping profits. Total's CEO Patrick Pouyanne warned of a potential oil-supply shortfall, but the deal presents a chance for companies like Total to start developing expensive new projects, such as the Brazil and Uganda projects. This could lead to a significant increase in investment, potentially offsetting the cuts made during the downturn.

site_title: Blockchain, a new-age tontine: OCBC chief
summary: OCBC Bank chief Samuel Tsien views blockchain technology as a potential game-changer in finance, likening it to a tontine, a form of informal micro-financing scheme where members contribute to a common pool and bid for loans. While he is optimistic about blockchain as a payment system, he doubts its ability to achieve a fully distributed ledger, citing the need for trust and advice from financial institutions. OCBC has successfully made its first blockchain payment transaction, but expects it to take time for the technology to become commercially available and scalable.

site_title: Gilead Sciences' patent loss to Merck started with a broken friendship
summary: Gilead Sciences may pay Merck US$2.54 billion in patent royalties due to a patent dispute over hepatitis C treatments. The issue began with a broken friendship between two scientists at Idenix, a unit Merck bought in 2014 for US$3.85 billion. Merck claims Idenix developed a new class of compounds to treat the virus, which affects 150 million people globally. The case highlights the complexities of patent disputes and the importance of relationships in the scientific community.

site_title: When the dust settles: 2016 and gold prices
summary: Global markets experienced a tumultuous start in 2016, driven by a Chinese equity selloff and the UK's Brexit vote. Steadily declining gold prices rebounded, only to spike after Donald Trump's election victory. However, following Trump's win, US equities and the dollar rallied, causing gold prices to decline. The year's gains were largely erased, leaving gold prices near their previous levels. The market's uncertainty and the prospect of a stronger greenback may limit gold's ability to recover, leaving its future trajectory uncertain.

site_title: Austria searches freight trains in new frontline on illegal migration
summary: Austria has started searching freight trains traveling from Italy at night to tackle illegal migration, following the deaths of two stowaways who froze to death in the country's Tyrol province earlier this month. Police have picked up about 90 African migrants trying to reach Germany, and are searching all goods trains from Italy between 2200-0600 local time. The new search regime aims to avert further deaths, with temperatures of minus 4 degrees Celsius posing a significant risk to migrants.

images.alt_text: Police pick up 100 to 150 illegal immigrants a day in Austria. The majority of those are found on passenger and freight trains.

site_title: Yen slide and Tokyo stock price climb set to continue
summary: The yen has reached a 10-month low of 118.20 to the dollar, with analysts predicting it will break through the 120 mark and continue to decline. This is expected to boost Tokyo stocks, with the Nikkei 225 index predicted to surpass 20,000 levels. The dollar's surge is linked to US President-elect Donald Trump's election, which has led to increased interest in the dollar and decreased tolerance for a weak yen. Analysts predict a 20-30% upside price potential for Japanese equities, making them a top global performer.

site_title: Asia remains attractive for private banks: LGT's Prince Max
summary: Asia remains attractive for private banks despite growth slowing, according to Prince Max of LGT Group. The acquisition of ABN Amro's private banking business in Asia and the Middle East with $20 billion in assets under management (AUM) is expected to boost LGT's AUM to $160 billion. LGT has been growing organically in Asia, enjoying net new money of $2-3 billion a year, and now employs over 400 people in the region. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand LGT's presence in the region, with a quick integration expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2017.

site_title: Developing staff via charity initiatives
summary: RCMA Group, a global commodities and supply chain management company, has been leveraging its partnership with the Bali Sports Foundation (BSF) to develop its staff through charity initiatives. Since adopting BSF as its corporate charity in 2010, RCMA has seen employees develop deeper connections, confidence, and collaboration through volunteer work in Indonesia. The initiative has also fostered greater knowledge sharing and skills exchange between Singaporean and international employees. By supporting para-athletes and hosting athletes, RCMA aims to strengthen relationships, drive business growth, and invest in its employees' development.

site_title: Economy pays tab for Japan Inc's free lunch on overtime
summary: Japan's economy is subsidizing companies for unpaid overtime, with workers putting in an average of 40.3 hours of unpaid overtime per month, despite the law requiring payment. This culture of long hours and unpaid work is linked to stagnant growth and deflation, and could boost consumer spending by 13.4% if employees were paid for their hours. The government's labor reforms aim to address this issue, but companies have resisted increasing wages, with staff compensation growing only 2.1% since 2012, while household spending has risen just 1.6% during the same period.

site_title: Influx of Chinese investors angers Madagascans
summary: Protests in Soamahamanina, Madagascar, against the Chinese gold mining company Jiuxing have led to its withdrawal, leaving behind empty tents and abandoned land. The protests, which began months ago, were fueled by concerns that the mining operation would ruin local farms and risk "selling the country" to foreign investors. Anti-Chinese sentiment is on the rise in Africa, with Beijing's growing presence in the continent sparking tensions and xenophobia.

images.alt_text: Every Thursday, city residents would take to the streets in downtown Soamahamanina to demonstrate against Jiuxing, which had secured a 40-year gold mining licence on a 7,500-hectare piece of land.

site_title: Bird flu hits British turkey farm
summary: Britain has detected a highly contagious strain of bird flu, H5N8, at a turkey farm in northeast England, prompting the culling of over 5,000 birds. The government has restricted animal movement and animal products around the site, but assures public health risk is "very low" and poses no food safety risk for Christmas turkey supplies. The H5N8 strain, infectious to poultry, has been reported in France, the Netherlands, and Sweden, but is not considered a threat to humans.

site_title: Chicago agricultural commodities end lower over the week
summary: Chicago agricultural commodities ended lower over the week due to profit taking and ample crop stock. Corn futures fell 3.25 cents to $3.5625 per bushel, wheat dropped 7 cents to $4.0925 per bushel, and soyabeans fell 0.75 cents to $10.3675 per bushel. Analysts expect futures to remain range-bound through winter, with the US dollar's rally potentially leading to inflation in emerging economies and a squeeze on US grain exports.

site_title: Asian markets key focus for OCBC in 2017: CEO
summary: OCBC's CEO, Samuel Tsien, expects 2017 to be similar to the second half of 2016, with uncertainty and volatility in global markets. He sees opportunities in Asia, particularly in Asean and China, driven by infrastructure spending and trade agreements. OCBC plans to pursue growth in Indonesia and Myanmar, with a focus on digital banking and structuring financing. Tsien believes Singapore should build on its connectivity role, playing to its strength in structuring financing beyond straight lending. He also expects challenges in emerging markets and cautions against over-reliance on local bankers, but remains optimistic about the prospects of Singapore banks.

images.alt_text: Mr Tsien believes that having local bankers head operations in each Asean market would help to deal with challenges in these emerging markets.

site_title: Chinese developer Vanke calls off deal to acquire Shenzhen Metro property unit
summary: China Vanke Co Ltd, the country's largest property company by sales, is terminating its $6.9 billion deal to acquire a Shenzhen Metro property unit after failing to get approval from major shareholders. The decision comes amid a complex corporate power struggle with Baoneng, a Chinese financial conglomerate seeking to oust Vanke's management. The termination is expected to have minimal impact on Vanke's short-term finances.

site_title: Venezuela cash crisis sparks looting, protests
summary: Venezuela's cash crisis worsened as President Nicolas Maduro's plan to introduce new banknotes sparked looting and protests nationwide. The removal of the 100-bolivar note, worth about three US cents, left people without cash, exacerbating the country's spiraling economic crisis. Thousands queued at the central bank to exchange the old bills, while others rioted, and clashes with police broke out. The government's decision to seal borders with Colombia and Brazil has exacerbated the chaos, leaving Venezuelans struggling to access basic necessities like food and medicine.

site_title: Air Berlin CEO Pichler to step down in February
summary: Air Berlin's CEO Stefan Pichler will step down on February 1, to be replaced by Lufthansa manager Thomas Winkelmann. Pichler has been in the role since 2015, aiming to restore the airline to profit after restructuring Fiji Airways. Air Berlin has recently announced a major restructuring, halving its fleet to around 75 aircraft, in an effort to reduce losses.

site_title: Conservative South Koreans rally to support Park, more big protests loom
summary: Conservative South Koreans rallied in support of President Park Geun-hye, who has been impeached over corruption, countering recent large protests calling for her resignation. Hundreds of thousands gathered in Seoul, with many older supporters claiming the media is fueling anti-Park sentiment. The Constitutional Court must review the impeachment motion, which could lead to a new election in 60 days if Park steps down or the impeachment is upheld. Park's lawyers have disputed the impeachment, calling it without legal basis, and she has refused to step down.

site_title: Deutsche Bank admits to misleading clients in dark-pool trades
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay US$37 million and admit to misleading clients about its dark-pool stock-trading platforms, settling a joint state and federal probe. The bank admitted to violating state and federal securities laws over a two-year period due to technical problems with its proprietary ranking model. The settlement brings the bank closer to resolving several potentially costly legal challenges in the US. The bank's actions were found to be a result of its failure to address known technical issues, rather than intentional misconduct.

site_title: Uber, Lyft face pushback from US hometown taxis
summary: A San Francisco taxi operator, Flywheel Taxi, is seeking to overturn the city's 2013 decision allowing ride-hailing services like Uber and Lyft to operate with lighter regulations. Flywheel claims the move gave Uber and Lyft a competitive advantage, allowing them to flood the streets with unlicensed drivers and undercut traditional taxi companies. Flywheel is seeking to have the regulations overturned, arguing that it has incurred significant costs, including $9 million annually for medallions and permits. A federal judge has already ruled against Uber in similar cases, and the CPUC has asked the court to dismiss Flywheel's lawsuit.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: A tech CEO and self-proclaimed geek, Debbie Lee, shares her weekend plans, which include catching the Star Wars film Rogue One and attending a screening of Werner Herzog's documentary Lo and Behold: Reveries of the Connected World. She also enjoys relaxing with her four adopted cats. The article does not provide further context or conclusions beyond Lee's personal weekend activities.

site_title: Venezuela delays demonetisation of 100 bolivar notes amid rioting, protests
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro delayed the demonetization of the 100 bolivar note due to ongoing protests and rioting, citing "mafias" hoarding cash abroad as the reason. The move was part of a plan to introduce new currency notes, but was delayed when four planes carrying the new currency were sabotaged. The government has closed borders with Colombia and Brazil to curb the alleged hoarding, while Venezuelans face long queues to exchange their currency and inflation continues to soar, with the IMF predicting a 475% inflation rate this year.

site_title: A gingerbread city guards its spicy secrets
summary: In Torun, Poland, medieval city and birthplace of astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus, a centuries-old debate surrounds the secret recipe for authentic gingerbread cookies, known as Torunskie pierniki. Artisans guard their recipes, and only a few master bakers know the precise blend of spices, honey, and flour required to create the perfect cookie. The city's unique location on the spice route and fertile soil contribute to the cookie's distinct flavor, with traditional recipes passed down through generations. Despite modernization, traditional pierniki remain a prized gift, and the city's gingerbread industry continues to thrive.

site_title: The empty days of S Korea's impeached president
summary: South Korea's impeached President Park Geun-hye is spending her days in solitude at the Blue House, the presidential residence, after her impeachment stripped away all substantial powers. With no official duties, she waits for the Constitutional Court to validate her impeachment, a process that could take up to six months. The only external presence is hundreds of thousands of protesters chanting outside the Blue House every Saturday. Aides say she spends her time resting and preparing her impeachment defense, with limited access to her offices and restricted movement within the 250,000-square-meter compound.

site_title: Electoral College, archaic and unloved, prepares to anoint Trump
summary: The Electoral College is set to select Donald Trump as the 45th US president, despite criticism of the system as archaic and unloved. The Electoral College method has been criticized for encouraging candidates to focus on a few key states, ignoring the rest of the country. Despite numerous attempts to reform the system, no changes have been successful. Trump's critics may dream of a last-minute revolt, but it appears the Electoral College will proceed with its selection.

site_title: VW gets weekend for 'intense' talks on diesel-cheating case
summary: A federal judge has said Volkswagen AG has made "substantial progress" in talks to settle a diesel-cheating case involving 80,000 vehicles with 3.0-litre diesel engines. Lawyers for VW, consumers, and the Justice Department are negotiating, but a settlement must be reached by Monday or the case may go to trial. The resolution of this case is a major milestone for VW as it tries to move beyond the scandal, which has already led to a $16.5 billion settlement for 480,000 vehicles with 2.0-litre engines.

site_title: Japan's Idemitsu to buy 33% of Showa Shell by year-end: Nikkei
summary: Japanese refiner Idemitsu Kosan Co will acquire 33.24% of Showa Shell by the end of the year for about 170 billion yen (S$2.1 billion) from Royal Dutch Shell. The planned merger has faced opposition from Idemitsu's founding family, but is expected to receive approval from Japan's Fair Trade Commission as early as next week. The move aims to consolidate the domestic refining industry, which faces pressure due to declining gasoline demand and a shrinking population.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to settle US rate-rigging lawsuit for US$56.5m
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay US$56.5 million to settle a US class action lawsuit accusing it and other banks of rigging the ISDAfix interest rate benchmark used in the US$553 trillion derivatives market. The proposed settlement comes after seven other banks agreed to pay a combined US$324 million to resolve the litigation. The case accuses 14 banks, including Goldman, of conspiring to rig the benchmark from 2009 to 2012, causing rapid trades and delaying trades to influence rates. This settlement is part of several pending cases in Manhattan federal court.

site_title: Fed hawk Lacker says may need more than three hikes in 2017
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Jeffrey Lacker suggests the US central bank may need to raise interest rates more than three times in 2017 to maintain price stability, contradicting the Fed's current forecast of three hikes. Lacker's comments come as investors anticipate policy tightening, pushing 10-year Treasury yields to 2.60%. His views align with those of St Louis Fed chief James Bullard, who expects Trump policies to boost growth but believes it won't be evident until 2018 or 2019.

site_title: Monte dei Paschi to launch share issue on Dec 19
summary: Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Italy's third-largest bank, will launch a share issue on December 19 to raise 5 billion euros (S$7.5 billion) by the end of the year and avoid a state bailout. The bank aims to raise 3.2 billion euros through the share issue, with the remaining capital coming from a debt-to-equity conversion offer. Italy is prepared to step in with a rescue plan if the fundraising plan fails, with the government only injecting capital after the forced conversion of 4.1 billion euros worth of subordinated bonds into shares.

site_title: China's OnePlus to make 3T phone in India from early 2017
summary: China's OnePlus plans to manufacture its 3T smartphone in India starting early 2017 to meet growing demand in the world's second-largest smartphone market. The company, which already generates a third of its global sales from India, has received 200,000 registrations for the 3T model priced at 29,999 rupees. OnePlus will work with multiple partners, including possibly Foxconn, and will continue to sell only on Amazon, with plans to open an experience centre in Bengaluru and add six more service centres.

site_title: EU seeks to calm budget row with Greece
summary: The European Union is seeking to calm a budget row with Greece, with a senior EU official stating that a technical level agreement could be reached in the next few months. European Commission vice-president Valdis Dombrovskis said a second examination of Greece's budget plan will be concluded by the start of 2017, amid surprise handouts to pensioners and a sales tax break for islands. The EU suspended debt relief for Greece after its premier, Alexis Tsipras, announced the handouts, but divisions within the eurozone have emerged, with French President Francois Hollande defending Athens.

site_title: China considers national appeals court on intellectual property rights: paper
summary: China is considering establishing a national appeals court specializing in intellectual property rights, according to a senior judge. This move comes after the country filed 1 million patent applications last year and saw a 19.5% increase in IPR cases in 2014. The proposal is seen as a strategy to improve IPR regulation, following the establishment of specialized IPR courts in Beijing, Guangzhou, and Shanghai, which have handled over 30,000 cases in the past two years.

site_title: Samba gets new rhythms 100 years after first recording
summary: In Rio de Janeiro's Little Africa neighborhood, 100 years after the first recording of samba, the traditional Afro-Brazilian style continues to evolve. Musicians like Walmir Pimentel and Fabiola Machado are reviving the genre, incorporating new rhythms and influences from tango, jazz, and other styles. The art form has also become more inclusive, with all-female band Moca Prosa breaking down sexism barriers. Samba's roots among African slaves in northeastern Brazil have given way to a more diverse and modern sound, with lyrics adapting to contemporary themes and social networks.

site_title: The inside story of Apple's US$14b tax bill
summary: The European Union's Maxforce team, led by Max Lienemeyer, ordered Ireland to collect $13 billion in back taxes from Apple Inc, citing that the country gave Apple a sweetheart deal. Apple's Irish units created stateless entities that allowed the company to avoid paying taxes, with the vast majority attributed to a "head office" with no employees and no specific home base. The EU claims Ireland broke European law by giving Apple a favorable tax arrangement, but Apple maintains it was selectively targeted. The company will face a US tax bill when repatriating profits, and the issue is expected to take years to resolve.

site_title: Nine Inch Nails return with 'impenetrable' music
summary: Nine Inch Nails released an EP titled "Not the Actual Events" on December 23, 2016, after a three-year hiatus. Frontman Trent Reznor described the five-song EP as "impenetrable" and a departure from his recent ambient sound projects. The EP marks the arrival of British sound engineer Atticus Ross as a full member of the band. Reznor also announced that Nine Inch Nails is remastering its major albums for vinyl editions starting in 2017. The EP's release comes after Reznor previously promised new music within 2016.

site_title: Europe: M&A talk, oil helps European shares stay close to 11-month highs
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Friday, staying near 11-month highs, driven by merger and acquisition speculation around Actelion and a rally in oil stocks. The Stoxx 600 index has gained 6% in two weeks, boosted by a rally in banking stocks and the strengthening US dollar.

site_title: Uber defies California, keeps self-driving cars rolling
summary: Uber plans to continue operating its self-driving cars in San Francisco despite a California state order to halt the test program. The company disputes the DMV's interpretation that the cars require a special permit, citing Tesla's optional "autopilot" feature. Uber's vice president, Anthony Levandowski, said the company's autonomous cars have a human driver capable of taking control at any time, and Uber will not seek a permit. The company is taking a "principle" stance, arguing for "uneven application of statewide rules" and will continue to pick up passengers despite potential legal action.

images.alt_text: Uber said Friday it planned to keep its self-driving cars on the streets of San Francisco, defying a state order to halt the test program.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic pilots vote for industrial action over union recognition
summary: Virgin Atlantic pilots voted 80.3% in favor of industrial action, with 88.6% voting to work to rule from Dec 23, over the airline's refusal to recognize their union, the Professional Pilots' Union. This move comes as British Airways cabin crew voted to strike and baggage handlers walk out in separate pay disputes. The action may leave some flights not covered, potentially affecting Christmas holiday air travel. The airline expects its flying program to remain unaffected, but the pilots' union warned that the action could continue indefinitely.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte: Bye-bye America and we don't need your money
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte threatened to repeal the US-Philippines Visiting Forces Agreement, citing the country's ability to find alternative funding sources. He also declared that the US could prepare to leave the Philippines. Duterte expressed frustration over a US decision to defer Manila's re-selection for compact development due to human rights issues. He suggested that China could provide the necessary funding, saying "We do not need the money. China said they will provide so many." Relations with the US could potentially improve under President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Two festive food options are available at Park Bench Deli: the Hot Butter Ball sandwich and Porchetta Sandwich. The latter features pork belly and caramelized onions. Single malt Scotch whisky, Auchentoshan, will take over Monti from Dec 21-24 with a pop-up bar offering whisky pairings with canapés.

site_title: 'Full French experience' at strike-hit Eiffel Tower
summary: A four-day strike at the Eiffel Tower in Paris has left thousands of tourists disappointed, with thousands gathering at the site to protest the management's decision. The strike, spearheaded by the CGT and FO unions, is rooted in French workplace culture and not related to pay rises or working conditions. The dispute centers around the management's plans for the tower, including a major paint-stripping and re-painting job, and fears for ticket office employees. The strike has disrupted activities at the country's most visited monument, with 6,000 people expected daily this Christmas rush.

site_title: Oil rises as output cuts seen curbing glut, US dollar rally stalled
summary: Oil prices rose 2% in New York, marking the first gain in three days, as the US dollar's advance stalled and investors shifted focus to projected production cuts. Goldman Sachs increased its second-quarter oil price forecasts, predicting inventories would return to normal levels by mid-2017. Opec production cuts, combined with a broader deal with non-members, are seen as supportive for prices. The market is expected to remain range-bound, with the US dollar's strength limiting price gains.

site_title: Highways shut, flights grounded as smog blankets China's Tianjin
summary: China's Tianjin city faced severe smog on December 18, 2016, with air quality index readings peaking above 400. Authorities grounded dozens of flights and closed most highways, and the environmental watchdog issued a five-day warning about choking smog in the northeast. The smog, which has affected over 40 cities in the region, prompted residents to stay indoors and curbed traffic and construction work. The situation highlights the ongoing pollution issues in China's industrial areas.

site_title: Boosting women farmers would dramatically cut world hunger: experts
summary: Experts say boosting women farmers would dramatically cut world hunger, with agricultural yields increasing by almost a third if they had equal access to resources. This could result in up to 150 million fewer hungry people worldwide. Women make up 60% of the chronically hungry and 45% of the agricultural workforce, yet own less than 20% of land. Climate change exacerbates the issue, requiring investment in climate-smart agriculture and initiatives that address the gender gap. Experts emphasize the need for concerted efforts to address this gap to avoid trapping rural women in a downward spiral.

site_title: Airbnb seeks to increase fundraising round to US$1b
summary: Airbnb has authorized the sale of an additional $153 million in equity, increasing its fundraising round to approximately $1 billion. The financing values the home-rental startup at around $30 billion. This brings Airbnb's total equity raised to over $3 billion since its founding in 2008. The company has sold at least $556 million in shares in the current round, with investors including CapitalG and Technology Crossover Ventures.

site_title: My Favourite Book
summary: A Singaporean book reviewer praises "Save The Date" by Olga Iserlis, calling it helpful for throwing successful parties. The book was compiled by Rachel Loi, Tay Suan Chiang, and Dylan Tan for SPH Media. This article appears to be part of a lifestyle section, featuring various articles on topics such as food, volunteering, and personal finance.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte defiant over kill admission
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has boasted of killing criminals during his war on drugs, despite international criticism and allegations of mass extrajudicial killings. Over 5,000 people have died since his term began in June, and human rights groups have condemned the violence. Duterte has repeatedly denied breaking any laws, but his government has rejected a UN rights rapporteur's request to investigate the drug war. Duterte's comments have sparked outrage and fears of a breakdown in the rule of law, with some Filipinos expressing hope for the president's campaign to eradicate drugs.

site_title: Keep the trolls on Facebook
summary: In the lead-up to the 2016 US presidential election, many people on Facebook unfriended friends with differing opinions, creating "insular worlds" and limiting social discourse. A Monmouth University poll found 7% of voters had lost a friendship due to differing views. The author argues that unfriending trolls may not be the solution, as it can create echo chambers and limit exposure to opposing viewpoints. Instead, staying in touch with those with differing opinions can foster listening, empathy, and a more nuanced understanding of issues.

site_title: British swimmer abandons Atlantic crossing attempt
summary: British swimmer Ben Hooper has abandoned his attempt to cross the Atlantic Ocean after his support boat was damaged in a storm. Hooper had been at sea for 33 days, swimming 140 of the planned 3,000 kilometers, but was forced to postpone the expedition due to weather issues and technical problems. The 38-year-old had been training for over three years for the journey, which was initially planned to resume at a later date. Only one man, French swimmer Benoit Lecomte, has previously completed a comparable feat across the Atlantic.

site_title: Emotional Lagarde tells trial she acted in France's interests
summary: Christine Lagarde, the IMF chief, testified in her trial in Paris, stating she acted in good faith when authorizing a 404-million-euro payment to tycoon Bernard Tapie to settle a dispute. Lagarde defended her decision to allow the dispute to be resolved by arbitration and her failure to contest the large award linked to Tapie's sale of Adidas to the state-owned Credit Lyonnais bank. She claimed she acted in France's interests, as the court heard the payment was intended to settle a long-running dispute and prevent further litigation.

site_title: China seizes US naval probe in South China Sea: Pentagon
summary: China has seized a US unmanned naval probe in the South China Sea, claiming it was in international waters, according to the Pentagon. The probe was taken by a Chinese submarine rescue ship after a non-violent incident while a US research vessel was retrieving it. The US has called on China to "immediately" return the probe, citing international law. The incident raises tensions in the disputed region, where China has been building artificial islands and fortifying its claims. The US has issued a formal request through diplomatic channels to retrieve the probe.

images.alt_text: China "unlawfully" seized an unmanned US naval probe in international waters in the South China Sea, the Pentagon said Friday, a move sure to heighten tensions around Beijing's military presence in the disputed area.

site_title: Deutsche Bank admits misleading clients in dark pool trades
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay $37 million and admit to misleading clients about its dark pool stock-trading platforms to settle a joint state and federal probe. The bank will acknowledge violating state and federal securities laws over a two-year period due to technical problems with its proprietary model. The US Securities and Exchange Commission and New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said misleading statements would not be tolerated, emphasizing the need for truthful promotion of electronic order routing systems.

site_title: Krystal Choo
summary: Krystal Choo, CEO of social messaging app Wander, believes that being an entrepreneur requires a "slightly delusional" mindset. Growing up in a lower-middle-income family, Choo developed a passion for technology and reading, which led her to start her first company, an e-commerce shoe company, at 19. She later pivoted to create Wander, which aims to create meaningful connections between people through a social group messaging app. Choo attributes her success to her determination and willingness to take risks, despite facing skepticism as a female tech entrepreneur.

site_title: Air-France KLM opens new regional office in Singapore
summary: Air France-KLM has opened a new regional office in Singapore to consolidate its three main businesses, serving passenger transport, cargo, and maintenance services in the Asia-Pacific and Oceania. The move aims to improve competitiveness and operational efficiency, with a goal to grow revenues to €28 billion by 2020 and carry 100 million passengers across 435 aircraft. The new office will boost headcount to 164, covering a larger group of markets, and follows the restructuring of regional offices from six to three, including the Singapore location.

images.alt_text: From left: Stephane Lemaire, vice-president for Asia & Middle East, Air-France KLM Martinair Cargo); Antoine Pussiau, senior vice-president, Air-France KLM, Asia-Pacific; Benjamin Dubertret, Ambassador of France to Singapore; Dominik Wiener-Silva, vice-president of sales, Asia-Pacific, Air France Industries KLM; Gijs van Popta; and Jacques Werner, Ambassador of the Netherlands to Singapore at the opening of the new regional office in Singapore.

site_title: Vancouver homes so pricey, government offering loans for down payments
summary: The British Columbia government in Canada is launching a program to help first-time buyers with down payments on homes in Vancouver, where prices have surged to $1.5 million. The program will offer up to $37,500 in loans with no interest for the first five years, but critics argue it may only encourage more debt and push prices higher. The program aims to help 42,000 households enter the market, but its effectiveness remains uncertain, and some experts warn it may not address the underlying issue of high property values relative to low incomes.

site_title: Ladies First
summary: IWC is launching a new Da Vinci collection featuring round cases, marking a shift towards women's watches as the brand bids farewell to its tonneau case. The collection, set to debut in January, will include highly complicated men's watches and will be marketed through digital channels. IWC's outgoing CEO Georges Kern emphasizes the brand's commitment to preserving its masculine image while catering to women's tastes, with watches designed to be elegant, sporty, and dressy. The move signals a significant change in IWC's product lines, with plans to introduce a fourth female line in the near future.

images.alt_text: Left: Da Vinci Lady Chronograph (2000). Right: Da Vinci Automatic 36
Left: Da Vinci Automatic Moon Phase 36. Right: Lady's Wristwatch (1958)
Left: Ingenieur-Lady SL quartz (1984). Right: Lady's wristwatch (1976)
CEO Georges Kern

site_title: Emerging market debt offers value, says fund manager
summary: BNP Paribas Investment Partners' deputy head of emerging fixed income, JC Sambor, says emerging market debt offers value despite a "lukewarm" macroeconomic picture. The firm is "cautiously positioned" due to the recent US Fed rate hike and dollar surge, but expects medium-term rebound in EM currencies. Sambor notes that institutional funds are under-allocated to EM debt, and high net worth individuals are seeking buy-and-hold products due to higher yields. He expects some credit rating downgrades, but sees room for fiscal and monetary stimuli in EM, making long-term EM debt a compelling investment proposition.

site_title: You are not getting hungry...
summary: People are turning to hypnosis to tackle wellness and beauty issues like weight loss, stress management, and smoking addictions. Celebrities such as Reese Witherspoon and Olivia Munn have credited hypnosis for their personal struggles. Certified hypnotist Elena Mosaner, 36, has built a following in New York, with clients seeking help for weight and stress management. Sessions typically involve guided meditation, affirmations, and daily exercises. While some in traditional medicine are skeptical, doctors like Holly Phillips refer patients to hypnotists, citing its stress-reducing and emotionally refreshing effects.

site_title: UBS axing nearly two dozen jobs in Asia to cut costs: sources
summary: UBS is cutting nearly two dozen jobs in its Asian investment banking business, mainly in Hong Kong and Singapore, as part of a cost-cutting effort. The Swiss bank joins rivals in trimming costs amid sluggish deal volumes in the region. The job cuts will include mid-level staff and managing directors, and are part of UBS's push to slash costs and achieve targeted net cost cuts of 2.1 billion Swiss francs by end-2017.

site_title: 'Tis the season to take a break
summary: Taking a break and utilizing annual leave is crucial for employee well-being and productivity. However, many struggle to take time off due to workplace pressures or poor work culture. Employees who don't take leave often fall into two camps: those who overwork and those who don't plan ahead. To address this, companies can encourage teamwork, provide clear project timelines, and support employees in making handovers. Employers can also set an example by not expecting employees to be contactable during vacation. By prioritizing employee well-being and taking breaks, companies can retain talent and improve overall performance.

site_title: Adrenaline Junkies
summary: Cirque Adrenaline, a live spectacle featuring death-defying acts, premiered in Singapore at Marina Bay Sands' Grand Theatre until December 25. The show combines traditional circus acts with modern elements, including stuntmen, fire-breathers, and aerial stunts. With a lineup of performers, Cirque Adrenaline promises a heart-pounding and jaw-clenching experience. Tickets are available from S$38.50.

site_title: Forget AT&T; the real monopolies are Google and Facebook
summary: Silicon Valley giants Google and Facebook have become the real media monopolies, surpassing the proposed AT&T-Time Warner merger in terms of market value and influence. Alphabet, Google's parent company, has a $550 billion market capitalization, while Facebook has a significant share of the US mobile search market and mobile phone operating systems. These companies dominate the content made available online, allowing them to achieve high profit margins and control the digital menu, shaping users' choices. Regulators should examine their power and consider hearings that include Alphabet and Facebook to address the unregulated world dominated by these Silicon Valley giants.

site_title: 'Great potential' to boost S'pore-Philippines trade, investment
summary: Singapore and the Philippines have a "close bilateral relationship" with great potential for two-way trade and investment. The Philippines is one of Asia's fastest-growing economies and a newly industrialized country, making it an important overseas destination for Singapore businesses. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) plans to work with the Philippine-Singapore Business Council to organize activities in 2017, including business missions and industry roundtable discussions, to promote trade and investment between the two countries.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat, banking shares lead decline
summary: US stocks retreated on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping less than 0.1% to 19,843.41, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declining 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively. Banking shares, including Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, led the decline, reversing gains since the November 8 election. A disappointing home construction report also contributed to the losses. Software company Oracle fell 4.4% after reporting a decline in earnings, while Chipotle Mexican Grill rose 2.5% after appointing new directors.

site_title: Sporty New Ride
summary: BMW's new 7th generation 5 Series features an evolutionary design with sharper lines, a bigger kidney grille, and improved handling. The car is 36mm longer and 100kg lighter, with a new suspension and variable dampers for enhanced comfort. The 5 Series now boasts new four- and six-cylinder turbo petrol engines, and the 540i variant has increased power and reduced emissions. The car also features advanced technology, including electric power steering, rear wheel steering, and a new infotainment system with gesture controls and live pads.

site_title: Merry Moomin Christmas
summary: The Moomins, a beloved Finnish fairy tale character, are featured at Parkway Parade in Singapore this festive season. The pop-up store will offer exclusive merchandise, themed snacks, giveaways, and snow. The Moomins will be on display daily until December 26 at 80 Marine Parade Road.

site_title: Picture Show
summary: The first public cinema in Singapore was a pitched tent set up by a Parsi showman in 1953. Initially, it charged 10 to 50 cents for a ticket. By the 1920s, cinema became a main form of entertainment for Singaporeans. After Loke Yew's death, his wife founded Associated Theatres (now Cathay Organisation) in 1935, which initially screened Western films but later screened Japanese propaganda films during the Japanese Occupation. The Cathay building, now an air-conditioned theatre, remains a historic part of Singapore's history.

site_title: Jingles & Jazz
summary: Jazz singer Alemay Fernandez and Rob Collins will perform at The Black Swan on Dec 23, bringing festive cheer to a sold-out crowd. The event features a four-course dinner and jazz set for $118. The duo previously performed at The Black Swan last Christmas and is set to warm the heart of even the biggest Grinch.

site_title: Trump sets the stage for US-China tensions
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has sparked tensions with China by questioning the "One China policy", which has been a cornerstone of US-China relations since the 1970s. Trump's comments, including a tweet referring to Taiwan's leader as "President of Taiwan", breached diplomatic protocol and were met with a strong reaction from China. China's foreign minister Wang Yi warned that Trump's actions could lead to a confrontation, and analysts speculate that China could retaliate by getting tougher on US companies, intensifying military exercises, and sanctioning arms sales to Taiwan. The move has raised concerns about the future of US-China relations, which are crucial for the global economy.

site_title: Singapore's NODX up a surprise 11.5% in November
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) unexpectedly rose 11.5% in November, contrary to market expectations of a decline. The month-on-month increase was 13.1%, driven by strong gains in exports to the EU, Hong Kong, and China. While the full-year NODX is still expected to decline, analysts see this as a positive sign for 2017 growth, with UOB Bank economist Francis Tan forecasting a 0.7% growth in 2017. This rebound is attributed to a rebound in pharmaceutical exports and increased shipments of specialized machinery and petrochemicals.

site_title: US$100 million deal to save Pier 40 in Manhattan approved
summary: The New York City Council approved a $100 million deal to save Pier 40 in Hudson River Park, allowing a developer to build a 5-tower residential complex in exchange for preserving the pier. The deal includes 1,586 apartments, 30% reserved for low and middle-income tenants, and a public recreation center. The developer agreed to dedicate one building to older tenants, reduce parking spaces, and prioritize local retailers. The project will also create a new South Village Historic District, limiting development in the area.

site_title: Migration control a must, says UK Brexit Secretary
summary: UK Brexit Secretary David Davis emphasizes control of migration as the key direction for exit negotiations with the EU. The UK will not negotiate free movement of people and will instead consider a "hard" or "clean break" Brexit, potentially leaving the single market. The UK government expects to complete talks within 18 months, with a deal to be agreed upon by European leaders, the European Parliament, and the British Parliament. A transitional exit phase is possible, and the UK may negotiate long-term payments for preferential economic access.

site_title: Old Times Goo'd Times
summary: Two new restaurants have opened in Singapore: Ippoh Tempura Bar by Ginza Ippoh and FOO'D by Davide Oldani. Ippoh Tempura Bar brings Osaka-style tempura to Singapore, using fresh and premium ingredients and cooking in prime safflower oil. Chef Masaru Seki, a fifth-generation member of the founding family, will oversee the restaurant. FOO'D by Davide Oldani offers Italian cuisine with a focus on simple ingredients and accessible fine dining. The restaurants' menus feature seasonal ingredients and unique pairings, with prices ranging from $60 to $200 for lunch and $140 to $200 for dinner.

site_title: Right Young Things
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Millennials, born after 1981, have unique privileges due to near-omniscient information and global connections. Brands are adapting to cater to this generation, with companies like Ascott's Lyf and Martell NCF targeting their needs. Social media influencers, like Melissa Koh and ShiGGa Shay, are becoming key marketing ambassadors, with nearly 40% of Twitter users making purchases based on influencer tweets. Experts say brands must connect with millennials early, addressing purpose and values, as the generation seeks authenticity and experiences. By targeting specific social groups and niches, brands can effectively reach and engage with millennials.

site_title: Fintech firm could help unravel mysteries behind flash crashes
summary: Citigroup is investing in Cobalt DL, a distributed ledger technology firm, to help identify causes of flash crashes in the currency market. Flash crashes have occurred at least three times in 14 months, causing significant market volatility. The technology aims to create a single, shared record of trades, replacing fragmented systems. This could help regulators analyze events more quickly and reduce the impact of flash crashes, which are a concern for banks and regulators, including the Bank for International Settlements.

site_title: Clicking with bricks
summary: Singapore's brick-and-mortar stores may be recovering from a decline in footfalls, with some retailers bucking the trend by opening large flagship stores to drive traffic. Despite the rise of online shopping, big names like Uniqlo, Victoria's Secret, and Apple are investing in physical stores to offer a unique shopping experience. Amazon, the world's largest online retailer, is also opening physical stores to complement its e-commerce business. Experts say the future of retail lies at the intersection of e-commerce and brick-and-mortar, with seamless integration and complementary experiences.

images.alt_text: John Little and Cold Storage (above) offer contrasting case studies of Singapore's physical stores.
John Little (above) and Cold Storage offer contrasting case studies of Singapore's physical stores.

site_title: Viva Cuba
summary: Cuba is experiencing a revolution of tourism, with over 3.7 million visitors expected this year. The country's unique blend of natural beauty, Latin-infused culture, and history is drawing in travelers. Proximity to the US and recent improvements in US-Cuba relations have led to a surge in foreign investment, although infrastructure improvements are still needed. Popular destinations include Santiago de Cuba, known for its Afro-Caribbean rhythms and colonial architecture, Camaguey, with its labyrinthine streets and colonial history, and Trinidad, a well-preserved colonial town on Cuba's south-central coast. Havana is also undergoing a transformation, with restored colonial buildings, new hotels, and trendy restaurants and bars.

site_title: Uber Singapore plans to enrol and engage more drivers in 2017
summary: Uber Singapore plans to engage more drivers in 2017, focusing on improving the experience for both riders and drivers. The company will host various initiatives, such as picnics, focus groups, and newsletters, to humanize its brand and promote driver-partners' businesses. Uber aims to increase its pool of driver-partners, which will lead to more competitive prices, and has set its sights on becoming more profitable. The company also reflected on its 2016 performance, with riders traveling 305 million kilometers and Changi Airport being the top destination.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Genting Singapore's stock price has been downgraded to "sell" by OCBC Investment Research due to the Japan's legalization of casinos, which may favor Las Vegas Sands. The company's continued decline in market share is a concern. Meanwhile, Maybank Kim Eng has maintained a neutral stance on Singapore property, citing recent restrictions on capital flows from China, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The impact on developers like CapitaLand, UOL, and Ho Bee is expected to be small, with some companies, such as Wing Tai and CDL, having lower leverage.

images.alt_text: Japan finally legalised casinos on Thursday. We expect that licences will only be awarded late 2018 or 2019 at the earliest.

site_title: Food For Less
summary: Singapore generates 785,500 tonnes of food waste in 2015, prompting Tan Jun Yuan to develop the 11th Hour app, which lists discounts from restaurants and F&B outlets offering leftovers at 30% off. Almost 200 outlets, including Swensens and The Black Swan, have signed up. The app aims to reduce food waste and promote sustainability.

site_title: Many Moons ago
summary: BT now has a Telegram channel for daily updates and weekend content. Thevar 2.0 showcases mod-Indian cuisine, while NCSS partners with organizations to better engage volunteers. The Social Kitchen sets up shop at Bank of Singapore, and CMC Markets partners with Sophia Women to promote financial literacy for women. Meanwhile, discussions on corporate purpose continue, a concept highlighting the importance of businesses prioritizing social and environmental impact alongside profit.

site_title: US: Stocks gain at open, oil shares strong
summary: US stocks rose at the opening of trading on Friday, with petroleum-linked shares leading the gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached 19,905.45, up 0.3% from the previous day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.3% each. The market rebounded from a decline on Wednesday following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, with investors seeking to capitalize on potential gains.

site_title: Rents in London tumble for first time since 2010
summary: London rents have fallen for the first time since 2010, with private rents edging down 0.3% between January and November 2016, according to a report by Landbay. This decline contrasts with a 1.9% rise in rents across the rest of Britain during the same period. Landlords are believed to have rushed into the rental market before a tax increase in April, which may lead to a rise in rents next year.

site_title: Hawkish FOMC this week's main feature
summary: The US Federal Open Markets Committee (FOMC) raised interest rates by 25 basis points, exceeding market expectations. This move unexpectedly boosted the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI), which lost 0.7% for the week. Liquidity has been a concern, but Friday's trading saw a 2.3 billion units worth S$1.3 billion in turnover. Companies such as Singtel and Keppel benefited from the STI's rise, while Genting Singapore dropped after its earnings were affected by Japan's casino legalization news. Analysts predict increased volatility in 2017 due to Brexit, elections, and differing monetary policies.

site_title: Ascott adds to portfolio with 31.3m-euro Irish hotel acquisition
summary: CapitaLand has acquired the 136-unit Temple Bar Hotel in Dublin, Ireland for 31.3 million euros. The acquisition is part of Ascott's expansion in Europe, with the goal of reaching 10,000 units by 2020. The hotel's location in Dublin's city centre and growing tourism industry make it an attractive target, with potential benefits from Brexit and a booming economy in Ireland, expected to grow by 4.9% this year.

site_title: Slowdown in New York's high-end housing market
summary: New York's high-end residential real estate market has slowed down, with several developers facing financial challenges. The market has slowed due to a decrease in demand, rising construction costs, and difficulty in securing construction loans. Several high-profile projects have defaulted or been put on hold, including a planned 290-metre-tall condominium tower on the Upper East Side. However, a slowdown in land prices offers a silver lining for developers, including the Durst Organization, which has acquired several distressed sites and plans to build rental towers.

site_title: Muddy Waters shorts top China dairy farm; shares suspended
summary: China Huishan Dairy Holdings Co, the largest dairy farm operator, had its shares suspended after Muddy Waters Capital LLC alleged the company overstated spending on cow farms and made an unannounced transfer of a subsidiary to a related party. The report, based on months of research, said chairman Yang Kai controls the subsidiary and farms, making it "worth close to zero" in profitability. The shares slid 4.3% to HK$2.69 before suspension, with a market value of HK$37.1 billion.

site_title: Merck wins record US$2.5b patent verdict against Gilead
summary: A US federal jury awarded Merck $2.54 billion in damages against Gilead Sciences, the largest patent-infringement verdict in US history. Gilead's Sovaldi and Harvoni, used to treat hepatitis C, were found to infringe on Merck's patented compound, which is the basis for all major hepatitis C treatments. The jury also found Gilead's use of the compound to be wilful, potentially increasing the award by up to three times. Gilead has pledged to appeal the verdict.

site_title: Connoisseur Class
summary: ANA, Japan's largest airline, has added renowned master chefs Takeshi Kikuchi and Joachim Splichal to its 'The Connoisseurs' program. Starting Dec 16, 2016, business class passengers flying from Japan to the US and Europe can enjoy Kikuchi's Tokyo Shiba Tofuya Ukai specialties. From March to May 2017, Splichal will design the menu for the same flights, offering California-inspired cuisine.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker Yvonne Seah gets two weeks jail and S$10,000 fine in 1MDB case
summary: Former BSI private banker Yvonne Seah Yew Foong was sentenced to two weeks' jail and fined S$10,000 for pleading guilty to three charges related to the 1MDB case. The charges involved forgery of reference letters and failure to disclose suspicious transactions. Seah, who counted Malaysian tycoon Jho Low as a "long-time client," earned S$4.1 million in salary and bonus from 2010 to 2015. The court took a "severe" stance in meting out the sentences, with District Judge Salina Ishak stating that a deterrent sentence was warranted.

site_title: Changi Airport Terminal 4 construction completed, on track for launch in 2H17
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 construction is complete, with a temporary occupancy permit received this month. The two-storey terminal, with a capacity for 16 million passengers, will feature fast and seamless travel (FAST) initiatives. The next phase of development will include interior fittings and training programs for airport staff.
