summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has revised its 2017 growth and inflation forecasts, predicting 1.7% growth and 1.3% inflation, up from 1.6% and 1.2% previously. ECB President Mario Draghi also unveiled 2019 projections, forecasting 1.6% growth and 1.7% inflation, nearing the bank's target of 2%. The revised forecasts are a positive sign for the European economy, indicating a potential recovery.

site_title: Trump picks fossil fuel ally to head environment agency
summary: President-elect Donald Trump announced the nomination of Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to head the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), despite opposition from critics who call him a climate change denier and a fossil fuel ally. Pruitt, a staunch opponent of EPA regulations, has sued the agency on behalf of Oklahoma utilities. Trump stated that Pruitt will "reverse this trend" and promote environmental protection while also promoting jobs and opportunity. Critics argue that Pruitt's nomination is a poor choice to lead the fight against climate change and environmental protection.

site_title: Oriental lodges report with CAD in relation to possible breach of securities laws
summary: Oriental Group Ltd has reported to the Commercial Affairs Department in Singapore regarding possible breaches of securities laws and other offences related to irregularities in its operations in Singapore and China. A special audit report by RSM Corporate Advisory highlighted potential legal and regulatory breaches from 2013 to 2015, involving former key directors and officers. The company is seeking legal advice and has received letters of demand for repayment of S$91,468.17 from Lian Hoe Hardware Pte Ltd, with a deadline for payment by December 13.

site_title: Toxic rice wine kills 10, hospitalises 50 in Cambodia
summary: Cambodia reports 10 deaths and 50 hospitalizations due to toxic rice wine, brewed with methanol, in a central village. The ceremonial drink is a staple at Cambodian festivals and funerals, but improper brewing can be deadly. This is not the first incident, as a similar outbreak occurred last year, killing 19 people and hospitalizing 200. Authorities believe tainted wine was responsible for the recent wave of deaths.

site_title: Zynga turnaround hinges on epic battles being played on phones
summary: Zynga, a video-game designer, is counting on its new mobile game "Dawn of Titans" to reverse years of losses and regain growth. The game, featuring epic battles and ferocious characters, launches as a free download for phones and tablets. Analysts expect strong monetization, with potential revenue of over $25 million per quarter. The game's success could validate Zynga's "fewer, bigger, better" strategy, focusing on higher-quality releases, and take sales from rivals.

site_title: ECB unexpectedly cuts asset buys to 60b euros per month from April
summary: The European Central Bank unexpectedly cut its monthly asset purchases to 60 billion euros from April, down from 80 billion euros. The decision, made to fight deflation, will continue until the end of 2017 or longer. Markets were expecting a six-month extension at the current pace. The ECB also kept its interest rates unchanged, with the primary interest rate at -0.40% and the marginal lending facility rate at 0.25%. The decision was made to provide fresh economic forecasts and detail on the December decisions at an upcoming news conference by ECB President Mario Draghi.

site_title: South Korea's Kia to start assembling cars in Pakistan
summary: South Korea's Kia Motor Co plans to start assembling cars in Pakistan, with local partner Lucky Cement investing 12 billion rupees (S$163.36 million) in a new plant. Kia had previously assembled cars in Pakistan but halted production due to disappointing sales. The new venture aims to manufacture and sell Kia vehicles, parts, and accessories in the country, which is expected to boost competition in the Japanese-dominated car market and potentially lower car prices. This move comes after Renault agreed to invest in a new factory in Pakistan, and the government introduced a new auto policy favoring new entrants.

images.alt_text: [ISLAMABAD] South Korean carmaker Kia Motor Co will start assembling cars in Pakistan, according to a local partner that is planning to invest 12 billion rupees (S$163.36 million) to set up a plant and manufacture the Kia vehicles.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as ECB trims stimulus program
summary: US stocks remained flat in early trade Thursday as the European Central Bank (ECB) announced it would decrease the pace of bond-buying, trimming its stimulus program to 60 billion euros per month in March from 80 billion euros. The move was seen as a step towards tapering its asset purchases, but ECB President Draghi's comments remained dovish.

site_title: Hot stock: Nico Steel faces SGX query as stock surges 31%
summary: Nico Steel's stock surged 31% after being queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The stock price rose to S$0.021, with 70 million shares traded. The query follows the sudden increase in trading activity, making it the second-most actively traded stock.

site_title: Australia: Shares up for third session
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 5,543.60, for a third consecutive session, driven by expectations of a European Central Bank extension to its quantitative easing program and strong Chinese import data. The material index rose 1.5% and financials rose 1.7%, with the 'Big Four' Australian banks gaining. China's trade figures beat forecasts, with imports of major commodities surging.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Nomura has cut its 2017 GDP growth forecast for Singapore, citing the openness of the economy and domestic labor market weakness. HDB resale prices rose 0.2% in November. Deutsche Bank predicts Singapore Inc needs a restructuring amid tech lag. AccorHotels invested S$24m for a 5% stake in Banyan Tree. The Straits Times Index closed firm, recording a net loss of 0.98 points.

images.alt_text: NOMURA has cut its 2017 GDP (gross domestic product) growth forecast for Singapore, citing the openness of the economy here and domestic weakness in the labour market. PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.280 points to 1643.750 on Thursday, with a volume of 1.092 billion lots worth RM1.568 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 390 to 313, resulting in a higher closing price.

site_title: Global airline industry to hit record profit of US$35.6b in 2016: Iata
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has revised its 2016 profit forecast to US$35.6 billion, lower than its June projection of US$39.4 billion, due to slower global growth and rising costs. This will still be the highest absolute profit generated by the industry, with a net profit margin of 5.1%. Despite this, growth is expected to pick up in 2017, but rising oil prices will impact airline profits.

site_title: UK house prices rise as supply fails to match demand growth
summary: UK house prices rose to a seven-month high in November, reaching a level not seen since April, as supply failed to keep up with moderate demand growth. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported a 30-point index, with respondents expecting prices to rise in the coming three months. However, confidence in London's market is lower due to tax changes, and the Bank of England warned that the outlook is uncertain. Despite this, a net 13% of surveyors reported a rise in new buyer inquiries, with 40 expecting growth in prices for the coming year.

site_title: Michael Jordan scores China legal victory for his chinese name
summary: China's Supreme People's Court ruled that Michael Jordan can have his Chinese name back, "Qiaodan," revoked from sportswear-maker Qiaodan Sports Co, which had registered the name more than a decade ago. The court agreed that Jordan's Chinese name is "well-recognised" in China and he should have the legal right to it. Qiaodan Sports must give up its trademark registrations of the Chinese version of Qiaodan. The decision may set a precedent for foreign companies seeking to protect intellectual property rights in China, but more legal action is needed for a broader impact.

images.alt_text: China's top court ruled that Hall-of-Fame basketball player Michael Jordan can have his name back.

site_title: Singapore shares close firm even as STI slips into the red
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped into the red on Thursday, closing at 2,958.86 with a net loss of 0.98 points. Despite this, the broad market remained marginally firm, with 240 rises and 216 falls. The index reached an intraday high of 2,980 earlier in the day. Trading volume was 1.8 billion units worth S$1.4 billion.

site_title: Fifa chief Infantino defends 48-team World Cup
summary: Fifa President Gianni Infantino has defended his proposal for a 48-team World Cup, stating it won't extend the tournament length or require more venues. The format would involve 16 groups of three teams, with the same 32-day duration and 12 stadiums as the current format. Infantino argued that the added teams would bring more countries and regions to the tournament, increasing its value and quality. Critics, including Germany coach Joachim Loew, have expressed concerns that adding 16 teams would dilute the tournament's quality.

site_title: Thailand to resume peace talks with Muslim separatists in Malaysia
summary: Thailand is set to resume peace talks with Muslim separatists in Malaysia next week, following a September round that ended without progress. The talks aim to minimize losses and violence in southern Thailand, where over 6,500 people have been killed in a decades-long insurgency. The Thai government will discuss "safety zones" to limit insurgency-related fighting and build trust. The talks are seen as a crucial step to addressing the grievances of Muslim separatists in southern Thailand.

site_title: China's yuan weakens on US dollar demand after Nov drop in reserves
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Thursday, falling to 6.8790 per US dollar, due to strong corporate demand for the US currency. The move came after China announced a November drop in foreign exchange reserves to the lowest level in nearly six years. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8731 per US dollar, firmer than the previous fix, but the spot market opened at 6.8796 per US dollar, 70 pips weaker than the previous late session close.

site_title: Glencore, Qatar buy 10.2b euros stake in Russian state oil giant
summary: Glencore and Qatar's sovereign wealth fund agreed to buy a 10.2 billion euro stake in Russia's largest oil producer, Rosneft PJSC, in a deal valued at 10.5 billion euros. The purchase gives the buyers a 19.5% stake in Rosneft and marks a triumph for Russian President Vladimir Putin over sanctions imposed by the West. The deal, which is expected to close in mid-December, is the largest foreign investment in Russia since the crisis in Ukraine and provides a boost to Rosneft shares, which jumped 6.2% to a record.

site_title: South Korean lawmakers set impeachment vote in motion
summary: South Korean lawmakers voted to set in motion the impeachment of President Park Geun-Hye over a corruption scandal, with a full vote scheduled for Friday. The motion accuses her of constitutional and criminal violations, including bribery, abuse of power, and failing to protect lives. Park has said she would accept a parliamentary decision, but will remain in office while the motion is considered by the Constitutional Court, which could result in her ouster as the first democratically elected South Korean president to do so.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up for 3rd day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the third consecutive day, driven by gains on Wall Street despite concerns over China's falling foreign exchange reserves and capital outflows. The Hang Seng index added 0.3% to 22,861.84 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index rose 0.7% to 9,896.82 points. The rally was tempered by weakness in mainland shares and anticipation of potential European Central Bank policy changes.

site_title: Banks in UK plan possible Paris move on Brexit: regulator
summary: International banks in the UK have inquired about relocating their operations to Paris following Britain's Brexit vote. France's markets regulator, the AMF, has received practical questions from large banks regarding their operations and relationship with French regulators. The prospect of regulating banks moving to Paris is seen as a "welcome challenge" but also poses a risk of new competition between countries. With the UK's formal EU divorce process set to trigger by the end of March 2017, firms may lose EU "passporting" rights, potentially prompting companies to move some activities to continental Europe.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes at highest this year
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed at its highest this year, rising 1.45% to 18,765.47, driven by Wall Street's record highs and anticipation of a European Central Bank meeting. The broader Topix index also gained 1.48% to 1,512.69. The positive move was attributed to investors' optimism over the potential for interest rate hikes and a strong US economy.

site_title: AirAsia in component support deal with Air France maintenance unit
summary: AirAsia has signed a US$105 million component support agreement with Air France Industries KLM Engineering & Maintenance (AFI KLM E&M) for its Airbus A320neo passenger jets. The 10-year contract covers 304 A320neo jets, with the agreement being signed in the presence of AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes and Air France CEO Franck Terner.

images.alt_text: [KUALA LUMPUR] Malaysian budget carrier AirAsia Bhd said on Thursday that it has signed a US$105 million component support agreement for its fleet of Airbus A320neo passenger jets with Air France Industries KLM Engineering & Maintenance (AFI KLM E&M).

site_title: Japan plans tax break to encourage spouses to work more hours
summary: Japan's ruling coalition approved a plan to increase a tax credit for married couples to encourage part-time working spouses to work more hours, aiming to address labour shortages in the country's fast-ageing society. The plan lets primary earners claim a tax deduction of 380,000 yen if their spouses earn up to 1.5 million yen, up from 1.03 million yen. The move aims to relieve chronic labour shortages and stimulate economic growth, but economists doubt if it alone will expand employment of medium- to low-income part-timers.

site_title: Nomura sounds bearish call on S'pore economy, cuts 2017 GDP growth forecast
summary: Nomura has cut its 2017 GDP growth forecast for Singapore to 0.7% due to concerns over the ultra-open economy, domestic labor market weakness, and potential trade protectionism. The bank cites UK Brexit, US trade policies, and European political risks as factors. Nomura expects firms to struggle with productivity growth, and the government to take a more hands-on approach to develop new sectors and retrain workers. The medium-term outlook remains downbeat, with labor productivity growth still lackluster and demographics unfavorable.

site_title: Moody's sees structural strength in Singapore amid restructuring, weak trade
summary: Moody's has maintained Singapore's Aaa rating and stable outlook, citing the country's structural strengths despite a prolonged slowdown in global trade. Singapore's restructuring efforts and fiscal buffers provide a cushion, with a high current account surplus and robust fiscal reserves. The country's aging population and restricted foreign worker inflows pose challenges, but Moody's notes that Singapore's economy has matured and its GDP per capita remains the highest in the Asia-Pacific. Household assets provide a substantial buffer against rising interest rates and softening real estate prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance as global stocks rally before ECB decision
summary: European stocks advanced on Thursday ahead of the ECB's policy meeting, with the FTSE 100 rising a few points to 6,904.71, the DAX 30 gaining 0.5%, and the CAC 40 rising 0.3%. The gains were attributed to a rally in global stocks and anticipation of the ECB's decision, which could impact European markets.

site_title: Manhattan's apartment landlords prop up market with incentives
summary: Manhattan apartment landlords are offering incentives such as free rent or discounted broker fees to attract tenants in a softening market. Incentives were given on 25% of new leases in November, up from 14% a year earlier. Median rent without concessions was $3,350, down 0.3% from last year, while with concessions it was $3,264, a decline of 1.6%. The vacancy rate rose to 2.11%, the highest in over seven years, suggesting incentives may not be enough to lure tenants.

site_title: English poised to be New Zealand leader as rivals quit race
summary: Bill English is poised to become New Zealand's next prime minister after rivals Jonathan Coleman and Judith Collins withdraw from the leadership race. English, the 54-year-old finance minister, will become prime minister if the National Party caucus formally endorses him on December 12. English has a strong economic platform, including a half-year budget update forecasting rising surpluses and a stronger economy. He is seen as a safe pair of hands, having overseen much of the economic reform under previous Prime Minister John Key.

site_title: Deutsche Bank records alleged to show silver-price rigging
summary: Deutsche Bank has released documents that allegedly show silver-price rigging by UBS Group AG, HSBC Holdings Plc, Bank of Nova Scotia, and other firms. The documents, part of a 2014 lawsuit settlement, provide "smoking gun" proof of a conspiracy to manipulate the silver market. Traders coordinated trades in advance of a daily phone call, fixed prices, and used illegal strategies to rig the market. The plaintiffs, seeking to file a new complaint, claim the scheme "far surpasses" earlier allegations, and are now seeking permission to include claims against additional banks.

site_title: Mahathir no longer invited to inauguration of Malaysia's new king: report
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has been excluded from attending the inauguration of the new king on December 13, amid a bitter feud with incumbent Prime Minister Najib Razak. The Conference of Rulers withdrew the invitation, citing Mahathir's aide. This move is seen as a snub to Mahathir, who has been critical of Najib's government. The decision may further escalate tensions between the two leaders.

site_title: China's illegal scrap crackdown zeros in on biggest steel city
summary: China's crackdown on illegal steel mills in Tangshan, the nation's biggest steel-making city, targets 6% of output, affecting 6 million tons of steel produced from scrap. The move aims to eliminate substandard steel, boosting demand for high-grade iron ore and potentially driving up prices. Steel futures have surged, with rebar and coil rising by 50% this quarter, but prices corrected on Thursday after the recent rally. The crackdown may cut supply at a time of robust demand, boosting profits at larger mills and benefiting top resources companies such as Posco and Rio Tinto.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise on upbeat export data, overseas gains
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose to their highest in nearly a month-and-a-half on Thursday, driven by gains in overseas markets and strong November exports data. Exports grew at a four-year high, boosted by global retailers stocking up on hi-tech gadgets for the year-end shopping season. The main Taiex index rose 0.9%, with Hon Hai Precision's 1.8% gain attributed to potential US manufacturing expansion. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: 'Handcuff king' Houdini's secrets unlocked in Hungary
summary: The House of Houdini, a Hungarian museum showcasing the secrets of magician Harry Houdini, has been opened in Budapest. The museum features handcuffs, padlocks, and props used by Houdini in performances, including a box from a "cut in half" illusion. A recently discovered bible signed by Houdini as a 19-year-old has also been added to the collection. The museum's owner, David Merlini, is a fellow escapologist who has dedicated his life to collecting Houdini's items, aiming to pay tribute to the illusionist and keep his legacy alive.

site_title: China top court rules in favour of Michael Jordan in trademark case
summary: China's top court has ruled in favour of former basketball star Michael Jordan in a trademark case against Qiaodan Sports, a sportswear firm in southern Fujian province. Jordan sued the company in 2012, alleging they used his Chinese name and jersey number "23" without permission. The court overturned earlier rulings against Jordan, upholding his claim. This decision reverses a 2015 court ruling that favoured Qiaodan Sports.

site_title: Solar Impulse founder sees electric passenger plane in 10 years
summary: Bertrand Piccard, co-founder of Solar Impulse, predicts electric passenger planes will operate in about 10 years. Despite concerns over US President-elect Donald Trump's appointment of a fossil fuel industry defender, Piccard remains optimistic about global clean technology efforts. Since completing the world's first fuel-free flight in July, Piccard and fellow pilot Andre Borschberg have worked on projects to apply their plane's technologies to other applications, including electric passenger planes.

images.alt_text: The co-founder of a project that saw a solar-powered aircraft complete the first fuel-free flight around the world this year expects electric passenger planes to operate in just under 10 years.

site_title: US policy under Trump may cut Indonesia's 2017 growth pace
summary: Indonesia's growth pace for 2017 is expected to slow by nearly half a percentage point if US President Donald Trump implements all his proposed policies, including a 45% tariff on Chinese imports. According to development planning minister Bambang Brodjonegoro, a 0.41 percentage point slowdown would occur under an extreme scenario, mainly due to a potential economic slowdown in China, which could reduce Indonesia's growth rate by 0.72 percentage points. The government plans to improve infrastructure projects and spend money timely to maintain growth momentum.

images.alt_text: [JAKARTA] Indonesia's growth pace in 2017 will be reduced by nearly half a percentage point if Donald Trump as US president implements all the policies he advocated while campaigning, the development planning minister said on Thursday.

site_title: Microsoft unveils Windows 10 for Qualcomm chips, a blow to Intel
summary: Microsoft has unveiled a version of Windows 10 designed for laptops powered by Qualcomm chips, a move that could challenge Intel's dominance in PCs and help Microsoft gain a foothold in mobile computing. The first devices are expected to be available next year, and the effort will allow Windows to run on devices with integrated cellular connections, enabling sleeker and more connected devices. This move follows Microsoft's previous attempt to bring Windows to mobile devices, which resulted in significant losses.

site_title: Urgent appeal for supplies after strong Indonesia quake
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake in Indonesia's Aceh province has killed over 100 people and injured over 700, with thousands left homeless. The quake, which struck on December 8, 2016, has caused widespread destruction, including leveling hundreds of homes, mosques, and businesses. Medical supplies and doctors are urgently needed to treat the injured, with the region's hospitals overwhelmed. Thousands of soldiers and emergency personnel are working to clear rubble and provide aid, with President Joko Widodo appealing for Indonesian citizens to pray for those affected.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks near 6-week high, Samsung Electronics hits record, won firms
summary: South Korean shares rose nearly one percent, reaching a six-week high, driven by gains on Wall Street and in Samsung Electronics, which hit a record high of 1,801,000 won. Foreign investors purchased 181.5 billion won worth of Kospi shares, supporting the index. Despite concerns over the South Korean economy and the impeachment vote on President Park Geun-Hye, investors remained bullish on Samsung Electronics ahead of its new product release.

site_title: China trade rebounds on strong demand, weakening currency
summary: China's exports rebounded 5.9% in November, driven by strong demand and a cheaper yuan. Imports rose 13% and resulted in a trade surplus of 298.1 billion yuan. The currency's 10% decline against the dollar since August 2015 suggests demand remains intact despite potential headwinds and policy uncertainty ahead of Donald Trump's presidency.

site_title: Airbnb backs off fight with governments, offers policy suggestions
summary: Airbnb released a set of policy suggestions for governments considering new laws on home-renting. The document proposes collecting lodging taxes from hosts, limiting nightly rentals, and setting up a permitting system. This comes after the company agreed to drop a lawsuit against New York City and enforce rental restrictions in London and Amsterdam. Airbnb aims to work with lawmakers to "get this right" and offers the policy suggestions as a resource for governments drafting or amending rules. The move is seen as a conciliatory gesture following previous concessions.

site_title: With fintech, Hong Kong-Singapore rivalry gets a new twist
summary: Singapore is gaining ground in the fintech industry, attracting more companies than Hong Kong with its tax benefits, government support, and access to regional markets. The city-state's fintech ecosystem has been recognized globally, ranking fourth among global fintech hubs, according to Ernst & Young. Companies such as Marvelstone Group and MatchMove Pay Pte have chosen Singapore as their headquarters, while Hong Kong is moving to catch up with the establishment of a Fintech Innovation Hub and sandbox. Despite Hong Kong's history as a major fundraising center, it faces challenges in attracting startups and talent, with Singapore emerging as a more attractive destination for fintech companies.

site_title: Actor Russell Crowe won't be charged for scuffle with rapper
summary: Actor Russell Crowe won't be charged for a scuffle with rapper Azealia Banks in October 2016 at his Beverly Hills hotel room. Prosecutors found that Banks was the assaultive party, with witnesses describing her as drunk or on drugs, using racial slurs and threatening violence. Banks had filed a police report, claiming Crowe grabbed her by the neck and spat on her, but no visible injuries were reported. The Los Angeles District Attorney's office deemed the incident "incidental" to preventing more serious violence.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars rise on risk appetite, yen slumps vs kiwi
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar, with the Aussie reaching its highest level in three weeks and the kiwi reaching a 12-month high against the yen. This surge in risk appetite was driven by strong commodity prices and upbeat economic outlooks, despite weak data showing the Australian economy shrinking for the first time in 11 years. Interbank futures suggest no rate cut in the near future, allowing the Aussie to break above key resistance levels.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.63 points to 1639.39. The market saw 17.72 million lots traded worth RM11.02 million, with 104 gainers for every 25 losers.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.2% in November from October: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.2% in November 2016 compared to October, according to the SRX Property Price Index. This marks a 0.7% decline from a year ago and an 11.3% drop since the peak in April 2013. Resale volume fell 5.3% in November but increased by 7.1% on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: Vietnam warns of return of protectionism as TPP hopes fade
summary: Vietnam Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc warned of the risk of protectionism as Southeast Asian nations face potential tighter trade controls in the US. The country's export-dependent economy would be significantly impacted if President-elect Donald Trump imposes trade barriers and opposes the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a preferential trade agreement covering 40% of the global economy. Vietnam's exports rose 10% in the first nine months of 2023, contrasting with Indonesia's 9% decline and the Philippines and Singapore's little change. The government plans to improve the nation's investment climate and increase domestic companies.

site_title: Oil prices rise on US crude stock decline, weaker US dollar
summary: Oil prices rose due to a weaker US dollar and a decline in US crude stocks, with international Brent crude futures increasing 18 US cents to $53.18 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices rising 29 US cents to $50.06 a barrel. A drawdown of 2.4 million barrels in US crude inventories and a 3.8 million barrel increase in stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub contributed to the price increase. The agreement between Opec and Russia to cut production aims to rebalance markets and prop up prices.

site_title: Original Madame Butterfly in Milan, 112 years later
summary: La Scala in Milan performed the original version of Giacomo Puccini's opera Madame Butterfly for the first time in 112 years, 112 years after its 1904 premiere, which was met with controversy and criticism. The original version, which included a harakiri scene, was booed and hissed by the audience and later withdrawn due to public backlash. A revised version was later performed and became a triumph, leading to the opera's global popularity. The recent performance was well-received by modern audiences, offering a unique opportunity to hear the opera in its original form.

site_title: Emirates ends A380 delivery standoff as Rolls agrees to fund fix
summary: Emirates has resolved its A380 delivery standoff with Rolls-Royce Holdings after the UK manufacturer agreed to fund fixes for performance and maintenance concerns. Emirates will take its first A380 with Trent 900 engines on December 16, two weeks later than planned. The deal involves technical and commercial elements and addresses issues with engine wear in Dubai's desert climate. Emirates has ordered 217 Trent 900s and plans to take 50 aircraft through 2019 and 25 more from 2021, with Airbus committed to supplying the model until 2026.

images.alt_text: Emirates, the biggest long-haul airline, said it struck a deal to accept deliveries of A380 jets powered by Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc engines after the UK manufacturer agreed to fund measures to address performance and maintenance concerns.

site_title: 'Star Wars' fans get early Christmas gift with 'Rogue One'
summary: "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" is set to release on December 16, 2016, as an early Christmas gift for fans of the "Star Wars" franchise. The film, directed by Gareth Edwards, is a spin-off that takes place just before the original 1977 film "A New Hope." The movie follows rebel Jyn Erso as she embarks on a mission to destroy a planet-sized Death Star. With a budget of $200 million, analysts expect the film to open at up to $150 million, building on the success of "The Force Awakens."

site_title: Broker's take: Singapore Inc due for makeover amid tech lag, says Deutsche Bank
summary: Deutsche Bank predicts Singapore Inc is due for a restructuring due to technology disruptions and intensified competition from regional peers. The city-state's Temasek-linked companies may need to improve their capital structure, with a focus on return on equity. The bank expects Singapore to shift towards building a Smart Nation, with technology and innovation at the forefront of its economic restructuring, and suggests that restructuring and rebuilding Singapore champions could be a key focus in 2017. This comes amid heightened competition from regional peers and a need for better capital management initiatives.

site_title: Trump taps wrestling tycoon to head small-business agency
summary: President-elect Donald Trump nominated wrestling tycoon Linda McMahon to head the Small Business Administration, a cabinet-level position. McMahon, 68, was chosen by Trump for her experience as WWE's CEO, growing the company from a 13-person operation to a global enterprise with over 800 employees. Trump praised McMahon as "one of the country's top female executives" and said she will be a "phenomenal leader" for small businesses. McMahon, married to WWE owner Vince McMahon for 50 years, is set to join Trump's cabinet in January.

site_title: Lululemon quarterly sales top expectations, shares jump
summary: Lululemon Athletica Inc reported quarterly profit beating analysts' forecasts, driven by higher-than-expected gross margins and sales. The company's gross margin rose to 51.1% and third-quarter sales grew 7%, exceeding expectations. Net income rose to $68.3 million, and shares jumped 10% in after-market trading. CEO Laurent Potdevin stated the company is on track to double revenue and earnings in the next five years.

site_title: Japan Q3 GDP revised down to +0.3% q-o-q
summary: Japan's economy grew at a revised annualized rate of 1.3% in the July-September quarter, down from a preliminary 2.2% annualized growth. The quarter-on-quarter growth rate was 0.3%, down from a preliminary 0.5% and median estimate of 0.6%. The change in base year for calculating GDP made forecasting more difficult.

site_title: Australia: Shares stoked by miners, ECB stimulus hopes, New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by gains in basic materials stocks, particularly miners like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, which rose 1-4%. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 1.2% to 5,545.7. Expectations of a European Central Bank stimulus extension also boosted sentiment. Financial stocks, including the 'Big Four' Australian banks, climbed to a 15-month high. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose, with gains in financial and consumer shares offsetting losses in telcos.

site_title: Asia: Stocks take cue from US, rising with bonds ahead of ECB
summary: Asian stocks rose to a one-month high, driven by a surge in US equities and declining bond yields ahead of the European Central Bank's policy update. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.8% as banks and mining companies fueled gains in Tokyo, Sydney, and Hong Kong. The euro and yen maintained gains, while the New Zealand dollar and Korean won strengthened. Yields on Australian bonds fell to their lowest level this month, and oil edged up to $50 a barrel. Expectations of the ECB prolonging its asset-buying program provided a boost to US equities, which had been struggling to extend their rally since Donald Trump's election win.

site_title: Vietnam Air to lease 20 A321neo planes to add regional flights
summary: Vietnam Airlines plans to lease 20 Airbus A321neo planes to expand its domestic and regional flights, starting deliveries in 2018. The airline aims to add flights within a five-hour radius, including the Hanoi-Ho Chi Minh City route. Vietnam Airlines is also planning to carry out its own flights to the US by late 2018, with options to use either Boeing's 787 Dreamliner or Airbus's A350 for the route. The airline reached a record 20 million passengers for the year and predicts 10% passenger growth next year.

site_title: Update: 10am market open for delayed opening for some derivatives contracts, says SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced a delayed opening for some derivatives contracts, including Nikkei 225 Index futures, at 10am. The affected members have been informed and SGX will update on the situation as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX) said on Thursday there has been a delay in commencement of trading in some derivatives contracts.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.88% at the open on December 8, 2016, following another record on Wall Street. The Hang Seng index reached 23,001.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. Investors await the European Central Bank meeting later in the day.

site_title: AT&T defends Time Warner megadeal to skeptical lawmakers
summary: AT&T defended its $85 billion megadeal for Time Warner, stating it would be "pro-competitive" and give consumers new lower-priced options. AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson said the deal would make the company a more formidable competitor to cable, increasing competition and offering innovative content and distribution. However, lawmakers and consumer advocates expressed skepticism, citing concerns about the deal concentrating power in one firm and potentially leading to higher prices and fewer programming options for consumers.

site_title: Jason Holdings' creditors to meet to approve scheme of arrangement
summary: Jason Holdings, a Singapore-based flooring company, has received approval from Singapore's High Court for its scheme of arrangement. The company's creditors will meet by February 1, 2017, to approve the plan, which aims to repay around S$1.69 million to ANZ bank. The company's executive directors, Jason Sim Chon Ang and Sim Choon Joo, have also been sent letters of demand for full repayment.

site_title: Royal Caribbean, Norwegian Cruise lines launch Cuba service
summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. and Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd. have received Cuban government approval to launch services to the island. Norwegian's Marina will begin sailing from Miami on March 7, while Royal Caribbean will announce its Florida-to-Cuba itineraries soon. This marks the first time all three of the world's largest cruise companies can serve the market, following Carnival Corp's introduction of its Fathom brand in May. The Norwegian brands will operate for a short season, while Royal Caribbean will announce its itineraries in the near future.

site_title: UK housing, hiring stay resilient despite Brexit vote: surveys
summary: British house prices rose 30% in November, the largest increase in seven months, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. Companies also hired more workers, suggesting the economy remains resilient despite the Brexit vote. However, a low number of prospective buyers and an uncertain economic outlook are expected to limit market recovery. The UK economy contracted for the second month, adding to concerns about its future growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Banyan Tree, Singapore Exchange, Foreland Fabrictech
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings announced a S$24 million investment by AccorHotels for a 5% stake, with an option for another 5% at a later date. The Singapore Exchange is expected to list at least four technology companies in the first half of 2026, potentially positioning itself as a global tech destination. Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has lodged a complaint with Singapore's white-collar crime police against its former executive chairman after a recent public reprimand by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Rescuers scrabble for survivors as Indonesia quake kills 97
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck western Indonesia's Aceh province, killing at least 97 people and leaving hundreds homeless. The quake, felt across much of Aceh, also damaged key infrastructure, including hospitals and schools. Rescuers are searching for survivors through rubble, using excavators and their bare hands. The district is in need of basic supplies like food and water, and many residents fear aftershocks and a potential tsunami. The area is still reeling from the devastating 2004 tsunami that killed over 170,000 people in Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore shares open up 9.45 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 9.45 points to 2,969.29 at 9:03am on Thursday, following Wall Street's record-breaking performance. UOB, DBS Bank, and Singtel were top gainers. The US S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average set new records, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. The 5-day rally in Singapore stocks precedes the release of GDP data.

site_title: A blanket cap on board tenure would do more harm than good
summary: A blanket cap on board tenure may do more harm than good, as long-serving independent directors can still effectively monitor and control management. The Singapore Directorship Report 2016 found that 64% of corporate boards have at least one independent director serving longer than nine years. Long-serving directors can increase trust and openness among board members and executives, but concerns arise if they become too cosy with others, potentially compromising their independence and ability to detect wrongdoing. Limiting committee terms instead may be a better approach.

site_title: Japan Inc warns of global trade contraction under Trump presidency: Reuters poll
summary: Corporate Japan is bracing for a global trade contraction under Donald Trump's presidency, with 73% of firms expecting no expansion in world trade. Trump's protectionist rhetoric and pledges to redraw trade deals threaten to shatter Japan's fragile economic recovery. His plans to impose punitive tariffs on Mexico and China have sparked concerns of a trade war that could roll back decades of liberalization. Japan Inc warns that Trump's policies could lead to a contraction in global trade, with over a third of firms anticipating a decline.

site_title: Trump vows to bring down drug prices, doesn't say how
summary: President-elect Donald Trump vowed to bring down drug prices in a Time magazine interview, stating he doesn't like the current situation. However, he didn't specify how he plans to achieve this goal. Trump previously suggested allowing the importation of cheaper medicines from overseas, but this option has been met with opposition from pharmaceutical companies. The announcement sent shares of pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies lower, but no concrete plans for reducing drug prices were outlined.

site_title: China pledges to increase openness with foreign investment rules
summary: China has published draft foreign investment guidelines aimed at increasing openness, cutting the number of restricted sectors from 93 to 62. The revised lists include openings in manufacturing sectors such as rail transportation equipment and new energy vehicle batteries, as well as service sectors like passenger transport and credit investigation services. Restrictions in critical banking and securities sectors remain largely unchanged, and gambling and pornography remain banned. The move is seen as a step towards China's reform agenda, but critics argue it does not go far enough in addressing concerns over closed markets.

site_title: Matteo Renzi leaves a convalescent Italy
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi formally quit, marking the end of a 1,000-day government that failed to meet its economic pledge. Despite a 1.6% GDP growth and 3% household consumption increase, Italy lags behind European peers, mainly due to competitiveness issues and weak banks. The country's banking sector faces significant debts and the government has established a relief fund, but banks expect to return to it. Renzi's government also implemented labor market reforms and social reforms, including same-sex civil unions.

site_title: South Korea worried about growing economic risks, amid impeachment push for Park
summary: South Korea's finance ministry expressed concerns about economic risks amid the impeachment push for President Park Geun-Hye. The ministry cited domestic issues as a threat to consumption and investment, despite a recent rebound in private consumption. The economy is struggling with weak industrial production and high household debt. An impeachment vote is expected on Friday, with the outcome uncertain and potentially leading to a prolonged political crisis. The ministry's assessment comes as global uncertainties persist.

images.alt_text: South Korea' finance ministry said on Thursday it is concerned about further risks to the economy from "domestic issues", as parliament prepares to hold an impeachment vote on South Korean President Park Geun-Hye.

site_title: Walmart plans US$1.3b investment in Mexico
summary: Walmart plans a US$1.3 billion investment in Mexico, creating over 10,000 new jobs, amidst US President-elect Donald Trump's tough stance on foreign trade. The investment will be used to build new distribution centers and expand existing ones. This move comes as Trump has threatened to sanction US companies that shift activities and investment abroad, and amid concerns over Mexico's migrants. The investment is on top of Walmart's existing 200,000 jobs in Mexico, making it the country's biggest private employer.

site_title: British PM challenges lawmakers to back Brexit timetable
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May secured a symbolic victory on Brexit, with MPs agreeing not to delay her plans to begin EU exit talks by the end of March 2017. Despite opposition from Labour, May fended off a rebellion with a last-minute amendment, securing 461 votes in favor of her timeline. The amendment requires the government to provide further details on its negotiating strategy before triggering Article 50, but leaves room for withholding key information.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 hit new records ahead of ECB meeting
summary: US stocks surged to new records on Wednesday ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, which is expected to prolong its stimulus program. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.6% to 19,549.62, while the S&P 500 rose 1.3% to 2,241.35, and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.1% to 5,393.76. Analysts attribute the gains to expectations of pro-growth measures from President-elect Donald Trump and the Republican-led Congress, as well as institutional investors' desire to boost trading positions before the end of the year.

site_title: World's oldest bank asks ECB for extension
summary: Italy's Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world's oldest bank, asked the European Central Bank for an extension to raise €5 billion in equity, citing political instability and investor reluctance. The bank has lost 85% of its market capitalization since the start of the year and is struggling with non-performing loans totaling €360 billion. The ECB is considering the request, which would extend the deadline from December 31 to January 20, 2017. The bank's failure would require Italy to recapitalize it, adding to concerns about the country's banking sector.

site_title: Euro inches up, hovers near 3-week high as focus shifts to ECB
summary: The euro held near a three-week high against the US dollar on Thursday, influenced by the European Central Bank's upcoming policy meeting and Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's resignation. Investors await the ECB's decision on a six-month extension to its quantitative easing program, which is expected to keep the size of asset purchases unchanged. The euro edged up 0.2% to US$1.0769, its highest level since November 15. Market concerns about an early Italian election are tempered by the focus on the ECB meeting, with traders expecting a decision on quantitative easing.

site_title: Macau gaming watchdog says revenue growth may revive in 2017
summary: Macau's gaming revenue is expected to see stable development next year, with a forecast of 200 billion patacas ($35.42 billion), according to the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau. The city's casinos are trying to attract more mass-market gamblers and reduce the risks from high-stakes bettors, with stricter regulations on junket operators and money laundering. The government aims to diversify the economy and reduce its reliance on a small group of VIP patrons.

site_title: JW Marriott upbeat about Asia-Pac's luxury-travel segment
summary: The Asia-Pacific luxury-travel market is experiencing robust growth, with a 50% increase in the past five years, according to JW Marriott Hotels and Resorts. The segment has grown twice as fast as other types of travel. This growth is despite the uncertain economic climate, indicating a strong demand for luxury travel in the region.

site_title: Beijing needs to find ways to close its soft-power deficit
summary: China's 15-year anniversary of joining the World Trade Organization marks a shift in global perceptions, with the country's economy now larger than the US on a purchasing-power-parity basis. However, this has led to increased scrutiny and criticism, particularly from US President-elect Donald Trump, who has threatened punitive tariffs on Chinese goods. China's "soft power deficit" has grown, with a decline in global favourability in many countries, including Europe and the US. To address this, Beijing must find ways to improve its international public diplomacy and demonstrate a responsible, peaceful global stakeholder.

site_title: Trump taps China ambassador, consults Obama
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump nominated Iowa Governor Terry Branstad as his ambassador to China, citing Branstad's close ties to Chinese President Xi Jinping. This move comes after Trump consulted with former President Barack Obama and amid tensions with China over trade and Taiwan. Trump has pledged to create jobs by commissioning infrastructure projects and slashing corporate tax rates, and has also threatened to cancel a massive contract for Air Force One jets. Trump's cabinet picks, including wrestling magnate Linda McMahon and Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt, have sparked backlash from Democrats.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump on Wednesday selected a political ally with close ties to China as ambassador to Beijing, stressed his determination to create US jobs and revealed he consulted with Barack Obama on his cabinet picks.

site_title: In Hollande call, Obama hails their 'close partnership'
summary: US President Barack Obama spoke with French President Francois Hollande by phone, thanking him for his support and leadership in the past few years. Obama expressed appreciation for their close partnership and France's contributions to the trans-Atlantic alliance. Hollande announced his non-re-election last week, and Obama will be succeeded by Donald Trump on January 20.

site_title: US dollar declines with bond yields before Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar declined 0.26% to 100.23 against a basket of six major currencies, holding above a three-week low, ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting where a rate hike is expected with a cautious tone. Treasury bond yields eased, and investors await the European Central Bank's meeting for possible indications on quantitative easing tapering. Analysts predict the ECB will maintain a cautious stance due to subdued inflation, with the euro up 0.37% against the US dollar.

site_title: New Zealand cuts budget surplus forecast on earthquake costs
summary: New Zealand's government has downgraded its 2016/17 budget surplus forecast to NZ$473 million due to estimated NZ$1 billion in costs related to a devastating earthquake in December. The revised estimate is lower than the prior forecast of NZ$719 million. However, the surplus is expected to increase to NZ$8.5 billion by 2020/21 as revenues outpace expenses. The earthquake costs were a major factor in the downgrade, but the government remains optimistic about its economic outlook.

images.alt_text: "The more positive outlook for the economy is driven by high levels of construction activity, exports, particularly tourism, a growing population and low interest rates," Finance Minister Bill English said.

site_title: AccorHotels invests S$24m for 5% stake in Banyan Tree
summary: AccorHotels has invested S$24 million for a 5% stake in Banyan Tree Holdings, a resort operator. The investment was made through a mandatory convertible debenture, giving AccorHotels an equity stake in Banyan Tree with an option to invest another 5% at a later time. The partnership aims to develop and manage Banyan Tree-branded hotels globally, with access to AccorHotels' reservations and sales network, as well as its loyalty programme.

site_title: Motor-insurance market to grow next year: AIG
summary: The motor insurance market in Singapore is expected to grow 20% in the upcoming year due to the rise of rental vehicles, telematics use, and younger car buyers. AIG Asia Pacific Insurance attributes this growth to the growing sharing economy.

site_title: India's indebted electricity retailers seen scaring off investors
summary: India's indebted electricity retailers are scaring off investors, according to Sembcorp Industries Ltd CEO Vipul Tuli. Delayed payments and reluctance to sign long-term contracts are major risks, eroding investor returns. The industry's woes have left 20% of the country without electricity. India must become competitive in sustainable infrastructure returns to attract investments, Tuli said. This concerns joins those of Acciona SA and ReNew Power Ventures, highlighting the precarious business environment in India's power industry.

site_title: Australia economy in rare contraction as spending falls
summary: Australia's economy contracted by 0.5% in the September quarter, its weakest figure in eight years, due to weaker government and consumer spending, as well as softer trade figures. The annual growth rate slowed to 1.8%, amid a transition from a mining investment boom. The Reserve Bank of Australia may need to ease interest rates to keep growth at a satisfactory level, with economists predicting a potential rebound in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks extend global gains despite weak Japan GDP
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.95% in early trading, driven by global gains, despite Japan's revised GDP showing a slower-than-expected 0.2% growth in the third quarter. The Nikkei 225 index reached 18,672.65, while the broader Topix index gained 0.96%. The global rally follows Wall Street's recent record highs, with investors brushing off new US trade threats.

site_title: Paris choked by worst winter pollution in a decade
summary: Paris experienced its worst winter pollution in a decade, with fine airborne particles (PM10) at 60% of Beijing's levels and a fraction of New Delhi's. The city implemented free public transport and restricted private cars with odd-numbered plates to combat the issue. Pollution levels have been above 80 microgrammes per cubic metre of air for over a week, prompting calls for politicians to target the most polluting vehicles and restrict diesel engine use. This is the fourth time Paris has used traffic restrictions to address air pollution, with officials considering further measures in other parts of France.

images.alt_text: Paris was smothered on Wednesday by its worst winter pollution in a decade, with commuters enjoying free public transport and half of all cars ordered off the road to try to clear the air.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Italy outlook following referendum
summary: Moody's downgraded Italy's sovereign debt outlook to negative due to the failure of a constitutional referendum aimed at speeding up economic reforms. The downgrade cited the likelihood of Italy delaying debt reduction, leaving it vulnerable to unforeseen economic shocks. The decision followed Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's resignation after the referendum defeat. The debt rating remains unchanged, but Moody's warned of increased risks for Italy's economy.

site_title: BBC under probe for profile of new Thai king
summary: The BBC is under investigation by Thai authorities over a Thai-language profile of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, published after his ascension to the throne. The article included personal details about the king's life, sparking criticism from royalists who accused the BBC of defaming the monarch. The Thai government has used the lese majeste law to jail critics and impose self-censorship, and the BBC's Thai service is one of few platforms publishing unfiltered reporting. The probe is seen as a delicate moment for the institution, with the king's lack of respect commanded by his father.

site_title: New China trend: borrow from the future to enjoy the present
summary: China's savers, who typically save a large portion of their income, are increasing debt as borrowing options expand. 94% of consumers have used a credit or loan in the past year, with peer-to-peer lending and car loans/mortgages nearly doubling. This shift, known as "Huo zai dang xia" or living in the moment, is driven by younger generations' willingness to spend on products with special features or tailored services. China's household outstanding loans are expected to rise 14% for the next five years, potentially supporting consumption and rebalancing the nation's economy.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit Q4 high as banks advance further
summary: European shares reached a 11-month high on Wednesday, driven by Credit Suisse's cost-cutting announcements and Italian banks' surge in value. The STOXX Europe 600 Banks index rose 2.3%, with Credit Suisse up 7.4% after announcing extra cost cuts. Italian banks also rose 4.4% as the government prepared to take a controlling stake in Monte dei Paschi di Siena. The market is expected to rise steadily in 2017, but analysts remain cautious about potential shocks due to recent political upsets.

site_title: Ikea sells key subsidiaries for 5.2b euros in major overhaul
summary: Ikea Group sold key subsidiaries, including supply chain and design management, to Inter Ikea Holding BV for 5.2 billion euros, as part of an overhaul to adapt to changing consumer preferences and competition. The deal boosts Inter Ikea's profits and allows it to take control of Ikea's business development, shifting Ikea Group to a pure retailer. The split aims to create tension and spur growth, and Inter Ikea will provide Ikea Group with rights to open new channels and improve product lines. The deal also increases Ikea Group's cash pile and enables it to resume paying a dividend.

site_title: A casino resort rises in Maryland, transforming sand to shimmer
summary: The MGM National Harbor casino resort in Maryland is set to open, marking a major development in Prince George's County, with 125,000 sq ft of gaming space, a 308-room hotel, and 10 restaurants. The $1.4 billion project has invested heavily in local jobs, with 40% of permanent workers and 20% of construction workers to be hired from the county. The resort is expected to draw 20,000 daily visitors and generate $41-47 million in annual taxes, with 11 million visitors, residents, and employees projected annually for the entire National Harbor site.

site_title: Tableall.com sells coveted dining access to Japan restaurants
summary: Tableall.com, founded by former Goldman Sachs trader Takashi Yamada, offers exclusive dining access to Japan's top restaurants. The platform secures reservations by paying restaurants in advance, then charges customers 3,000 yen (S$37) per seat on top of the meal's price. Currently offering 11 eateries in Tokyo, Tableall aims to expand to 31 locations by the end of 2017, including Kyoto and Hokkaido, with a focus on providing authentic Japanese dining experiences for foreigners.

images.alt_text: "I want foreigners to enjoy real Japanese culture. I want them to know the real, deep Japan," says Mr Yamada.

site_title: Henderson holding Reits, avoiding banks (Amended)
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (Reits) remain attractive sources of income despite a dim growth outlook for the overall Singapore stock market. Henderson Global Investors has largely avoided investing in Asian banks due to low loan demand and non-performing loans. The fund favors Singapore Reits, holding shares in Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust, CapitaLand Mall Trust, Ascendas Reit, Singtel, and Singapore Post, citing their operational strengths and steady dividend yields. However, analysts note that the local Reit market has underperformed, and Australian and Japanese Reits may offer better opportunities.

site_title: Top US court backs Samsung in smartphone fight with Apple
summary: The US Supreme Court has ruled in favor of Samsung, throwing out an appeals court ruling that the company must pay a $399 million penalty to Apple for copying key iPhone designs. The court held that a patent violator does not always have to pay its entire profits if the designs covered only certain components. The justices sent the case back to the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit to determine how much Samsung must pay, but did not provide a roadmap for lower courts to navigate similar disputes.

site_title: RWS pledges up to S$300,000 to Community Chest
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) has pledged up to S$300,000 to the Community Chest through its annual charity drive. The integrated resort will donate S$10 for every ticket sold at the SEA Aquarium and Pokémon Research Exhibition in December. The funds will support the construction of Singapore's first specialized adult home for those with Autism Spectrum Disorder. The initiative aims to promote inclusivity and provide long-term care for those in need. RWS Cares, the resort's corporate social responsibility program, has been hosting the charity drive for years.

site_title: HK builders Wheelock, Sun Hung Kai may cut loan costs
summary: Hong Kong real-estate developers Wheelock & Co Ltd and Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd are seeking loan discounts of 20-40% compared to the first half of the year, despite a new stamp duty and expected rate hikes. Banks are competing to lend to corporates by lowering interest rates and fees, driving down loan pricing further. This trend is expected to continue, with lenders facing increasing liquidity and capital costs, potentially leading to a further lowering of prices in 2017.

site_title: Low family fights to stop 1MDB asset seizure by US
summary: Malaysia financier Low Taek Jho's family is fighting to stop the US from seizing $650 million in assets linked to the 1MDB scandal. The family claims Swiss trustees are afraid to fight back due to fear of prosecution. They plan to ask courts in the Cayman Islands and New Zealand to replace the Swiss trustees, aiming to avoid the US taking control of their assets. The assets include real estate, investments, and artworks allegedly bought with stolen 1MDB funds.

site_title: Banks doing a slow dance in a burning room
summary: A McKinsey report predicts the global banking industry will remain in a "low-growth, low-profit" state into 2017, with European banks at risk. Emerging market banks, such as those in Singapore, are expected to thrive despite looming bad debts. The report also notes that a hard landing in China could significantly impact profits.

site_title: Ex-senator lobbies Trump transition officials for Taipei: documents
summary: Former US Senator Bob Dole, a registered foreign agent for Taiwan, secretly lobbied Trump transition officials on behalf of the Taiwanese government, arranging a historic phone call between President-elect Donald Trump and Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen. Dole coordinated with Trump campaign officials and arranged a meeting between Taiwanese diplomats and Trump campaign officials. The US has traditionally followed a One-China policy, but Taiwan used Dole's influence to establish ties with Trump before his election. The move has raised tensions with China, which views Taiwan as a renegade province.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A consortium led by Citic Envirotech has secured a 3.2 billion yuan (S$659.5 million) infrastructure project in Shantou Chaonan, China. Fraser & Neave is bidding for a 2.7% stake in Vietnam's Vinamilk, while Silverlake Axis sold 6.8 million shares of Global Infotech for 144.4 million yuan. New Silkroutes Group has redesigned its lead independent and non-executive director, Ho Sheng, as chairman. Oriental Group received letters of demand for payments from Hoe Leong Metal & Machinery and Steelforce (SEA), and its board rejected a slate of board nominees proposed by minority shareholders.

site_title: Boeing proposes plan to cut Air Force One cost
summary: Boeing proposes reducing the cost of a new Air Force One by revising specifications with the US Air Force and Secret Service. The current estimated cost is over $4 billion, with the Pentagon budgeting $3.2 billion for research and development through 2021. Boeing executives suggest reducing costs by $1.5 billion by streamlining the plane's features, which include advanced communications and defensive capabilities. The plan aims to deliver the best plane for the president at the best value for taxpayers, following President-elect Donald Trump's tweet that the current cost is "ridiculous."

site_title: Controlling shareholder of Abterra under liquidation
summary: Abterra Ltd, a Singapore-based natural resources trader, has its controlling shareholder General Nice Resources (Hong Kong) put under liquidation by the High Court of Hong Kong. This move affects 34.96% of Abterra's shares. The company has called for an immediate trading halt to assess the impact and has reported a net loss of S$940,000 in its third quarter. Abterra is exploring options to restart its core trading business and reviewing its business continuity plans. The news has led to a 17% dive in the company's stock price to 48.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Mixed views over West Coast Vale residential site
summary: Singapore's West Coast Vale residential site, released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), is expected to attract warm interest from developers due to improved sentiment and limited available sites. However, some consultants believe slow take-up at nearby Parc Riviera condominium project may dampen interest. The site's GLS price has not been announced yet.

site_title: Delinquent debts down but SMEs feel cashflow squeeze
summary: Delinquent debts among Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) declined to 46% in Q3, down from 48% in Q2 and 49% in Q1. Construction and hospitality sectors had the highest delinquent debt rates, while commerce-retail had the lowest at 21%. However, tightening credit conditions have led to cashflow concerns for SMEs, with 34% citing suppliers' tightened credit access as an issue and 7% citing cashflow problems. Experts warn that reduced trade credit access may impact SMEs' growth and liquidity.

site_title: Trump scores on first foreign policy test?
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's phone conversation with Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen has sparked debate about his foreign policy approach. Critics argue that the call, arranged by former senator Bob Dole, is a protocol breach and may have triggered an angry response from China. However, Trump's aides claim the call was part of a new strategy to engage with Taiwan as a strategic ally. Trump's approach could be seen as a geo-strategic move to strengthen ties with Taiwan and apply pressure on China, potentially altering the US's stance on the One-China policy.

site_title: Masayoshi Son's US$50b investment pledge shows his knack for spectacle
summary: Masayoshi Son, founder of SoftBank Group Corp, has pledged a US$50 billion investment in the US, promising 50,000 jobs. The investment, from SoftBank's US$100 billion technology fund, was announced at Trump Tower in New York. Son's US debut is part of his global 300-year plan for his technology empire, which includes investments in startups and advanced artificial intelligence. SoftBank shares jumped to the highest in 15 months after the announcement, while Sprint and T-Mobile shares rose on speculation of a potential deal.

site_title: MISC may land first floating production contract award in 2017
summary: MISC, a Singapore-listed shipping giant, is leading in the tender for a floating production unit (FPU) for Husky-CNOOC Madura Limited's (HCML) MDA-MBH project in Indonesia. The joint bid from MISC and Duta Marine is approximately US$386 million, below HCML's estimated US$460-480 million. The contract, expected to be awarded in early 2017, is the first FPU award in the floating production segment since 2016, and MISC's win would mark its first venture into Indonesia's floating production space.

site_title: When President Tony Tan turns broker
summary: President Tony Tan of Singapore turned broker and closed four trades worth over S$520 million at ICAP plc's Singapore office, generating commissions for charity on the company's 24th annual global Charity Day. The event raised S$229 million for over 200 charities worldwide, with four Singapore charities receiving funds, including the President's Challenge and KK Women's and Children's Hospital. This is the largest amount raised by ICAP in its 24-year history.

site_title: Trump towers over financial market perceptions
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's economic policies, dubbed "Trumponomics," have led to a surge in the dollar, a mini bull market, and concerns about inflation and rising interest rates. This reversal of economic fortunes cannot be solely attributed to Trump's claims, as the global economy was already showing signs of slowing growth and potential recession. Other factors, including fiscal stimulus and the "new paradigm" of monetization of government debt, have contributed to the shift. The Federal Reserve has hinted at accelerating interest rate hikes, adding to the inflationary excitement. The article concludes that the "Trump effect" on markets has roots deeper than just Trumponomics, and its impact may be more profound than initially thought.

site_title: Abe's Pearl Harbor visit takes on heightened significance
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's planned visit to Pearl Harbor later this month has taken on heightened significance amid US-Japan relations concerns. The visit comes as US President-elect Donald Trump has made pre-election statements casting doubt on the future of the post-war bond, including calling for allies to pay more towards the cost of a US military presence. The visit is seen as a strong symbol of the close relationship between the two countries, with Abe seeking to "console" the spirits of those who died in the Japanese attack, rather than apologizing.

site_title: Sony breach said to have inspired Russian hacking into US election
summary: A senior congressional Democrat, Adam Schiff, suggests that the US failure to retaliate strongly against the 2014 Sony Pictures cyberattack may have inspired Russian hackers to interfere in the 2016 US election. Schiff proposes that the US and European allies impose sanctions on Russia to deter future hacking. The alleged hacking benefited Republican Donald Trump's presidential campaign, and Schiff warns that Russian hackers could turn on Trump if they disapprove of his policies. Schiff calls for a bipartisan committee to combat Russian hacking efforts.

site_title: India keeps rates unchanged as cash crunch roils economy
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, kept its key policy rate unchanged at 6.25% despite a cash shortage that threatens the country's fastest-growing large economy. The monetary policy committee voted 6-0 to leave the rate unchanged, citing the need for more time to assess the impact of the cash squeeze. The RBI trimmed its growth forecast for the year, citing the expected ebb of the impact from the measures to abolish high-denomination notes.

site_title: Starbucks courting millennials with upscale 'Reserve' brand stores
summary: Starbucks is launching a new prestige brand, "Reserve," with co-founder Howard Schultz stepping down as CEO to focus on building 1,000 Reserve stores and 30 large Roastery and Tasting Rooms globally. The upscale brand aims to attract millennials like Megan Sauers, who are drawn to premium products. Schultz's plan is a bet that moving upscale can raise Starbucks' profile and appeal to younger consumers.

site_title: Japan's Idemitsu, Showa Shell have not decided on capital tie-up
summary: Japan's Idemitsu and Showa Shell have not decided on a capital tie-up despite reported negotiations, according to a joint statement. The proposed tie-up would allow for a merger ahead of a planned deal that has been delayed due to opposition from Idemitsu's founding family. The two companies aim to exploit synergies and achieve annual savings of around 30 billion yen, but no formal decision has been made.

site_title: S Korea to fine VW 37.3b won, pursue execs over emissions ads
summary: South Korea plans to fine Volkswagen AG's South Korean unit a record 37.3 billion won (S$45.49 million) for false advertising on vehicle emissions. The company will also pursue criminal complaints against five former and current executives. This fine follows the suspension of most of Volkswagen's sales in the country since August. The move indicates South Korea's tough stance on Volkswagen's emissions-test cheating, amid ongoing investigations globally.

site_title: Trump-linked uncertainty affecting Apac's outlook: S&P
summary: S&P Global Ratings warns that US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, particularly trade tariffs on China, pose significant uncertainty affecting the Asia-Pacific region's economic outlook. The uncertainty is the single biggest factor, with potential downsides including a trade and investment war between the US and China. However, some upside is expected from infrastructure spending and tax cuts in the US, which could boost demand for Asia's exports. Countries like Singapore, with smaller economies, are likely to feel the effects more severely. S&P Global Ratings maintains its forecasts unchanged until Trump's economic team is in place.

site_title: Italy preparing to take controlling stake in Monte dei Paschi - sources
summary: Italy is preparing to take a 40% controlling stake in Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the country's third-largest bank, after Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's decision to quit. The government plans to buy junior bonds from retail investors to increase its stake, avoiding losses for ordinary investors. This move aims to stabilize the bank and prevent a wider banking crisis. The European Commission will assess the government's intervention to ensure it is taking place at market prices.

site_title: Credit Suisse to slash costs by 1b francs
summary: Credit Suisse slashes costs by 1 billion Swiss francs, lowering profit targets for its international wealth management and Asian units. The Zurich-based bank aims to achieve an operating cost base of less than 17 billion francs by 2018, down from an earlier goal of below 18 billion francs. CEO Tidjane Thiam adjusts his turnaround plan to focus on cost reductions, citing unsupportive market conditions.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse says it has cut 6,050 jobs this year, exceeding its target of 6,000 positions.

site_title: Hong Kong faces housing risks as Fed tightening looms: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Hong Kong of housing risks due to potential interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve, which could lead to higher borrowing costs and a potential downturn in the property market. The IMF also flags risks from market volatility linked to UK and European banks, as well as exposure to China's slowing economy. With Hong Kong's economy growing at 1.5% in 2016 and 1.9% next year, the IMF advises caution due to stretched property valuations and high household debt.

site_title: Foxconn confirms US investment; Softbank soars
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced a $50 billion investment deal with Taiwanese tech giant Foxconn and SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son in New York. Foxconn confirmed preliminary discussions on a potential investment to expand its US operations, while SoftBank shares soared 6.19% after the announcement. The deal aims to create 50,000 new jobs in the US over the next four years. Analysts expect the investment to focus on automation, design, and research and development rather than manufacturing due to high labor costs in the country.

site_title: US$ edges up against yen; traders await ECB cues
summary: The US dollar edged up 0.1% to a 10-month high against the yen at US$1.0724, awaiting the European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday. The ECB is expected to announce an extension of quantitative easing, but uncertainty surrounds the size of monthly asset purchases. A potential scaling back of asset purchases could boost the euro, which has fallen 4% against the dollar over the past month. The dollar also rose 0.2% to 114.20 yen, its highest against the Japanese currency since early February.

site_title: Digging into ISR's mining deal just yields more questions
summary: ISR Capital's proposed acquisition of a rare-earth mining asset in Madagascar has raised concerns due to unanswered questions. The Singapore Exchange has suspended trading of the company's shares, citing "circumstances that prevent trading on an informed basis." ISR has been trying to complete the 60% stake acquisition since May 2016, but the lack of transparency has raised red flags. The company's answers to queries have only fueled more questions, casting doubt on the deal's legitimacy.

site_title: Vallianz: Two directors probed as Swiber board members
summary: Two directors of Vallianz Holdings, Yeo Jeu Nam and Yeo Chee Neng, were interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department as non-executive directors of Swiber Holdings, amid investigations into alleged infringements under Section 199 of the Securities and Futures Act. The investigations are related to false and misleading disclosures, including Swiber's failure to properly disclose a US$710 million project award. Vallianz stated that the matters are not related to its business and operations, and the company will continue as normal. No formal charges have been brought against the directors.

site_title: New bond trading platform to help spread risks
summary: Fundsupermart is launching the Bond Express platform, allowing investors to trade wholesale bonds in smaller lots of S$5,000 or S$1,000 for retail bonds. This move aims to lower risks by giving investors easier access to bonds, with immediate execution and live prices. The platform, which starts with 17 bonds, plugs a hole in the market and reduces concentration risk for accredited investors. Bond Express charges a 0.35% fee per trade, with a S$10 minimum.

site_title: Fitbit close to buying software assets from smartwatch startup Pebble
summary: Fitbit is close to acquiring Pebble's software assets for under $40 million, mainly to hire software engineers and gain intellectual property such as the Pebble watch's operating system and cloud services. The deal aims to help Fitbit compete with Apple's Apple Watch. Pebble, which has struggled financially, will sell off its product inventory and server equipment separately. Fitbit's acquisition of Pebble's software talent and resources could bolster its smartwatch offerings and features.

site_title: Bank Negara's reserves down less than expected
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia's international reserves decreased by less than $2 billion to $96.4 billion as of November 30, a smaller drop than expected. The central bank attributed the decrease to liquidity support in the foreign exchange market.
