Reserves are sufficient to finance 8.3 months of retained imports and are 1.2 times the short-term external debt. Despite market speculation, the central bank did not intervene significantly to prop up the ringgit, which has depreciated by about 5% in the last month.

site_title: Alaska Air gets nod for Virgin America takeover
summary: Alaska Air Group Inc received US antitrust approval for its acquisition of Virgin America Inc, expanding its access to the lucrative cross-country market. The Justice Department required Alaska Air to reduce a marketing accord allowing it to sell tickets for American Airlines flights on over 250 routes, ensuring competition against American rather than partnering. This marks years of consolidation in the industry.

site_title: Starbucks sets 5-year growth targets, to open 12,000 more stores
summary: Starbucks sets 5-year growth targets, aiming for 10% annual revenue growth and 15-20% profit growth. The company plans to open 12,000 stores globally by 2021, with high-end Reserve Roastery and Tasting Room locations in Europe and "bars" selling premium coffee in up to 20% of its 37,000 stores. This follows the announcement that CEO Howard Schultz will step down to focus on high-end coffee shops.

site_title: NY hotel project seeks to recapture shining moment in air travel
summary: A US$265 million project is underway to revive the historic Trans World Flight Center at Kennedy International Airport in New York, with MCR Development planning to restore the building as the public entrance to a new six-storey hotel. Designed by Eero Saarinen in 1962, the flight center was an iconic symbol of the jet age, but its check-in and baggage-handling capacities were quickly overwhelmed by modern jetliners. The restoration project, expected to open in late 2018, will include a reception desk, restaurants, and event space, and has been licensed by American Airlines.

site_title: dnata Singapore clinches deals with Cathay Pacific and subsidiary
summary: dnata Singapore has secured multi-year contracts with Cathay Pacific for passenger and ramp services, and with Air Hong Kong for freighter aircraft and cargo handling. The agreements will support Cathay Pacific's move to Terminal 4 in 2017 and Air Hong Kong's six weekly flights from Changi Airport. dnata Singapore will operate at Terminal 4, providing services to 131 airports across 84 countries.

site_title: Trump is Time's 'Person of the Year'
summary: TIME magazine named Donald Trump its "Person of the Year" for 2016, citing his stunning upset election victory and its profound influence on the country. Trump welcomed the honor, praising outgoing President Barack Obama, and is featured on the magazine's cover. The decision reflects Trump's ability to "empower a hidden electorate" and "frame tomorrow's political culture" despite widespread divisions.

site_title: JPMorgan, Credit Agricole and HSBC fined for Euribor rigging
summary: JPMorgan Chase, HSBC Holdings, and Credit Agricole SA were fined 485.5 million euros (S$738 million) for rigging the Euribor benchmark. The trio colluded on euro interest rate derivative pricing elements and exchanged sensitive information, breaching EU antitrust rules. The European Commission conducted a five-year investigation into the scandal.

site_title: At least four tech Catalist IPOs lined up for H1 next year: SGX
summary: At least four tech companies, including financial technology firm Ayondo, are set to list on Singapore's Catalist board in the first half of 2023. The listings, including a "software-as-a-service" company and a local e-commerce startup, demonstrate the board's momentum and potential to become a global destination for tech floats. SGX's head of capital market development says the country's substantial investment in its tech sector will make it possible for the board to become a "very good base" for tech listings, with companies potentially moving up to the mainboard to access a wider investor base.

site_title: Medtronic's China unit fined 118.5m yuan for price fixing
summary: Medtronic's China unit has been fined 118.5 million yuan (S$24.4 million) by the National Development and Reform Commission for price fixing in the cardiovascular and diabetes medical device products market. The firm allegedly carried out monopolistic behavior with distributors and partners to fix prices and set resale price limits. This is the latest in a series of price fixing fines in China, targeting medical device makers and foreign firms.

site_title: Climate change a challenge for Australia winemakers
summary: Climate change poses a significant threat to Australia's A$2 billion wine industry, with record-breaking heat expected to become the new "normal" in the country, which is warming by approximately one degree Celsius since 1910. This warming causes grapes to ripen earlier, leading to lower-quality wines with higher alcohol content. To mitigate the effects, winemakers are trialling methods such as pruning later, switching varieties, and increasing soil moisture. The Australian government and grape-growers are also exploring alternative varieties that can thrive in warmer climates, with some predicting that up to 70% of wine-growing areas in the country may become less suitable for grape growing by 2050.

images.alt_text: ''Good farmers think about what's coming,'' said Mr Jarrett, who has started growing prosecco, a white Italian variety he believes could suit Orange's climate in 20 years' time.

site_title: Banks continue to spearhead STI rise
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.72 points to 2,959.84, driven by gains from banking shares, including OCBC and DBS. The index closed 0.36% higher, despite concerns over Italy's referendum and the European Central Bank's policy meeting. Wall Street's extended gains also contributed to the local market's buoyancy. Key movers included Singtel, which rose 3.4 index points, and Genting Singapore, whose stock benefited from speculation on Japan's casino legalization. Analysts expect increased volatility in 2017 due to factors such as interest rate hikes and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Early M'sian GE in delicate climate could strain multi- racial country more
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has hinted at calling a general election "soon", despite a financial scandal affecting his reputation. The move could be influenced by the upcoming Southeast Asian Games in August 2017, which may boost nationalist sentiments for the ruling coalition. Najib has strengthened his position by purging critics and cracking down on protesters, but this has come at the cost of governance and reputation. The timing of the election remains uncertain, with polls not due until August 2018.

site_title: Bombardier seeking new C series mega deal
summary: Bombardier is seeking a new mega deal for its C Series jet, following successful deals from Delta Air Lines and Air Canada in 2016. The company anticipates another major order next year and may announce a smaller contract this month. Deliveries will step up to 30-35 in 2017, with production curtailed by engine issues. Bombardier hopes to gain a foothold in the low-cost airline segment and is exploring opportunities for a larger version of the C Series with 150-plus seats.

site_title: UK lower house seen supporting move to trigger Brexit: study
summary: A Reuters study suggests that the UK's lower house of Parliament would likely support triggering Brexit, despite the government's efforts to prevent it. At least 64 Conservative and Labour lawmakers have stated their intention to vote to trigger Article 50, and 73 lawmakers have expressed respect for the referendum outcome or would not block the start of divorce talks. The government has prepared a bill that could easily pass with abstentions, and lawmakers from the Scottish National Party and Liberal Democrats may also vote against, but their opposition is not guaranteed.

site_title: Mermaid cancels order for dive support vessel
summary: Mermaid Maritime Public Co cancelled its order for the dive support and construction vessel Mermaid Au-sana due to challenging oil and gas industry conditions. The company will forfeit a $20.4 million instalment and is not liable for the remaining $124.8 million of the order value. This decision follows Mermaid's impairment of the pre-paid sum and associated costs in its 2015 financial statements, as the company's net profit halved to $7.5 million for the three months ended September. The cancellation is attributed to the global oil and gas industry's significant challenges.

site_title: Tata Steel agrees deal on jobs, investment
summary: Tata Steel UK has agreed a deal to keep jobs and production at its Port Talbot steel plant in Wales for at least five years, with no compulsory redundancies for five years. In return, the company wants to close its debt-laden pension scheme and replace it with a defined contribution scheme. The deal, subject to union approval, aims to secure the future of the plant and its 4,000 employees.

site_title: Alibaba's Ant team prepares for IPO, tours Silicon Valley
summary: Alibaba's Ant Financial, a Chinese payments and banking arm, is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) expected as soon as next year. The company, which serves 450 million customers in China, aims to expand globally and provide financial services to 2.5 billion people worldwide. Ant's CEO, Eric Jing, took over from Lucy Peng, who emphasized the company's broader ambitions beyond payments. The IPO will provide transparency to investors and raise funds for acquisitions, but faces challenges due to regulatory hurdles and concerns about Alibaba's accounting practices.

site_title: COE premiums mostly down; goods vehicles, buses buck trend
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for cars fell across most categories in the latest bidding round, with the premium for big cars dropping to S$48,000 for cars of up to 1,600cc. The premium for goods vehicles and buses rose, with companies anticipating a surge in demand next year. The Land Transport Authority received 5,170 bids, with 4,011 successful bids. The decline in COE premiums is attributed to a wait-and-see attitude among buyers due to economic uncertainties and a traditionally quiet month for vehicle sales.

site_title: Trump to pick retired General Kelly for Homeland Security: CBS
summary: President-elect Donald Trump plans to nominate retired Marine General John Kelly to lead the Department of Homeland Security. Kelly, the former head of the US Southern Command, has accepted the offer. This would be Trump's third high-level position nomination, following General James Mattis for Secretary of Defense and General James Jones for National Security Adviser.

site_title: BP ships nearly three million barrels of US crude oil to Asia
summary: BP has successfully shipped nearly three million barrels of US crude oil to Asia, worth around $150 million, in a complex operation involving seven tankers and ship-to-ship transfers. The shipment, which took four months to complete, was facilitated by BP's global shipping and trading network, allowing the company to overcome US port limitations and transport oil to customers across Asia. The operation is seen as a precursor to more US crude exports to Asia, with OPEC's production cuts expected to increase demand for alternative supplies.

site_title: Aides to Korean 'Rasputin' testify to her power
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye's long-time confidante Choi Soon-sil is accused of exerting significant influence over the president, including her wardrobe, speeches, and top appointments. Choi allegedly used her power to strong-arm major conglomerates into donating funds to her foundations and colluded with the president to meddle in state affairs. A parliamentary hearing has summoned business tycoons and associates, including a K-pop video director, to testify against Choi, who has refused to appear despite warnings of potential jail time. The scandal has sparked mass protests calling for the president's resignation.

site_title: ISR Capital chairman defends mining asset purchase
summary: ISR Capital's chairman, Chen Tong, defends the company's proposed S$40 million acquisition of a rare earth oxide mine in Madagascar, citing a need for a third independent valuation report. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) had previously suspended trading in ISR Capital shares due to concerns over the valuation of the mine. Chen, a former managing director at Bao Steel Group, emphasizes the demand for rare earth materials and the environmental benefits of the mine, stating that China's crackdown on domestic mining activities will lead to a global shortage. He also asserts that ISR Capital will commission a third independent report to assess the value of the mine and address concerns.

site_title: Kerry to resume talks with Lavrov on Syria
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry will hold talks with Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov in Hamburg, Germany, on efforts to halt fighting in Aleppo, Syria. Kerry aims to relaunch peace talks between the Syrian regime and opposition with Russia's help. The US, Britain, France, and other countries have called for an immediate ceasefire to allow aid to reach Aleppo. Kerry has had previous meetings with Lavrov on Syria, and the talks are seen as an attempt to find a way to get the negotiating table. A separate meeting on Syria is planned in Paris.

site_title: Citi giving e-commerce players a hand to expand in Asean
summary: Citi is supporting e-commerce players in expanding their operations in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region, where the potential for growth is significant but hindered by a lack of infrastructure and complex regulations. The bank's head of Asean and Singapore, Melvyn Low, notes that Asean e-commerce is in its infancy compared to India and China, and that Citi expects double-digit revenue growth for its Asean e-commerce business over the next three years. To support growth, Citi has invested in operational infrastructure and connectivity, and is helping clients navigate regulatory nuances and manage FX and liquidity risk.

site_title: China cautions against 'irrational' overseas acquisitions
summary: China has cautioned domestic companies against "irrational" overseas investments, amid a record-breaking buying spree that has raised concerns about capital outflows and downward pressure on the yuan. The Ministry of Commerce and other agencies issued a joint statement advising companies to make cautious decisions, citing high-profile deals in sports, hotels, and entertainment. Chinese overseas investments reached $61.7 billion in the first eight months of 2016, surpassing those for all of 2015. The move aims to stem capital outflows and control the depreciation of the yuan.

site_title: Special auditor finds missing money, backdated invoices at Oriental
summary: A special auditor and independent directors at Oriental Group found missing money, inaccurate disclosures, and backdated invoices from 2013 to 2015. The auditor identified potential breaches of laws, including the Companies Act and Securities and Futures Act. Former directors and officers, including Lee Wan Sing and Wu Dingrong, were involved in the potential breaches. The company bought goods without board approval and made claims under the Productivity and Innovation Credit scheme using backdated invoices. An independent review also found irregularities in Oriental's China operations, including personal guarantees and unsupported fund transfers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Reits experienced moderation in DPU growth, with some recording negative growth, due to slowing rental reversions, higher operating costs, and dilution from equity fund raisings. Analysts predict unfavorable demand and supply dynamics will persist in 2017, impacting Reits' performance. However, locked-in rental leases provide some resilience to income streams. Key sector picks include Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel DC Reit, and Ascendas Reit, with recommended target prices. Meanwhile, Singapore banks OCBC and UOB are expected to benefit from rising interest rates, with OCBC's target price raised to S$10.30 and UOB's to S$21.80.

site_title: Taiwan November exports grow at fastest rate in nearly four years
summary: Taiwan's exports in November grew 12.1% year-over-year, the fastest pace in nearly four years, driven by strong demand for hi-tech gadgets, particularly Apple's iPhones, ahead of the year-end shopping season. However, analysts expect momentum to fade as seasonal demand peaks. The growth is expected to influence Taiwan's central bank decision to keep interest rates unchanged at its quarterly meeting on December 22. The country's export trend is a key gauge of global demand for technology gadgets, and Taiwan's exports for the fourth quarter are upbeat despite uncertainties for 2017.

site_title: US: Stocks pause from post-election rally
summary: US stocks paused from their post-election rally on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping 0.1% to 19,238.47. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also shed 0.1% each. Analysts attribute the pause to expectations of pro-growth policies from Washington, which may temper investor enthusiasm.

site_title: Fitbit buys smartwatch maker Pebble's software assets
summary: Fitbit Inc. acquired Pebble's software and intellectual property assets in a deal that closed on December 6, 2016. The purchase did not include Pebble's hardware products. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: Uncertainty over US position delays action on Ukraine peace deal: Germany
summary: Germany's foreign minister, Frank Walter Steinmeier, says uncertainty over US President-elect Donald Trump's policies on Ukraine and Russia's future relationship hinders progress in implementing the Minsk ceasefire accord. Steinmeier also mentioned that Turkey's aim to join the EU's visa-free travel program may be unachievable unless it revises its domestic policies.

site_title: Time names Trump its 2016 'Person of the Year'
summary: Time magazine named Donald Trump its 2016 "Person of the Year" for his surprise election victory, citing his ability to "remind America that demagoguery feeds on despair" and "demolishing yesterday's" to frame tomorrow's politics. Trump welcomed the honor, praising outgoing President Barack Obama, while acknowledging the country's divisions. The magazine highlighted Trump's ability to "empower a hidden electorate" and "mainstream its furies and live-stream its fears."

site_title: Shell to sign 3 deals to develop Iran oil and gas fields
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will sign three agreements to develop Iran's South Azadegan, Yadavaran oilfields, and the Kish gas field in Tehran. The deals aim to develop these oil and gas fields, marking a significant move for Shell in the country. Total will begin negotiations for new projects but will not sign any deals on this occasion. This development comes amid ongoing efforts to revive Iran's oil and gas industry after international sanctions were lifted in 2016.

site_title: Myanmar bans workers going to Malaysia as Rohingya crisis grows
summary: Myanmar has banned its workers from going to Malaysia amid strained relations with the country over its military crackdown on the Rohingya minority. The ban comes after Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak criticized Myanmar's de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi for allowing "genocide" on her watch. The move follows a recent surge of Rohingya refugees into Bangladesh, with thousands seeking asylum in Malaysia. The crisis has galvanized protests in Muslim countries, including Malaysia, and has raised concerns about regional stability.

site_title: Aides to Korean 'Rasputin' testify to her power
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye's longtime confidante Choi Soon-Sil is accused of exerting significant influence over the president and senior officials, including ordering aides to leak confidential documents and colluding with her in strong-arming conglomerates into donating funds to her foundations. Aides testified to Choi's power, describing her as "Korea's Rasputin" and noting her control over the president's wardrobe, appointments, and even the treatment of senior officials. Choi has refused to testify, citing health reasons and a pending trial.

site_title: Foreland Fabrictech lodges complaint with CAD against former exec chairman
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has lodged a complaint with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) against former executive chairman Tsoi Kin Chit, alleging possible breaches of securities laws related to a public reprimand by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The SGX had previously rebuked the company and Mr Tsoi for failing to promptly announce a significant claim and implementing internal controls to address financial and operational risks. The outcome of the complaint is yet to be determined.

site_title: Digital Asset says blockchain platform allows confidential trades
summary: Digital Asset Holdings, backed by major banks, has developed a blockchain platform that allows traders to use the technology without revealing confidential information. The platform aims to address the confidentiality issue holding back blockchain adoption in financial markets. Led by former JPMorgan banker Blythe Masters, the platform provides a shared record of transactions and asset ownership while maintaining user confidentiality. This solution is expected to increase the adoption of blockchain technology in financial markets.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic demand up 5.8% in Oct - IATA
summary: Global air passenger traffic demand rose 5.8% in October, according to IATA, driven by strong growth in Middle East and Asia Pacific airlines. However, North American carriers experienced slower growth, leading to a 0.4 percentage point drop in load factors to 80.1%. Despite a decrease in yield due to terror attacks and instability, the long-term trend has leveled off, with IATA's head Alexandre de Juniac attributing the growth to the Middle East and Asia Pacific regions.

site_title: Foreland Fabrictech lodges CAD complaint against former exec chairman
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has lodged a complaint with Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) against its former executive chairman Tsoi Kin Chit, related to a public reprimand by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for failing to promptly announce a significant claim and address financial risks. The SGX had reprimanded Foreland for paying 290 million yuan (S$60 million) in compensation for allegedly defective textiles, and for breaches of fiduciary duties by Tsoi, Zhang Hong Lai, and Chen Chao Ying. The CAD complaint follows an independent review that cast doubts on the settlement and accounting for Fulian's claim.

site_title: Merkel's party wants dual nationality rule scrapped
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) voted to scrap a dual nationality rule for German-born children of foreigners, a key demand of the Social Democratic Party (SPD). The move, which affects mainly Turkish migrants, sets the party on a collision course with its junior coalition partner. The decision aims to address integration issues, but is unlikely to be implemented due to lack of support from other parties. Merkel's party also called for migrants to be taken into custody before deportation and a partial ban on the Muslim full-face veil, sending a signal ahead of next year's general elections.

site_title: UK govt will publish statement on Brexit strategy before triggering Article 50
summary: The British government will publish a statement on its Brexit negotiating strategy before triggering Article 50, a move aimed at reassuring lawmakers, businesses, and investors. Prime Minister Theresa May plans to set out a broad picture of Britain's future relationship with the EU, while avoiding giving too much away to weaken the UK's negotiating hand. This move is seen as an attempt to maintain a united front among the government and its allies ahead of the formal divorce procedure.

site_title: BMW to compensate thousands of Australian clients in loan scam
summary: BMW has agreed to pay Aus$77 million to compensate thousands of Australian clients who were misled into taking loans they could not afford. At least 15,000 customers may have suffered hardship due to BMW Finance's compliance failure, with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission citing a "sales-driven culture" that failed to comply with credit laws. The company will also be subject to external oversight and a "live review" of credit applications. The compensation package includes Aus$50 million in loan write-offs, Aus$14.6 million in remediation payments, and Aus$7.6 million in interest rate reductions.

site_title: India's RBI unexpectedly keeps rates unchanged
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) unexpectedly kept its key policy rate unchanged at 6.25% despite calls for action amid a cash shortage threatening the country's fast-growing economy. The RBI cited the need for more time to assess the impact of the recent cash shortage and the government's plan to abolish high-value notes. The central bank trimmed its growth forecast for the year ending March 2017, but economists expect a possible rate cut in February due to the potential for inflation and economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: India's central bank unexpectedly kept its key policy rate unchanged at 6.25 per cent on Wednesday, despite calls for action in the face of an intense cash shortage that threatens to slam the brakes on the world's fastest growing large economy.

site_title: JPMorgan, HSBC, Credit Agricole fined $481.5m euros over Euribor
summary: JP Morgan Chase & Co, HSBC Holdings Plc, and Credit Agricole SA were fined a total of 485.5 million euros by European Union antitrust regulators for rigging the Euribor benchmark. The trio colluded on euro interest rate derivative pricing and exchanged sensitive information, breaching EU antitrust rules. JPMorgan was fined 337.2 million euros, HSBC 33.6 million euros, and Credit Agricole 114.7 million euros. The fines follow a five-year investigation and come after the three banks refused to settle the case earlier, delaying the process.

site_title: Xi said to become first Chinese president at Davos summit
summary: President Xi Jinping will become the first Chinese head of state to attend the World Economic Forum in Switzerland, a trip scheduled for January 17-20. The move comes as China seeks a larger role in shaping the global financial order, following Donald Trump's "America First" campaign. Xi will likely highlight China's signature projects, including the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the One Belt, One Road initiative, to tout its economic might and geopolitical clout. The trip coincides with a key Communist Party gathering next year, where Xi is expected to secure a second term as leader.

site_title: Kirk Douglas at 100, still in love with soulmate Anne Frankie
summary: Kirk Douglas turns 100, crediting his six-decade marriage to wife Anne Frankie as a key factor in his longevity. The actor, a three-time Oscar nominee, has overcome adversity, including a stroke and a helicopter crash, to live a full life. He will celebrate with 200 friends and family, including daughter-in-law Catherine Zeta Jones, and has expressed his intention to give most of his fortune to charity on his death.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: COE premiums dropped for cars up to 1,600cc and above 1,600cc, with decreases of S$2,961 and S$7,772 respectively. A Singaporean was sentenced to 36 months in jail for fraudulently obtaining work passes for foreign workers. Vallianz Holdings stated that a CAD probe into two of its non-executive directors is unrelated to the company. The STI ended the day up 10.72 points, while Pfizer opened a development centre in Singapore.

site_title: Opec ministers see oil market balanced if non-Opec joins in cut
summary: Opec ministers believe a global oil output cut of 1.8 million barrels a day, combined with non-Opec nations reducing production by 600,000 barrels a day, will balance the market by mid-2017. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has agreed to a 1.2 million barrel per day production cut, with Russia pledging to reduce output by 300,000 barrels a day. If prices don't stabilize, Opec is prepared to take further action, with prices expected to rise if non-Opec producers agree to cut production, potentially reaching $50-$60 per barrel.

site_title: STI ends Wednesday's session up 10.72 points
summary: Singapore shares ended Wednesday's session up 10.72 points or 0.36% at 2,959.84, driven by gains in banking shares. DBS, OCBC, UOB, and Genting Singapore led the rally. The Straits Times Index saw 222 gainers beating 194 losers, with a turnover of S$1.2 billion on 1.8 billion shares. The gains come ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting and amidst concerns over Italy's referendum and US-EU tariffs.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase denies wrongdoing in EU rate rigging case
summary: JPMorgan Chase has denied any wrongdoing in the EU's interest rate rigging case, stating it cooperated fully with the European Commission's investigation. The US bank claims it did not engage in any wrongdoing and will defend its position through possible appeals. The EU's anti-trust regulator fined JPMorgan Chase, along with HSBC and another bank, for alleged Euribor benchmark manipulation.

site_title: Economic 'boom' to hit Denmark after half a decade below zero
summary: Denmark's economy is set for an "economic boom" after half a decade of negative interest rates, according to the central bank. The economy is expected to expand 1.4% in 2017, driven by household spending, but risks running out of labor resources. The central bank warned that fiscal policy must be balanced to stabilize the economy, citing concerns over labor shortages and housing market imbalances, particularly in Copenhagen. The outlook also includes potential fallout from US President-elect Donald Trump's economic proposals, which could lead to wage and price pressure if labor supply isn't increased.

images.alt_text: After half a decade of negative interest rates, Denmark's economy is headed for an economic "boom" and risks running out of the labor resources needed to support sustainable growth, the central bank said on Wednesday.

site_title: Taiwan November exports grow at fastest rate in nearly 4 years
summary: Taiwan's exports grew 12.1% in November, the fastest pace in nearly four years, driven by strong semiconductor demand and improving commodity prices. This growth is expected to lead to a decision to keep interest rates unchanged at the central bank's quarterly meeting on December 22. Despite the upbeat exports, analysts warn that momentum will fade due to stiff global competition, protectionism, and uncertainties in China's supply chain. Taiwan's exports to China and the US rose 19% and 9.1%, respectively, in November.

site_title: Probe on pound flash crash focusing on Citigroup Japan: FT
summary: A UK investigation into the 2016 pound flash crash is focusing on Citigroup Japan's role in exacerbating the sudden 6.1% drop in the currency. The investigation, which found no clear fundamental trigger, is looking at a single incident involving multiple sell orders by a Citigroup trader. The bank denies any wrongdoing, stating its systems and controls functioned properly, but declined to comment on discipline or trading practices.

site_title: Biggest change to Apac's outlook is Trump-related uncertainty: S&P Global Ratings
summary: S&P Global Ratings notes that the biggest change to the Asia-Pacific's economic outlook is Trump-related uncertainty. The potential downside scenario involves trade policy, where a 45% tariff on China could lead to a trade and investment war. However, infrastructure spending increases and tax cuts could boost US growth and raise demand for Asia's exports in the short run.

site_title: Switzerland makes progress in money laundering fight
summary: Switzerland has made progress in combating money laundering over the last decade, according to the Financial Action Task Force (FATF). The country has strengthened its anti-money laundering measures, including legal reforms and assistive investigations, which have helped return assets in several high-profile corruption cases. However, the FATF urges Switzerland to do more to prevent financial crime, particularly by improving banks' efforts to spot and report suspicious transactions. The Swiss financial watchdog Finma has called on banks to be more thorough in their checks, and the finance ministry will analyze the report's recommendations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.7% to 6,829.06 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 1.0% to 10,885.05. This follows Italy's rejection of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's constitutional reform proposals, which had raised concerns about the country's political future and the eurozone. Despite this, share prices of Italy's troubled banks surged on Tuesday, and markets appear less worried about the uncertainty.

site_title: One ship left in MH370 underwater search
summary: The official search for MH370, a Malaysian Airlines Boeing 777, has been reduced to one ship, the Fugro Equator, in the Indian Ocean. The vessel is in the 120,000 square-kilometre search zone where investigators believe the plane went down. Relatives of the missing passengers have launched their own search in Madagascar for potential crash debris. The search has been ongoing since 2016.

site_title: May accepts call to reveal more details of Brexit strategy
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May agreed to reveal more details of her Brexit strategy in a debate with lawmakers. The main opposition Labour Party presented a motion demanding more details of May's Brexit proposals, which she accepted if Labour supports her plan to invoke Article 50 by the end of March.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up before ECB meeting, aided by commodity shares
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by gains in the energy and raw materials sectors, as investors awaited the European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday. The Hang Seng index advanced to 22,800.92 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index rose to 9,829.58 points. The ECB is expected to extend its asset-purchase program beyond March 2017, but traders remain cautious ahead of the outcome.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.740 points to 1632.470 on Wednesday, driven by higher shares. Volume was 1.040 billion lots worth RM1.374 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 414 to 283.

site_title: Pfizer, Flynn Pharma fined record £84.2m by UK regulator
summary: Pfizer Inc and Flynn Pharma Ltd were fined a record £84.2m and £5.2m respectively by the UK's Competition and Markets Authority for abusing their dominant position by charging unfair prices for phenytoin sodium, an anti-epilepsy drug. Prices increased by 2,600% following a 2012 rebrand, costing the NHS and taxpayer tens of millions of pounds. The companies have been ordered to reduce their prices. Pfizer has denied the finding, stating the price was acceptable to the Department of Health.

site_title: UK house price growth speeds up for 1st time since March
summary: UK house prices rose 6% in the three months to November, the first time since March, according to Halifax. This growth is in line with economists' median forecast. In monthly terms, prices increased 0.2% in November, down from a 1.5% rise in October. Despite this slowdown, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, according to an index.

site_title: China Nov forex reserves fall more than expected to US$3.05 trillion, lowest since 2011
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell by $69.06 billion in November to $3.052 trillion, the lowest since 2011. This marks the fifth straight month of decline, as authorities struggle to support the sliding yuan. Economists had expected a $30 billion drop, instead seeing a larger decline. The move is seen as a response to the rising dollar.

site_title: BOJ Iwata keeps focus on money printing, exposes rift in board
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Kikuo Iwata expressed disagreement with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's view that the central bank may slow money printing if it hits interest rate targets. Iwata stated the BOJ remains committed to using both rate cuts and asset purchases to revive the economy, contradicting Kuroda's shift in focus. The BOJ's policy shift from base money to interest rates has sparked a rift within the board, complicating the central bank's communication with markets as it struggles to reflate growth.

site_title: Refugees who fled Communist Vietnam lured back by startup dreams
summary: Overseas Vietnamese defectors, known as Viet Kieu, are returning to Vietnam to invest in the country's growing tech industry. Many fled the country after the communist victory in 1975, but now they are lured by the nation's improving living standards, education system, and government incentives. The government is actively seeking investment, particularly in high-tech sectors, with a US$10 million fund launched this year. Viet Kieu are contributing significantly to the economy, sending US$13.2 billion in remittances last year, and some are even investing in companies like Intel and Fossil Group.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends higher as US dollar strength wanes, Kospi firmer
summary: The South Korean won strengthened 0.3% to 1,167.9 per US dollar, while the Kospi index rose 0.1% to 1,991.89 points. Samsung Electronics reached a record high before closing up 1.37%. The US dollar's strength waned ahead of European Central Bank and Federal Reserve policy decisions.

site_title: COE premiums down across most categories
summary: COE premiums declined across most vehicle categories in the latest bidding exercise, with the lowest drops seen in cars up to 1,600cc (S$2,722) and motorcycles (S$99). The open category premium decreased to S$50,010, while goods vehicles and buses saw a rise to S$51,209. The decline in COE premiums is attributed to a surplus of available vehicles.

site_title: Sharing economy and telematics to drive growth in auto insurance market
summary: A 20% rise in rental vehicles on Singapore roads is projected to drive the growth of the auto insurance market in 2017. The sharing economy and telematics are key contributors to this growth. The use of telematics is expected to reduce traffic accidents and improve community safety, leading to a 10% or greater decrease in auto insurance premiums over the next two years. Younger drivers buying new cars and the influx of ride-hailing services also increase the risk of accidents, with drivers who use rental cars for commercial purposes being more likely to have accidents.

site_title: India seeks nod to up net spending by US$5.2b
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley sought parliamentary approval to increase net spending by 351.7 billion Indian rupees (S$7.38 billion) in the current fiscal year, citing a healthy 7.3% economic expansion led by state spending. The request comes amid economic disruption from the government's decision to abolish high-value banknotes, and is likely to be approved given the government's large majority in the lower house. The increased spending includes funding for a rural jobs program, farm ministry, and higher pensions bill.

images.alt_text: Indian Finance Minister Arun Jaitley sought parliamentary approval on Wednesday to increase net spending by 351.7 billion Indian rupees (S$7.38 billion) in the current fiscal year that ends in March 2017.

site_title: Japan's Idemitsu, Showa Shell say not decided on capital tie-up
summary: Japanese oil refiners Idemitsu Kosan and Showa Shell Sekiyu have not decided on a capital and business tie-up despite reported negotiations. The planned tie-up aims to exploit synergies and avoid shareholder approval, with the goal of operationalization ahead of a delayed merger. The tie-up would allow Idemitsu to acquire a stake in Showa Shell and vice versa, while maintaining voting rights and protecting Showa Shell's independence. The two companies have yet to make a formal decision on the tie-up, citing the need for further work.

site_title: Apple's top assembler Foxconn confirms plans for US investment
summary: Foxconn Technology Group, Apple's top assembler, is in preliminary discussions to invest $7 billion in the US, expanding its operations and creating 50,000 jobs, according to a statement. The investment is part of US President-elect Donald Trump's $50 billion plan to create jobs. Foxconn, which currently assembles iPhones and other Apple devices in China, aims to move production to the US after Trump called for Apple to do so. The company's leadership will discuss the plan with US officials before announcing details.

site_title: Malaysia's international reserves slip to 8-month low at end-Nov
summary: Malaysia's international reserves fell to an 8-month low of US$96.4 billion as of November 30, down from US$98.3 billion on November 15, due to foreign investors fleeing the country's bond market amid speculation of US stimulus policies. The reserves are sufficient to finance 8.3 months of retained imports and are 1.2 times the short-term external debt. The ringgit has slid nearly 5% since November 9, with economists expecting further declines in December before stabilizing again.

site_title: United States has "enduring" interests in Asia-Pacific, defence secretary says
summary: US Defense Secretary Ash Carter stated that the US has "enduring" interests in the Asia-Pacific region and is working to maintain an orderly transfer of power to President-elect Donald Trump's administration. Carter sought to reassure allies in Japan and South Korea about the US commitment to their security, amid Trump's proposal for them to shoulder more defense costs. Carter also emphasized the shared interests with Japan on regional issues, including freedom of navigation and coercion.

site_title: Commodities trader Trafigura earnings fall, sees challenging conditions
summary: Commodities trader Trafigura reported a 13% decline in core earnings in 2016 to $1.628 billion, citing challenging trading conditions and writedowns in Colombia and Brazil. The company expects similar conditions in 2017, with pressure on producers and other players. Net profit fell 12% to $975 million, while revenue remained flat. Trafigura traded 4.3 million barrels of oil daily, up 42% from 2015, and grew its metals and minerals book by 13%. The company attributed core earnings decline to a $43 million write-off and a $250 million write-down in Brazil.

site_title: Credit Suisse steps up cost cutting as revenue eludes CEO Thiam
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG has stepped up cost cutting efforts under CEO Tidjane Thiam's plan to refocus on wealth management and reduce profit goals. The bank aims to lower its operating cost base to under 17 billion Swiss francs by 2018, down from an earlier goal of below 18 billion francs. This move follows previous adjustments to Thiam's plan, which includes downsizing the investment bank and holding an initial public offering of the Swiss business. The bank's shares have lost 41% in the period due to investors questioning ambitious profit goals for new units.

site_title: Italy preparing to take controlling stake in Monte dei Paschi: sources
summary: Italy is preparing to take a 2 billion-euro stake in Monte dei Paschi di Siena, its third-largest bank, as private funding rescue efforts fade following Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's resignation. The government plans to buy junior bonds from retail investors to increase its stake to 40%, allowing it to control the bank and its shareholder meetings. This move aims to raise the bank's 5 billion-euro shortfall and prevent it from being wound down. The European Commission will assess the government's intervention for potential state aid.

site_title: Thailand plans extra US$5.3b spending for 2017 fiscal year
summary: Thailand's military government plans to spend an extra $5.33 billion in the current fiscal year on investment projects in provinces, mainly financed by savings bond issues. This will increase the budget deficit to $23.1 billion. The new spending aims to boost economic growth and development in the country.

site_title: Thailand to investigate BBC over profile of new king: minister
summary: Thailand's defence minister plans to investigate the BBC over a Thai-language profile of the new king, King Maha Vajiralongkorn, that has sparked social media anger. The profile, published by the BBC Thai service, was deemed insulting to the monarch under Thai law, which carries a penalty of up to 15 years in prison. Authorities blocked the profile and police are investigating, despite no formal complaint being filed. The move is part of Thailand's strict enforcement of lese-majeste laws, which have been criticized by international rights groups.

site_title: New Zealand doubles cost of investment visa, raises quota
summary: New Zealand is doubling the investment requirement for permanent residency to NZ$3 million, effective May 2017, and increasing the annual quota to 400 visas. The move aims to rebalance investment towards growth-oriented sectors, addressing concerns about the country's immigration policy not translating to economic benefits. The 'Investor 2' visa, previously available to NZ$1.5 million investors, will now require NZ$3 million.

site_title: Opec deal seen helping Norway oil investment as soon as 2017
summary: Norway's oil industry is expected to benefit from the Opec deal, which has led to a 16% increase in Brent crude prices since its implementation. Despite declining investments in the industry for the third consecutive year, Norway's Petroleum and Energy Minister Tord Lien expects the Opec deal to accelerate a re-balancing of the global oil market, benefiting producers and consumers alike. Norway's oil output is on track to increase for a third consecutive year, driven by efficiency gains.

site_title: China: Stocks flat as investors watch regulatory moves
summary: China shares remained flat on Wednesday morning due to lingering concerns about regulatory moves, which may restrict some investments by insurers. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index remained unchanged, while the Hang Seng index rose 0.4% and 0.5% respectively. Analysts attributed the dampening of mainland markets to profit-taking by investors after regulatory moves.

site_title: China needs 5,550 new pilots a year as travel soars, Boeing says
summary: China needs 5,550 new pilots annually for the next two decades due to soaring travel demand, according to Boeing. The nation will require 111,000 new aviators through 2035, surpassing the Asia-Pacific region's 40% pilot requirement. Local airlines offer lucrative pay packages to foreign pilots, while the global demand for pilots is expected to reach 617,000 by 2035. The Asia-Pacific region will also need 15,130 new aircraft valued at $2.35 trillion in the next two decades. China's aviation industry is booming, with air traffic expected to almost quadruple in the next two decades.

site_title: Pfizer opens development centre in Singapore
summary: Pfizer has launched a manufacturing technology development centre in Singapore, marking a significant investment in the region's science and technology capabilities. The centre, located on Jurong Island, will collaborate with local research institutes to advance and implement science and manufacturing technology. This new development complements Pfizer's existing manufacturing facility in Tuas, which employs over 300 staff. The investment aims to broaden Pfizer's capabilities in the region and further enhance its science and technology presence.

site_title: Hong Kong faces housing risks as Fed tightening looms, IMF says
summary: Hong Kong's economy is vulnerable to rising interest rates, with the IMF warning of a potential downturn in the property market. The US Federal Reserve's expected rate hike next week will increase borrowing costs in Hong Kong, which is pegged to the US dollar. Stretched property valuations and China-linked stress are also identified as key risks.

site_title: South Korea to slap Volkswagen with record fine, pursue execs over emissions ads
summary: South Korea's antitrust watchdog will file criminal complaints against several Volkswagen executives and fine the company a record 37.3 billion won (S$45.3 million) for false advertising over its vehicle emissions. The fine is related to Volkswagen's false claims of environmentally friendly vehicles when equipped with defeat devices designed to deceive government tests. The regulator will also investigate Volkswagen's headquarters and five former/current executives. This decision follows the suspension of most Volkswagen sales in South Korea since August.

site_title: China calls on US to bar transit of Taiwan president
summary: China has urged the US to block Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen's transit through the country, citing Beijing's "One China policy" and warning against giving a "signal to 'Taiwanese independence' forces". The call comes after President-elect Trump accepted a congratulatory phone call from Tsai, angering Beijing, which views Taiwan as a rogue province. The US State Department said the transit is in keeping with "longstanding US practice" and that Taiwan's leaders usually pass through the country.

site_title: PM Najib destroying Malaysia, stoking racial tensions: Dr Mahathir
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has accused current leader Najib Razak of "destroying" the country by clinging to power despite a corruption scandal. Mahathir, 91, has vowed to campaign vigorously for the opposition in upcoming elections, including working with former jailed deputy Anwar Ibrahim. He has accused Najib of bringing in racism and committing serious crimes, and predicts the opposition could win the elections, citing widespread discontent with Najib's leadership.

site_title: Trip to Tokyo? Ex-Goldman trader sells secret dining access
summary: A former Goldman Sachs trader, Takashi Yamada, has launched Tableall, a company that secures reservations at Tokyo's most exclusive restaurants for foreigners. For a set fee, ranging from $37 to $120 per person, Yamada pays the restaurant in advance and then charges customers the meal's price. Currently, Tableall offers 11 restaurants in Tokyo, with plans to expand to 20 by the end of next year. The company's goal is to provide a seamless dining experience for foreign visitors and promote Japanese culture.

site_title: India's indebted electric retailers seen scaring off investors
summary: India's money-losing state power retailers are deterring investors due to delayed payments and reluctance to sign long-term purchase contracts. Companies like Sembcorp Industries and ReNew Power Ventures are voicing concerns over the industry's precarious business environment. About 22 gigawatts of thermal plants lack long-term purchase commitments, forcing generators to sell in short-term markets. To attract investments, India needs to become more competitive in terms of sustainable long-term infrastructure returns.

site_title: In mammoth task, BP sends almost 3m barrels of US oil to Asia
summary: BP is shipping almost 3 million barrels of US crude to customers across Asia via one of the world's longest sea routes, involving seven tankers and ship-to-ship transfers. This operation marks a significant step in developing new routes to sell cheap US shale oil to Asia, the world's largest consumer region. The move comes after Opec announced deep production cuts, and BP's efforts are likely to become more popular as oil traders seek to capitalize on the increased demand for US crude. The shipment marks a significant milestone in the growth of US oil exports to Asia.

images.alt_text: Oil major BP is shipping almost 3 million barrels of US crude to customers across Asia, pioneering a lengthy and complex operation likely to become more popular after Opec last week announced deep production cuts.

site_title: Apple says iPhone 6 battery fires in China likely caused by external factors
summary: Apple has stated that iPhone 6 battery fires in China were likely caused by external factors, not a design flaw. The Shanghai Consumer Council reported battery fires in eight iPhone 6 handsets, with some powering down before depletion. Apple is widening its investigation into the power-down issue. The company's sales in China have declined in recent quarters due to competition from domestic smartphone makers. The Samsung Note 7 recall also led to increased distrust of foreign brands, with some Chinese users switching to domestic brands.

site_title: Alibaba's finance arm tours Silicon Valley as it preps for IPO
summary: Alibaba's finance arm, Ant Financial, has visited Silicon Valley to prepare for an initial public offering (IPO) expected next year. The company, which serves over 450 million customers in China, aims to become a global financial powerhouse. Ant's executive chair, Lucy Peng, believes an IPO will allow the company to tell its story, provide transparency, and raise funds for acquisitions. Despite being a Chinese entity, Ant faces challenges in persuading foreign investors to trust its services, but Peng sees the IPO as an opportunity to change perceptions.

site_title: Foreign-worker employment scam: Mastermind gets 42 months of jail time
summary: A Singaporean, Mui Chee Mun, was sentenced to 42 months in jail for running a foreign-worker employment scam. He obtained work passes for 37 foreign workers, collected bribes, and fabricated employment documents. Mui managed a shell company, Blue Apple Design Pte Ltd, to bring in foreign workers without providing them with work. He made over S$46,000 in kickbacks and pleaded guilty to 74 counts under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act.

site_title: At least 25 dead in Indonesian earthquake: officials
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia's Sumatra island, killing at least 25 people and injuring hundreds in the Pidie Jaya district. The quake, which occurred at dawn, flattened mosques and shops in the town of Meureudu, prompting people to flee their homes. No tsunami alert was issued.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise despite GDP contraction
summary: Australian shares rose despite the country's GDP contraction of 0.5% in the last quarter, driven by Wall Street's record close and hopes for monetary or fiscal stimulus. The financial and materials sectors led the gains.

site_title: Nikkei rises on Wall Street record; SoftBank soars on US investment plan
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 0.7% to 18,496.69 points on Wednesday, driven by a surge in SoftBank's US investment plan, which announced a $50 billion investment in US companies. SoftBank's stock rose 6.2% after CEO Masayoshi Son's announcement. The Nikkei's gains were supported by a record close on Wall Street overnight and other regional markets, including the Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400, which also rose.

site_title: Details emerge of final moments of California blaze vicitms
summary: Details of the California warehouse fire's final moments emerged, with desperate text messages from victims revealing the tragedy. The messages, sent by 36 victims, included a mother's text from her dying daughter: "Mom, I'm dying." Authorities are searching for clues on the cause of the blaze, which occurred late Friday. The Alameda County Sheriff's office shared these messages, providing a glimpse into the devastating final moments of the victims.

site_title: China to help 1MDB settle multibillion-dollar legal dispute with Abu Dhabi
summary: China is to assist Malaysia's state investment fund 1MDB in settling a multibillion-dollar legal dispute with Abu Dhabi's state-owned fund. The dispute revolves around a breach of contract, with 1MDB owing US$6.5 billion. This move marks a step forward in resolving the fund's financial position. Chinese assistance will help 1MDB make a repayment, although the terms of the agreement remain undisclosed. The settlement is seen as a positive development for the heavily indebted state fund.

site_title: Ford makes contingency plans in case of China year-end tax surprise
summary: Ford Motor is preparing for a potential tax surprise in China, where a tax cut on small engine cars is set to expire at year's end. The US automaker is making contingency plans for three scenarios: the tax cut expires, is extended at a reduced rate, or continues in full. Despite this uncertainty, Ford expects fundamental demand for cars to remain strong, with sales predicted to be only marginally affected by the tax cut. Ford's China sales results will be announced later on Wednesday.

site_title: Top-tier Hong Kong developers cut loan costs by as much as 40%
summary: Hong Kong's top developers, Wheelock & Co and Sun Hung Kai Properties, have secured loan financing with discounts of up to 40% compared to the first half of the year. Despite recent stamp duty and expected rate hikes, banks are competing to lend to corporates, driving down loan pricing. This trend is expected to continue, with prices potentially lowering further in 2017, according to BNP's Wayne Green. Loan margins have dropped 15% year-on-year to 192.21 basis points, the lowest since 2011, amid dwindling syndicated and club loans in Hong Kong.

site_title: Bad debt among SMEs falls in Q3 due to tightening credit terms: DP Info
summary: Bad debt among small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore decreased to 46% in Q3 2016, down from 48% in Q2 and 49% in Q1. This drop is attributed to tighter credit terms, with SMEs demanding faster payment from customers. The manufacturing industry saw the most significant decrease in delinquent debts, while the commerce-retail sector had the lowest percentage of unpaid debts at 21%. This reflects a shift towards prompt payment and vigorous debt collection among retailers.

images.alt_text: The level of bad debts among small and medium enterprises (SMEs) fell in the third quarter of 2016, as credit terms between SMEs and their customers continue to tighten, said DP Information Group on Wednesday.

site_title: 'Game of Thrones' star Peter Vaughan dies age 93
summary: British actor Peter Vaughan, best known for his role as Maester Aemon in "Game of Thrones", died on Tuesday at the age of 93. Vaughan had a long career in television, appearing in shows such as "Porridge" and "Our Friends in the North". He was partially sighted in real life and played a blind character in "Game of Thrones". Vaughan was married to actress Billie Whitelaw for 12 years and is survived by his second wife, Lillias Walker.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat despite Samsung Electronics' record high, won edges up
summary: South Korean shares were flat on Wednesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rising 0.1% to 1,999.79 points. Samsung Electronics rose 1.3% to a record high, despite investors' caution ahead of the ECB policy decision and US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The South Korean won edged up 0.3% against the US dollar. Investors are awaiting a vote on impeaching President Park Geun-hye and are closely watching policy changes from the ECB and Fed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong shares opened higher on Wednesday, extending gains from the previous day. The Hang Seng index rose 0.57% to 22,805.13, following a record close on Wall Street and positive leads from Europe. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to form housing refinancing company
summary: Saudi Arabia announced the formation of a housing refinancing company to provide up to $13.33 billion in financing for the kingdom's housing sector over five years. The move aims to boost homeownership among Saudis to 52% by 2020, as part of the government's efforts to diversify the economy away from oil. The company will help develop the housing mortgage sector, which has been restricted by Islamic sharia law. This initiative is part of Saudi Arabia's long-awaited efforts to create a housing mortgage sector.

site_title: Climate change battle heats up for Australian winemakers
summary: Australia's winemaking industry is facing a climate change battle as extreme weather events, such as heatwaves, become more frequent. The country's wine export industry, valued at A$2 billion, is at risk due to warmer temperatures, altered rainfall patterns, and shorter harvesting seasons. To mitigate the effects, winemakers are trialling methods like pruning later and switching to grape varieties that thrive in warmer climates. The industry is also exploring alternative crops like nuts, as some regions may become less suitable for grape growing by 2050.

site_title: Broker's Take: Maybank Kim Eng picks office Reits over developers
summary: Maybank Kim Eng recommends investors choose office real estate investment trusts (Reits) over property developers in Singapore due to the risk-averse environment. The brokerage favors office Reits like Capita Commercial Trust and Keppel Reit for attractive valuations and low lease expiry. In contrast, property developers, including UOL, are expected to struggle to meet their cost of capital, with intense competition for land potentially weighing on margins. The market is expected to remain oversupplied in 2017, with the occupier market remaining weak due to slowing population growth and job creation.

site_title: Valls seen losing French presidential race in first round: poll
summary: Manuel Valls, France's former Prime Minister, is unlikely to advance to the second round of the presidential election, according to a poll. Valls would receive only 13% of votes in the first round, behind conservative candidate Francois Fillon and far-right Marine Le Pen. Even if Valls' main competitor, Jean-Luc Melenchon, and potential challenger Emmanuel Macron were not in the running, Valls would still fall short. The poll predicts Fillon will win the election with 67% of votes in a two-way run-off against Le Pen.

site_title: US dollar, euro tread water as ECB meeting comes into view
summary: The euro and US dollar remain steady ahead of Thursday's European Central Bank policy meeting, which may influence currency markets. The euro was little changed at US$1.0720 after a 0.5% overnight drop, while the US dollar remained steady at 114.069 yen. Market traders are awaiting the ECB's stance on policy tapering, which could impact the Trump rally and currency markets. The Australian and New Zealand dollars also experienced fluctuations, while commodity-linked currencies like the Canadian dollar sagged due to retreating oil prices.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up, tracking overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, tracking overseas markets, ahead of the release of export data. The latest figures are expected to show exports rose for a second month, following a year-over-year increase in October. The electronics subindex rose 0.2%, while display makers Innolux and AU Optronics gained 1.8% and 1.7% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.930 per US dollar.

site_title: Trump introduces 'mad dog' Mattis, pledges to rebuild military
summary: President-elect Donald Trump introduced General James Mattis as his Defense Secretary nominee, calling him "a popular choice" and "one of the most effective generals." Trump pledged to rebuild the US military and fight terrorism, saying "From now on, it's going to be America first." The announcement was made at a rally in Fayetteville, North Carolina, near the Fort Bragg military base.

site_title: US lawmaker: Sony breach may have inspired Russian election hacking
summary: US Representative Adam Schiff suggests that the US failure to retaliate strongly against Sony Pictures' 2014 cyber attack may have inspired Russian hackers to interfere in the 2016 US election, potentially damaging trust in democratic institutions. Schiff and other lawmakers are calling for stronger action against Russian hacking, including sanctions to hit the Russian economy. Schiff also notes that Russian hackers could target President-elect Donald Trump if they disapprove of his policies. The issue has sparked calls for investigations and legislation to address the hacking issue.

site_title: Australia shares rise on Wall St, stimulus hopes after GDP contraction; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of further monetary or fiscal stimulus following a 0.5% contraction in the economy last quarter. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 5,466.4, boosted by solid gains in US stocks and solid gains in Wall Street. The US financial sector rose nearly 1% overnight, driven by expectations of lower corporate taxes and reduced regulations under Donald Trump. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% as telecom and utilities stocks declined.

site_title: BOJ won't hesitate to ease more to hit price goal: Iwata
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Kikuo Iwata stated that the central bank will not hesitate to ease monetary policy further to achieve its 2% inflation target. Iwata emphasized the BOJ's commitment to expanding the monetary base, including government bond purchases, under its new policy framework. The BOJ's policy target has shifted from the pace of money printing to interest rates, and it has pushed back its inflation target timeframe due to weak consumption and a strong yen. Iwata stressed that the BOJ will take additional easing measures if necessary to maintain economic momentum.

site_title: Stung by SGX suspension, ISR Capital to issue third report over mining asset
summary: ISR Capital, whose shares have been suspended by the Singapore Exchange (SGX), plans to issue a third independent report to value a proposed $40 million acquisition of a 60% stake in Tantalum Holding (Mauritius), which holds a mining concession for rare earth oxides in Madagascar. The previous reports were deemed insufficient by SGX, citing listing rules requirements. The company's newly appointed chairman, Chen Tong, has expressed confidence in the company's governance and ethics, and has invested $2 million in the company. The report aims to address remaining issues raised by SGX.

images.alt_text: ISR Capital, which has had its shares suspended by the regulator, said on Wednesday it will commission a third independent report to value a proposed purchase in Madagascar that would allow the firm to mine for rare earth oxides.

site_title: Starbucks courts millennials with US$10 coffee at new Reserve bars
summary: Starbucks is launching a new prestige brand, Reserve, with US$10 coffee at upscale bars in major cities. The Reserve project, led by co-founder Howard Schultz, aims to attract millennials with higher-quality coffee and espresso drinks. The company plans to open 1,000 Reserve stores and 30 large Roastery and Tasting Rooms worldwide. Analysts expect Reserve to drive twice the financial returns of typical Starbucks stores, with potential for higher prices and increased customer spending. The Reserve brand will offer exotic, small-lot coffees, potentially with prices higher than those of competitors like Blue Bottle and Intelligentsia.

site_title: Protectionism, China's slowing credit growth spell trouble for Singapore: report
summary: A report from the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW) warns that protectionism and slowing credit growth in China pose threats to Singapore's economy. The report forecasts Singapore's GDP growth to be 1.4% in 2016, 2% in 2017, and 3.5% in 2018. The TPP's demise and potential slowdown in globalisation also pose risks to Asean economies. Additionally, a slowdown in China's credit growth could weaken global demand for raw materials and impact Singapore's logistics hub.

site_title: Aussie dollar slides after economy contracts more than forecast
summary: Australia's dollar dropped 0.6% against the greenback after a report showed the economy contracted 0.5% in the three months to September, exceeding the forecasted 0.1% contraction. The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates at a record low 1.5% and Governor Philip Lowe noted potential slowing in growth before a rebound. The Australian dollar fell to 74.26 US cents, its first drop in three days, as investors reacted to the weaker-than-expected economic data.

site_title: Shareholders lose 99% as Hong Kong rights offerings go wrong
summary: Hong Kong-listed property firm Eminence Enterprise Ltd is seeking fresh capital from shareholders via a rights offering, aiming to raise HK$478.2 million, nearly twice its current market value. This is the eighth time in five years the company is seeking additional capital, resulting in a 99.99% loss over the past five years. The move comes as China gives its citizens greater access to Hong Kong small-caps, increasing scrutiny on repeat rights issuers.

site_title: Ikea looks to 5b euro revamp to spur growth
summary: Ikea Group sold key subsidiaries to Inter Ikea Holding BV for 5.2 billion euros, aiming to spur growth by reorganizing its business. The transaction boosted pre-tax profits by 23% to 5.4 billion euros, with Inter Ikea controlling development of the Ikea range and supply chain. The split of responsibilities aims to create a tension that spurs growth, while maintaining tax efficiency. Ikea Group will focus on retail operations, and Inter Ikea will handle design and manufacturing. The move is expected to benefit the overall franchise, with analysts praising the strategic benefits for Ikea Group.

site_title: Trump invites tech leaders to talk after industry opposition
summary: President-elect Donald Trump has invited tech leaders, including Oracle CEO Safra Catz and Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins, to a discussion in New York on December 14. The meeting aims to build relationships with the incoming administration, which initially distrusted and criticized the tech industry. The agenda has not been decided, and the meeting follows a series of public clashes between Trump and tech companies during the campaign. The discussion may address concerns over Trump's positions on immigration, trade, and net neutrality.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump invited technology leaders to a discussion next week in New York where Silicon Valley will begin building relationships with an incoming administration it initially distrusted and mostly criticized.

site_title: UK's Hammond kicks off Brexit reassurance tour in South Africa
summary: British finance minister Philip Hammond embarks on a reassurance tour in South Africa and Japan to alleviate concerns about Brexit's impact on trade and investment. Hammond will meet with South African business representatives and Softbank's CEO in Japan, addressing concerns about the implications of Brexit. The visit aims to reassure partners that Brexit will not hurt trade and investment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.18 points to 1633.15 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 14 million lots worth RM6 million. Gainers outpaced losers 62 to 25.

site_title: BP is most-exposed among oil majors to Opec-Russia cuts
summary: BP is most exposed to Opec-Russia production cuts among major oil companies, with 20% stake in Rosneft and significant operations in Iraq and Angola. The agreement aims to boost oil prices and revive the industry, with Opec cutting its output by 32.5 million barrels daily. BP is likely to be affected, with its Iraq operations and Rosneft fields potentially impacted if Russia delivers on its production cut. Total, Shell, Exxon, and Eni are also expected to comply, with Total facing a 2-3% reduction in Opec production.

site_title: Barclays to save US$45m in office sublet to government
summary: Barclays has agreed to sublet office space in London's Canary Wharf to the UK government, saving the bank about £35 million (S$63 million) a year. The 50,168 square meter space will be leased by the Cabinet Office, with staff relocating to Barclays's headquarters or another office in the district. This move is part of Barclays' efforts to reduce its real estate costs, with CEO Jes Staley aiming to make "tremendous savings" by downsizing its London office space.

site_title: Asia: Shares edge up as markets look to ECB after Italian vote
summary: Asian shares rose 0.2-0.4% on Wednesday as investors covered short positions in European equities ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, following Italy's referendum. Italian shares surged 4.2%, while French shares hit 11-month highs. The ECB is expected to extend its asset-purchase program, which could boost the euro. Oil prices steadied, while the Australian dollar fell after data showed the economy contracted in the third quarter.

site_title: China shuts thousands of illegal live streaming accounts: Xinhua
summary: China has shut down thousands of illegal live streaming accounts on Beijing-based websites, with over 4,500 accounts closed and 3,100 programmes removed, following new regulations by the Cyber Administration of China. The regulations, which came into effect in November, require streaming services to report users who stream content deemed a threat to national security or social order. The move aims to curb violent, obscene, and vulgar content on live-streaming websites and enhance surveillance measures on leading firms.

site_title: US Supreme Court backs Samsung in smartphone fight with Apple
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 8-0 in favor of Samsung, dismissing a $399 million penalty imposed by an appeals court for allegedly copying key iPhone designs. The court held that a patent violator doesn't have to pay its entire profits if the designs covered only certain components, not the whole product. The case will be sent back to the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit to determine the amount Samsung must pay. The ruling sends a message that copying designs is not acceptable, but leaves uncertainty on how to navigate similar disputes in the future.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, tracking global gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following global gains, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.40% and the Topix index up 0.45%. This comes after a record close on Wall Street and a surge in Italian banks. European stocks were mixed, with mining and healthcare shares propelling gains, while US-EU trade talks are in focus. Despite US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats, the rally in Asian markets continues.

site_title: China railway bureaus to sign long-term coal contracts: media
summary: China's state-owned railway departments will sign long-term coal transport contracts with suppliers and buyers to meet winter demand and stabilize prices. The contracts, worth over 200,000 tonnes annually, will be signed with key miners and buyers. This move aims to prevent a winter shortage of coal and follow the government's efforts to enforce mine closures and restart production. The contracts will be priced below prevailing spot rates, with one contract already executed at 580 yuan (S$120) per tonne for 5,500 kilocalorie/kg thermal coal.

site_title: SoftBank shares jump after CEO says to invest US$50b in US
summary: SoftBank shares surged 5.1% to 7,311 yen after CEO Masayoshi Son announced a $50 billion investment in US businesses during a meeting with US President-elect Donald Trump. This marks the highest level in over a year for SoftBank shares.

site_title: Oil falls on output cut skepticism, Opec and Russia output rise
summary: Oil prices fell for the first time since Opec agreed to cut output on Nov 30, as record-high production data fueled skepticism about the output reduction. Brent futures dropped $1.01 to $53.93 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 86 cents to $50.93 a barrel. The decline follows a 15% surge in oil prices since the Opec meeting.

site_title: Egypt, China sign currency swap deal
summary: Egypt and China signed an 18-billion-yuan (S$3.7 billion) currency swap deal, easing pressure on Egypt's foreign reserves. The agreement allows Egypt to use the yuan in transactions with China, while China can use the Egyptian pound in return transactions. The deal, valid for three years, is seen as positive by analysts, as it increases liquidity and reduces demand for US dollars. This comes as Egypt struggles to boost its foreign currency reserves following the 2011 uprising and recent IMF loan approval.

site_title: Heavy security at LA metro stations after threat
summary: Police deployed heavily at Los Angeles metro stations after an anonymous man from overseas warned of a bomb attack on the Universal City metro stop, near Universal Studios theme park. The threat, described as "very specific," was relayed to the FBI's terrorism task force and prompted increased security measures, including random bag searches and orange barriers. Authorities are still investigating the credibility of the threat and its origin. Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti rode the metro to reassure the public and emphasize the importance of citizen vigilance.

site_title: Singapore shares open 8.21 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index up 8.21 points to 2,957.33. DBS Bank, Great Eastern, and UOB were top gainers, with 48.3 million shares changing hands worth S$57.9 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, marking a 5-day rally.

site_title: Vallianz says CAD probe into Swiber-linked directors 'not related' to company
summary: Vallianz Holdings stated that two non-executive directors, Yeo Jeu Nam and Yeo Chee Neng, were interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) regarding their roles as directors of Swiber Holdings. Vallianz clarified that the matter is "not related" to the company, and its operations will continue as normal. The interview occurred a day after Swiber announced similar investigations.

site_title: MasterCard to buy back shares worth US$4b
summary: MasterCard Inc announced a US$4 billion share repurchase programme, which will be effective upon completion of its existing US$4 billion programme with US$1.3 billion remaining. The company also raised its quarterly cash dividend by 16% to 22 cents per share. This move aims to return capital to shareholders while maintaining a strong financial position.

images.alt_text: Payment processor Mastercard Inc said on Tuesday it would buy back class A shares worth US$4 billion and raised its quarterly dividend.

site_title: Australia economy slams into reverse, first contraction since 2011
summary: Australia's economy contracted for the first time in over five years, shrinking 0.5% in the third quarter, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This was the first contraction since 2011 and challenges policymakers' optimism for growth. Business investment, particularly in mining, and home building were major contributors to the decline.
