The local dollar fell, and investors remain optimistic about future growth, with rate futures implying no further rate cuts.

site_title: Strong 6.4-magnitude quake hits off Indonesia's Aceh: USGS
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck off Indonesia's Aceh province in the early hours of Wednesday, with the USGS assessing a low likelihood of casualties and damage. The quake, which hit 10km north of Reuleuet, was shallow but did not trigger a tsunami alert. Aceh was devastated by the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami, which killed over 170,000 people. Indonesia is prone to seismic activity due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

site_title: Cityneon cites positive CIMB report as reason for trading surge
summary: Cityneon Holdings' shares surged 5.5% on Tuesday due to a positive research report from CIMB, released on December 5, with a target price of S$1.41. The company attributed the large gain to the CIMB report, stating it had no other explanation for the unusual trading volume. This report comes after a period of stronger-than-usual trading activity over the last five days.

site_title: US clears Alaska Air takeover of Virgin America
summary: US antitrust regulators approved Alaska Airlines' US$4 billion acquisition of Virgin America, but requires the companies to scale back a route-sharing alliance with American Airlines. The Justice Department prohibits sharing on routes where Virgin and American compete and where Alaska is likely to introduce service after the merger. The acquisition is expected to close soon, strengthening Alaska's coverage and making it the fifth-largest US carrier. Alaska's shares rose 1.3% and Virgin's 0.6% following the news.

site_title: Trump trumpets US$50b investment ahead of victory rally
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced a $50 billion Japanese telecoms investment, set to create 50,000 US jobs, in a meeting with Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son at Trump Tower. The investment comes from SoftBank's $100 billion US fund, and Trump claimed it was a personal coup, stating Son had agreed to invest after Trump won the election. The move aims to bolster Trump's populist credentials and create jobs ahead of his victory rally in Ohio.

site_title: Abterra's controlling shareholder under liquidation by Hong Kong court
summary: Abterra's controlling shareholder, General Nice Resources (Hong Kong), has been put under liquidation by the High Court of Hong Kong. General Nice Resources holds a 34.96% interest in Abterra, an iron-ore product trader. The company stated it will assess the impact on its operations and make a necessary announcement. The move affects Abterra's ability to operate as a going concern.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as Italy bank rally powers sector
summary: European shares rose for a second day, driven by a surge in Italian banks, which climbed 9% to an 11-month high. The rally followed Italy's constitutional referendum defeat, leading investors to cover short positions and support cyclical stocks. The European bank sector index rose 4.4%, while the utilities sector also gained, driven by Drax Group's plans to buy Opus Energy. The rally was capped by a decline in commodities-related stocks.

site_title: Japan's economy is about to grow by 19.8t yen - on paper
summary: Japan's economy is set to grow by 19.8 trillion yen, equivalent to New Zealand's economy, when the government announces a revision of gross domestic product data using a new accounting standard. This change will add to the nation's GDP, bringing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe closer to his goal of expanding GDP to 600 trillion yen. The revision, which will treat research and development as capital formation, will not alter the fundamental problem of weak economic growth in Japan, which expanded about 6% in the five years to 2015.

site_title: Jho Low's family broadens bid to protect US$650m nest egg
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low's family is seeking court orders in the Cayman Islands and New Zealand to replace trustees controlling US$650 million in assets seized by the US, claiming they are beneficiaries of the trusts. The US alleges the funds were stolen from 1Malaysia Development Bershad, a state-owned investment fund, with over US$3.5 billion misappropriated between 2009 and 2015. The Low family will attempt to postpone a US hearing on their right to intervene in the cases, fearing their possessions will be forfeited if they can't bring a claim.

site_title: Indonesian child prodigy again up for Grammy
summary: Indonesian child prodigy Joey Alexander, 13, has been nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Improvised Jazz Solo for his take on John Coltrane's "Giant Steps". This is his second nomination for the prestigious award. Joey, who began playing the piano at a young age, was inspired by his parents' jazz records and eventually moved to New York to pursue his music career. He will compete against notable jazz musicians such as Ravi Coltrane and Brad Mehldau. The Grammy Awards will be presented on February 12 in Los Angeles.

site_title: Park digs in; tycoons deny seeking favours
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye said she would wait for a court to uphold an impeachment decision if she is removed from office, amid a growing influence peddling scandal. A critical impeachment vote is expected on Friday, which must be upheld by the Constitutional Court, potentially prolonging the crisis.

site_title: London tech leaders propose post-Brexit plan to British government
summary: London's status as Europe's leading tech destination is at risk if the British government doesn't clarify plans to retain skilled migrants, warn nine tech entrepreneurs and investors. They called on Prime Minister Theresa May to address EU market access and other issues, citing quotas on specific skills as a major concern. The letter also urged the government to campaign for access to the European Union's digital single market and ensure a simple framework for companies, labor, tax, and bankruptcy protection.

site_title: US business lobby warns Trump tariffs could backfire
summary: US business lobby chief Doug Oberhelman expressed optimism about President-elect Donald Trump's emphasis on boosting US manufacturing jobs, but warned that tariffs could backfire if provoked. Oberhelman, CEO of Caterpillar, expressed concern over Trump's threats of 35% punitive tariffs on imports, which could harm companies like Caterpillar with global sales. However, he supported Trump's goal of improving free trade agreements. A quarterly survey by the Business Roundtable showed 67% of CEOs expected sales to increase in the next six months, but only 35% expected higher capital spending.

site_title: US: Dow at record again as banks lead rally
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average setting a record close at 19,251.78, a 0.2% gain. Financial shares, particularly banking stocks, led the rally, driven by positive commentary from JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, with the Nasdaq rising 0.5% to 5,333.00. However, some stocks fell, including Teva Pharmaceutical Industries and Chipotle Mexican Grill, due to announcements from their CEOs.

site_title: New margin rules from March to hike trading cost in HK, S'pore, Australia
summary: Hong Kong, Singapore, and Australia will implement new margin rules for trading over-the-counter derivatives on March 1, requiring dealers to post and collect collateral. This global reform aims to address the 2008-2009 financial crisis and is set to increase the cost of trading in the $500 trillion global swaps market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vallianz, Abterra, Cityneon, Del Monte
summary: Vallianz Holdings faces scrutiny after two non-executive directors were interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department in relation to Swiber Holdings, but the matter was deemed unrelated. Abterra's controlling shareholder General Nice Resources has been put under liquidation by the High Court of Hong Kong, affecting its 34.96% stake. Cityneon Holdings experienced an unexpected surge in shares without a positive research report, while Del Monte Pacific's second-quarter net profit fell 57.8% due to restructuring costs. These developments may be watched on Wednesday.

site_title: Current, ex-Swiber directors questioned by CAD
summary: Current and former Swiber Holdings directors have been questioned by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and released on bail. The directors, including executive chairman Raymond Kim Goh and ex-vice chairman Francis Wong Chin Sing, were investigated for alleged infringements under Section 199 of the Securities and Futures Act, related to making false and misleading disclosures. Swiber is cooperating with CAD's investigations, which are ongoing, and no formal charges have been brought against those individuals. The company had filed a winding-up application in July but reversed course to seek judicial management instead.

site_title: RBA holds key rate due to commodity upswing
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held interest rates at 1.5% due to a global commodity upswing easing the impact of a weaker Australian economy. Governor Philip Lowe noted "some slowing in the year-ended growth rate is likely" but also warned that further easing could destabilize the economy. The RBA is watching and waiting, citing the Federal Reserve's expected tightening of policy and the removal of a mining investment boom drag on growth.

site_title: SIA CEO bags Dwight D Eisenhower Global Innovation Award
summary: SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong has been awarded the Dwight D Eisenhower Global Innovation Award by the Business Council for International Understanding (BCIU). He is the first recipient from South-east Asia for his "transformational leadership of Singapore Airlines". The award was presented in New York, recognizing his drive to innovate and his airline's commitment to enhancing the travel experience for customers. Goh accepted the award on behalf of the 25,000 SIA employees, praising their perseverance and shared enthusiasm.

site_title: Amid challenges, insurers see silver lining in region's low penetration
summary: Insurance companies see a silver lining in the region's low insurance penetration despite economic and political uncertainties. Low interest rates have pushed insurers to seek returns through riskier investments, with 47% of respondents planning to increase exposure to investment risk. Central bank policies, demographic changes, and geopolitical tensions also pose challenges, but insurers are exploring new products and partnerships to adapt. Despite these headwinds, low penetration rates create growth opportunities, and insurers are investing in financial technology and partnerships with startups to capitalize on the trend.

images.alt_text: BlackRock's Mr Lomas said insurers' success will increasingly depend on the smart and efficient management of their investments.

site_title: Snap out of the win-win fantasy of liberal democracy
summary: Recent populist victories, such as Brexit and Donald Trump's presidency, can be attributed to complex factors beyond simplistic explanations. The "elites" - academia, media, and business - have been accused of ignoring the grievances of less educated and connected groups, who have benefited least from globalization. While communication and fact-based discourse can help, addressing the root causes of inequality and creating redistributive policies are necessary. The liberal-democratic West's assumption of win-win solutions is flawed, and negotiations are needed to facilitate cooperation on issues like energy policy and security. Compromise is key, and acknowledging medium-term win-lose situations is essential.

site_title: Citi Bike under pressure to expand to low-income neighbourhoods
summary: Citi Bike, a bike-sharing system in New York City, is expanding into low-income neighborhoods like Harlem and Astoria. The company, which narrowly avoided bankruptcy, has seen significant growth with tens of thousands of daily users. Its success has led to plans for further expansion. Despite financial struggles, Citi Bike remains a popular mode of transportation in the city, offering a more affordable alternative to traditional transportation options.

site_title: Economic growth not a zero-sum game: President Tan
summary: Singapore President Tony Tan Keng Yam stated that economic growth is not a zero-sum game, but rather a plus-sum game where increased growth benefits everyone. During a 9-day state visit to Japan, he emphasized the strong sharing of minds between the two nations on economic growth. Tan also urged Japanese companies to view Singapore as a pivot to expand into the region, suggesting opportunities for collaboration and growth.

site_title: At Dakota pipeline protest, activists gird for fight ahead
summary: Thousands of protesters in North Dakota celebrated the federal government's ruling against the Dakota Access Pipeline, but activists warn of a long fight ahead as President-elect Donald Trump's team supports the project. The US Army Corps of Engineers rejected an application to tunnel under Lake Oahe, a reservoir on the Missouri River. Despite the victory, protesters remain concerned about the pipeline's impact on sacred lands and water sources. The company behind the pipeline, Energy Transfer Partners, says it won't reroute the line, and Trump's team plans to review the project after the president-elect takes office.

site_title: China fund manager arrested after market crash admits to manipulation
summary: A Chinese hedge fund manager, Xu Xiang, pleaded guilty to manipulating the market, following a crackdown on financial crimes after a 2015 stock market crash. Xu, known as "Hedge Fund Brother No1," and two others were detained in November 2015 and asked for leniency in sentencing. Authorities blamed market manipulation and malicious trading for the 40% decline in Chinese bourses in summer 2015, and investigations targeted journalists, executives, and regulators. Xu's funds had achieved high annual yields before his arrest.

site_title: Tech investors say UK must clarify Brexit immigration stance
summary: Tech investors warn the UK must clarify its Brexit immigration stance to avoid losing its position as a leading destination for startups in Europe. Six months after the referendum, investors call on the government to address concerns about access to talent, citing 31% of EU tech workers in the UK. Despite government initiatives, investors believe the UK needs to show more leadership and clarity on attracting global talent.

site_title: Pacific Radiance co-founder faces corruption probe
summary: Executive director Mok Weng Vai, co-founder of Pacific Radiance, was arrested on December 2 for suspected graft and released on bail. The investigation, led by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, relates to Section 6(c) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. Mok, who co-founded Pacific Radiance in 2002, heads the offshore support services division and was primarily in charge of the OSV chartering business in Malaysia and Indonesia.

site_title: Opportunity for US in a post-TPP world
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) may create an opportunity for the US in a post-TPP world. China, with its Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) agreement, could fill the void, potentially enhancing its economic power. However, RCEP's tariff reductions and high standards are less stringent than TPP's, and its impact on global trade liberalization is uncertain. Trump's deal-making strength could lead to a new bilateral investment treaty with China, but the outcome remains unclear.

site_title: Oil and gas heavyweights make strong bids for Mexican offshore drilling rights
summary: International oil companies, including Total, Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and China National Offshore Oil Corp, agreed to pay billions of dollars to the Mexican government for rights to drill in the country's Gulf of Mexico. The auction, which awarded eight blocks, indicates confidence in the potential of the deepwater fields, with some estimates suggesting 11 billion barrels of oil and gas reserves. The companies' investments are expected to total around $40 billion, with many analysts predicting oil prices could reach $80 a barrel or more in the next decade, making the deepwater Mexican fields a promising opportunity for profit.

site_title: Top Dalian Wanda executive resigns
summary: Dalian Wanda Group's top executive, Lu Xiaoma, has resigned as vice-president of Dalian Wanda Financial Group, citing "personal reasons." Lu was behind the company's US$4.4 billion plan to take its Hong Kong-listed property arm private and relist it in China. However, regulatory approval has been delayed due to increased scrutiny of backdoor listings. The plan's failure signals difficulties for the conglomerate, owned by China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, in listing the property business in China. Regulatory issues and policy changes have made the listing process challenging.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) has acquired three properties in the business parks/science parks space for S$420 million, deepening its exposure to the sector. The acquisition offers a 6.0% yield, low for its relatively young age and long land lease tenure. A-Reit's debt expiry profile is spread out over 3.8 years, and its interest rate risk management strategy is prudent. Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) is expected to benefit from ADCF's acquisition of a data centre, with potential for higher development fees and a higher target price of S$2.53.

site_title: Generals dominate new Thai king's Privy Council
summary: Thailand's new King Maha Vajiralongkorn appointed 11 members to his Privy Council, including three generals linked to the ruling junta, in a move reflecting the close military-royal alliance that has defined Thai politics for decades. The council now has a majority of military members, with eight ex-generals and three new ones, including Cabinet ministers Justice Minister General Paiboon Koomchaya and Education Minister General Dapong Ratansuwan. The appointment suggests the new king is seeking to balance military factions and limit the council's influence.

site_title: Commodity bulls' 5 years of pain nears end as gains are on the cards
summary: Commodity bulls are experiencing relief after five years of pain, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index poised for its first annual gain since 2010. Demand is increasing, and production gluts are easing, with zinc up 72% and nickel surging amid mine-supply concerns. Citigroup projects a global pick-up in 2017, while Goldman Sachs recommends an overweight position in commodities. Stabilisation in China's economy and a potential OPEC output cut are driving the gains, with copper and crude oil also rising.

site_title: ABN Amro to sell Asia, M-E private banking assets to LGT
summary: ABN Amro NV agreed to sell its Asia and Middle East private banking assets to LGT for a "substantial book gain". The unit manages around $20 billion in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Dubai, representing 10% of ABN Amro's private banking assets globally. The sale allows ABN Amro to focus on its European operations, while LGT's assets under management will increase to over $40 billion in Asia and $160 billion in total.

site_title: S Africa startup set to be first firm to make smartphones in Africa
summary: A South African startup, Onyx Connect, is set to become the first company to manufacture smartphones in Africa, starting production in the first quarter of 2017. The company, backed by $15.6 million, will produce devices based on Google's Android system and plans to create 600 jobs. With labor costs reduced by a 40% drop in the value of the South African rand, Onyx can produce devices at a lower cost, making them more affordable for African consumers, with prices starting at around $30.

site_title: Opec rally fails to aid crippled Latin oil giants
summary: Latin American oil giants, including Petrobras, Pemex, and PDVSA, failed to benefit from the recent Opec-driven price rally. Despite a 15% surge in Brent crude, the companies remain hindered by financial, political, and technical issues. State-owned quasi-companies with social obligations have limited freedom to respond to market forces, unlike US companies. The companies' debt loads and lack of investment in new drilling technology further hinder their ability to respond to the rising prices. Petrobras is in a better position to take advantage of rising prices, while Pemex and PDVSA require much higher prices to sustain production.

site_title: Apple Watch sales to consumers set record in holiday week
summary: Apple Watch sales to consumers reached a record during the first week of holiday shopping, according to Apple Inc chief executive Tim Cook. The gadget's sell-through, a measure of units sold to consumers, reached a new high. This marks the best quarter ever for the Apple Watch, with sales set to continue strong.

site_title: Oxley to acquire 40% stake in Aussie property group
summary: Oxley Holdings Limited, a Singapore developer, has acquired a 40% stake in Australian property group Pindan Group Pty Ltd for A$32 million. The deal expands Oxley's global footprint to 10 markets. Pindan Group has an annual turnover of over A$500 million and work on hand of more than A$1 billion. Oxley executive chairman and CEO Ching Chiat Kwong and group deputy CEO Eric Low See Ching will join Pindan's board. The partnership aims to create attractive business opportunities for both parties, following Oxley's "result-proven" strategy of partnering with local companies overseas.

site_title: Barclays' energy trading exit raises concerns
summary: British bank Barclays Plc has exited its energy trading business, joining a string of top banks to scale back in commodity markets due to regulatory scrutiny. The departure raises concerns among oil producers that falling liquidity will limit their ability to hedge risk using derivatives. With Barclays' exit, the scarcity of counterparties for trade increases the cost to lock in future prices, potentially forcing cash-strapped producers to forgo protection and putting them at risk.

site_title: Five trends in payments for 2017
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The financial services sector is undergoing significant changes due to fintech innovations, with mobile payments, encryption technology, and tokenization expected to dominate the coming year. Cybercriminals are targeting the payment ecosystem, prompting merchants to invest in point-to-point encryption and tokenization to secure transactions. The Internet of Things (IoT) will also fuel crime, and the use of blockchain technology is gaining traction for secure transactions. As m-commerce grows, more payment options will emerge, and businesses must prioritize innovation and security to protect payment transactions. Global collaboration is vital to ensuring data security and protecting the future of payments.

site_title: Bank of England chief: gains in globalisation must filter down to all
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney defended globalisation, calling for a more inclusive model where everyone has a stake. He acknowledged that gains from trade and technology haven't been felt by all, and urged bankers and governments to improve the balance of monetary and fiscal policy. Carney also defended the central bank's current policy stance, citing powerful global forces such as debt and demographics. He expressed support for UK Prime Minister Theresa May and Chancellor Philip Hammond, and called for investment to boost productivity.

site_title: MCL Land tops bids for Margaret Drive residential site with S$238.4m
summary: MCL Land emerged as the top bidder for a 99-year leasehold residential land parcel at Margaret Drive in Singapore, securing a top bid of S$238.39 million. This translates to S$997.85 per square foot per plot ratio, with analysts interpreting the aggressive bidding as a positive sign for developers reading the market. The government's decision to release more residential sites in the next GLS programme is also being considered.

site_title: Canadian commercial real estate hits highs
summary: Canada's commercial real estate market reached a record C$11.16 billion in quarterly transaction volumes, driven by investors seeking yield and gains in Alberta's oil-producing region. The market is on track to exceed C$35 billion in 2016, a new Canadian record, as oil prices rise and the industry shows cautious optimism. This represents a 87% increase in transactions compared to the same period in 2015 and a 13% increase from the second quarter of 2016.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: XMH Holdings, an engine maker, reported a net loss of S$88,000 in the second quarter due to weak market sentiment. Oriental Group, a steel trader, faces a potential directorship dispute after four nominees were not written up for election. Olam International priced US$175 million of five-year notes at 3.9% interest. China Environment's subsidiary faces additional civil suits. YuuZoo Corporation introduced an electronic wallet service, YuuWallet.

site_title: Time to review and modify property cooling measures
summary: Singapore's property cooling measures will continue, but a review is needed to make adjustments. Introduced to prevent a speculative bubble and ensure affordability, the measures have largely addressed these concerns. Graduated seller stamp duties and the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) have reduced speculation and overleveraging risks, respectively. The review aims to fine-tune the measures to maintain property affordability while minimizing potential negative impacts on the banking system.

site_title: The future for bunker trading looks even murkier
summary: The OW Bunker case highlights the complexities of bunker trading. A bunker agent, OW Bunker Malta Ltd, supplied fuel to a tanker in Russia, but the case was later tested in the UK Supreme Court. The Shipowners P&I Club has published a summary of the legal implications, which suggests that bunker agents with market knowledge have a place in the supply chain. However, the case may be an argument for dropping bunker agents from the supply chain, citing the convoluted nature of the business and the need for greater transparency.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific's Q2 profit down 57.8%
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited's Q2 profit plummeted 57.8% to US$20.2 million due to the closure of its North Carolina plant and severance expenses. Excluding one-off items, net profit rose 32.9% to US$21 million. Revenue declined 4.6% to US$636.2 million, mainly due to lower sales in the US, but was partially offset by strong performance in the Philippines and Asia. The company aims to improve its US business and strengthen its core business in Asia.

site_title: Italian crisis could be Trump's baptism by fire
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump may face a significant economic challenge with the Italian crisis, as Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's defeat in a constitutional referendum threatens to destabilize the country's banking system and economy. Italy is a large economy with systemic importance, and its financial instability could have a ripple effect on global markets. A weak government and opposition movement could hinder economic reform, making it difficult for Trump's administration to offer adequate support to Italy, especially during key European elections in April and September.

site_title: China transforms frontier neighbours with cash for rails to power
summary: China is investing heavily in its neighboring countries, Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar, transforming them into major destinations for its exports. This is driving the region's fastest economic growth rates and providing Chinese companies with low-cost alternatives. As the US withdraws its commitment, China is seizing the opportunity to expand its influence and sell products at a good return. The investments include railroads, real estate, and other infrastructure projects, as China's own costs increase, making it more expensive for its companies to operate.

site_title: Fed officials in favour of a rise in interest rates
summary: US Federal Reserve officials, including William Dudley, Charles Evans, and James Bullard, favor interest rate increases amid the uncertainty of President-elect Donald Trump's fiscal policies. They expressed close proximity to achieving their dual mandate of full employment and 2% inflation. The pace of monetary tightening remains uncertain.

site_title: Tamil Nadu chief minister dies after prolonged illness
summary: Tamil Nadu's Chief Minister Jayalalithaa, 68, died after a prolonged illness at Apollo Hospital in Chennai, India. Her death has plunged the state into a period of political uncertainty, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi offering condolences. Jayalalithaa's loyalist cabinet aide, O Panneerselvam, was sworn-in as the new Chief Minister. The state is expected to face challenges in ruling smoothly without the charismatic leader, who had a highly polarizing presence and implemented populist schemes that earned her widespread loyalty.

site_title: Paris mega-campus Station F wooing tech startups in London
summary: French billionaire Xavier Niel is seeking tech startups to base themselves in Station F, a 34,000-square-meter mega-campus in downtown Paris, which is set to open in spring 2024. Niel will host an event in London to attract entrepreneurs and businesses, particularly in the UK, amidst Brexit uncertainty. The venue aims to provide a hub for innovation and collaboration, with the goal of becoming a major destination for tech companies.

site_title: Ford sells US$2.8b in auto debt to boost tech spending
summary: Ford Motor Co sold US$2.8 billion in auto debt, including 10-year and 30-year notes, to boost spending on self-driving cars, mobility services, and electrified vehicles. Investors ordered US$8.7 billion, exceeding the initial US$2 billion anticipated. This debt sale allows Ford to reduce interest rates on the bonds and funds its efforts to transform into a mobility company, including investing US$4.5 billion in electrified vehicles and offering bike sharing services.

site_title: Uber drivers in Taiwan face NT$25m in fines
summary: Uber drivers in Taiwan face up to NT$25 million (S$1.1 million) in fines and license suspensions under draft rules proposed by three lawmakers, a move seen as unprecedented for the company. The fines are part of a broader push by the Taiwanese government to regulate ride-hailing services, with the aim of fostering innovation and attracting startups. The move has sparked concerns among Uber officials, who argue that the rules are too restrictive and could harm the company's operations in the country.

site_title: Sleek new generation of recreational vehicles hits the road
summary: A new generation of recreational vehicles, including the Airstream Basecamp, has hit the market, sparking a buying boom in the US with a shift towards young buyers. The industry expects sales to increase by 4.4% next year, with Americans buying around 420,000 homes-on-wheels by the end of the year. New models, smaller and lighter than traditional coaches, have drawn younger customers, with companies like Thor Industries and Winnebago Industries marketing to new demographics. The industry's surge in sales coincides with a strong economy and low unemployment rates.

site_title: Tyson starts US$150m VC fund aimed at meat substitutes
summary: Tyson Foods Inc has launched a $150 million venture capital fund focused on investments in meat substitutes, companies reducing food waste, and technology products related to food and agriculture. This move comes after the company's 5% stake in plant-based protein maker Beyond Meat and amid growing consumer interest in alternative proteins due to concerns over animal welfare and environmental impact. The fund aims to broaden Tyson's exposure to innovative protein sources and ways of producing food, despite potential financial performance implications.

site_title: Don't write off dividend stocks yet
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, but dividend growth stocks may still offer attractive returns due to rising bond yields and a focus on income. Despite structural economic changes, such as aging populations and weak productivity, dividend growth stocks are seen as a fertile field for income seekers. These stocks are less susceptible to rising rates and have a clear return advantage over bonds, with valuations potentially needing to fall 30% over five years to generate negative returns.

site_title: Surging US dollar forcing yen and euro investors to pay more
summary: The US dollar's surge has led to increased costs for investors in the yen and euro to hedge their dollar obligations, forcing them to pay a "Trump premium." The Fed's trade-weighted dollar index rose 3.9% between November 8 and November 29, while cross-currency basis swap spreads widened for all Group of 10 currencies, particularly the yen. Researchers found a strong correlation between dollar strength and deviations from the "covered interest rate parity" condition, indicating a slowdown in cross-border bank capital flows in dollars.

site_title: Despite falling private property prices, market stability is priority
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reaffirmed its stance on maintaining property market cooling measures, citing continued vigilance due to early signs of demand growth and economic uncertainty. Despite a 12-quarter decline in private housing prices, the MAS notes that demand and transaction volumes remain firm, boosted by low interest rates and strong foreign buyer activity, particularly from China. The government prioritizes market stability over easing measures, warning of a premature market rebound if the cooling measures are relaxed too early.

site_title: Twinkle, twinkle, little . . . (insert name here)
summary: Astronomers have long struggled with the lack of standardized names for stars, with some having multiple, often conflicting, designations. The International Astronomical Union (IAU) has now taken steps to address this issue, publishing its first set of approved names for 227 stars. The list, compiled by the IAU's Working Group on Star Names, includes traditional names from various cultures and languages, such as Arabic and Latinized versions of ancient names. The move aims to bring order to the naming of stars and prevent confusion with other celestial bodies.

site_title: S'pore bourse lags SE Asia peers in growth, but fares better in IPOs
summary: Singapore's bourse has lagged behind regional peers in growth, with its total domestic market capitalisation increasing only 2.5% in US dollar terms over the past year, the smallest among major exchanges. However, the local bourse excelled in IPO fundraising, with a total of US$1.66 billion raised this year, outpacing Thailand and Indonesia. Liquidity, measured by share turnover velocity, ranked in the middle among the six exchanges. Market watchers attribute the sluggish growth to flat market performance and low valuation, making it less attractive for companies to list in Singapore.

site_title: New York City to get a new skydeck near Grand Central
summary: New York City is set to gain a new observation deck near Grand Central Terminal with the addition of an indoor-outdoor skydeck at 1 Vanderbilt, a 1,401-foot skyscraper expected to be completed in 2020. The skydeck will be connected to Grand Central and is expected to generate $78 million in revenue, making it a "very high-margin business" for SL Green Realty Corp. The new deck will join existing observation decks at iconic NYC landmarks such as the Empire State Building and One World Trade Center, and is expected to differentiate itself with its unique location and experience.

site_title: Debt revamp: how issuers can better win noteholders' support
summary: Noteholders in Singapore are resisting debt restructuring efforts due to lack of understanding of the instruments they hold. Issuers must educate noteholders on the risks of unsecured notes, which may be subordinated to other debtholders. A significant portion of noteholders are individuals seeking higher-yield returns, but may not fully comprehend the risks. To gain support, issuers must acknowledge the underlying investment objectives and be transparent about the demands of the debt restructuring process, which may require significant haircuts.

site_title: Jobless by choice - or pain?
summary: In the US, about one in eight prime-age male workers (25-54) are dropouts, totaling around seven million, and are not looking for work. This phenomenon has sparked debate, with scholars and politicians attributing it to declining wages, technology, automation, and globalisation. A recent report from the Council of Economic Advisers suggests that lower wages for low-skilled workers are a major cause, with wages for high school graduates falling to 60% of those for college graduates. The issue raises concerns about lower living standards, economic disparities, and social crises, with some arguing that government welfare programs may encourage labour force dropouts.

site_title: Banks dominate in mixed session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6.07 points to 2,949.12 on Tuesday, driven by a continued push on banks, with DBS contributing the most. Despite the index's rise, trading volume remained low, and market sentiment was mixed. Analysts, such as Macquarie Warrants, expect a challenging year for Singapore's property sector and a possible rate hike in the US. DBS's chief investment officer, Lim Say Boon, believes the "Trump Trade" may return after a brief pause, citing US jobs data and OPEC's production cuts.

site_title: Flash Boys writer pens story of brilliant psychologists
summary: Michael Lewis, the author of "Flash Boys," has written a new book, "The Undoing Project: A Friendship That Changed Our Minds," which tells the story of psychologists Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman, who won the Nobel Prize in economics for their groundbreaking work on behavioral economics. Lewis explores how their intellectual romance led to a deeper understanding of human decision-making and how their research challenged the traditional assumption of rational, self-interested optimizers. The book is a biography of the two psychologists, offering insights into their collaboration and the development of their ideas, which have had a significant impact on the field of economics.

site_title: Noble unit sells stakes in four UK power firms
summary: Noble Group, a majority-owned subsidiary, has sold four UK power development companies to Drax Developments Limited for US$23.5 million, with an additional consideration of up to US$91.6 million dependent on UK capacity market auctions. The disposal follows the completion of Noble Americas Energy Solutions disposal to Calpine Energy Services Holdco II. The sale aims to pare debt and fund growth in Noble's high-return businesses.

site_title: Samsung wins over Apple in US$399m patent appeal
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 8-0 that Samsung should not be required to forfeit the entire profits from its smartphones for infringing on design components of Apple's iPhone. The court tossed out a $399 million patent award, sending the case back to a lower court. This decision is a significant win for Samsung, closely watched by the tech industry.

site_title: Missed connections master makes strong contact
summary: Makoto Shinkai's animated film "Your Name" has become Japan's third-highest-grossing movie, surpassing expectations and earning over $243 million. Shinkai, 43, credits his success to exploring themes of human connection, not replacing legendary director Hayao Miyazaki, who inspired him. The film's blend of romance, time travel, and disaster resonates with audiences, including fans who have made pilgrimages to locations believed to have inspired key scenes. Shinkai's work has been praised for its allegorical depiction of human longing, and the film has garnered international attention, including an Annie Award nomination.

site_title: China-led Asia trade pact should wrap up fast, says ADB
summary: China's Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is poised to fill the void left by the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after President-elect Donald Trump vowed not to revive it. The RCEP, which covers 30% of the global economy, is expected to conclude negotiations in 2017, with countries urging nations to wrap up talks next year due to global trade uncertainty. The deal aims to level tariffs, liberalise investment, and introduce dispute-resolution mechanisms, but faces challenges in balancing differing views on trade and investment liberalisation.

site_title: Heavy flooding in Thailand kills 14, inundates tourist isles
summary: Heavy flooding in Thailand has killed 14 people and affected tourist islands, including Samui and Pha Ngan, as a low-pressure system brought heavy rain to the south. The floods have also severed the rail link to Malaysia and caused drainage problems, forcing tourists to avoid swimming. The country is experiencing its December-January high season for tourism, which could be impacted by the disaster. Authorities say the country is open for business despite a year of mourning following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

site_title: Delta, United and Copa offer to partner troubled Avianca airline
summary: Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, and Copa Airlines have submitted bids to partner with struggling Avianca airline. The hedge fund Elliott Management, which holds a stake in Avianca as collateral, is helping to broker the deal. The bids include a US$500 million loan from United, a potential merger from Copa valued at over US$2 billion, and a US$1 billion cash offer from Delta, which would value Avianca at US$1.9 billion. A special committee of Avianca's board is set to meet to decide on the offers, with Elliott's involvement potentially leading to one of the largest deals in the airline industry this year.

site_title: Euro steady; A$ dips as interest rates stay intact
summary: The euro remained steady near a 3-week high, while the Australian dollar dipped slightly after the Reserve Bank kept interest rates on hold. The euro had previously bounced 1.5% after the Italian constitutional referendum, and bets on market volatility remained high ahead of the European Central Bank meeting. Other major currency pairs traded in a tight range, while oil rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and tariffs.

site_title: McDonald's revamps McCafe brand as it lags Starbucks
summary: McDonald's is revamping its McCafe brand in an effort to challenge Starbucks and Dunkin' Donuts. The company plans to reintroduce the McCafe concept next year, about eight years after its debut, with upgraded java and sustainable sourcing. This move aims to improve the brand's performance, which has been lagging behind its competitors.

site_title: McDonald's to keep up to 25% stake in China, HK stores: source
summary: McDonald's plans to sell up to 25% stake in its China and Hong Kong stores to a consortium led by Carlyle Group LP and Citic Group Corp, raising $1-2 billion. The sale comes as the company reorganizes operations in the region and switches to a less capital-intensive franchise model. McDonald's aims to maintain a stake in the business to tap into future growth in China, the world's second-largest economy. The sale is part of the company's efforts to recover from food-supply scandals in China affecting other fast-food operators like Yum Brands Inc.

site_title: Amazon testing system that will make checkout lines obsolete
summary: Amazon is testing a new system in its Seattle concept store, Amazon Go, which will eliminate checkout lines by allowing customers to grab groceries without scanning and paying. The system uses a mobile app and tracks items picked up or returned to shelves, charging customers automatically upon exit. The technology aims to reduce wait times and provide a seamless shopping experience, potentially paving the way for similar stores in cities across the US.

site_title: Cash-rich Chinese opt for Seattle, Toronto homes after Vancouver slaps 15% housing tax
summary: Wealthy Chinese buyers are shifting their investment focus from Vancouver to Seattle and Toronto after the Canadian city imposed a 15% tax on foreign property investors. Since the tax was announced, there has been a surge in demand for high-end properties in both cities, with Chinese buyers driving up prices. Seattle's median home value is significantly lower than Vancouver's, making it an attractive option for Chinese investors. The influx of foreign capital is expected to continue, with Toronto also experiencing robust demand for luxury properties.

site_title: Goldman, Citigroup targeted by diversity activists in 2017
summary: US financial institutions Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Bank of America, and Wells Fargo are being targeted by activist investors for their lack of diversity. Arjuna Capital, Trillium Asset Management, and Pax World Management are pushing for the disclosure of compensation data for men and women, and statistics about the race and gender of employees. The investors claim a diverse workforce produces better results and have previously succeeded in pushing technology companies to divulge information about pay gaps. Despite opposition from President-elect Donald Trump, companies are expected to continue efforts at diversity as research shows that diverse groups make better decisions and get better returns.

site_title: Singapore tops latest Pisa education survey
summary: Singapore topped the latest OECD Pisa education survey, followed by Japan, Estonia, Finland, and Canada, with 15-year-olds scoring the highest in science, reading, and mathematics. The survey, covering 540,000 students across 72 countries, found that students' knowledge in science was stable over the past decade, but many students struggled to achieve the baseline level of proficiency. The OECD Secretary General noted that science education is not keeping up with the rapid pace of scientific progress, and that spending per student had little impact on students' scores.

site_title: Obama to deliver speech defending his counterterrorism fight
summary: President Barack Obama will deliver his final major speech on national security on Tuesday, defending his counterterrorism policies and arguing they have helped protect Americans from evolving international threats. Obama will claim his administration has successfully built coalitions and taken out militant leaders without overextending the US military. However, some experts have criticized his approach, citing the rise of the Islamic State, and Republican President-elect Donald Trump has blamed him and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton for the group's spread. Obama will also address his decision not to use waterboarding.

site_title: Trump says Boeing's Air Force One order should be cancelled
summary: President-elect Donald Trump suggested canceling Boeing's Air Force One order due to high costs, stating "Boeing is building a brand new 747 Air Force One for future presidents, but costs are out of control, more than $4 billion." The Pentagon plans to replace its aging fleet of 747-200 aircraft, with the new planes expected to begin operations in 2023. The move is expected to impact Boeing's stock price, which fell 0.7% before trading resumed.

site_title: Google will be powered completely by clean energy next year
summary: Google aims to power its entire operations with clean energy by 2018, with a goal to meet or exceed all of its consumption at its offices and 13 data centers. The company has already signed contracts for 2.6 gigawatts of capacity from 20 wind and solar farms worldwide, requiring a $3.5 billion investment. Google's efforts are part of the global fight against climate change, with 83 major companies worldwide pledging to power their operations with renewable energy. This move is seen as a significant step by businesses in driving clean power adoption.

site_title: BMW to pay A$77m for irresponsible lending in Australia
summary: BMW will pay A$77 million to compensate Australian customers who received loans they couldn't afford between 2011 and 2016. The payment covers at least 15,000 customers and includes A$50 million for loan write-offs, smaller sums for compensation and interest rate reductions, and initiatives to improve financial literacy. The Australian Securities & Investment Commission (Asic) found that BMW Australia Finance Limited had a sales-driven culture that failed to comply with credit laws, resulting in poor outcomes for consumers. BMW has confirmed its agreement with Asic.

site_title: ICAP glitch adds to yuan investor jitters
summary: Yuan investors experienced jitters after ICAP Plc data showed the currency sinking to 7.5 yuan per US dollar, an error that caused a stir on Twitter. The actual official exchange rate rose 0.1% to 6.8770 yuan per dollar, while the yuan traded in Hong Kong's overseas market fell 0.3%. The yuan has weakened 3% against the greenback this quarter amid increased pressure from US President-elect Donald Trump's focus on China's currency policy.

site_title: US: Dow edges down from record on oil weakness
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average retreated slightly from its record close on Tuesday, down less than 0.1% to 19,213.57, due to weakness in oil prices. ExxonMobil and Chevron lost 0.7% and 0.8% respectively, as the rally in oil prices after last week's Opec meeting showed signs of fatigue. The US trade deficit grew 18% in October to $42.6 billion, in line with analyst expectations.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grab launches GrabShare, a paid car-pooling service, to compete with Uber. Swiber directors are released on bail after questioning by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department. Noble Group sells stakes in UK power firms for at least $23.5 million. Oxley Holdings invests $32 million for a 40% stake in an Australian developer. MCL Land tops bids for a residential land parcel with a $238.39 million offer. SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong receives the Dwight D. Eisenhower Global Innovation Award.

site_title: US productivity in third quarter fastest in two years
summary: US worker productivity rebounded sharply in the third quarter, rising at a 3.1% annual rate, its quickest pace of growth in two years. Productivity increased by 3.6% in output per worker, the fastest pace since 2014. However, the trend remained weak due to a 0.5% increase in total hours worked. Unit labour costs rose at a 0.7% pace, while hourly compensation increased at a 3.8% rate. This marks a reversal from the previous three quarters of decline.

site_title: EU-Nato cooperation best way to preserve US ties: Stoltenberg
summary: NATO head Jens Stoltenberg stated that strengthening EU-NATO cooperation is the best way to address concerns over the future of transatlantic security ties amid doubts raised by US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on Nato's defense spending. Stoltenberg emphasized that the cooperation will be pragmatic and complementary to NATO, not duplicating its activities. The two-day talks in Brussels aimed to address hybrid threats and cyber attacks, with a focus on increased information sharing and coordinated exercises. Stoltenberg expressed confidence in the US commitment to NATO and European security.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai: no major policy shifts, despite Trump call
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen stated that she doesn't anticipate significant policy shifts despite her call with US President-elect Donald Trump, which China considered a provocation. The call was the first with a US president-elect or president since 1979, when Jimmy Carter switched diplomatic recognition to China. Tsai played down the significance, citing the importance of regional stability, and expressed respect for Trump's election victory. The US reaffirmed its commitment to the "One China" policy, which China considers Taiwan a renegade province.

site_title: EU clears with conditions Microsoft's US$26b buy of LinkedIn
summary: Microsoft's US$26 billion acquisition of LinkedIn has been cleared by the European Union after the company agreed to allow rivals to operate with its products. Microsoft will permit computer makers to choose not to install LinkedIn on Windows and users to remove it. The concessions were made to preserve competition in Europe, with the European Commission approving the deal. The approval was previously flagged by Reuters on November 23.

site_title: Japan PM to meet US Trump around Jan 27
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to meet US President-elect Donald Trump around January 27, about a week after Trump's inauguration. The meeting comes after Trump's election victory, where Abe was the first foreign leader to meet him. The US-Japan military alliance is a key aspect of Japan's defense and foreign policy, and the meeting may address concerns about Trump's commitment to it. The meeting also raises questions about the potential impact of Trump's protectionist policies on Japan's export-dependent economy.

site_title: Airbus posts 600 orders, delivers 577 jets in Jan-Nov
summary: Airbus sold 600 aircraft in the first 11 months of 2016, including 577 delivered, with a focus on the A350 and A320neo models. The company aims to sell at least as many aircraft as it delivers this year, with a target of 670 total deliveries. In contrast, Boeing booked orders for 558 aircraft, or 466 after cancellations, and maintained its lead over Airbus in October. Airbus aims to step up deliveries in the final two months of the year to meet its target.

site_title: Daimler may make electric cars in China to boost sales
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, is considering local production of electric cars and batteries in China to boost sales. The company aims to increase its presence in the world's largest car market, where sales have grown 28% this year. Building a battery factory in China is an option, and Mercedes plans to have over 10 all-electric vehicles in its portfolio by 2025. Chinese authorities are encouraging production of zero-emission cars with incentives such as trading credits and a 10% tax on luxury cars.

site_title: South Korea expands cull to contain bird flu
summary: South Korea has expanded a cull of chickens and ducks to contain a bird flu outbreak caused by the H5N6 virus. The agriculture ministry has culled over 6.1 million birds, with 28 confirmed cases reported nationwide. Health authorities have also issued a "standstill" order to restrict workers at poultry farms from moving around the country. The World Health Organization has warned of severe infection in humans, but no ongoing human-to-human transmission has been reported, with no human cases in South Korea.

site_title: US trade deficit widens on drop in exports
summary: The US trade deficit widened 17.8% to $42.6 billion in October, driven by a 1.8% decline in exports to $186.4 billion. Exports fell due to declining shipments of soybeans, food, industrial supplies, and automobiles. Imports rose 1.3% to $229.0 billion, with petroleum goods imports reaching their highest level in a year. Despite the trade deficit, consumer spending and a firming housing market are expected to support the economy, while rising gas and oil drilling are also expected to boost growth.

site_title: Saudi Arabia switches Opec tack with eye on world's top IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia has reversed its "pump-at-will" strategy in the oil market, agreeing to cut production by 4.7% as part of an Opec deal to stabilize prices. The move aims to plug budget holes and pave the way for the privatization of state-owned oil company Saudi Aramco. Oil prices have jumped 18% to around $55 a barrel, and analysts expect prices to stay above $50 a barrel next year. The deal is seen as a step towards Saudi Arabia's goal of weaning its economy off oil, but also carries risks if prices fall or non-Opec oil floods the market.

site_title: Trump victory pushes up spot trading on Thomson Reuters FX platforms
summary: Thomson Reuters' FX platforms saw a surge in spot trading volumes in November, reaching a five-month high, driven by big moves in foreign exchange markets following Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. Average daily spot trading volumes jumped to US$101 billion, up 8% from October and 14% from the same month last year. This increase is attributed to heightened market volatility following the election result.

site_title: Lego CEO step downs in historic shift at billionaire-owned Firm
summary: Lego CEO Jorgen Vig Knudstorp is stepping down as CEO and will become chairman of the company, replacing Bali Padda, who will take over as CEO at the end of the year. Knudstorp led the company's transformation from a declining toy maker to the world's most profitable, increasing revenue five-fold from 2005 to 2015. He will oversee a new entity, the Lego Brand Group, focusing on the brand's long-term potential. The move marks a historic shift at the billionaire-owned firm, with Padda becoming the first non-Dane to run the 84-year-old company.

site_title: EU finance ministers back larger investment plan to spur growth
summary: European Union finance ministers agreed to support an expanded investment plan, doubling its financial capacity and duration to at least 500 billion euros by 2020. The plan aims to attract 500 billion euros in private investments, with 33.5 billion euros in EU cash and guarantees. The European Commission-led initiative, European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), aims to counter economic stagnation. Despite the agreement, EU finance ministers did not commit to national funds, leaving the plan's implementation uncertain until approval by the European Parliament.

site_title: Bernard Cazeneuve named French PM after Valls quits: official
summary: French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve was appointed as the new prime minister on Tuesday after Manuel Valls resigned to seek the Socialist presidential nomination. Cazeneuve will lead the government until legislative elections in June. Valls had been prime minister for two and a half years and announced his resignation to rally the fractured French left ahead of a primary in January.

site_title: US tech giants get EU rebuke in fight over online hate speech
summary: The European Union has rebuked US tech giants Facebook, Twitter, Google, and Microsoft for failing to meet their pledge to tackle online hate speech within 24 hours. Only 40% of reported hate speech notifications are reviewed within the timeframe, according to the European Commission. The EU Justice Commissioner, Vera Jourova, criticized the companies for not taking responsibility in combating online radicalization and hate speech. The EU has called on the companies to live up to their role in addressing these issues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.760 points to 1629.730. The index saw a trading volume of 1.089 billion lots worth RM1.553 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 409 to 304.

site_title: Swiber directors out on bail as CAD probes alleged breach of disclosure law
summary: Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has taken current and former directors of Swiber Holdings for questioning regarding alleged breaches of disclosure law under Section 199 of the Securities and Futures Act. The directors, including Raymond Kim Goh and Yeo Jeu Nam, were released on bail. Investigations are ongoing, with no formal charges filed against the individuals. Swiber Holdings is under judicial management, and the company is cooperating with the CAD's investigation.

site_title: Russia says Opec, non-Opec countries to discuss oil cuts
summary: Russia's energy ministry announced that Opec and non-Opec countries will meet in Vienna on Saturday to discuss oil production cuts. The meeting follows Russia's decision to reduce crude output by 300,000 barrels a day in the first half of 2017. The move comes after Opec members agreed to cut oil output for the first time in eight years, leading to a 16-month high in oil prices. However, prices have since dipped as doubts over the deal's implementation remain, with US shale oil producers gearing up to raise production.

site_title: British PM joins Gulf summit for post-Brexit trade talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May attends a Gulf Arab leaders summit in Bahrain, focusing on post-Brexit trade talks and defense ties. May is the first British premier and first woman to attend the summit, meeting with six GCC states to discuss free trade arrangements and cooperation on security and defense. Human rights concerns, particularly in Bahrain, were urged by advocacy groups, but May did not explicitly address them. The talks aim to develop a new trade relationship and transform British business practices.

site_title: 21,000 Rohingya flee to Bangladesh from Myanmar: IOM
summary: More than 21,000 Rohingya have fled to Bangladesh in the past two months to escape violence in Myanmar's Rakhine state, with the vast majority taking refuge in makeshift settlements and official refugee camps. Humanitarian officials and satellite images show widespread destruction of Rohingya villages and allegations of gang-rape, torture, and murder by Myanmar's security forces. The international community has condemned the violence, with Aung San Suu Kyi facing a growing backlash for her government's handling of the crisis. Bangladesh has reinforced its border posts and deployed coastguard ships to prevent further influxes of refugees.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly flatline at open
summary: European stocks remained flat at the start of trade on Tuesday, following the outcome of an Italian referendum that sent shockwaves through world markets. The FTSE 100 index was flat at 6,743.88 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices were unchanged. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi resigned, but his departure will be delayed until the 2017 budget is passed, expected by the end of the week. The market reaction is considered minimal, with analysts noting that Renzi will eventually leave office, but the timing is uncertain.

site_title: MCL Land's S$238.4m bid emerged top among 14 bids for Margaret Drive site
summary: MCL Land has emerged as the top bidder for the Margaret Drive site with a bid price of S$238.39 million, surpassing Allgreen Properties' S$220.9 million bid. The 99-year leasehold site can accommodate 275 homes and translates to S$997.85 per square foot per plot ratio. The top bid is about 8% higher than the second-highest bid.

site_title: Korea corporate chiefs deny seeking favours for donations
summary: South Korean corporate chiefs, including Samsung leader Jay Y Lee, denied seeking favors when they made donations to foundations at the center of a scandal that could bring down President Park Geun-hye. The donations, totaling 20.4 billion won, were made in support of initiatives backed by Park, but she did not specifically request money. The conglomerates, which control over half of South Korea's economy, acknowledged that it was difficult to decline government requests. Park faces an impeachment vote on Friday, which could lead to her early departure from office.

site_title: UK unveils rail reform for 'best possible' customer experience
summary: The UK government has unveiled plans to reform the rail industry, aiming for the "best possible" customer experience. Rail operators in England will be required to manage both train services and track infrastructure, with the East West Rail link between Oxford and Cambridge being the first new integrated rail operation in decades. The Transport Secretary, Chris Grayling, believes this change will improve the passenger experience and address the current fragmented system. Private sector involvement will be secured for the East West Rail group to design, build, and operate the route, with the goal of creating a more efficient and effective rail network.

site_title: Singapore shares close broadly mixed; banks push STI up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6.07 points to 2,949.12, driven by a push from banks. The STI ended mixed despite a new all-time high on Wall Street and a broad advance-decline score of 218-209. Trading volume was low at 1.75 billion units worth S$1.1 billion, with banks accounting for 27% of the market's dollar business, led by DBS's S$157.5 million in trades.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rebound from Italy sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares rebounded on Tuesday, climbing 0.75% to a close of 22,675.15, following a sell-off the previous day due to Italy's economic concerns. The Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.16%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.16%. The rebound comes as US stocks closed at record highs, with the Dow tracking the previous day's gains.

site_title: For London's food and wine businesses, Brexit has a bitter taste
summary: London's food and wine businesses, which rely heavily on the free movement of goods and workers within the European Union, are facing significant challenges due to Brexit. Many firms, such as Brindisa and Barton Brownsdon & Sadler, have had to increase prices and face uncertainty about future trade barriers. The industry is particularly concerned about restrictions on immigration, which could lead to a shortage of cheap foreign labor. With over half of London's food and drinks trade estimated to be staffed by foreign workers, the impact of Brexit on the sector is expected to be severe.

site_title: Euro steady near 3-week high, big bets on market volatility
summary: The euro held steady near a three-week high against the US dollar, driven by data showing the biggest rise in German industrial orders in over two years, and bets on market volatility remained high ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting to give new guidance on its quantitative easing program. The euro rose 0.1% against the US dollar, while the Australian dollar dipped 0.25% after the Reserve Bank kept interest rates on hold. The ECB's news conference on Thursday is expected to provide clarity on the quantitative easing program, which may lead to a euro positive if the bank announces a reduction or tapering of the program.

site_title: South Korea's Park agrees to resign in April: Yonhap TV
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye agreed to resign in April due to an influence-peddling scandal, following opposition lawmakers' threat to impeach her. A faction of her party, with 29 lawmakers, will support the impeachment motion regardless of her resignation. If impeached, Park will be suspended from power until the constitutional court's decision. Her resignation paves the way for a presidential election in 60 days. The opposition has enough votes to pass the impeachment motion, making Park's resignation potentially too late to halt momentum.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises as strong US data calms Italian fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei share average rose 0.5% to 18,360.54 on Tuesday, following strong US economic data that calmed Italian fears of EU instability after Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's resignation. The Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gained 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: Japan's market watchdog recommends fine for Morgan Stanley MUFG
summary: Japan's market watchdog, the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission, recommended fining Morgan Stanley MUFG Securities Co Ltd 220 million yen (S$2.7 million) for alleged market manipulation related to Seibu Holdings Inc. shares. The recommendation was made to the Financial Services Agency.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific's Q2 profit down 57.8% to US$20.2m on one-off expenses
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited reported a net profit of US$20.2 million for the second quarter, down 57.8% due to one-off expenses related to the closure of a North Carolina plant and severance. Excluding the one-off item, net profit rose 32.9% year-over-year to US$21 million. Revenue fell 4.6% to US$636.2 million, driven by lower sales in the US but strong performance in the Philippines and rest of Asia.

site_title: Toyota to expand hybrid system development to further cut emissions
summary: Toyota plans to expand its hybrid system development to reduce emissions, aiming to introduce 19 new lower-emission powertrain components by 2021. The company aims to increase hybrid vehicle sales to 20% of global annual vehicle sales by 2025. Toyota plans to expand its hybrid technology development team by 30% and will reduce global average CO2 emissions from new vehicles by 90% by 2050. The move is in response to stricter emissions standards in regions such as China and the US, and will involve the development of longer-range battery-electric cars.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise on strong US economic data, RBA easing hopes
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose on Tuesday, driven by strong US economic data and easing hopes for an interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.5% and the NZX 50 index rose 0.8%. Financials, materials, and healthcare stocks led the gains. The RBA kept its cash rate unchanged but sounded caution on economic growth. US services sector activity hit a one-year high, boosting Wall Street overnight.

site_title: Tata-Mistry letter wars escalate as group shareholder votes near
summary: Cyrus Mistry, ousted chairman of Tata Group, accused major shareholders of eroding governance and portrayed himself as a defender of independent decision-making in a letter to investors. He accused Ratan Tata and other trustees of overstepping their roles and attempting to control decision-making. The conglomerate refuted his allegations, charging Mistry with concentrating power and diminishing the role of the board. A series of extraordinary general meetings will be held from Dec 13-26 to remove Mistry as a director from six companies, including Tata Power and Tata Motors.

site_title: South Korea expands poultry cull to fight bird flu
summary: South Korea plans to cull around 8% of its poultry population, approximately 4.4 million birds, due to an outbreak of bird flu. The H5N6 strain has been confirmed in 28 cases since mid-November, with another 10 possible cases being investigated. If the virus spreads, the government may issue a 'standstill order' to prevent workers from the poultry industry from moving around the country. Chicken prices are expected to fall as consumer worries grow, but supplies of chicken, eggs, and duck meat remain unaffected.

site_title: China fund manager, arrested after market crash, admits to manipulation
summary: A Chinese hedge fund manager, Xu Xiang, pleaded guilty to market manipulation in a Shanghai court. Xu, known as "Hedge Fund Brother No 1" and "China's Carl Icahn", was detained in 2015 and is part of a trial involving two others. The court accepted their guilty pleas and the men asked for leniency in sentencing. Xu's actions are linked to the 2015 stock market crash in China, which was a major financial crisis at the time. The trial's outcome is seen as a significant step in holding those responsible accountable for the market manipulation.

site_title: SoftBank's Son said to plan meeting with Trump in New York
summary: SoftBank's founder and CEO Masayoshi Son is planning to meet with President-elect Donald Trump in New York, seeking to discuss potential investments in the US, including wireless operator Sprint Corp. Son is raising a $100 billion investment fund and wants to put some of the money into the US, where he has had a mixed record. A meeting with Trump could lead to a reevaluation of US telecom regulations, potentially benefiting Sprint.

site_title: China-championed Asia trade pact should wrap up fast, ADB says
summary: China is pushing to conclude its Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade pact, which includes 16 countries and covers 30% of the global economy, as the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal appears to be dead due to President-elect Donald Trump's protectionist stance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) suggests the RCEP should be concluded expeditiously to fill the trade vacuum, with expectations of completion in 2017. The pact aims to liberalize trade and investment, but some countries have differing views on its scope and coverage.

images.alt_text: The death knell sounding for a US-led Pacific trade pact creates a vacuum that a separate Asia deal being championed by China should quickly fill, according to the Asian Development Bank.

site_title: Thai king appoints new members to royal council
summary: Thailand's new King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, 64, appointed three new members to his royal advisory council and removed some former members in his first acts as king. This move reinforces expectations of institutional stability in financial markets. The king, also known as King Rama X, succeeded his father, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died on October 13 at the age of 88 after a 7-decade reign.

site_title: China iron ore, steel extend gains to 4th day on demand hopes
summary: China's steel and iron ore futures rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by hopes of increased construction activity to meet housing and property demand. Despite a 27% increase in property sales, construction activity has only grown by 3%, leading to low inventories. This has led to higher prices, with iron ore rising 3.4% and steel rebar up 2.2%. Speculative investors remain in the market, causing volatility, but further gains could push spot prices back to near $80 a tonne.

site_title: French PM Valls quits to enter presidential race
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls is resigning to run for the Socialist presidential nomination in next year's election, aiming to unite the fractured left ahead of a primary in January. Valls, a divisive figure, vows to take on the conservative opposition and far-right National Front, warning of Marine Le Pen's potential electoral upset. He faces competition from other candidates, including Emmanuel Macron and Jean-Luc Melenchon, and a challenging task to unite the divided French left.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls is set to resign on Tuesday to free himself to do battle for the Socialist nomination in next year's presidential election.

site_title: Japan's lower house passes long-awaited casino bill
summary: Japan's lower house of parliament passed a bill to legalize casinos, a move seen as a potential global gaming powerhouse. The bill, which was delayed due to concerns over gambling addiction and organized crime, is expected to pass the upper house and be sent to the prime minister for signature. The move aims to boost tourism and the economy, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe betting that casinos can bring billions of dollars in investment. Possible locations for major resorts include Osaka, Tokyo, and Yokohama.

site_title: Britain opens supplementary oil and gas licensing round
summary: Britain's Oil & Gas Authority has announced a supplementary licensing round for offshore oil and gas exploration in the UK Continental Shelf. The round offers 14 blocks across the Southern North Sea to East of Shetland, with applications opening on Tuesday and closing on March 7, 2017. The move aims to stimulate exploration in the North Sea, which is expected to yield billions of barrels of oil worth around 200 billion pounds. The UKCS has both frontier and mature basins, and the round is part of the OGA's approach to facilitate exploration across the entire shelf.

site_title: Grab introduces GrabShare, sharing paid car-pooling market with Uber
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing platform, has launched GrabShare, a car-pooling service that pairs two passengers with similar trip routes. Available from Tuesday, GrabShare aims to reduce travel time and fares by up to 30% compared to GrabCar Economy fares. The service uses Grab's matching algorithm to optimize routes and maximize driver earnings. This move puts Grab in the same car-pooling market as UberPool, with GrabShare fares fixed and displayed upfront, and drivers able to reduce time and distance spent on a single ride.

site_title: Heavy flooding in Thailand kills 14, inundates tourist isles
summary: Heavy flooding in southern Thailand has killed 14 people and severely affected tourist islands, including Samui and Pha Ngan, as the country heads into its December-January high season for tourism. The floods, caused by a low-pressure system, have also severed the rail link to Malaysia. Despite the mourning period for the late king, authorities are optimistic about the tourism outlook, expecting a record 32.4 million arrivals this year. The flooding is a rare disruption to the country's struggling economy, which has been impacted since the army seized power in 2014.

site_title: Global prescription drug spend seen at US$1.5t in 2021
summary: Global prescription drug spending is projected to reach nearly US$1.5 trillion by 2021, with the US accounting for up to US$675 billion. Estimated spending in 2016 was US$370 billion. Net spending will be closer to US$1 trillion when discounts and rebates are accounted for.

site_title: Face-recognition startup Megvii said to raise US$100m
summary: Megvii Inc, a Chinese facial-recognition technology developer, has raised at least $100 million from investors including Foxconn Technology Group and CCB International Holdings Ltd. The company plans to improve facial recognition technology, especially in the financial industry, smart cities, and robotics. Megvii provides face-scanning systems to Ant Financial and is working on a system allowing users to set up bank accounts online through facial scans. The funding will be used to enhance facial recognition technology without compromising user privacy.

site_title: Australia's Origin Energy to spin off some assets in IPO, cut debt
summary: Australia's energy retailer Origin Energy Ltd plans to spin off oil and gas assets in an IPO, expected to fetch A$1 billion, and cut debt. The move, led by new CEO Frank Calabria, aims to refocus on retail gas and power businesses. This is part of a strategy to reduce debt, following AGL Energy's decision to exit coal-seam gas and coal-fired power stations. The IPO is set to be Australia's biggest since 2014, and will not require shareholder approval.

site_title: Security boosted on LA transit stations following threat
summary: Security measures were increased at Los Angeles metro stations following a threat from an anonymous overseas caller who claimed an explosive device would detonate at Universal City station on Tuesday. The threat, deemed "very specific" and imminent, prompted the FBI to alert authorities and deploy undercover deputies and uniformed officers. Los Angeles officials, including the mayor, reassured commuters that heightened security is in place for their protection, with Mayor Eric Garcetti planning to ride the metro to alleviate fears. The Universal City station is one of the busiest in the network.

site_title: Samsung's Lee in crosshairs as tycoons grilled over scandal
