Singapore's stock index is set to post its biggest increase in Asia this week, driven by its longest winning streak in two years, but may be short-lived due to economic headwinds. Meanwhile, Swissco Holdings has been authorized to pay wages to its crew and service assets, and commodity trader Noble Group has completed the disposal of its US energy unit for US$800m.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed a penalty of S$5.2 million on the Singapore branches of Standard Chartered Bank (SCB) and of S$2.4 million on Coutts, for breaches of MAS's anti-money laundering (AML) requirements by the two banks.

site_title: ARA Trust Management announces new CEO
summary: ARA Trust Management has announced the appointment of Chan Kong Leong as its new CEO, effective January 1, 2026. Chan will also serve as executive director, replacing retiring CEO Yeo See Kiat, who led the company to grow its assets under management from S$2.2 billion to S$9.3 billion. Under Kiat's leadership, Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Suntec Reit) executed several large acquisitions and expanded into Australia. Chan previously worked at the CapitaLand Group, holding senior management positions.

site_title: UK says it will not block EU common defence policy
summary: Britain will not block the European Union's efforts to create a common defence policy, according to Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson. This decision comes as the UK negotiates its exit from the EU. Johnson stated that if the EU wishes to pursue this policy, the UK will not intervene or block further steps towards EU integration. This change in stance contrasts with Defence Minister Michael Fallon's previous comments, which suggested that an EU army would undermine the NATO military alliance. The UK's decision may impact its relations with the EU and NATO.

site_title: China seizes opening in US backyard after Trump upends policy
summary: China is rapidly strengthening its ties with Latin America, capitalizing on US President-elect Donald Trump's "America First" platform. Chinese President Xi Jinping has signed over 40 deals with Latin American countries, including energy and infrastructure agreements, and upgraded diplomatic relations with Ecuador and Chile. China's trade with the region has grown 20-fold in a decade, and it aims to reach $500 billion in trade within a decade. This shift in focus comes as Trump vows to withdraw from trade pacts and crack down on immigration from Latin America.

site_title: German car sales headed for highest growth in six years
summary: German car sales are expected to experience the highest growth in six years in 2016, with 11-month registrations up 5% to 3.09 million vehicles. The country's auto industry association, VDA, predicts a 5% increase in annual sales to almost 3.4 million autos, the highest level since the start of the decade. Favorable financing conditions and good economic development are cited as contributing factors, with VDA expecting no weakening in 2017 registrations.

images.alt_text: German car sales are headed for the highest growth in about six years in 2016, the country's auto industry association said on Friday, after registrations kept growing in November.

site_title: Swissco IJMs to pay wages to crew of vessels, service asset
summary: Swissco Holdings and its subsidiary Swissco Offshore (SOPL) have been authorized by a court to pay wages to crew members of certain vessels and service assets employed by SOPL. The interim judicial managers (IJMs) made this decision to ensure the vessels and assets continue to generate revenue and preserve their value. The order was sought and obtained on December 1, 2016. The IJMs will update the court on January 5, 2017, on the progress of seeking judicial management.

site_title: French leftwing field wide open after Hollande bows out
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced his decision not to seek a second term, opening the left-wing field for his Prime Minister Manuel Valls to run in next year's election. With historically low approval ratings, Hollande cited his failure to rally the Socialist Party and keep unemployment promises. Polls suggest no left-wing candidate will reach the second round, with right-wing candidate Francois Fillon leading the Republican Party. Fillon's chances are bolstered by the far-right National Front's Marine Le Pen, who has gained popularity in recent years.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande's dramatic announcement that he will not seek a second term opens the way for his prime minister Manuel Valls to make a bid for power in next year's increasingly open election.

site_title: Chaos at protest over Taiwan holiday cuts
summary: Protesters in Taiwan clashed with police outside the parliament building on Friday over a proposed cut to public holidays, which would see seven annual holidays scrapped. Workers, who would be guaranteed one mandatory day off and an additional "rest day" under the revised law, accused President Tsai Ing Wen of betraying her campaign promises to protect labor rights. The protests, which have been ongoing since May, have seen a significant drop in Tsai's popularity, with recent polling showing her at a record low of 41.1%. The Democratic Progressive Party condemned the violence and called for an investigation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall; investors brace for US jobs data
summary: South Korean shares and the won fell on Friday due to losses on Wall Street and Europe, with investors waiting for key US jobs data and an Italian constitutional referendum. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 0.7% at 1,970.61 points, with foreigners selling shares. The South Korean won was quoted at 1,172.6 to the US dollar, down 0.4% from the previous day.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week lower, following a sell-off across the region, as traders stepped back after recent gains. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.37%, closing at 22,564.82, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.90% to 3,243.84. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.66%. The losses were attributed to a sell-off in banks and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Japan regulators working on new rules to prevent leaks by company execs
summary: Japan's regulators are set to recommend new fair disclosure rules to prevent company executives leaking insider information, part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push for improved corporate governance and foreign investment. The move aims to clarify what constitutes material and insider information, following recent scandals involving Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse. The rules will not impose criminal penalties, instead taking a "soft" approach to enforcement, and are expected to be submitted to parliament next year.

site_title: Oil softens after Opec decision prompts big weekly rally
summary: Oil prices fell 1.5% to steady at around $53 a barrel after the biggest weekly rally since 2009 following Opec's decision to cut crude output by 1.2 million barrels per day. The deal, which includes Russia's agreement to cut output by 300,000 bpd, aims to rein in a global glut. However, analysts caution that oversupply remains a possibility, and the impact of the deal is still uncertain, with prices potentially falling back to pre-Opec levels.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell 1.5 per cent to steady at around US$53 a barrel on Friday after the biggest weekly rally since 2009 following Opec's decision this week to cut crude output in order to rein in a global glut.

site_title: Nam Cheong client cancels vessel contract; legal action being considered
summary: Nam Cheong, a vessel builder, has received a cancellation notice from Petra Offshore Limited regarding the sale of an Accommodation Work Barge. Despite completing the vessel according to the contract, Nam Cheong claims POL is in breach of the terms. The company is considering legal action and notes the cancellation will impact earnings for the current financial year, although the extent is still undetermined.

site_title: Europe: Stocks cede ground at open
summary: European stocks declined at the start of trade on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.8%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.9%, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.7%, amid investor uncertainty ahead of US jobs data and a weekend Italian referendum on constitutional reform. Asian stocks also fell, and oil prices retreated as investors took a step back from a recent rally. The US November jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans, is set to be released later.

site_title: British fighters to overfly South China Sea; carriers in Pacific after 2020: envoy
summary: British fighter planes visiting Japan will fly over the South China Sea to assert international overflight rights. Britain's ambassador to the US, Kim Darroch, stated that once the country's two new aircraft carriers become operational in 2020, they will be deployed in the Pacific. This move aims to address concerns about freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.

site_title: Shenzhen-HK stock link lets foreigners access China's booming tech firms
summary: A link between China's Shenzhen stock market and Hong Kong has opened, allowing foreign investors to access the country's booming tech firms for the first time. The Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connect scheme was approved two years ago, but delays have held up the Shenzhen opening. Analysts expect a subdued start, citing lower disclosure levels and smaller-cap technology companies in Shenzhen. Foreign investors can access 881 Shenzhen stocks and 417 Hong Kong counters, with daily limits of 13 billion yuan and 10.5 billion yuan. Despite Shenzhen's advantages, investors may initially favor Hong Kong due to China's weak currency.

site_title: Prince Harry, Rihanna take HIV tests on World Aids Day
summary: Prince Harry and Rihanna took HIV tests on World AIDS Day, December 1, 2016, in Barbados to raise awareness about the fight against HIV/AIDS. They participated in a campaign that included finger prick tests at a clinic in Bridgetown. Prince Harry emphasized that early detection and treatment can lead to a normal life with loved ones. This event joined other global events to promote awareness and education about HIV/AIDS.

site_title: Singapore shares finish Friday mixed but STI gains 2.1% over the week
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 1.1% for 2016, driven by a rebound in oil prices and the Dow Jones Industrial Average's push to new highs. However, the index fell 9.21 points on Friday, cutting its weekly gain to 2.1%. Turnover declined from a 2016 high on Wednesday to $1.2 billion on Friday. Despite the index's fall, the advance-decline score was 202-223, indicating that the weakness was not widespread.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down with eyes on US data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, down 0.47% or 87.04 points, after reaching a 2016 high the previous day. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 18,426.08. Investors were cautious ahead of US jobs data and an Italian referendum over the weekend. The broader Topix index also dropped 0.36%.

site_title: Asia's progress in closing the gender gap is slow, uneven
summary: Asia's progress in closing the gender gap is slow and uneven, with the Philippines and New Zealand leading the pack but still scoring lower than a decade ago. India struggles with female health despite gains in wage equality and education, while China's gender gap flat-lined due to declining workforce participation. The region's decline in female participation rate is a global concern, and economic equality remains elusive, with no Asian country ranking in the top 10 for economic participation. It will take 170 years for women to achieve global pay equality at current rates.

site_title: Singapore banks lose up to 40 per cent of new product sales to competitors: survey
summary: Singapore retail banks lose up to 40% of new product sales to competitors due to their better digital marketing, sales, and service capabilities, according to a Bain & Company survey. This "hidden defection" of consumers could worsen, posing a challenge to the country's banking industry. The consultancy's seventh annual report highlights the need for Singaporean banks to adapt to changing consumer behaviors.

site_title: Houses too pricey? Data show Aussies shouldn't blame foreigners
summary: A recent Australian Treasury report suggests that foreign demand for real estate contributed to rising property prices in Sydney and Melbourne by no more than A$122 per quarter from 2010 to 2015, compared to an average increase of A$12,800 per quarter. This means that foreign investment accounts for a relatively small proportion of the strong property price growth in the nation's largest cities. The report also notes that domestic household formation is the primary driver of demand, with foreign investment being the "cream on the top."

site_title: Singapore stocks' winning run threatened by economic headwinds
summary: Singapore's stock index rose 2.4% to 2,928.58, its longest winning streak in two years, but a prolonged economic slowdown and rising protectionism pose risks to the export-dependent nation. The Straits Times Index is trading at 12.4 times reported earnings, the lowest in the region, and investors remain cautious about further gains. The government has cut its 2016 growth forecast to 1.5% from 2% and faces mounting global concerns, including financial market volatility and uncertainty over interest rates.

site_title: Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher welcome second child
summary: Actors Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher welcomed their second child, a baby boy, on Wednesday. The couple, who have a 2-year-old daughter, Wyatt, announced the news through a spokeswoman. This is the couple's first child together after being married in July 2015. Kutcher, 38, and Kunis, 33, met as co-stars on the TV series "That '70s Show" in 1998.

site_title: Shareholders of SPH Reit ask about buying over Seletar Mall, threat of online shopping
summary: Shareholders of SPH Reit questioned the potential addition of Seletar Mall to the Reit's portfolio and the threat of online shopping during the annual general meeting. Chairman Leong Horn Kee stated that the Reit is interested in Seletar Mall but is waiting for SPH to sell it at a favorable price. Dr. Leong also emphasized the challenges in the retail environment, citing muted consumer sentiment, labor constraints, and competition from e-commerce, while reaffirming the Reit's commitment to creating value and long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: SHAREHOLDERS at the SPH Reit annual general meeting on Friday asked if the real estate investment trust sponsored by media group Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) would add Seletar Mall to its portfolio and queried about the threat of online shopping, among other things.

site_title: IS tactics evolving, may include car bombs: Europol
summary: Europol warns that terrorist groups like the Islamic State may evolve their tactics to attack soft targets in Europe, potentially using deadly car bombs. Although vehicle-borne improvised explosive devices have not been used in EU attacks, it's possible that jihadist groups will adopt this method. The report notes that IS groups have previously planned to use such devices but changed their plans due to police actions. Experts also express concern that Libya could become a second springboard for IS attacks in the EU and North Africa.

site_title: Trump talk of higher tariffs a bargaining chip, Scaramucci says
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on imports is a bargaining chip for better trade deals, according to Anthony Scaramucci, a member of Trump's transition team. Scaramucci stated that the administration believes in free, fair trade but is willing to impose tariffs as a negotiating chip to make deals fairer. The administration aims to renegotiate trade deals that have contributed to job losses and push for global growth. Scaramucci emphasized that the goal is to achieve "better than terrifically" or "terrifically" trade outcomes, rather than restricting trade.

site_title: Australia shares falter ahead of US economic data; NZ slips
summary: Australia's benchmark index closed 1.02% lower at 5,444 points, with financials and energy shares leading losers. Oil majors Woodside and Oil Search fell, while Bellamy's Australia plummeted 44% after new import rules in China created a supply glut. Dairy companies A2 Milk and Bega Cheese also slumped. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4%, with consumer staples and material shares leading losses.

site_title: US November payrolls seen strong, to cement rate hike views
summary: US employers likely added 175,000 jobs in November, surpassing expectations, as the economy continues to grow. The Labor Department's report on Friday will confirm the hiring boost, with the unemployment rate expected to remain at 4.9%. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates later this month, driven by strong economic data, including a brisk third-quarter growth and gains in consumer spending and inflation. Wage growth is expected to slow, but economists attribute this to calendar effects rather than a sign of a weakening economy.

site_title: Indonesian Muslims protest against Christian governor
summary: Over 100,000 Indonesian Muslims protested against Jakarta's Christian governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, for allegedly insulting Islam. The protests, the second major demonstration in weeks, call for his arrest on blasphemy charges. The case has sparked widespread anger, with conservative groups pushing for his prosecution, and critics accusing it of being a test of religious tolerance and a ploy to reduce his support. The protests, initially peaceful, turned violent, with clashes between protesters and security forces leaving one person dead and hundreds injured.

site_title: China, grappling with Trump, turns to 'old friend' Kissinger
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is seeking to defuse tensions with the US under President-elect Donald Trump, with the help of former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger. Kissinger, 93, has been shuttling between the two countries for decades, including a secret 1972 trip that paved the way for Nixon's visit. Chinese officials are assessing whether Trump's China-bashing will follow him to the White House, and Kissinger hopes to contribute to healthy US-China relations. The US-China relationship is seen as increasingly entwined, with minimal mutual trust, and Kissinger's unique position as a messenger is crucial in avoiding miscalculation.

images.alt_text: As he's done for decades, Henry Kissinger is again shuttling between the US and China to defuse tensions, this time as President Xi Jinping tries to figure out how much of President-elect Donald Trump's China-bashing will follow him to the White House.

site_title: Taiwan Foxconn manager indicted for stealing thousands of iPhones
summary: A former senior manager at Taiwan's Foxconn, a contract electronics maker, has been indicted for stealing and selling 5,700 iPhones in China, pocketing around US$1.56 million. The manager, Tsai, instructed eight employees to smuggle out iPhones 5 and 5s from Foxconn's factory in Shenzhen, China. Tsai's actions were discovered after an investigation, and he is expected to face prosecution. The incident highlights potential corruption and theft within Foxconn's supply chain, which assembles products for international brands such as Apple and Sony.

site_title: Draft law gives Chinese police control of online discussion on disasters
summary: China's county-level police will have control over online discussion on disasters under a revised draft of the country's policing law. The law, currently in public consultation, would grant police the power to censor internet coverage of natural and man-made disasters, allowing them to limit or block individuals or vehicles from entry into disaster areas. This move aims to contain public grief and anger, as seen in the aftermath of recent disasters in China, including a crane collapse that killed 74 people and chemical blasts in Tianjin that killed over 170.

site_title: Opec deal hinged on 2am phone call and it nearly failed
summary: OPEC successfully reached a deal to reduce oil supply, marking the first production cut in nearly a decade. The agreement, finalized on November 30, saw OPEC decrease output by 1.2 million barrels a day, while Russia and other non-OPEC producers agreed to cut 600,000 barrels. The deal was nearly derailed by Indonesia's objections, but ultimately resulted in oil prices surging over 15% to above $50 a barrel. The agreement was the result of months of intense negotiations, including a crucial 2am phone call between Saudi Arabian Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih and Russian counterpart Alexander Novak.

site_title: China orders coal mines to conduct safety overhaul
summary: China has ordered all coal mines to conduct a safety overhaul within a month, citing recent accidents that have resulted in 33 deaths, including a gas explosion at a mine in Chongqing. The move aims to prevent mines from operating over capacity and reducing overtime work, which increases the risk of accidents. The State Administration of Coal Mine Safety is also urging mines to improve ventilation and emergency response systems.

site_title: China's yuan set for best week since July on state bank buying, drooping US dollar
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar on Friday, its best weekly gain in over four months, due to state-owned bank buying and a decline in the US dollar. The yuan traded at 6.8835 per US dollar, a 0.06% gain from the previous close. Despite the firming, the yuan has lost nearly 6% of its value against the US dollar this year, raising concerns about capital outflows. Analysts predict the yuan will continue to depreciate to 7.14 by the end of the year, its lowest level in nearly a decade.

site_title: South Korea opposition says to vote on Park impeachment on Dec 9
summary: South Korea's opposition parties plan to vote on a motion to impeach President Park Geun-Hye on December 9, despite her offer to resign. The opposition parties have 165 seats, requiring some Saenuri Party members to join them to reach a two-thirds majority. Park is accused of colluding with a friend to pressure conglomerates to contribute to her policy initiatives. A failed impeachment motion could harm the opposition's efforts to force her out, with a new election to be held if the motion passes.

site_title: Japan's reindeer pizza delivery a Domi-no go
summary: Domino's Japan cancels reindeer pizza delivery plans due to difficulty in controlling the animals, according to the Japan Times. The plan, which was intended to promote the company's winter services, was met with concerns over animal welfare. The decision marks a "Domi-no go" for the reindeer pizza delivery concept.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks down at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.96% at the open, tracking losses across Asia, after recent gains. The Hang Seng index dropped to 22,659.55, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.10% to 3,270.12. The decline was attributed to a breather from investors.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hold ground with commodities, carry trade
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars maintained stability against the US dollar on Friday, driven by firm commodity prices and demand against the yen. The Australian dollar was steady around US$0.7410, with support at US$0.7370 and resistance at 75 US cents.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall tracking Wall St; US data eyed
summary: South Korean shares and the won fell 0.7% and 0.4% respectively on Friday, tracking Wall Street's losses ahead of the US jobs report. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped to 1,970.37 points, snapping a five-day gain streak. Analysts attributed the decline to offshore troubles, with US data expected to impact the market.

site_title: Gold rises from 10-month lows but heading for fourth consecutive weekly drop
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,173.76 an ounce, rebounding from a 10-month low, as the US dollar fell ahead of US jobs data. Despite the gain, gold is still on track for a fourth consecutive weekly decline, falling 0.7% for the week. The metal's price recovery is attributed to the US dollar's decline, but gold's overall trend remains bearish.

images.alt_text: Gold recovered from its lowest since early February on Friday as the US dollar drifted lower ahead of US jobs data, but the metal is still on track for a fourth consecutive weekly decline.

site_title: StanChart says 1MDB-linked breaches 'historical', vows to donate profits to charity
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has acknowledged 28 breaches of Singapore's anti-money laundering requirements, related to 1MDB transactions from 2010 to 2013. The bank has taken remedial and disciplinary action, and will donate profits from these transactions to charity. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has imposed a S$5.2 million penalty. StanChart has strengthened its controls and raised staff awareness, citing its Financial Crime Risk Mitigation Programme. The bank regrets the breaches and has cooperated with authorities investigating the matter.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit one-week low with overseas markets; techs drag
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell to a one-week low on Friday, down 1.05% to 9,165.90 points, due to declines in tech heavyweights like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. The electronics subindex dropped 1.5% and the financials subindex lost 0.6%. The decline was tracked from overnight losses on Wall Street and regional bourses.

site_title: Australia retail sales jump for 3rd month in welcome relief for economy
summary: Australia's retail sales surged 0.5% in October, beating forecasts and marking the best three-month period since mid-2014, providing welcome relief for the economy. The robust numbers alleviate concerns of a slowdown or recession, and are a positive sign for inflation and overall economic growth. The retail sector's annual sales of A$290 billion and 1.25 million workers also provide comfort to the Reserve Bank of Australia, which has been monitoring weak business investment and construction data.

site_title: South Korea, Japan impose new unilateral sanctions on North Korea
summary: South Korea and Japan have imposed new unilateral sanctions on North Korea, targeting senior officials and entities involved in the country's nuclear and ballistic missile programs. The sanctions, which expand existing measures, include blacklisting key officials, banning foreign experts' visits, and freezing assets of North Korean groups. The UN Security Council resolution, which imposed penalties on North Korea's exports, was rejected by Pyongyang, which claims it is a US conspiracy to deny sovereignty. Japan also added ships that have called at North Korean ports to its sanctions list, citing a "new phase of threat" from North Korea.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 2,932.44 on Friday, driven by a 3.86-point gain. The market was ahead of the US non-farm payrolls data, with about 90 million shares changing hands. Global Logistic Properties led gains with a 0.16-S$ rise. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 57, marking a 3:2 ratio.

site_title: Australia central bank to stand pat on rates at December meeting: poll
summary: Australia's central bank is expected to keep its cash rate at a record low of 1.5% at its December meeting, according to a Reuters poll of 64 economists. This would be the third consecutive rate cut, following May and August. While 17 economists predict at least one more rate cut by mid-2017, opinions are divided on the longer-term outlook, with 20 forecasting a rate hike by early 2018 and 15 anticipating a cut.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank is seen certain to keep its cash rate at a record low of 1.5 per cent at its monthly policy meeting next week, a Reuters poll of economists found on Friday.

site_title: Twitter changes product head for third time in a year
summary: Twitter appointed Keith Coleman, founder of startup Yes Inc, as its new product head, the third executive to lead the division in less than a year. Coleman joins Twitter after the departure of Jeff Seibert, who stepped down in June, and Kevin Weil, who left for Instagram. The move comes as Twitter faces stagnating user growth and faces potential acquisition offers from companies like Walt Disney Co and Alphabet Inc. Financial terms of the acquisition of Yes Inc were not disclosed.

site_title: 'Tis the season to window shop in New York
summary: New York department stores have unveiled their holiday window displays, featuring whimsical winter landscapes, animated windows, and festive fashion. Lord & Taylor's "Enchanted Forest" display, Saks Fifth Avenue's "Land of 1000 Delights," and Macy's "Believe" display are among the notable themes. The displays, which began appearing in November, attract a million daily viewers and are created by teams of designers, marketers, and digital experts. The displays will remain up until after Christmas, with some stores also auctioning off unique chandeliers to benefit charities.

site_title: Australia shares fall ahead of key US payroll data; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.53% on Friday, led by materials and financials, ahead of key US payroll data that could influence US interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track to slide 0.66% for the week. BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group fell 2%, 1%, and 4% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.12% despite gains in healthcare stocks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Swiber, Global Logistic Properties
summary: NOBLE Group has completed the disposal of Noble Americas Energy Solutions to Calpine Energy Services Holdco II for $1.16 billion. Swiber Holdings has had its judicial management period extended to October 1, 2017, by the Singapore High Court. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is undertaking a strategic review of options to enhance shareholder value after receiving a request from its largest shareholder, GIC Real Estate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.07 points to 1627.51, driven by a 68-30 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 19.4 million lots worth RM6 million.

site_title: World cities seek US$375b to fight climate change
summary: The world's major cities are seeking $375 billion in investment to combat climate change. According to the C40 network, cities will need this amount to reduce emissions and meet the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting global warming to two degrees Celsius. The gathering of mayors in Mexico City comes as US President-elect Donald Trump has expressed skepticism about the accord. Cities plan to implement measures such as cycling and renewable energy to reduce emissions, and 38 US cities have signed a letter to Trump pledging to continue their efforts against climate change.

site_title: Trump taps retired general Mattis as new Pentagon chief
summary: President-elect Donald Trump announced the nomination of retired US Marine General James Mattis as his defense secretary, referring to him as "Mad Dog" Mattis. Mattis oversaw US war efforts in the Middle East and is described as the closest thing to General George Patton. Trump made the announcement publicly, despite his transition team's earlier statement that there would be no more cabinet announcements this week. Mattis' nomination is seen as a nod to his tough and experienced leadership.

site_title: Thailand's crown prince becomes country's new king
summary: Thailand's Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn, 64, has become the country's new king after accepting an invitation from parliament to succeed his father, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died in October. The new king, who will be known as King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, was widely regarded as a pillar of stability during decades of political turbulence and rapid development in the Southeast Asian nation. His ascension is expected to allay worries about instability following the death of the previous king, and the United States has sent its "warmest congratulations" to the new monarch.

site_title: Asia flat following a weaker Wall Street as Treasury yields hit 16-month high
summary: Asian shares were flat in early trade on Friday following a weaker US market, with the 10-year US Treasury yields hitting a 16-month high. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record closing high, but the S&P 500 and Nasdaq ended the day with losses. Crude futures surged to 16-month highs, and the euro strengthened against the US dollar. Investors remain cautious ahead of a constitutional referendum in Italy and a presidential election in Austria this weekend, and are watching November's employment report for further evidence of economic improvement.

site_title: Pro-EU candidate wins London suburb 'Brexit by-election'
summary: Pro-EU candidate Sarah Olney won a parliamentary by-election in Richmond, London, defeating pro-Brexit incumbent Zac Goldsmith with 20,510 votes. The result, with a 53.6% turnout, is seen as a blow to the British government and a mini-referendum on Brexit in a pro-European Union heartland. Olney, a Liberal Democrat, won with a significant margin, while Goldsmith's vote was down from his 2015 general election result. The outcome is a surprise given Goldsmith's previous majority and the Conservative Party's decision not to field a candidate.

site_title: Obama said poised to block Chinese takeover of Germany's Aixtron
summary: US President Barack Obama is expected to block a Chinese company's acquisition of Germany's Aixtron SE, a semiconductor-equipment supplier, citing national security risks. This would be the third time the White House has rejected an overseas buyer's investment due to security concerns. The deal, worth 670 million euros, was recommended to be stopped by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US, citing Aixtron's technology that can be used in military applications. The decision comes at a critical moment for US-China relations, with President-elect Donald Trump vowing to brand China a currency manipulator and impose tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: StanChart and Coutts fined by MAS for anti-money laundering breaches
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has fined Standard Chartered Bank and Coutts $5.2 million and $2.4 million, respectively, for anti-money laundering breaches related to 1MDB fund flows. The breaches involved inadequate customer due diligence measures and controls at both banks. MAS also plans to issue a prohibition order against Tim Leissner, a former Goldman Sachs director, for making false statements on behalf of the bank regarding 1MDB. The regulator emphasized that it will not tolerate the abuse of Singapore's financial system for illicit purposes.

site_title: ANA joins efforts to start space trips as possible Virgin rival
summary: ANA Holdings Inc has invested 20.4 million yen in PD Aerospace Ltd, a Japanese company developing a space craft capable of carrying eight people to 100km above the earth, aiming for commercial flights in December 2023. This investment positions PD Aerospace as a potential rival to Virgin Galactic Ltd, with a target price of under S$100,000 per ticket. The move comes after Virgin Galactic reported 700 bookings at S$250,000 per ticket, and PD Aerospace's president Shuji Ogawa stated that bigger investments are needed to accelerate development.

site_title: IPO for Vietjet to raise up to US$194m: IFR
summary: Vietnamese budget airline VietJet plans to raise up to $194 million in an initial public offering (IPO) with 44.7 million shares, which could be increased by an additional 14.9 million shares. The offering is expected to be priced between 75,900-98,400 dong, suggesting a market capitalization of $1.08 billion to $1.4 billion. VietJet, which commands 40% of Vietnam's domestic market, is set to list on the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange with BNP, Deutsche Bank, JP Morgan, and VietCapital as joint global coordinators.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.38% and the Topix index down 0.18%. The yen's firming contributed to the decline.

site_title: Pimco to pay US$20m over misleading investors about ETF performance
summary: Pimco, a unit of German insurer Allianz SE, agreed to pay US$20 million to settle charges it misled investors about the performance of its top exchange-traded fund, PIMCO Total Return Exchange-Traded Fund (BOND). The Securities and Exchange Commission found Pimco overstated the ETF's value by using a third-party pricing service that valued bonds as larger pieces, adding 54% to the fund's monthly cumulative performance returns in 2012. Pimco will also retain an independent compliance consultant and enhance its policies and procedures.

site_title: Noble completes disposal of US energy unit for US$800m
summary: Noble Group completed the disposal of its US energy unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, to Calpine Energy Services Holdco II for US$1.16 billion, exceeding the initial US$800 million sale price. The deal includes US$800 million in cash and US$356 million in net working capital.

images.alt_text: Commodity trader Noble Group said late on Thursday it has completed the disposal of Noble Americas Energy Solutions to Calpine Energy Services Holdco II, following its announcement of the potential sale in October.

site_title: Great Barrier Reef 'not dying', Australia insists
summary: Australia has updated UNESCO on its efforts to protect the Great Barrier Reef, insisting it is "not dying" despite facing pressure from climate change, farming run-off, and other threats. The government has reported progress on its "Reef 2050" plan, with 32 of 151 actions achieved, but critics argue that climate change remains the reef's biggest threat and that the plan lacks urgency and new funding. The plan includes commitments to improve water quality and tackle the crown-of-thorns starfish, but no new actions on climate change.

site_title: Jakarta on high alert as Muslim groups protest Christian leader
summary: Hard-line Islamic groups in Jakarta, Indonesia, have begun gathering to protest Christian Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, who faces blasphemy charges for comments deemed insulting to Islam. President Joko Widodo has deployed 22,000 soldiers and police to maintain order, as foreign embassies warn of potential violence. Purnama, locked in a governorship battle, could face up to five years in prison if convicted. The case risks emboldening extremists in Indonesia, a secular Muslim-majority nation, and has sparked concerns about the country's democratic values.

site_title: Bolivia suspends airline as Colombian crash probe points to lack of fuel
summary: Bolivia has suspended the license of charter airline Lamia Bolivia, whose plane crashed in Colombia, killing 71 people, including a Brazilian soccer team. Investigators found no fuel in the wreckage, suggesting a lack of fuel may have caused the crash. International regulations require aircraft to carry enough fuel for 30 minutes after reaching their destination. The suspension follows concerns raised by a Bolivian aviation official about the airline's flight plan, which was deemed too long for the plane's maximum range. The incident has sent shockwaves across the soccer community and plunged Brazil into mourning.

site_title: Polls close in London suburb 'Brexit by-election'
summary: Polls closed in Richmond, a London suburb, for a parliamentary by-election that has become a mini-referendum on Brexit. Liberal Democrat Sarah Olney is running against independent candidate Zac Goldsmith, who held the seat for the Conservative Party. Olney, a pro-EU candidate, hopes to send shockwaves to the government, while Goldsmith, a Brexit supporter, faces a tough task in retaining the seat. The result is expected, with polls indicating Olney may win 47% of the vote.

site_title: UK firms looking to Ireland after Brexit: central bank
summary: UK firms are increasing their presence in Ireland following the Brexit vote, with Ireland's central bank reporting a "material increase" in applications for licenses to operate in the country. Several UK-based financial firms have started the application process, and the bank is open to firms with a "substantive presence" in Ireland. The move is seen as a response to the UK's risk of losing passporting rights into the EU when it leaves the bloc. This could provide a softer landing for UK firms seeking to maintain EU access.

images.alt_text: Ireland's central bank has seen a "material increase" in UK-based financial firms considering a licence to operate in Ireland since the Brexit vote, its deputy governor Cyril Roux said Thursday.

site_title: South Korea revised Q3 GDP growth 0.6% q-o-q, ticks down from estimate
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.6% in Q3, down from the estimated 0.7% rise. This marginally lagged the 2.7% growth in the previous quarter. The country's GDP expanded by 2.6% in Q3 last year. The revised Q3 growth is the latest in a series of downward revisions, with Q2 growth revised to 0.8% from 1.1%.

site_title: A comedian with many hats
summary: Comedian Bill Bailey has used his humor to navigate various situations, including performing at the 2011 Sonisphere rock music festival alongside Slipknot. He has since become known for his sense of humor and musical virtuosity, releasing the album "Bill Bailey In Metal." Bailey will return to perform in Singapore with his new show "Larks in Transit," which explores life on the road and tackles various topics with his trademark wit. He is also an avid naturalist and activist, with a new book and documentary projects showcasing his environmental work.

site_title: Formula One: France to 'return to world championship in 2018'
summary: The French Grand Prix will return to the Formula One world championship in 2018 after a 10-year absence, with the Castellet circuit hosting the event. The last French Grand Prix was held at Magny Cours in 2008. The circuit, previously owned by Bernie Ecclestone, will host the 2018 event, marking its return to the championship after a decade-long absence. An official announcement is set to be made on Monday.

images.alt_text: The French Grand Prix will return to the Formula One world championship in 2018 after a 10-year absence with the race to be staged at the Castellet circuit, sources said.

site_title: Oil soars, Brent hits 16-month high after Opec output deal
summary: Oil prices surged 4% on Thursday, reaching a 16-month high, after OPEC and Russia agreed to restrict output to reduce the global supply glut. The deal, OPEC's first in 15 years, included Saudi Arabia's acceptance of output cuts and coordination with non-member Russia. Azerbaijan also expressed willingness to discuss cuts. The agreement aims to quickly reduce the supply glut, with Brent crude reaching its highest level in about 16 months.

site_title: France's Hollande says will not seek re-election
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced Thursday he will not seek re-election next April, bowing to historic low approval ratings. Hollande, who has some of the lowest approval ratings for a French president since World War II, cited his inability to rally his party behind his candidacy and keep a promise to slash unemployment. The decision opens the door to other Socialist candidates, including ex-economy minister Arnaud Montebourg and Prime Minister Manuel Valls, who has already submitted his name for the party's primaries.

site_title: Brazil executives in graft probe agree major plea deal: source
summary: Brazilian construction firm Odebrecht's executives, including Marcelo Odebrecht, have agreed to a plea deal in exchange for lighter sentences and a $2-billion fine. The deal, signed by 77 executives, could implicate President Michel Temer, who was named by Marcelo Odebrecht in testimony to investigators. This development comes as part of a corruption probe into Petrobras, which has led to the resignation of several ministers and threatens to engulf the government. The plea deal may reveal more about the extent of corruption involving Temer and other politicians.

site_title: US car sales heat up in November, boosted by discounts
summary: US car sales surged in November, driven by deep discounts and extra selling days, reversing three months of year-over-year declines. The industry sold 1.38 million units, with GM, Ford, and Toyota reporting sales gains. Nissan and Honda also set November records, while Volkswagen reversed declines. However, FCA US, Fiat Chrysler, and BMW posted significant declines. The industry's seasonally adjusted annual rate fell 2% to 17.87 million units. Despite the boost, some analysts warn that elevated incentive spending may pose a risk to the long-term health of the auto industry.

site_title: Voters in London hit the polls for 'Brexit by-election'
summary: Voters in Richmond, London, cast ballots in a parliamentary by-election that has become a mini-referendum on Brexit. Liberal Democrat candidate Sarah Olney, who advocates for a second Brexit referendum, is competing against independent candidate Zac Goldsmith. Richmond, a traditionally pro-EU borough, voted 69% to remain in the EU, and the high turnout of 82% underscores the local passion for the issue. The outcome is seen as a potential shock to the government's Brexit plans, with the Lib Dems hoping for a strong result to force a rethink on a "hard Brexit."

site_title: Fed may face unnerving shake-up under Trump administration
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's team plans to rapidly fill high-level positions at the Federal Reserve, potentially altering the central bank's economic assumptions and prompting a faster interest rate increase. Fed Chair Janet Yellen faces a 14-month window to preserve her legacy and ensure the Fed's independence, with concerns about a possible four or more Trump appointees to the Board of Governors. Trump's economic proposals could push inflation higher, and his administration's plans may rewrite policymakers' core assumptions.

site_title: HK developers hit by double whammy; stock rally fades in Nov
summary: Hong Kong developers, once the top performers in the market, have seen their stocks slump 6.6% in November due to home price curbs and expected rate hikes following Donald Trump's US presidential election win. Higher borrowing costs and levies have deflated buyer demand, leading to a leg down in the property market. Analysts are becoming less bullish on property stocks, with some predicting underperformance for the sector in the next six months.

site_title: EU budget adopted with more for migration, security
summary: The European Parliament adopted a 2017 EU budget of nearly 158 billion euros, including a 6 billion euro increase to address the migration crisis and terrorism. The budget aims to help member states resettle refugees, create reception centers, and integrate migrants, while boosting border protection and counter-terrorism activities. The 11.3% increase is the largest since 2014, with funds allocated for programs spanning over one year. The budget was approved by 438 votes, with 194 against and 7 abstentions.

site_title: Companies leaving US will face 'consequences': Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump warned companies leaving the US that they will face "consequences" if they relocate abroad. He made this statement during a public remarks at the Carrier plant in Indianapolis, where a deal was reached to keep 1,100 jobs in the country. Under the deal, Carrier received US$7 million in incentives over 10 years. Trump threatened tariffs on firms that decamped to countries like Mexico or Asia, but the deal with Carrier is seen as an exception.

site_title: US factory activity at five-month high, bottlenecks emerging
summary: US factory activity reached a five-month high in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's index rising 1.3 percentage points to 53.2, the best reading since June. This suggests the manufacturing sector is regaining momentum after a prolonged slump. While gains are likely to be modest due to renewed US dollar strength, the sector's recovery is driven by easing dollar drag and stabilizing oil prices. Bottlenecks in the supply chain are also emerging, with supplier deliveries surging to a five-year high.

site_title: Room for more ambitious works
summary: Hong Kong's Pearl Lam Galleries has opened its second gallery space in Singapore, located at Dempsey Hill, after scaling down its space in Gillman Barracks. The 358 sqm gallery aims to allow for more ambitious programming, including large-scale installations and immersive video projections. The gallery plans to engage with the local community through social and community projects, such as promoting local street art and reaching out to youths through art. This move is seen as an opportunity to further engage with the audience in Singapore and the region.

site_title: Switzerland eyes exchanging banking info with 21 more countries
summary: Switzerland aims to expand its automatic exchange of information (AEOI) with 21 countries, including Argentina, Brazil, and India, to increase international fiscal transparency. The move, part of efforts to phase out banking secrecy laws, will bring the total number of countries cooperating with Switzerland to 59. The government expects the accords to take effect by January 1, 2018, with information exchange to begin a year later. The move is seen as a step towards strengthening Switzerland's financial center's competitiveness and credibility.

site_title: Credit Suisse freezing accounts to look for US assets
summary: Credit Suisse has frozen dozens of accounts in the US to determine if clients are hiding money from the IRS. The bank is looking for indicators such as phone numbers or powers of attorney to verify account owners. The move comes as the US investigates Credit Suisse's failure to disclose US$200 million in assets held by an American client who pleaded guilty to tax evasion. The bank aims to show that hidden accounts were a lapse in controls, not a criminal act.

site_title: Starbucks' Schultz to step aside as CEO; stay on as chairman
summary: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz will step down on April 3, handing the reins to President Kevin Johnson. Schultz will remain as executive chairman and chairman of the board, focusing on high-end coffee shops, including Starbucks Reserve Roasteries. The move aims to boost foot traffic as the company faces increased competition from higher-quality retail coffee shops. Schultz, 63, will devote his time to developing the Reserve Roasteries, citing a desire for entrepreneurial freedom. Johnson, a tech industry veteran, will oversee the company's operations and expansion plans, including a plan to double stores in China over five years.

site_title: EU maps out blueprint to boost renewables usage
summary: The European Commission has outlined a 1,000-page reform plan to boost renewables usage, aiming to power half of Europe by 2030. The plan includes cutting energy use, phasing out coal subsidies, and increasing cross-border trade. It also aims to adapt the grid to digital technologies and accommodate intermittent wind and solar power. The proposal is part of the EU's efforts to meet emissions reduction goals and adapt to the changing energy landscape.

site_title: Russia weaponised social media in US election: FireEye
summary: Russia allegedly weaponized social media in the 2016 US presidential election, using fake accounts and online personas to promote leaked documents and misleading narratives. FireEye, a cybersecurity company, analyzed thousands of postings and linked thousands of documents to identify a Russian-backed campaign. The operation was a new escalation by Moscow in the cyber domain, according to FireEye chairman David DeWalt. The campaign included direct and indirect advocacy, targeting influential people and journalists. US officials have acknowledged minor cyber incidents on Election Day, but there's no evidence of significant hacking of vote tabulation systems.

site_title: Savings Bonds of up to S$2b to be offered in 2017: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced plans to issue up to S$2 billion of 10-year Savings Bonds in 2017, with the first bond set to be issued on January 3. The interest rate for the January 2017 bond is 0.91% for the first year. The MAS expects interest rates to rise, which may motivate depositors to consider Savings Bonds. Existing investors can choose to redeem and reinvest in the new higher-paying tranche.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said on Thursday that up to S$2 billion of 10-year Savings Bonds will be offered in 2017.

site_title: Dec rate hike: Muted impact for Reits as event already priced in
summary: Real estate investment trusts (Reits) are expected to experience a muted impact from a potential interest rate hike in December, as investors have already factored it into their expectations. The probability of a rate increase is near 100%, but the expected impact on Reits is minimal. Analysts believe that Reits' steady dividends will cushion the impact, and institutions will likely maintain their allocations, supporting capital values and Reit prices. The bigger question for 2017 is the uncertainty surrounding US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, which could lead to volatility in the market.

site_title: Oil price surges after Opec action but shale could spoil the party
summary: Oil prices surged 9% after Opec agreed to cut output by 1.2 million barrels a day for the first six months of 2017, but analysts caution that shale production in the US may limit the upside. Stocks on the Singapore Exchange rallied, with oil-linked stocks gaining 3-10% gains. However, analysts expect oil prices to remain below US$60 a barrel, citing concerns about non-Opec country participation and the potential for higher US output. The agreement is seen as a short-term relief for service providers, but long-term survival depends on capital expenditures from oil producers.

site_title: Hangover awaits as Opec celebrates
summary: OPEC successfully agreed to its first production cut in eight years, with oil prices rising 10% following the deal. Analysts hail the agreement as a "resurrection" and a "comeback" for the oil club. However, concerns remain about cheating by OPEC members, particularly Iraq and Iran, and potential exemptions for Libya and Nigeria. Non-OPEC countries like Russia and Mexico also agree to cuts, but their compliance is uncertain. The deal could push oil prices to $60 a barrel by the end of 2016, benefiting OPEC but also potentially weakening demand growth and benefiting US shale producers.

site_title: US dollar slips after November's gains; sterling strengthens
summary: The US dollar slipped against a basket of currencies on Thursday, following gains in November, as traders booked profits. The pound strengthened against the dollar, rising 0.5% to a three-week high, after Brexit minister David Davis hinted at Britain potentially paying into the EU budget for market access. The pound reached a high of $1.2696 and was last up at $1.2575.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth in November strongest since January 2014
summary: Eurozone factory growth in November reached its strongest level since January 2014, with a final manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index of 53.7. The weaker euro and stronger demand contributed to the growth, pleasing policymakers who are expected to extend the European Central Bank's asset purchase program. Eurozone inflation inched up to 0.6% year-on-year, while unemployment fell below 10% for the first time since 2011, boosting the European economy's slow recovery.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties undertakes strategic review
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) is undertaking a strategic review of options to enhance shareholder value, following a request from its largest shareholder, GIC. The company has appointed JP Morgan as its financial adviser and formed a special committee to oversee the review. GLP has made preliminary approaches to various parties, but no assurance is given that a transaction will materialize. The review comes after unsolicited interest from an investor group, including China Investment Corp and Hillhouse Capital Management, which manage significant assets.

site_title: SPH on the lookout for bigger projects
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is seeking "bigger projects" to support its business, citing declining core media revenue. Chairman Lee Boon Yang stated that the company needs investments to increase revenue and profit. SPH has already diversified into property with its Reit and is scouting for more strategic assets. The company's core media business saw a 7.6% decline in revenue for FY2016, with a net profit of S$265.3 million. Despite this, the newspaper business maintained its leading position, with a 2.8% increase in total circulation.

site_title: Mixed results in American effort to stop trade in 'conflict minerals'
summary: The US is leading efforts to curb trade in "conflict minerals" - tin, tungsten, tantalum, and gold ore - extracted in conflict zones and funding armies and rebel groups. Despite the 2010 Dodd-Frank law requiring manufacturers to audit supply chains, progress is slow, with only a few companies meeting minimum standards. The US has partnered with companies and NGOs to build systems for conflict-free sourcing in Africa, but the problem persists, and global trading community remains reluctant to give up commodities extracted in conflict zones.

site_title: 3 Heartland Mall levels, 2 Havelock II units sold
summary: Master Contract Services has acquired the lower three levels of Heartland Mall-Kovan and two strata retail units at Havelock II near Chinatown for approximately S$250 million. The properties, previously owned by Alpha Investment Partners, a fund managed by Keppel Capital, are part of a bigger retail portfolio. The sale is seen as a strategic move to boost Master Contract Services' investment portfolio, with Knight Frank noting strong interest in commercial properties with a net yield of over 4%.

site_title: Making Singaporeans hungry to learn, strive and achieve
summary: Singapore's GDP per capita has increased 100-fold since 1965, making it the sixth richest people in the world. To maintain this growth, the city-state must continue to develop its infrastructure and people in an inclusive and sustainable manner. Key points for future Singapore include: prioritizing values such as integrity, respect for diversity, and meritocracy; achieving a net-zero-emissions world through sustainable energy; and fostering a culture of continuous relearning and adaptation. By focusing on these areas, Singapore can remain a city of choice for individuals and businesses and ensure its position as a critical node in the regional network.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq dragged lower by tech; Dow hits record close
summary: The US stock market experienced a mixed day on December 1, 2016, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average hitting a record close, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 indexes declined due to a sharp drop in technology stocks. The Dow rose 68.35 points to 19,191.93, driven by gains in financial and energy shares, including Goldman Sachs and Chevron. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 technology indexes fell 2.3% and 2.8% respectively, their worst daily performances since June 24 and November 14.

site_title: GOP out to woo the Asian-American voter
summary: Asian-Americans have increasingly shifted towards the Democratic Party, with 65-75% voting for Hillary Clinton in 2016, compared to 41% for George W. Bush in 2000. This trend began in the early 2000s, driven by a decrease in foreign policy issues and the adoption of more liberal voting patterns by second- and third-generation Asian-Americans. President-elect Trump's appointment of three Asian-American women to his Cabinet may help Republicans outreach to this community, but the growing political and economic power of Asian-Americans suggests they could become a reliable Democratic constituency.

site_title: Italy outshines weaker European shares as referendum worries ease
summary: Italian shares rose to a three-week high, outshining weaker European markets, as concerns over Sunday's referendum on Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's constitutional reform eased. The Italian stock market rose 1% to its highest intraday level since November 10, while the Pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3%. Banks in Italy were in demand, with the Italian bank index rising 2.6% for its third straight session of gains, as investors feared a "no" vote would make it difficult to raise capital for ailing banks.

site_title: Crown Prince is first new Thai king in seven decades
summary: Thailand's Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn, 64, became the country's new king after accepting an invitation from Parliament to succeed his father, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died in October. This marks the first new monarch in seven decades. King Maha Vajiralongkorn, who will be known as King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, is expected to bring stability to Thailand after the death of his father, who was widely loved and regarded as a pillar of stability during decades of political turbulence.

site_title: Sterling surges on Brexit minister's remarks
summary: Sterling surged 1.2% to a three-week high of US$1.2663 after Brexit minister David Davis said Britain would consider paying into the EU budget for market access, potentially softening the "hard Brexit" line. This move offered hope that a solution may not be as disruptive to Europe's economies as previously feared. The US dollar was roughly steady against the yen, but showed signs of fatigue, with some brokers forecasting parity or below parity with the euro.

site_title: As auto lending surges, US regulators worry about rising delinquencies
summary: US regulators are expressing "significant concern" about rising delinquencies in auto lending, with subprime loan balances becoming at least 90 days delinquent at a rate of 2% in the third quarter, up from 1.6% in 2014. Economists fear that if the economy dips into another recession, the already large number of Americans on the verge of losing their cars to repossession could swell to record levels. Industry experts have dismissed comparisons between subprime auto loans and the mortgage bubble, but widespread repossessions could deliver a stinging hit to the economy.

site_title: Missing the economic big picture
summary: The article discusses the current state of the global economy, highlighting the disconnect between market growth and individual well-being. Despite technological innovation and globalisation, annual productivity growth in North Atlantic countries has fallen to 1% from 2%. Economist Robert J Gordon argues that all game-changing innovations have already been exhausted, but others suggest that new inventions will continue to emerge. The article also touches on the issue of inequality, stating that the "overclass" has emerged, with the top 20% of earners holding disproportionate economic power. The author argues that market capitalism has not delivered shared prosperity, and that a broader perspective is needed to understand the global economy's trajectory.

site_title: Beyond making and selling products - rethinking CPG brands in a digital age
summary: CPG brands are shifting their focus from solely selling products to engaging with consumers in a more intimate and fluid relationship. The rise of digital technology has fostered "liquid expectations" among consumers, who now expect personalized experiences and interactions with brands. To adapt, brands must assess their products as either "utility" or "experience" brands, with experience brands being more likely to engage consumers on a new level. By partnering with digital providers and experts, brands can create platforms that support communities and deliver services to meet consumers' needs. This shift in perspective is crucial for CPG companies to remain relevant in the digital age.

site_title: S'pore-Malaysia leaders' retreat postponed: NST
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will have to wait until December 21 for the planned high-speed rail (HSR) project linking the two neighbors to be signed, as their annual leaders' retreat has been postponed due to scheduling and administrative issues. The HSR project, which aims to connect Singapore and Kuala Lumpur in 90 minutes, had initially been scheduled for signing during the retreat. Despite the delay, both countries have expressed confidence in the project's progress, with the HSR agreement expected to be signed by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Singapore and Malaysia will have to wait a little longer to sign a bilateral agreement for the planned high-speed rail (HSR) project linking the two neighbours.

site_title: 'There's too much pain in this world'
summary: Filmmaker Darren Aronofsky attributes his preference for dark films to the existence of pain in the world, stating that tragedy allows for a deeper understanding of human behavior. He believes the art of tragedy has been lost in storytelling in the US, and his films, such as "Requiem for a Dream" and "Black Swan," aim to explore this. Aronofsky's latest film, "Jackie," stars Natalie Portman as the First Lady after JFK's assassination, and he considers Portman a "mature woman" who brings authenticity to her roles.

images.alt_text: "You can understand and study human behaviour through tragedy - perhaps more so than you can through a crowd-pleasing story and a happy ending," says Aronofsky (seen here on the roof of ArtScience Museum in Singapore).
The Aronofsky-produced Jackie stars Portman as Jackie Kennedy in the aftermath of the assassination of her husband, US President John F Kennedy.

site_title: Singapore games publisher takes Hong Kong's GEM route
summary: Singapore-based tabletop games publisher CMON has successfully listed on Hong Kong's GEM board, raising HK$415.4 million (S$76.5 million) through a placing of 323 million shares at HK$0.23 apiece. The listing aims to capitalize on the consolidating gaming industry, allowing CMON to retain key talent and expand into new markets. The company plans to use the funds for game development, sales and marketing, acquisitions, and working capital, with a focus on mobile games and international expansion, particularly in Europe, South America, and Asia.

site_title: Firmer oil, play on banks push STI up
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 23.41 points higher at 2,928.58 for its eighth consecutive rise, driven by a 10% surge in oil prices and gains in the banking sector. The FTSE ST Oil and Gas Index rose 7.3% in response. Banks, such as Keppel Corp and DBS Vickers, contributed to the gains, with Keppel Corp jumping 8.1% to S$5.89. Turnover was healthy at 2.3 billion units worth S$1.67 billion.

site_title: Nestle scientists find method to cut sugar in chocolate by 40%
summary: Nestle has developed a method to reduce sugar in chocolate by up to 40% through altering the structure of sugar, making it taste sweeter in smaller amounts. The company plans to start selling confectionery products made with this process in 2018 and gradually reduce their sugar content. This move comes as food producers face increasing pressure to make products healthier, with governments and health advocates pushing for reduced sugar content in foods. Nestle aims to reduce sugar use and create a more natural taste, but the process's impact on taste and cost remain to be seen.

site_title: UK house prices resume gains in Nov
summary: UK house prices increased 0.1% in November, with a 4.4% gain from last year, according to Nationwide Building Society. Despite economic uncertainty, tight supply conditions are expected to support prices. Mortgage approvals rose to a seven-month high, and consumer credit surged. The impact of Brexit is expected to be less harsh than initially thought, with growth slowing to 1.2% next year from 2% in 2016.

site_title: Factory activity at 5-month high as orders pick up, boosting the economy's outlook
summary: US factory activity reached a five-month high in November, with the Institute for Supply Management index rising to 53.2, indicating expansion in manufacturing. New orders and production increased, while factory employment fell slightly. The economy's outlook remains strong, with consumer and construction spending also showing growth. However, a strong dollar may pose challenges for exports and multinational corporations, potentially squeezing profits and capital spending budgets.

site_title: Distilling lessons in corporate leadership from Shakespeare
summary: A theatre company, Bell Shakespeare, collaborated with executive search firm Heidrick & Struggles to analyze Shakespeare's plays for corporate leadership lessons. The event, "Where Caesar Went Wrong: Anatomy of a Boardroom Coup," featured 60 top executives in Singapore, who discussed leadership styles, integrity, and the importance of teamwork. The play Julius Caesar was used to illustrate five different leadership examples, including Julius Caesar, Marcus Brutus, Caius Cassius, Mark Antony, and Octavius Caesar. The event sparked robust conversations and highlighted the need for leaders to be aware of their team's motivations and to prioritize corporate goals.

images.alt_text: Above: Mr Bell (left) and Mr Evans (right) reading selected lines from Shakespeare's Julius Caesar, and then explaining how they reflected the different leaders in the play.
The dinner event at Chijmes Hall was attended by some 60 top executives in Singapore.

site_title: Have yourself a merry little Christmas, Brexit or not
summary: The UK's Christmas dinner bill remains largely unchanged from last year, with the cost of imported ingredients like raisins increasing by 21% due to the falling pound. However, supermarkets are delaying price hikes until next year, and the overall cost of Christmas dinner is expected to rise by 1% year-on-year. Despite this, food retailers are predicted to see sales growth of 2% during the festive season, benefiting national producers and the National Farmers Union's campaign to promote local foodstuffs.

site_title: Najib eyes snap election, vows fight to the death
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has vowed to fight "until the death" to maintain his party's power, signaling the possibility of snap elections as early as next year. He addressed the annual assembly of his ruling United Malays National Organisation (Umno) amidst a financial scandal surrounding the 1MDB fund, which he denies involvement in. Najib warned of "nightmares" if the opposition's Democratic Action Party comes to power, and Umno has begun preparing for a vote, with polls expected within the next six months.

site_title: Credit quality of S-Reits coming under pressure: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that the credit quality of Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) will face pressure over the next 12-18 months due to weakening leverage and debt-funded investments. The industry's debt-maturity profile has improved since the global financial crisis, but Moody's notes that S-Reits' capacity to weather potential asset value declines will be weakened. Occupancy and rental rates for office and industrial properties are expected to come under pressure due to abundant supply and soft demand, while the stock market's selling pressure amid looming Fed rate hikes has drawn concerns about the sector's fundamentals.

site_title: Australia cuts tax to ensure juicy pickings for fruit harvesters
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has struck a deal to halve the tax rate for overseas workers picking fruit, from 32.5% to 15%, to ensure a secure harvest. The tax rate change, announced just in time for the harvest season, aims to prevent fruit from rotting due to a lack of workers. The deal provides security and assurance to farmers, who rely heavily on overseas labor. The tax rate will affect fewer than 20,000 people with weekly earnings between A$200 and A$400.

site_title: Local indie acts at the top of their game
summary: Malaysian indie acts are gaining international recognition, with Mandopop newcomer Mandy Ke's debut single "So Wrong" reaching No. 2 on the Malaysian Mandopop iTunes chart. Producer-composer Evan Low, 27, has collaborated with top artists and worked on projects with international musicians, and singer-songwriter Charlie Lim's album "Time/Space" has sold out on vinyl, with 1.5 million plays on Spotify. The local music scene is "blossoming," with success largely attributed to digital platforms and public support from the National Arts Council.

site_title: Modi to 'Amazonise' US$400b in procurement
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi plans to move all government purchases to an Amazon-like online marketplace worth a fifth of the country's $2 trillion economy. The new system, launched in August, has already traded $8.15 million and aims to reduce corruption and increase transparency. With 20% of trades expected to be worth India's GDP, the portal faces challenges of training staff in rural areas with limited internet access. Critics argue that digitizing purchases alone may not stamp out corruption, and the government must ensure data security.

site_title: No raining on Neon Lights' parade
summary: Neon Lights 2016, a homegrown music and arts festival in Singapore, was affected by torrential rain on the first day, causing a mud fest and destroying several pairs of footwear. Despite the adverse weather conditions, 15,000 attendees still attended the festival on the second day. The event, held at Fort Canning, showcased music and arts, with the rain and slushy ground failing to dampen the spirits of the partygoers.

site_title: Indonesia targets Google, Facebook in push for more tax
summary: Indonesia is targeting global tech giants Google and Facebook to increase tax revenue amid weak commodity prices and subdued demand from China. The country's finance minister is seeking to boost income from penalties and tax assessments, with Google's bill potentially reduced from 5 trillion rupiah to 1 trillion. This push may deter foreign investment and hurt economic growth, with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development warning of a deteriorating fiscal balance.

site_title: A tale of fear and loathing, violence and vengeance
summary: Tom Ford's revenge thriller "Nocturnal Animals" weaves together a tale of fear and loathing, blending fictional and real worlds. The film, based on Austin Wright's novel, follows art gallery owner Susan Morrow (Amy Adams) as she reads a manuscript about her ex-husband Edward Sheffield (Jake Gyllenhaal), whose family is terrorized by a trio of rednecks in rural West Texas. As Susan becomes engrossed in the story, she reflects on her past relationship with Edward and the choices she made. The film is a stylish and unsettling psychological thriller that explores the foibles of the art world and the harsh realities of the rural south.

site_title: 35 China cities at 'high risk' of falling house prices, says think tank
summary: A Chinese government think tank identified 35 major cities with over-valued property markets, facing risks of falling home prices. China's first-tier cities, including Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing, and second-tier cities, such as Nanjing and Zhengzhou, are most exposed to property market risks. The think tank warned of an "overcorrecting" property market, which could drag on economic growth and impair financial stability, and called for improved short-term housing policies to guide a "soft landing".

site_title: YuuZoo enters India market with new franchisee
summary: YuuZoo Corporation, a Singapore-listed company, has entered the Indian market by selling a regional franchise licence to iComp Digital Media, a local digital solutions firm. iComp Digital Media is the largest partner of Apple India. This move marks YuuZoo's expansion into the Indian market, following its previous presence in other countries. The company did not disclose the terms of the licence agreement.

site_title: Maersk to buy German shipping line Hamburg Sud
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, has agreed to buy Hamburg Süd, a German rival, for an undisclosed amount. The deal is expected to boost Maersk's presence in global trade, particularly in Latin America. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to consolidate the industry, which has been grappling with low freight rates and oversupply. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to be finalized in the second quarter of 2017.

site_title: Australian home price growth accelerates
summary: Australian home prices rose for the 11th consecutive month in November, with annual growth accelerating to 9.3% from 7.5% in October. Sydney's home prices surged 0.8% and annual growth reached 13.1%, while Melbourne experienced a rare monthly decline of 1.5%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to maintain its current interest rate policy, citing concerns about a debt-fuelled bubble, following the tightening of lending rules.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Q&M Dental Group received approval for Aidite's quotation on China's new third board, subject to completion of quotation procedures and filings with securities regulatory bureau. MIDAS Holdings awarded international and China supply contracts worth RMB232.1 million. Allied Technologies plans to transfer its listing from mainboard to Catalist due to trading price below the minimum requirement. EPICENTRE Holdings entered into a memorandum of understanding to negotiate a potential cooperation or acquisition with Japan IPL Holdings. The Straits Times Index will remain unchanged in its December quarterly review.

site_title: O&M will take years, post-oil rebound, to make a turnaround
summary: Industry analysts warn that offshore & marine (O&M) companies won't recover quickly due to geopolitical risks, overcapacity, and regulatory challenges. Even with Opec's production cut agreement, O&M players will need holding power to bet on a turnaround, with some predicting a 3-4 quarter wait before projects can return on a sustainable basis. The market will take years to recover, with fleet utilisation of rigs and vessels showing improvement only after 18-30 months. Over-capacity and margin erosion from regulatory challenges in key O&M sub-sectors, such as Brazil and Indonesia, also hinder the road to recovery.

site_title: China's November manufacturing sector continues upward trend
summary: China's manufacturing sector continued its upward trend in November, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 51.7, its strongest pace in over two years. However, the gap between state-backed firms and smaller private ones persists, and inflationary pressures are building.
