The sector's growth is driven by record credit growth, government investment, and a real-estate boom, but analysts warn that this form of investment-led growth is unsustainable in the long-term, potentially leading to bubbles and debt.

site_title: Taking a rich tradition to new heights
summary: Chinese artist Su Xiaobai has been creating "wall relief" lacquer paintings for over a decade, blending traditional Asian methods with Western pigments. Using three layers of linen and lacquer, Su's works appear raised and textured, defying the typical 2D painting. He discovered lacquer in the early 2000s while researching Asian materials and has since mixed traditional Chinese lacquer with German pigments. Su's art reflects his journey of cultural exchange between East and West, and his use of lacquer has led to a unique, luminescent style.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oil prices rise 2% amid OPEC's agreement to a 1.2 million bpd output cut, expected to last six months. However, execution is key, and demand growth remains a fundamental factor. Analysts at Maybank Kim Eng Research maintain a neutral view on the oil sector, predicting average US$42.50/bbl in 2016 and US$47.50/bbl in 2017. Genting Singapore's stock is downgraded to sell, while CapitaLand's stock is upgraded to add due to its on-ground activities and asset-light strategy.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat chairs first CFE meeting since his stroke
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat co-chaired the fifth and final meeting of the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) at the Treasury building, marking his first in-person meeting since suffering a stroke in May. The meeting, attended by industry leaders and experts, discussed the need for partnership between the public, private, and people sectors to keep Singapore's economy competitive. The CFE's final report, set to be released in early 2017, will contain recommendations to position Singapore for the future and identify areas of growth.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: GM to chase electric car boom despite red ink trail
summary: General Motors is set to lose up to $9,000 on every Chevrolet Bolt sold in the US, but the company will continue to produce the electric vehicle to meet California's clean-air rules. The state's rules require zero-emission vehicles to comprise 15.4% of sales by 2025, a goal that could be increased to 40% by 2030. While some manufacturers are losing money on electric cars, industry experts believe that as charging infrastructure improves and battery costs fall, electric vehicles will become more profitable. California's clean-air policies are expected to remain a driving force behind the electric vehicle boom in the US.

site_title: China hikes tax on supercars amid luxury crackdown
summary: China has imposed a 10% tax on supercars and luxury models costing 1.3 million yuan (S$269,300) and above, as part of a luxury crackdown and efforts to reduce emissions. The tax affects top-of-the-range models from brands like BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Audi. Carmakers downplayed the impact, stating it would affect only a small number of models and won't deter wealthy Chinese buyers. This move follows Beijing's efforts to curb lavish spending and luxury sales, including new rules for officials to cut down on expensive travel and owning fancy cars.

site_title: Wall Street back in favour with Trump cabinet picks
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet picks, Steven Mnuchin and Wilbur Ross, position Wall Street for renewed influence over the US economy, following a retreat in the Obama years. Mnuchin, a former Goldman Sachs executive, and Ross, known as the "king of bankruptcy," drew praise from business circles but criticism from Democrats, who warn of excessive coziness between the Treasury Department and Wall Street. The picks may revive concerns about the industry's excessive influence over the economy, with some critics likening it to a "wholesale takeover of government by an extremist faction of the corporate class."

site_title: With Trump in power, geopolitical risks in 2017 will be significant
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory has led to a surge in global stocks, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average crossing 19,000 for the first time in history. However, investors are cautioned against overestimating the positive impact of Trump's presidency, as geopolitical risks will be a major factor in 2017. The Brexit vote and Trump's win have highlighted voter dissatisfaction with globalization, leading to uncertainty in European elections and potential upheaval within the EU. Additionally, the market may underestimate the number of interest rate hikes in 2017 if Trump delivers on his campaign promises.

site_title: SPH builds on resilience of core media business while seeking opportunities
summary: SPH (Singapore Press Holdings) aims to build resilience for its core media business by launching a group-wide review and integrating marketing teams across print, digital, radio, and out-of-home. The move is expected to deliver more effective integrated solutions to advertisers and business partners. Despite a 17.5% net profit decline and 7.6% revenue fall, the company's core newspaper business maintained its leading position with a 2.8% increase in total circulation for print and digital editions.

site_title: Netflix users can now watch movies offline on mobile devices
summary: Netflix has announced that users worldwide can now download some videos to their mobile devices, allowing them to watch content offline. This feature will be particularly useful for users with spotty or unavailable internet signals, such as those traveling by airplane, on road trips, or in areas with poor Wi-Fi. The move aims to keep users engaged with the app, even when cellular signals are weak.

site_title: DBS eliminates a dozen brokerage jobs
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd has cut at least 12 roles at its brokerage unit, DBS Vickers Securities, as part of a broader effort to rationalize its institutional business unit and become more competitive. The move comes amid declining volumes in the market. DBS cited a need to be "more responsive to market changes" as the reason for the job cuts.

site_title: Eurozone heading for highly uncertain week
summary: The eurozone is heading for a highly uncertain week with an Italian referendum and Austrian presidential election on Sunday, amid concerns over the nation's banks, high unemployment, and government debt. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's referendum to change the constitution could lead to his resignation, potentially triggering elections and a rise in the right-wing populist 5-Star Movement. Analysts estimate that Italian banks have non-performing loans totaling 360 billion euros, and some are technically insolvent, requiring bailouts. Meanwhile, a populist politician in Austria could be elected president, with implications for the European Union.

site_title: Food and decor that try to please
summary: A Turkish eatery, Fat Prince and Ottoman Room, serves a mixed bag of dishes with varying levels of success. Fat Prince, the brighter and breezier sibling, excels with dishes like truffled baba ganoush and okra falafel. In contrast, Ottoman Room, with its darker and more contrived atmosphere, struggles with flavors that don't balance out, including a dry lamb shoulder and an overly strong lentil salad. Despite its efforts to impress, Ottoman Room falls short of its sibling, earning a 6 out of 10 rating, while Fat Prince scores a 7.

site_title: SMRT, senior executive charged over fatal track accident in March
summary: SMRT Trains' director of control operations, Teo Wee Kiat, and a former employee have been charged by the Attorney-General's Chambers over a fatal track accident on March 22, resulting in the deaths of two SMRT employees. The charges relate to failing to take necessary safety measures under the Workplace Safety and Health Act. Additionally, the former leader of the track-inspecting team has also been charged for causing death by negligence. The incident occurred in Singapore.

site_title: Swiber Holdings' judicial management period extended till Oct 1, 2017
summary: Swiber Holdings Limited's judicial management period has been extended until October 1, 2017, by the Singapore High Court. The extension allows the judicial managers to send a statement of proposals to creditors and convene a creditors' meeting. The informal creditors' meeting is set to take place in January ahead of the formal meeting. This decision comes after the judicial managers' application for an extension was approved by the court.

site_title: GLP doing strategic review to enhance shareholder value on request from GIC
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) is conducting a strategic review to enhance shareholder value, following a request from its largest shareholder, GIC Real Estate. A special committee and JP Morgan (SEA) Limited have been appointed to oversee the review. GLP has made preliminary approaches to various parties, but no assurance is given that any transaction will materialize. This move comes after unsolicited interest from an investor group, but GLP has not confirmed receiving an official letter of interest. The review aims to explore options for improving shareholder value.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oil and metals experienced strong gains in 2016, driven by Opec's output cuts and expectations of firmer demand. Benchmark zinc, steel rebar, and rubber rose around 60% this year, while Brent crude climbed over 50%. Outlooks suggest oil prices will rise towards $60 a barrel by end-2017, but gains will be capped by a strong dollar and US oil exports. Other metals, such as copper and gold, also saw significant gains, with copper up 17% and gold up 9%.

site_title: Taking Noma's Nordic philosophy to Tokyo
summary: Copenhagen's renowned chef René Redzepi is opening a full-blown Noma pop-up in Tokyo, marking the Nordic philosophy's urban farm iteration. The pop-up, documented by filmmaker Maurice Dekkers, will challenge Redzepi's team to reinvent the restaurant in a radically different form. The Tokyo pop-up follows Redzepi's plan to close Noma's Copenhagen location and reopen in late 2017, with the urban farm concept serving as a precursor to the new restaurant.

site_title: Trades near US$50 after Opec deal as focus moves to execution
summary: Opec approved its first supply cuts in eight years, agreeing to reduce collective production to 32.5 million barrels a day. Oil prices surged 9.3% to a seven-month high, with West Texas Intermediate trading near US$50 a barrel. The deal aims to drain record global inventories and bolster prices, with Goldman Sachs predicting a possible crude rally to US$60 a barrel. Analysts highlight the need for Opec to comply with the agreement, which is seen as a significant step towards stabilizing the market.

site_title: Up to S$2b Savings Bonds on offer for 2017
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced plans to offer up to S$2 billion of 10-year Savings Bonds in 2017, with the first issue set for January 3, 2017. The interest rate for the first year is 0.91% for the January Savings Bond, down from 0.87% for the December Savings Bond. The MAS expects interest rates to pick up in 2017, despite slow applications. The issuance calendar for 2017 is available on the MAS website.

site_title: Reminiscing a great wine and a dear friend
summary: A 1982 Jaboulet's Hermitage La Chappelle wine evoked memories of Gerard Jaboulet, a charismatic general manager of Paul Jaboulet Aine in the Rhone Valley. He visited Singapore in the late 1980s and 1990s, introducing Rhone Valley wines, particularly Jaboulet's Hermitage La Chappelle, to local wine enthusiasts. The author recalls a close friendship with Jaboulet, who made a lasting impression with his amiable nature and deep knowledge of wine. The encounter has left a lasting impression on the author's memory.

site_title: Lufthansa joins list of distressed German companies
summary: Lufthansa, Germany's largest airline, has joined a list of distressed German companies due to a strike by its pilots. The six-day strike, involving over 4,400 flights and 500,000 passengers, is over wages, with pilots seeking a 30% increase. The strike has highlighted the challenges faced by major German companies, including Volkswagen and Deutsche Bank, which are struggling with the aftermath of the financial crisis and emissions scandals. The airline's troubles also underscore the growing power of labor unions and the need for mediation in resolving industrial disputes.

site_title: 2016 GDP growth to be "one-plus per cent": PM Lee in New Year Message
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow by "one-plus per cent" for 2016, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Despite global economic uncertainties, the country is not doing badly, and the government is working to support workers and professionals through initiatives like the SkillsFuture movement. The country is also strengthening ties with major partners and pursuing other economic cooperation avenues. PM Lee emphasized the need for small countries like Singapore to stay open and adapt to change, rather than shutting themselves off from foreign competition.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers charged SMRT Trains and two employees over a fatal train accident in March, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore offered up to S$2 billion of 10-year Savings Bonds in 2017. DBS Group Holdings cut 12 roles at its brokerage unit, and Maybank Kim Eng partnered with Daishin Securities to expand its equities footprint in Asia. The Fresh Start Housing Scheme is now open for applications, and Singapore Press Holdings aims to build resilience for its core media business.

site_title: Oil down, but ends year with biggest gain since 2009
summary: Oil prices ended the year with their biggest annual gain since 2009, rising 52% for Brent and 45% for West Texas Intermediate. The gains came after Opec and partners agreed to cut output to reduce a supply overhang. Despite a two-rig rise in US oil rigs, the total count remained below last year's level. Oil prices have surged due to expectations of oil demand growth and "proof of international credibility" for Opec and partners.

site_title: Maersk Line to buy German container shipping company
summary: Maersk Line, a Danish shipping company, has agreed to buy Hamburg Sud, a German container shipping company, in a move to consolidate the industry amid a downturn. The acquisition will increase Maersk Line's global capacity share to 18.6% and will be completed by the end of 2017. The deal is part of a wave of consolidation in the shipping industry, which has been affected by overcapacity and slumping global trade, with other major players including Japan's three largest shipping firms and France's CMA CGM also making significant moves.

site_title: HK to sell first commercial site in Central since 1996
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced the sale of a commercial land site in Central, valued at HK$15.8 billion to HK$17 billion, after 20 years. The 31,000 square foot site, currently used as a car park, is the first commercial development site available in Central since 1996. The sale is expected to set a new indicator for office rents in Central, amid a strong demand from Chinese companies and low prime-office vacancy rates. The sale is slated for the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Kenyans tackle huge housing shortage to stem spread of slums
summary: In Kenya, affordable housing is being addressed through initiatives like Karibu Homes, which offers 1,000 apartments at a cost of 1.8 million Kenyan shillings (S$25,400), significantly cheaper than the average asking price of a house. This development aims to stem the spread of slums and improve quality of life for many, particularly young Kenyans. Despite high land prices and government bureaucracy, Karibu Homes and other developers are working to provide decent housing options, with plans to build more units and increase financing options for affordable housing.

site_title: McDonald's drops supplier in Malaysia over worker exploitation claims
summary: McDonald's has dropped a labour supply agency in Malaysia following claims of worker exploitation, including underpayment of wages (as low as 75 US cents an hour) and confiscation of passports. An investigation by The Guardian found these practices among 15 Nepali workers at various Kuala Lumpur McDonald's restaurants. The decision to drop the agency aims to address the alleged mistreatment of migrant workers.

site_title: Star-studded Countdown
summary: Alicia Keys is set to headline an all-star concert, Rock On! 2017, at The Float @ Marina Bay on December 31, featuring Taiwan's Rainie Yang and local singer Joi Chua. The event will conclude with a major fireworks display at midnight. Tickets range from S$48 to S$218 and are available from apactix.com and SingPost outlets.

site_title: Britain disappointed at UN panel decision on Assange
summary: Britain expressed disappointment after a UN panel rejected its request to review a ruling that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is being arbitrarily detained in the UK. The British government stated that Assange's detention is not arbitrary and that his presence at the Ecuadoran embassy was self-inflicted. The UN Working Group's opinion is described as "deeply flawed and incorrect."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.32 points to close at 1,626.44 on Thursday, driven by a 1.5 billion lots traded valued at RM1.6 billion. The market saw 493 gainers and 307 losers.

site_title: Ban Ki-Moon bids farewell to United Nations
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon bid an emotional farewell to the United Nations on Friday, concluding a two-term stint after a decade leading the organization. He will be succeeded by former Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Guterres, who will serve a five-year term. Ban praised his colleagues, saying they should be proud to work at the UN, which he described as a "fairy tale" experience. He will ring in the new year at Times Square, marking the end of his time as UN leader.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end up after oil agreement
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on December 1, 2016, following Opec's agreement to cut oil output, which boosted energy firm stocks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.39%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The price surge was also welcomed by dealers, who noted a surge in Chinese factory activity.

site_title: Indonesia's rich see their wealth rebound this year
summary: Indonesia's 50 richest people saw their combined wealth increase by US$7 billion in 2016, reaching US$99 billion, according to a Forbes list. The top 50, led by Budi and Michael Hartono, whose joint wealth is US$17.1 billion, benefited from the country's growing economy, which is expected to grow 5% this year. The increased wealth may also be due to a tax amnesty aimed at pushing the rich to repatriate offshore wealth.

site_title: China markets: yuan down, stocks down, bonds faltering
summary: China's markets experienced significant declines in 2016, with the yuan down the most since 1994, stocks down the most since 2011, and bonds clinging to the smallest return in three years. However, some strategists see potential for a turnaround in 2017, particularly for assets that are not heavily tied to the yuan. Weakening yuan and dollar asset diversification are expected to drive growth in the Asian market.

site_title: Nestle touts new technology to reduce sugar in chocolate
summary: Nestle, the world's largest packaged food group, has developed a new technology that can reduce sugar in its chocolate products by up to 40% without affecting the taste. The technology, which uses natural ingredients, involves hollowing out sugar particles to make them dissolve more quickly on the tongue. The company plans to patent its findings and implement the technology across its confectionery products starting in 2018, in response to growing pressure to make healthier products amid the global obesity epidemic.

site_title: China, Brexit & Trump
summary: China's economy may see a brighter year ahead, with analysts noting a flat 2016. Meanwhile, oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook and global trade tensions. In the US, stocks fell from record highs amid tariff threats, particularly with the EU. The US-EU trade tensions were also in focus. Companies like Creative Technology and NTT DC Reit reported mixed results, with revenue and operating loss concerns. The global market outlook remains uncertain, with investors closely watching for further trade developments and their impact on the economy.

site_title: Brookfield said in exclusive talks to buy Bharti Infratel
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has entered exclusive talks to buy Bharti Infratel, India's largest listed wireless tower owner, for around $11 billion. The Canadian firm is offering to buy a majority stake in the company for approximately 400 rupees per share, while an investor group including KKR & Co and Blackstone Group LP is offering a minority stake. A sale would help Bharti Airtel pay down net debt and is Brookfield's largest investment in India. No final agreements have been reached, and there's no certainty the discussions will result in a transaction.

site_title: Nobel laureates urge action to protect heritage sites
summary: Nobel laureates Aung San Suu Kyi, Helen Johnson Sirleaf, Kofi Annan, Orhan Pamuk, and Mario Vargas Llosa urge international action to protect heritage sites from extremist groups and conflicts. The destruction of sites such as Palmyra's temples, the Mosul Museum, and Bamiyan's Buddha statues has irreparably damaged world history. A $100 million fund will be established to help restore and safeguard damaged monuments and artifacts. The five laureates call for urgent action, stating that the time for powerless expressions of indignation is over.

site_title: China says new North Korea sanctions not meant to harm "normal" trade
summary: China's Foreign Ministry stated that new UN Security Council sanctions on North Korea are not intended to harm "normal" trade with the country or affect civilians. The sanctions aim to cut North Korea's annual export revenue by a quarter by slashing coal exports by 60% and setting an annual sales cap of $400.9 million. The 15-member council unanimously adopted the resolution, which also imposed a 7.5 million metric tonne sales cap, whichever is lower. The move is seen as an effort to curb North Korea's biggest export and reduce its annual revenue by a quarter.

site_title: China theme park to raise the Titanic, with Wi-Fi
summary: Construction has begun on the world's first full-size replica of the Titanic in China, measuring 269 meters long and 28 meters wide. The 1 billion yuan project, funded by Seven Star Energy Investment Group, will feature Wi-Fi and replicas of the ship's grandeur, including a ballroom and swimming pool. The replica will be docked permanently on a reservoir in Sichuan province, offering a unique tourist attraction. The project marks China's booming domestic tourism industry, with over 300 theme park projects funded in recent years.

site_title: Net oil importer Indonesia leaves producer club Opec, again
summary: Indonesia has suspended its membership of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) due to disagreements over production cuts. The country, a net oil importer, refused to accept Opec's proposed 5% production reduction of 37,000 barrels per day. This decision comes after Indonesia rejoined Opec less than a year ago, with the Energy and Mineral Resources Minister citing government revenue needs and the country's status as a net oil importer. The suspension is seen as a setback for Indonesia, Opec's only East Asian member, and may impact the country's oil industry.

images.alt_text: [JAKARTA] Indonesia has suspended its membership of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec), less than a year after rejoining the cartel, as the net oil importer said it could not agree to the group's production cuts.

site_title: Google, Facebook targeted by Indonesia in push for more tax
summary: Indonesia is targeting global technology giants like Google and Facebook Inc in a push for more tax revenue, seeking to squeeze an additional $10.5 billion from these companies. The move comes as the country struggles to fund its ambitious infrastructure goals, with President Joko Widodo facing the risk of deterring foreign investment. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati is seeking fair treatment and aims to boost tax revenues, but experts warn that excessive tax assessments could harm foreign investment and hinder economic growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: European stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Thursday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 falling 0.4% and Paris's CAC 40 losing 0.2%. London's FTSE 100 index remained unchanged. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks. The focus is now on US-EU trade talks, with concerns about potential tariffs.

site_title: Superheroes, sequels and reboots galore
summary: In 2017, the film industry is expected to continue its trend of superhero sequels and reboots, with Marvel, DC, and other studios releasing new movies. The year will also see the release of family-friendly films like "Despicable Me 3" and "The Emoji Movie", as well as nostalgia-driven reboots of classic films like "Blade Runner" and "Baywatch". The year's biggest releases will include "Star Wars Episode VIII", "Justice League", and "Thor: Ragnarok", and will likely continue to drive box office revenue.

site_title: Net migration from EU to Britain hit record high ahead of EU vote
summary: Net migration from the European Union to Britain reached a record high of 189,000 in the year to June 2016, exceeding the previous record by 1,000. This surge in EU migration was a key factor in the Brexit debate, with concerns about immigration driving opposition to the EU. The overall net migration to Britain was 335,000, just short of the record high set in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Net migration from the European Union to Britain hit a record high in the year to June 2016, according to official data for the twelve months before the EU referendum in which concern about rising immigration drove much opposition to the bloc.

site_title: Asia's factory activity grew in November, but may have peaked
summary: Asia's factory activity grew in November, with China's PMI rising to 51.7, its strongest growth in two years. Japan's factory activity also showed growth, but at a slower pace. However, some analysts caution that the growth may be temporary, as stimulus measures wear off, and an uncertain outlook for global trade poses risks to export-driven economies. The US President-elect's protectionist leanings and potential withdrawal from free trade agreements also raise concerns.

site_title: Notable deaths in 2016
summary: Notable figures who died in 2016 include legendary singer David Bowie, Cuban leader Fidel Castro, boxer Muhammad Ali, and actors Alan Rickman and Harper Lee. Other notable deaths include Italian writer Umberto Eco, music producer George Martin, football star Johan Cruyff, writer Jim Harrison, musician Prince, and film directors Michael Cimino, Abbas Kiarostami, and Andrzej Wajda. The year also saw the loss of influential leaders, including Uzbekistan's Islam Karimov and Israeli former president Shimon Peres, as well as long-reigning monarch Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand.

site_title: CATL aims for global domination
summary: China's Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd (CATL) has tripled its lithium-ion car battery production capacity in a year, aiming to become a global leader. The company's value has quadrupled to 80 billion yuan, and it plans to grow its battery capacity sixfold by 2020, potentially surpassing Tesla's gigafactory. CATL has already overtaken LG Chem and is chasing down Panasonic and Warren Buffett-backed BYD Co Ltd. The company's expansion is driven by China's top-down industrial policy and subsidies for electric vehicles.

site_title: Let's remember who really makes shipping work
summary: The shipping industry faced a difficult year, marked by low freight markets, the Hanjin Shipping crash, and a struggling offshore industry. Despite these challenges, dedicated seafarers continue to work tirelessly, often without recognition. Industry leaders, such as InterManager president Bjorn Jebsen and International Chamber of Shipping secretary-general Peter Hinchliffe, have emphasized the importance of investing in and supporting seafarers to ensure the industry's long-term success. They highlight the crucial role seafarers play in global trade and the humanitarian efforts of seafarers, particularly in rescue operations.

site_title: Bank lending limps along in November
summary: Bank lending in Singapore grew 0.4% in November, down from 0.8% in October, reflecting weakening growth in business and consumer loans amid a pessimistic economy. Business loans rose 0.7% to S$361 billion, while lending to manufacturing firms contracted, and lending to the construction industry inched up 0.2% to S$120 billion. Consumer loans were 0.1% higher at S$250 billion, with housing loans staying at 0.6% growth. The data contrasts with expectations for stronger growth, echoing a recent report that expects Singapore's medium-term outlook to remain downbeat.

images.alt_text: Gains in bank lending eased in November from the previous month, reflecting weakening growth in business and consumer loans amid more pessimistic times for the economy.

site_title: Italy banking measures should curb contagion risks: Moody's
summary: Italy's government approved a 20 billion euro bailout for weak banks, including Monte dei Paschi di Siena, to curb contagion risks. Moody's said the measures are credit positive for senior bondholders and depositors, increasing their protection and reducing the probability of contagion spreading to stronger banks. Monte dei Paschi will apply for a precautionary recapitalisation by the state after failing to raise privately 5 billion euros. The bailout aims to support the Italian banking sector and mitigate potential risks.

site_title: More changes to Companies Act proposed
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance proposes changes to the Companies Act, Limited Liability Partnerships Act, and the Accountants Act, including updates to beneficial ownership rules. The changes aim to enhance transparency and compliance.

site_title: The gifts of Christmas past and present
summary: The modern Christmas season has expanded beyond the traditional 12 days, now spanning 61 days from November 1 to December 31. This phenomenon, known as "Christmas creep," has led to the inclusion of non-traditional holidays like Thanksgiving, Black Friday, and Cyber Monday in the festive season. As a result, retailers have seen a significant increase in sales, with the term "Christmas creep" describing this extended period of shopping. This trend has become a staple of the modern festive season.

site_title: Oil dips after an unexpected US crude inventory build
summary: US crude oil inventories unexpectedly rose 614,000 barrels last week, reversing an advance in prices that had boosted benchmarks to their highest levels since July last year. Oil futures dipped 29 US cents, or 0.5%, to $53.77 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 8 US cents, or 0.1%, to $56.14 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration data contradicts analysts' forecasts of a decline in US crude inventories. The market is expected to remain volatile, with front month US distillate and gasoline futures expiring on Friday.

site_title: Resolved: Trump is serious about trade - and that's troubling
summary: US President Donald Trump has appointed a leading trade hawk and China critic to a top position, sparking concerns of potential conflict. This move comes during a time of geostrategic instability and geoeconomic uncertainty, where big businesses are willing to pay for forecasts on global events. Trump's actions are seen as sowing confusion in the markets, and his policies may have far-reaching implications for international relations and global trade. The appointment has raised eyebrows among experts, with some viewing it as a troubling development in the current global economic climate.

site_title: Flash: Petronas to cut crude output by 20,000 bpd from Jan 2017
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, announced plans to cut 20,000 barrels per day of crude oil from its average production starting January 2017 as part of an agreement with Opec and non-Opec producers to slash global oil output. This voluntary reduction aims to stabilize the global oil market.

site_title: No excuses
summary: Linda Tsao Yang, a 91-year-old Chinese-American, has spent her life breaking glass ceilings and paving the way for women in finance. She began her career at 50, becoming the first non-white person to serve on the board of the California Public Employees' Retirement System (Calpers). Yang went on to become the first woman to serve as California's Savings and Loan Commissioner and later represented the US at the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for six years. Her philosophy, "no excuses," was instilled in her by her mother, who taught her to be self-reliant and persevere. Yang's determination and accomplishments have inspired countless women, and she remains a champion for women's empowerment in the finance industry.

site_title: WTO rules against Indonesia in food import barriers case
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ruled against Indonesia in twin cases brought by New Zealand and the US, finding its import restrictions on food and animal products, including beef and poultry, to be in breach of WTO rules. The panel has prohibited 18 of Jakarta's measures, covering products such as apples, cattle, and chicken, and urged Indonesia to bring its measures into conformity. All sides have 60 days to appeal the findings.

site_title: The Marketer
summary: Chuck Brymer, president and CEO of DDB Worldwide, discusses his approach to staying ahead of the curve in the advertising industry. He emphasizes the importance of focusing on servicing clients better, resisting the lure of self-promotion, and adapting to the changing knowledge-based economy. Brymer highlights the need for speed and agility in business, as size and scale are no longer differentiators. He also emphasizes the importance of talent development and recruiting, recognizing, and retaining top talent. To achieve this, DDB has launched its first technology and innovation center in Singapore, Equator, which aims to develop new marketing solutions and groom young creative technologists. Brymer's leadership philosophy is centered around inspiring others to do more, dream more, and be more, and he prioritizes his family life and personal well-being to maintain a healthy work-life balance.

site_title: China Environment lodges CAD report against ex-Chairman and ex-CFO
summary: China Environment has lodged a report to the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) against former Executive Chairman Huang Min and former CFO Chiar Choon Teck, citing non-existent receivables from two companies. The complaint relates to a China legal firm's opinion that trade receivables from Anhui Shengyun Mechnical Co. Ltd and Nanning Youji Technology Co Ltd are non-existent. China Environment had previously issued a Writ of Summons against Huang Min. The exact details and implications of the complaint remain unclear.

site_title: Exploring Japanese music, both past and present
summary: A concert, Sounds of Japan 3, celebrating Japanese music, will be held on Friday, featuring wind band performances, traditional folk songs, popular culture, and Japanese enka music. Conducted by Japanese maestro Yasuhide Ito, the event marks 50 years of diplomatic relationships between Singapore and Japan. The performance includes a Concerto for Tsugaru-Shamisen and Wind Band, as well as popular theme songs from anime series and classic Japanese music by Joe Hisaishi.

site_title: Rio gives up on Olympic pledge as bay clean-up workers fired
summary: Rio de Janeiro is abandoning its promise to treat the raw sewage polluting Guanabara Bay after workers building a pipeline network and treatment plant were fired due to a fiscal crisis. A $450 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank is set to expire in March, and Rio's government won't extend it. The project, meant to address the bay's pollution, was a key legacy promise before the 2016 Olympics, but it has stalled due to funding issues and bureaucratic delays.

images.alt_text: Rio de Janeiro is abandoning its promise to treat the raw sewage polluting the Guanabara Bay as workers building a pipeline network and treatment plant are being fired and the state sinks into fiscal crisis.

site_title: Chinese lawyers sue government for failure to stop smog
summary: Chinese lawyers are suing the cities of Beijing and Tianjin, and the surrounding province of Hebei, for their failure to combat smog, which has reached record levels in the region. The lawsuit claims the governments prioritized "toxic economic growth" over air pollution control, endangering millions of people's health. The region has declared 24 cities under pollution "red alerts" since Saturday, with the lawyers seeking a formal apology and damages. This case marks one of the first times Chinese citizens have sued the government for environmental issues.

site_title: EU charges Facebook with misleading information during WhatsApp takeover
summary: European Union antitrust regulators have charged Facebook with providing misleading information during its 2014 takeover of WhatsApp. The charge relates to a WhatsApp privacy policy change in August 2014, which claimed it could not reliably match user accounts. The EU Commission claims Facebook intentionally or negligently submitted incorrect information, breaching its obligations under the EU Merger Regulation. Facebook has until January 31 to respond, and a fine of up to 1% of its turnover is possible if the Commission's concerns are confirmed.

site_title: China regulator to step up curbs on insurers' stock speculation
summary: China's insurance regulator, the China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC), plans to step up scrutiny of stock-trading activities by insurers, citing aggressive investments in listed firms. Chairman Xiang Junbo warned insurers to act as "friendly investors" and not become "barbarians" speculating in stocks. The regulator will reduce the proportion of insurance funds invested in stocks, intervene in frequent share purchases, and cut the amount a single shareholder can own in an insurer. The move aims to curb risks associated with insurers' leveraged buying spree.

images.alt_text: The China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC) chairman Xiang Junbo questioned the recent aggressive investments by insurers, ranging from buying sizeable stakes in listed companies to speculating in stocks with dramatic swings, according to a statement on the regulator's website that was based on an internal speech by Mr Xiang.

site_title: 10 outrageous predictions for 2017
summary: In 2017, Saxo Bank predicted 10 outrageous market events, citing past predictions that often came true. The bank's chief investment officer, Steen Jakobsen, stated that the most hated idea tends to materialize. Notably, Saxo had previously predicted the unpopularity of emerging-market Brazil, which proved correct.

site_title: Ten minutes of play sums up Nintendo's messy Mario Run debut
summary: Nintendo's debut game for smartphones, Super Mario Run, has faced backlash after its release, with thousands complaining that the three levels available for free were over too quickly and the $10 price tag to unlock the rest was too steep. The game's poor word-of-mouth has impacted its profitability, and analysts are questioning Nintendo's ability to execute on mobile devices. The game's download charts are still impressive, but its low ratings and high price have raised concerns about its long-term success.

images.alt_text: Nintendo Co's debut game for smartphones is turning out to be anything but super.

site_title: IHH unit sets up JV healthcare firm in China
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad has established a joint venture healthcare firm in China, ParkwayHealth Chengdu Hospital Company Ltd, with a business licence valid until 2036. M&P Investments Pte Ltd, an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of IHH, owns 70% of the company, while Shanghai Broad Ocean Investments Co Ltd holds 30%. The joint venture was formed through a licensing agreement, with M&P contributing 43.4 million yuan (S$43.4 million) and Broad Ocean contributing 18.6 million yuan (S$18.6 million) in cash subscriptions.

site_title: Apple can sell iPhone 7s in Indonesia after R&D investment commitment
summary: Apple has committed to invest around $44 million in a research and development centre in Indonesia over three years, allowing it to sell its iPhone 7 in the country. The investment meets Indonesia's 30% local content rule, enabling Apple to distribute devices priced above $645.25. This comes as Apple faces competition from Samsung and OPPO, which dominate Indonesia's smartphone market. With a young, internet-savvy demographic, Apple aims to gain a foothold in the country of 250 million people.

site_title: Goldman names Solomon, Schwartz as Cohn's successors
summary: Goldman Sachs has named David Solomon and Harvey Schwartz as co-presidents and co-chief operating officers to succeed Gary Cohn, who will head the White House National Economic Council. Solomon, a Bear Stearns veteran, co-heads the investment banking division, while Schwartz, who was CFO, will remain in the role until April 2017. The move returns Goldman to a co-president, co-CEO structure, which was previously in place from 2009 to 2013.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post biggest weekly fall in 6 months
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell to a 4-1/2-month low, posting their biggest weekly drop in half a year, as investors braced for faster US interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng index dropped 0.2% to 22,020.75 points, with a 3.3% weekly loss. The market was spooked by the Federal Reserve's quarter-point rate hike and its projection of three interest rate hikes next year, leading to a decline in most sectors, including telecommunication and raw materials shares. The dollar's 14-year high against major currencies also weighed on emerging market assets.

site_title: WhatsApp, Skype set to come under new EU security rules: draft document
summary: The European Union is set to propose new security laws that would extend existing regulations on telecom operators to messaging services such as WhatsApp and Skype, requiring them to guarantee customer data confidentiality and obtain consent for location data processing. The proposed rules aim to simplify cookie consent requirements and adapt to the upcoming data protection regulation. Telecom companies have long complained about the uneven playing field, and the EU aims to address this by extending similar provisions to Web companies offering OTT services.

site_title: Putin, Abe order joint economic action plan for disputed islands
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to create a joint economic action plan for four disputed islands, known as the Northern Territories in Japan and the South Kurils in Russia. The two leaders discussed a special system for joint economic activity on the islands, including medicine, tourism, and fisheries, which will be implemented on the basis of Russian legislation. The talks are seen as a breakthrough in the seven-decade territorial dispute and come at a crucial time for both countries, with Russia facing low oil prices and international sanctions, and Japan seeking to diversify its energy sources.

site_title: Putting the common back into wealth
summary: Baroness Patricia Scotland, the sixth Secretary-General of the Commonwealth, is working to revive the organization's relevance in a fast-changing world. The Commonwealth, comprising 52 voluntary members, represents almost one-third of the world's population and promotes democracy, rule of law, human rights, and social and economic development. Scotland emphasizes the unique platform of diversity and similarities among member states, which she believes fosters unity and cooperation. She highlights issues such as climate change, good governance, and youth development as key areas of focus, and proposes practical initiatives like the 33Sixty leadership program to bridge gaps between nations. Scotland aims to boost trade within the Commonwealth, citing a 19% advantage in trade between member states, and encourages pragmatism to drive sustainable growth and development.

site_title: Olam clashes with green group over Gabon deforestation
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-commodity trading group, has been accused by US-based environmental group Mighty Earth of clear-cutting trees in the Congo rainforest and buying unsustainably produced palm oil. Olam disputes these claims, stating that it uses ecologically degraded areas for its palm plantations and has released a list of its third-party suppliers. The company argues that Gabon has the sovereign right to convert its least valuable forested land for agriculture as long as it is done responsibly and transparently.

site_title: Japan authorities fear rising condo loans could lead to bad debts
summary: Japan is increasing bank supervision amid concerns over rising condo loans that may lead to bad debts. Construction financing for new apartment blocks has grown, but much is speculative, driven by tax breaks and low interest rates. Vacancy rates are rising in prime markets like Tokyo, outpacing demand. This speculative investment may ultimately lead to a surge in bad debts, as supply outstrips demand in the economy. Authorities are taking steps to mitigate this risk.

site_title: Dollar up against yen as US bond yields rise
summary: The US dollar rose to its highest level since February against the yen due to rising US bond yields, driven by expectations of higher inflation and a 5% increase in global oil prices. The Norwegian crown and Canadian dollar also gained. Traders are cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting on Wednesday, with Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen's signal on future interest rate hikes being closely watched. Speculators increased positive bets on the dollar for the third straight week, but concerns about President-elect Donald Trump's comments on China remain.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Emas Offshore refinanced its financial obligations over a five-year period, while IHH Healthcare received a business license for a Sino-foreign equity company in China. M1 CEO Karen Kooi sold 60,000 shares, reducing her stake. CMC Infocomm won three contracts worth S$7.8 million, and POSH is facing alleged damages of S$84 million from Makamin Offshore. Oxley Holdings launched its first development project in Batam, Indonesia, and Fragrance Group incorporated a wholly owned subsidiary.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Tough year looms as China's real estate developers face record wall of debt
summary: China's real estate developers face a record wall of debt in 2017 due to regulators choking off a key source of funding. The Shanghai Stock Exchange has raised the threshold for property firms to sell bonds, limiting smaller builders' access to onshore debt. This move, combined with a global pullback in bonds and targeted central bank steps, is expected to make funding conditions more challenging for developers, with only stronger players able to issue onshore bonds. The environment is becoming increasingly challenging, with average yields on dollar-denominated bonds from Chinese developers jumping 30 basis points and banks charging higher loan margins.

site_title: Into the wild
summary: Glamping, a luxury camping experience, has gained popularity over the last decade, offering city dwellers a chance to escape into the great outdoors without sacrificing comfort. Eurotours & Travel saw a 25% increase in glamping travelers in the last five years, with seasoned travelers seeking a blend of adventure and luxury. Luxury getaways, such as Olare Mara Kempinski in Kenya, offer high-end amenities like private tents, Wi-Fi, and fine dining, while also providing opportunities to spot wildlife like lions, elephants, and zebras. Similar glamping experiences can be found in India's Thar Desert and Indonesia's Bintan, offering a range of activities like game drives, camel rides, and water sports.

site_title: Trump says US not necessarily bound by "one China" policy
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump questioned the US's long-standing "one China" policy, suggesting the country isn't necessarily bound by it. Trump accepted a congratulatory phone call from Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen, prompting a diplomatic protest from Beijing, which considers Taiwan a renegade province. Trump's comments risk antagonizing Beijing and could provoke military confrontation with China if pressed too far, despite the Obama administration's insistence that the policy remains intact.

site_title: Foodie Heaven
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided text appears to be a collection of article titles and publication dates from various sources, but it does not contain a specific article to summarize.

site_title: Putin heads to Japan for hot spring meet on disputed islands
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to meet Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Nagato, Japan, for a two-day visit focusing on a territorial dispute over the Kuril Islands. The islands were seized by Soviet troops in 1945 and remain a point of contention between Russia and Japan, with no formal treaty to end World War II signed. Despite months of negotiations, hope for a breakthrough is scarce, with Putin indicating that Russia wants "full normalisation" of relations with Japan. The visit includes a forum in Tokyo and is seen as a bid to break the ice on an agreement over the islands.

site_title: Taiwan frets at being pawn in any Trump reset of US, China ties
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on Taiwan's "one China" policy have raised concerns on the island, with Taiwan's government warning it may become a pawn in wider superpower discussions. Trump stated he understands the policy but doesn't see a need to be bound by it unless a trade deal with China is made. China has responded to a congratulatory phone call from Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen by lodging a diplomatic protest, and has increased military exercises near Taiwan. Taiwan's government fears it may be used as leverage in US-China negotiations, with President Tsai never recognizing Beijing's "one China" policy.

site_title: Click Up A Storm
summary: Online shopping has become increasingly global, with Singaporeans leading the way as the most adventurous shoppers in the region. Personal online shoppers can now source unique items from around the world, with services like ShopandBox, Airfrov, and Personal Shopper Japan connecting buyers with sellers in over 28 countries. These platforms offer savings of up to 30% and cater to various interests, including beauty products, fashion, and rare collectibles. With a global reach and personal touch, online shopping has become a convenient and exciting way to fulfill retail desires.

site_title: Sony to release as many as 6 mobile phone games next year
summary: Sony plans to release up to 6 mobile games in the 2026 financial year, targeting the success of Pokémon GO with its own gaming franchises. The titles will initially be available in Japan and Asian countries, freeing up popular franchises like Everybody's Golf from PlayStation consoles. This move aims to expand Sony's gaming presence on mobile platforms and replicate the success of Nintendo's popular game.

site_title: UK MPs and courts confuse electorate who voted for Brexit
summary: UK MPs and courts have caused confusion among Brexit voters, who were 48% of the electorate, by debating the process. The Supreme Court will rule on whether the government can trigger Brexit without an Act of Parliament. The ruling, due in January, may impact the UK's unwritten constitution. The confusion has led to a fall in sterling and increased business uncertainty, with some arguing that a parliamentary motion is not enough to begin the process, and a comprehensive bill is needed.

images.alt_text: Mr Davis likened the negotiating process as "trying to thread a needle - even harder to do when 650 MPs are jogging your elbow".

site_title: Trump may be just what the doctor ordered to rescue the eurozone
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump may rescue the eurozone with his economic policies, which could boost growth and employment in the region. His plans to implement sweeping tax cuts, increase infrastructure investment, and increase military spending are expected to lead to rapidly rising fiscal deficits and higher demand in the US, benefiting the eurozone, particularly peripheral countries like Italy. A stronger US dollar and suppressed oil prices could also contribute to a rebalancing of the eurozone. Trump's policies have already led to a positive impact on the eurozone, with long-term interest rates rising and a rate increase in Europe, and are likely to continue to benefit the region.

site_title: South Korea opposition files impeachment motion
summary: South Korea's opposition parties have filed an impeachment motion against President Park Geun-Hye, backed by 171 lawmakers, as massive weekly protests against her administration are expected to draw a million protesters. The motion will be put to a vote in the National Assembly on Friday, requiring the support of nearly 30 Saenuri Party members to secure the two-thirds majority needed to impeach the president. Park has offered to step down, but the opposition claims her offer is an attempt to buy time and avoid impeachment.

site_title: Seniors driving consumption growth as Japan ages
summary: Japan's seniors are driving consumer spending, accounting for nearly half of the country's consumer spending despite making up only a third of the population. The elderly spend more on medical care, social activities, travel, and home renovation, offsetting falling consumption among younger generations. However, many seniors rely on public pensions and live modestly, with spending habits shifting towards convenience stores and discount shops. This trend is expected to continue, with the elderly's consumption playing a key role in propping up the country's economy.

site_title: Vietnamese brewer Sabeco's shares jump 20% on debut
summary: Sabeco, Vietnam's largest brewer, debuted on the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange, with shares jumping 20% to 132,000 dong. The company, which holds 41% of the domestic beer market, was valued at US$3.72 billion. Sabeco aims to sell its entire 89% stake in the company by 2017, following the government's plan to accelerate IPOs and increase transparency. The company reported a 28.2% increase in 2015 net profit and a 20% rise in third-quarter net profit this year.

site_title: Ford will work with Trump - provided right policies in place
summary: Ford Motor Co CEO Mark Fields stated that the company will work with President-elect Donald Trump to keep US jobs, provided Trump implements the right policies, including currency-manipulation rules, tax reform, and safety guidelines for autonomous vehicles. Ford plans to lobby for softer fuel-economy rules, which they claim hurt profits by forcing carmakers to build more electric cars than warranted by customer demand. The company has added nearly 28,000 jobs in the US over the last five years and employs 85,000 workers domestically.

site_title: Vallianz faces two foreign lawsuits related to Swiber
summary: Vallianz, a Singapore-based offshore-support vessel provider, is facing two foreign lawsuits related to distressed company Swiber Holdings. The Indian lawsuit claims S$10 million in unpaid invoices, while the Indonesian lawsuit claims S$8.7 million in unpaid invoices and damages. The lawsuits involve Vallianz's wholly-owned subsidiaries and Swiber Offshore (India) Pte Ltd. The companies did not provide further details on the cases.

site_title: Beijing may ease foreign investment limits in some sectors
summary: China may relax foreign investment restrictions in certain sectors, including automotive electronics, rail transport equipment, and theme parks, to counter capital flight and boost the yuan. The move comes amid concerns over huge outflows of capital and a record-setting wave of Chinese investment abroad. The National Development and Reform Commission has issued a notice, which typically results in policy changes, to ease restrictions and attract more foreign investment. The decision is seen as a response to US President-elect Donald Trump's accusations of protectionism and the country's struggling economy.

site_title: Merkel draws up battle lines ahead of 2017 election
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is preparing for her fourth term in office, launching a campaign ahead of the 2017 elections. Despite her party's strong support, Merkel faces challenges from the rising populist AfD party, which has gained 12% support. Merkel's supporters are rallying behind her bid to stay in power, but there are concerns within her own party about her policies on refugees and her ability to adapt to a changing world. Merkel's re-election is seen as crucial to maintaining stability in Germany and Europe.

site_title: Nam Cheong client cancels contract
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singapore-based vessel builder, has had a contract with Petra Offshore Limited cancelled. The cancellation notice was issued on December 1, 2016, for the sale of one accommodation work barge, despite Nam Cheong completing the vessel according to the contract. Nam Cheong is considering legal action and believes the cancellation is without basis. The cancellation is expected to impact Nam Cheong's earnings for the current financial year, although the extent is still uncertain.

site_title: Trump's Cabinet could be the wealthiest in modern history
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet is expected to be the wealthiest in modern history, with many appointees coming from old money and having a combined net worth of over $10 billion. Trump's nominees include industrialist Wilbur Ross, former Goldman Sachs executive Steven Mnuchin, and Michigan billionaire Betsy DeVos, among others. Critics argue that their privileged backgrounds may lead to policies favoring the rich, despite Trump's populist campaign promises. Experts say that public policy is shaped by one's life experiences and that millionaires may prioritize policies benefiting themselves over the working class.

site_title: Ali's boxing gloves, Fidel Castro cigars highlight sports auction
summary: Muhammad Ali's fight gloves and a box of cigars signed by Fidel Castro are among the highlights in an auction of sports memorabilia. Ali's gloves from a 1970 match at Madison Square Gardens are expected to fetch $60,000, while Castro's autographed cigars are valued at $60,000. Other notable items include a Pele soccer shirt and a mouthguard worn by Ali during the 1974 "Rumble in the Jungle" fight, projected to sell for $5,000 and $8,000, respectively. The auction features over 500 sports memorabilia lots and will be held in Los Angeles.

site_title: Opec decision to cut production helps boost Iran's budget
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani presented his 2017-2018 budget, boosted by Opec's decision to cut oil production by 1.2 million barrels per day, increasing oil prices to over $50 per barrel. Iran was exempted from the cuts, allowing its oil production to rise from 2.7 million to 3.8 million barrels per day. Rouhani aims for 8% growth over the next five years, despite the rial losing over 8% of its value and facing uncertainty due to US sanctions and the Trump administration.

site_title: Have rail will travel
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that both Singapore and Malaysia have made "very good progress" on the high-speed rail (HSR) project, expected to start construction in 2018 and complete by 2026. Meanwhile, Malaysia is set to hold its general elections "soon", amidst a protracted scandal that has hurt the country's leadership and institutions. The election's outcome could impact the HSR project, but Najib Razak's confidence in his leadership suggests UMNO may retain power.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip as investors take step back
summary: Asian stocks slipped on Friday, reversing recent gains, as investors took a step back from a rally sparked by Donald Trump's US election win. The dollar and oil prices also retreated, following a nine-month high for the dollar. The Nikkei, Hong Kong, and Shanghai indexes fell, while Japanese exporters retreated due to a strengthening yen. The US releases its November jobs report and Italy holds a constitutional referendum on Sunday, which could create uncertainty in the EU.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher on firm oil and play on banks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore rose for the eighth consecutive session, ending 23.41 points higher at 2,928.58, driven by gains in the three banks and higher oil prices. Keppel Corp jumped 8.1% to S$5.89, while the banks contributed 13 points to the index's rise. Despite a relatively mixed market, turnover was healthy at S$1.67 billion.

site_title: UN calls on Myanmar's Suu Kyi to visit crisis-hit Rakhine
summary: The UN has urged Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi to visit crisis-hit Rakhine state, where the army is accused of a brutal crackdown on the Rohingya minority, resulting in mass rape, murder, and arson. Over 20,000 Rohingya have fled to Bangladesh. The UN special adviser on Myanmar, Vijay Nambiar, called on Suu Kyi to intervene and reassure the civilian population that they will be protected. The situation presents a major challenge to Suu Kyi, who has faced growing international criticism for her inaction.

site_title: Japan Display to receive US$640m in state-fund aid
summary: Japan Display Inc, a struggling display maker, has received a 75 billion yen (S$924 million) state-fund bailout from the Innovation Network Corp of Japan (INCJ). INCJ will purchase convertible bonds and provide subordinated loans to help the company invest in advanced screens for cars and gaming headsets, as growth in the smartphone market slows. This publicly funded bailout aims to reduce Japan Display's dependence on Apple Inc.

site_title: Trump picks opponent of higher minimum wage for Labor Dept
summary: President-elect Donald Trump named fast-food executive Andy Puzder to head the US Department of Labor, drawing criticism from labor advocates over his opposition to a higher minimum wage and government regulation of the workplace. Puzder has argued that higher minimum wages would hurt workers by forcing restaurants to close. Trump praised Puzder for his "record fighting for workers," but labor leaders have expressed concern over his appointment, saying it would roll back key regulatory initiatives and weaken safeguards for workers.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump named fast-food executive Andy Puzder to head the US Department of Labor on Thursday, drawing criticism from labour advocates worried about his opposition to a higher minimum wage and government regulation of the workplace.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end higher on Wall Street gains, Samsung Elec
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.35% to a four-week high, driven by Wall Street gains and reduced concerns about the Italian political crisis. Samsung Electronics reached an all-time intraday high before closing up 1.75%. The won strengthened 0.27% to 1,171.4 to the US dollar. Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee appeared at a parliamentary hearing, stating he would take responsibility for the influence peddling scandal.

site_title: Let wonder last
summary: Singaporeans' love for traveling can have a profound impact on their lives, changing their perspectives, and helping them grow as individuals. With globalization and advancements in technology, traveling has become more accessible and affordable, allowing Singaporeans to explore the world and discover new experiences. For some, trips overseas can be transformative, altering their lives and careers. They return home with newfound insights, a broader perspective, and a deeper understanding of themselves. This phenomenon is not limited to young people, as seen in the stories of individuals like Ong Boon Kok, who credits his 16-day trek in Nepal with changing his whole perspective on life.

site_title: 60 more cash-withdrawal spots for DBS, POSB customers
summary: DBS Bank has added 60 new SPH Buzz newsstand outlets to its POSB Cash-Point network, increasing the total number of non-bank cash-withdrawal points to 880. Customers can withdraw up to S$200 for free with any item purchased at these locations, which are strategically placed at retail outlets such as 7-Eleven and Cold Storage. This expansion aims to reduce cash holdings and handling efforts for retail businesses while providing convenient cash withdrawal services for DBS and POSB customers.

images.alt_text: DBS Bank said on Wednesday it has added about 60 SPH Buzz newsstand outlets to its POSB Cash-Point network.

site_title: Banking digitised
summary: ING's CEO Ralph Hamers believes the future of banking lies in delivering existing products smoothly, rather than creating new ones. The bank is investing 800 million euros in digital initiatives over the next five years to build a single global scalable banking platform and improve customer service. ING is collaborating with fintech startups, such as a US firm, to offer services like instant loans to small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The bank is also using third-party application programming interfaces (APIs) to access bank data, allowing customers to view their financial information across multiple banks.

images.alt_text: ING chief executive Ralph Hamers.
Mr Hamers: "I am a big believer in the commoditisation of products. I don't think products will make the difference when it comes to financial services."

site_title: Singapore's 2017 median wage to rise 4.7%: study
summary: Singapore's median base salary is projected to rise 4.7% in 2017, higher than the 4.3% growth in Asia, according to a Korn Ferry Hay Group report. This comes despite a sluggish economy and talent retention challenges. Most companies (75%) in Singapore are expected to implement salary increments, driven by a need to retain talent amid tightening foreign-labour policies and a lack of expertise at junior to middle levels.

images.alt_text: The median base salary in Singapore is expected to rise 4.7 per cent in 2017, after factoring in disinflation, higher than the 3.7 per cent increase in 2016, a report by Korn Ferry Hay Group on Friday showed.

site_title: Painted Christmas trees challenge tradition
summary: A New Jersey Christmas tree farm is challenging traditional holiday customs by selling vibrant, spray-painted trees in various colors, including pink, purple, and blue. The farm's owner, John Wyckoff, began selling the colorful trees after discovering a new line of paint from a wholesaler, and hundreds of customers have flocked to buy them, with all 250 trees sold by Sunday. The unusual trees have sparked debate among the Christmas tree industry, with some viewing them as a bold innovation and others seeing them as an eyesore.

images.alt_text: While many tree-buyers have welcomed the flair, some see the plants as a garish breach of Christmas orthodoxy.

site_title: China's Xi calls for universities' allegiance to the Communist Party
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has urged universities to prioritize allegiance to the Communist Party, calling for adherence to party leadership and policies in education. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to tighten control over education and suppress "Western values." This comes after the government cracked down on free expression, detaining activists and lawyers, and muzzling internet critics. Xi emphasized the need for universities to serve the party, potentially limiting academic freedom and hindering China's ambitions to build world-class universities.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping has called for allegiance to the ruling Communist Party from the country's colleges and universities, the latest effort by Beijing to tighten its hold on education.
